Egypt and Saudi Arabia, hesitant only a few years ago to be closely identified with the United States, have been driven by their fear of Iraq's President Saddam Hussein into unabashed ties with Washington. They are ready to create a new and permanent security structure with the United States in the Persian Gulf. And Syria has suddenly become candidate to join the coalition despite its record of human rights abuses and terrorism accusations, including sponsorship of a radical Palestinian group suspected in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988 in which 280 people perished. Baker announced Monday at NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, that he will go to Damascus to meet with President Hafez Assad. The purpose, Baker said, was to explore ``how we might cooperate to achieve what happens to be our mutual goals.'' He said the joint aim was to isolate Saddam with a strict economic boycott and to confront him with an international ground and sea force. Baker acknowledged the United States had ``differences'' and ``difficulties'' with Syria and would discuss them with Assad when they meet Friday. But Baker did not dwell on the terrorism and human rights problems. While constructing this new alliance, the Bush administration has begun to put more pressure on Israel to make peace with Palestinians and to return territory Syria and Jordan lost in their humiliating defeat in the Six-Day War of 1967. President Bush and Baker have revived consideration of an international peace conference. It is an idea that drives Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir up the wall because he fears that a Soviet-Arab coalition would force unfavorable terms on Jerusalem. Bush on Sunday also called for implementing ``sooner, rather than later,'' 1967 and 1973 U.N. Security Council resolutions providing for Israel to give up the Golan Heights to Syria and the West Bank to Jordan. The president made the statement in Helsinki, Finland, at the windup of his summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It obviously pleased Gorbachev, who said the Arab-Israeli dispute was of ``equal concern'' with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait _ ``even more,'' in fact, he said. Bush and Baker also have reversed the two-decade-old U.S. policy of trying to undercut Soviet influence in the Middle East. Baker called that approach ``old thinking.'' Israel has been taking the administration's advice and maintained a low profile since Iraq invaded Kuwait five weeks ago. The United States, after all, had adopted the Israeli view that Iraq posed a grave danger in the volatile Middle East and was organizing a campaign designed to cut Saddam down to size. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy met with Baker in Washington last Thursday and emerged on a first-name basis, praising Bush and Baker as courageous. ``Mr. Secretary, or rather my friend, Jim, I can go home with a positive feeling and happy, fully believing in our possibility of cooperating and working together,'' Levy said. Perhaps that spirit still prevails. Even as the United States proceeded with its new makeshift alliance, former Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Shamir said recently: ``I believe the U.S. will achieve its goal and the situation will return to what it was'' before the Iraqi invasion. And yet Baker's mission to Damascus after he completes talks here Thursday with Soviet leaders will draw the United States closer to the Arabs with unforeseen consequences for Israel. In the meantime, the administration's plan to isolate Iraq is being tested by the restoration of diplomatic relations by Baghdad with Iran.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered U.S. diplomacy in the Middle East since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Activation of Reserve Cargo Ships Behind Schedule
DOC.TEXT: The first large activation of reserve U.S. cargo ships is behind schedule, but the Navy says it's satisfied with the fleet's performance in transporting supplies to the Persian Gulf. The Navy has activated 42 ships of the 96-ship Ready Reserve Force, but 26 of them did not meet individual readiness timetables of either five, 10 or 20 days, according to official figures supplied to The Associated Press. The crisis in the gulf region provided the Navy with its first opportunity to activate the Ready Reserve Force, created in 1976 and positioned in ports around the country. Vice Adm. Stanley R. Arthur, deputy chief of naval operations for logistics, said there were ``glitches'' in getting the reserve fleet ready to transport helicopters, tanks, howitzers and other equipment. But he told a House Merchant Marine subcommittee that the vessels _ mostly of 1960s and 1970s vintage _ have ``exceeded expectations.'' Delays were caused in part by equipment failures, including problems with steam boilers, and by the time necessary to find merchant seamen to run the ships. Some ships have been delayed for weeks, while others missed their deadlines by only a day. The figures were provided to The Associated Press by the Maritime Administration, a Transportation Department agency that maintains the cargo ships until they're needed by the Navy's Military Sealift Command. Seven ships met their timetables and nine were not counted against the deadlines because they needed major repairs. The Navy activated these nine ships knowing they would not meet the timetables, Maritime Administration officials said. The ships are crucial to supplying U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia because heavy military equipment will not fit in the containers used in modern cargo vessels. The reserve force includes: roll on-roll off ships, where equipment can be driven up and down ramps; break bulk carriers, where equipment is placed on platforms and then hoisted on the vessels; ships that carry barges or other floating devices that can be sent with their equipment down rivers; and ships that have cranes aboard to load and unload cargo without the need for unloading facilities at a port. Among the Ready Reserve Force ships activated so far, all but one were assigned either a five- or 10-day period for the Maritime Administration to make them ready for Navy sealift duty. Of those in the five-day period, 24 were delivered to the Navy late, four were tendered on time and seven were in need of repairs and therefore not counted against the timetable. Among the 10-day ships, two were delivered late, three were turned over before the deadline and one was in need of repair. The single 20-day ship was in a repair yard and not counted against the timetable, although it was fixed and given to the Navy before the deadline. The Ready Reserve Force is part of the 217 ships in the National Defense Reserve Fleet that are considered militarily useful. Many of the vessels date back to the World War II era. Congress is considering legislation that would force about 100 of the oldest ships to be sold for scrap to U.S. salvage firms. Arthur said three of those ships are in the Ready Reserve fleet, including two that were activated. But the rest are in the portion of the national defense fleet that is unlikely to be called to duty. Those ships built before Jan. 1, 1946 would, under the legislation, be sold to domestic salvage companies. ``These World War II-era ships are floating rust buckets,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., who with Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., sponsored the bill to junk the older ships in the fleet. During a Monday subcommittee hearing, the two pressed for passage of their bill. ``I do not pretend to be an expert in maritime affairs. But I recognize junk when I see it,'' Broomfield said. Added Wyden: ``These are the oldest, most decrepit portions of the fleet and they serve no useful purpose.'' But Robert Martinez, deputy administrator of the Maritime Administration, said the outward appearance of the older ships is poor, but the interiors are protected by dehumidification. He said it would be a mistake to dispose of the vessels ``without any recognition ... as to U.S. national security requirements.'' Martinez said his agency already has a successful program to exchange outmoded ships in the fleet for newer vessels that will upgrade the reserve fleet. This program, he said, is a way of modernizing the reserve fleet. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said he was considering whether to ask that the government resume subsidies to the U.S. maritime industry that were eliminated by the Reagan administration, The Washington Post reported today. Skinner, in an interview with the newspaper, said he would not make a recommendation, however, until his department has had a chance to study U.S. shipping performance in Operation Desert Shield.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Consider Free Mail for Persian Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT: The 100,000 U.S. troops on duty in the Middle East could begin sending letters home by simply signing their names on the envelopes under legislation moving rapidly through Congress. On a unanimous voice vote, the Senate on Monday approved a measure by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to provide free mail privileges, last widely used during the Vietnam War, to American service personnel in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region. Similar legislation, which has been endorsed by the Bush administration, was introduced in the House by Rep. William Ford, D-Mich., chairman of the its Post Office and Civil Service Committee. Ford said he hopes the House will vote on it early next week. Several lawmakers who visited with U.S. troops in the region the past two weeks while Congress was on vacation said a common complaint they heard was the inability to find stamps. ``No one needs to be told that mail is the crucial link between the fighting man or woman and his family and friends back home,'' he said. ``They did not have stamps, they could not get stamps and, if by some chance stamps came their way, they were soon stuck together by the humidity and the sweat.'' The measure would apply only to mail sent from the Middle East to the United States. It would cover letters, post cards, and audio and video cassettes but not other items. Under current law that dates from World War I, troops get free mailing privileges only during combat. The Postal Service estimates the free mail privileges would cost taxpayers $500,000 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate's Mailing Includes Offers for Condoms
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Note subject matter
DOC.TEXT: A homosexual congressional candidate is soliciting political contributions in a campaign mailing that also offers condoms and subscriptions to gay magazines. Sean O'Brien Strub's marketing and direct mail company recently targeted the gay market with packets to about 100,000 households across the country. Enclosed with Strub's political pitch comes an offer for a pamphlet from the Gay Men's Health Crisis that promises ``hotter, safer sex for gay men.'' Each pink, black and silver envelope contains postcards that can be mailed away for products or services, including condoms. Strub, an openly gay Democrat from Rockland County, N.Y., northwest of New York City, is hoping to defeat nine-term incumbent Rep. Benjamin Gilman, R-N.Y. Strub faces one of the few Democratic primaries in New York today. He is running against John Dow who, at age 85, is trying to recapture a long-lost congressional seat. Dow served in Congress from 1964-68 and from 1970-72. Strub said he has resisted being labeled ``the gay candidate.'' ``I'm no more the gay candidate than Ann Richards is the woman candidate for Texas governor or than David Dinkins was the black candidate for mayor or than Ben Gilman is the Jewish candidate,'' he said. Asked whether it bothered him to have his appeal sandwiched in with condom offers, Strub said: ``You've got to look at it as one of the ads. If I bought an ad in a magazine and that was one of the ads, would I be upset? No.'' Strub's campaign bought the advertising space, at cost, from Strub's company, he said last week. ``My company didn't make money from my campaign,'' he stressed, although the card pack is a profit-making enterprise. The 32-year-old Strub said he was confident he'd win today's primary. If he beats Gilman in November, he would become the first person elected to Congress as an openly gay candidate. Two members, Reps. Barney Frank and Gerry Studds, both D-Mass., revealed their homosexuality after they were already in office.

DOC.HEAD: Policy Makers Ready To ``Rachet up The Pressure'' Around Iraq
DOC.TEXT: With President Saddam Hussein of Iraq vowing to hold on to Kuwait, policy-makers in Washington and Moscow are studying what steps the United Nations can take to tighten the noose around Iraq. ``There are a lot of ways you could rachet up the pressure'' in a series of small steps, said a State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in their Helsinki Summit communique, said: ``We are determined to see this aggression end, and if the current steps fail to end it, we are prepared to consider additional ones consistent with the U.N. Charter.'' Four days after the Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait, the Security Council ordered a complete embargo on trade with Iraq, with the only goods exempted being medicines and medical equipment ``and, in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs.'' On Monday, Saddam tried to skirt the oil blockade by offering to give away crude oil to any Third World country that sends tankers through the blockade to pick it up, an indication Baghdad is becoming desperate in its attempt to break out of international isolation. But for any move Saddam makes, the Security Council can offer a countermove. The U.N. ambassador for the exiled Kuwaiti government, Mohammad Abulhasan, on Thursday proposed that the Security Council urgently consider ``blocking the air corridors, seizing Iraqi ships, going to a formal (naval) blockade.'' All those moves are possible under Chapter Seven of the U.N. Charter, which goes so far as permitting ``demonstrations, blockade, and other operations by air, sea, or land forces of Members of the United Nations.'' However, a State Department official, speaking privately, said Monday that Washington and Moscow want to move cautiously: ``The immediate concern is how do you make the current sanctions stick.'' The Soviets have said they would be willing to send troops to the Persian Gulf if there were a joint U.N. military command, and if they would be under the command of a Soviet general. Gorbachev, however, said in Helsinki that the Soviet Union is not now considering even sending ships to help enforce the embargo. ``I don't see the point of doing that now,'' he said, and Bush replied, ``I'm not disappointed in that answer.'' The State Department official said, ``There are a lot of ways you could rachet up the pressure, through being more and more explicit about the resolutions already in place, short of major Chapter Seven actions. ``The thrust is to make sure other countries live up to these angles,'' he said. India, Bangladesh, the Philippines and other nations are already petitioning the Security Council's sanctions committee for permission to ship food into Iraq and Kuwait to feed the hundreds of thousands of their people who are still stranded there. The council's sanctions committee has not yet determined that conditions in Iraq or occupied Kuwait are desperate enough to allow the import of food as a ``humanitarian'' step. The Kuwaiti ambassador and other diplomats have spoken of the possibility of having the Security Council impose an air blockade on Iraq, comparable to the current naval embargo enforced by the U.S.-led fleet in the Persian Gulf. But the U.S. official said ``you could say that shipment of cargo by air is already prohibited by the sanctions; that is both a service and an export, and clearly ruled out.'' If countries neighboring Iraq allow the use of their airspace for Iraqi flights, they would be ``facilitating transshipment,'' which the U.S. official said also would violate the embargo. Nations that violate a Security Council embargo may be subjected to sanctions themselves. Some American officials believe a formal council resolution endorsing an air embargo is not just unnecessary but could also lead to dangerous confrontations.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Official: Heating Oil Supplies Adequate Barring Problems
DOC.TEXT: Severe cold or operating problems at oil refineries could force heating oil shortages this winter, but otherwise adequate supplies are expected, Energy Department officials say. That assessment came Monday during a congressional hearing at which several congressmen expressed concern about the outlook. ``There now is a very small margin of safety,'' said Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., chairman of the House energy and power subcommittee, who suggested that the Energy Department ``tends to underestimate what can go wrong.'' The reliance on foreign oil and lack of a domestic energy program by the Bush administration was expected to come under renewed attack today as another House subcommittee looks into what measures should be to improve energy efficiency and conservation. Among those scheduled to testify before the House Interior subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources will be the sponsors of legislation that would require automakers to sharply increase the fuel economy of automobiles. A bill that would call for a fleet average fuel economy requirement of 40 miles per gallon by the end of the decade could come up for Senate floor action later this week, according to Senate sources. On Monday, Energy Department officials cautiously predicted adequate fuel oil for this winter, but said the situation could change for the worse if there is a severely cold winter or if operating problems develop at refineries, which are have been going at near-maximum 96 percent capacity. Further disruptions to Mideast oil shipments, also could cause shortages, they said. Several congressmen complained the assessment was based on ``rosy assumptions'' and suggested that it provides little comfort to Americans relying on oil to heat homes and factories. Calvin A. Kent, head of the Energy Information Administration, told Sharp's subcommittee that U.S. petroleum stocks ``appear adequate'' and that the shortfall of an estimated 1 million barrels of crude oil a day worldwide toward the end of the year ``can be handled'' as increased prices dampen demand. Kent said that refineries were operating at their maximum, but that the capacity to refine crude both in the United States and elsewhere ``appears to be adequate ... and will remain so over the next three to six months.'' Nevertheless, several other congressmen reiterated their call for President Bush to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Sharp said the president should consider ``at least a modest'' drawdown of the 590-million barrel reserve ``to get confidence up and hopefully force prices down.'' The Bush administration has rejected use of the reserves unless there are ``significant supply interruptions.'' Rep. Terry Bruce, D-Ill., said he was ``nervous'' about the slim margin in refining capacity. ``I fear we will run out of heating oil, gasoline and jet fuel,'' he said. Kent gave these assessments on the expected supply of various refined crude oil products:
DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil
DOC.TEXT: Current stocks are ``well above normal'' and rising. Supplies in the Northeast, which relies heavily on oil to heat homes and factories, are 16 percent above last year. The stocks ``appear to be adequate, barring any unusually cold weather or refinery breakdowns.''
DOC.HEAD: Gasoline
DOC.TEXT: Localized supply problems could develop. Inventories are at the lowest level since July 1988 _ 5.9 million barrels above the minimum operating inventory required to prevent shortages. Stocks, while tight, ``should be adequate to see us through the fourth quarter.''
DOC.HEAD: Jet Fuel
DOC.TEXT: Supply is above last year's levels but still tight and problems could develop late in the winter. Demand from the military is 300,000 barrels a day greater than normal because of the Persian Gulf deployment.

DOC.HEAD: Report: World Facing Education Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A global education crisis is underway with more than 100 million youngsters in the world's poorest countries not receiving any formal schooling, a report says. There will be more than 1 billion illiterate adults by the end of the decade if the United States and other nations fail to address this Third World education crisis, said the report released by RESULTS Educational Fund, an international citizen lobbying group. The report precedes a ``World Summit for Children,'' scheduled for Sept. 29-30 at the United Nations, and calls on President Bush to use his speech to the group to launch a new U.S. foreign aid basic education initiative. The main recommendation of the report is that the United States double within the next three years the annual amount of foreign aid going to basic education. In evaluating America's current contribution, the report found that less than 1 percent of U.S. foreign aid goes for that purpose. Furthermore, the report said, U.S. aid in basic education will decrease this year by 25 percent, from $129.5 million in fiscal year 1989 to $96.9 million in fiscal year 1990, a drop of more than $32 million. To reverse the decline, the United States must increase the amount of its foreign aid going to basic education to at least $370 million per year, the group said. Just by shifting a small portion of current aid funds away from less productive spending, such as military foreign aid, would provide all the new funding needed, the report added. The report said that Bush, by launching the new initiative, could prompt similar efforts by other donor nations and ``make a powerful contribution to making basic education and literacy for all a global reality.'' Right now, there are more than 850 million adult illiterates, with close to 98 percent of them in the developing nations, and more than 60 percent of them women, the report said. Women made up 86 percent of the 154 million new adult illiterates from 1960 to 1985; and more than 100 million primary-age children, mostly girls, currently are not enrolled in school. Thirty-four countries have literacy rates of about 40 percent or less. In 15 more, at least one-third of all adults are illiterate, the report said. RESULTS Education Fund is a non-partisan, non-profit organization. Most of the statistics were gathered during a March world conference in Thailand and from information tallied by countries since 1946, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Could Repeat `Misconduct' at Another S&L, OTS Warns
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush is capable of repeating the conduct that harmed a collapsed Colorado savings and loan by becoming a director at another thrift, regulators have told an administrative law judge. In written arguments submitted Monday to Judge Daniel J. Davidson, the Office of Thrift Supervision opposed Bush's request to dismiss the government's conflict of interest case against him. The president's son was an outside director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that failed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers estimated at $1 billion. The OTS is seeking an order against Bush which effectively would bar him from working for a bank or a savings and loan. In his arguments filed late last month, Bush said there was no possibility that he could continue the alleged abuses since Silverado already has been taken over by the government. Bush, 35, continued to deny any wrongdoing. The thrift agency called that argument ``specious.'' Under the S&L bailout legislation enacted by Congress last year, regulators are supposed to stop harmful practices whether or not the practices would damage a specific institution if continued, the OTS said. ``Bush is perfectly capable of becoming a director at another institution and repeating his misconduct there,'' the agency's brief said. ``Indeed, throughout these proceedings he has evinced no willingness to consider that he has done anything wrong, nor even any understanding that he ever had potential conflicts of interest. ``In fact, the reasons that moved a $2 billion institution to invite the then-30-year-old Bush, who had no experience in (savings and loan operations) to become a director are even more forceful today.'' The OTS said it is clear that Bush's conduct ``was contrary to generally accepted standards of prudent operation'' and could cause harm to any financial institution if continued. The regulators have accused Bush of conflict of interest for not disclosing his business ties to two big Silverado borrowers, developers Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters. Bush also could be a target of a negligence lawsuit that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing against him and other former Silverado directors. Bush has been ordered to appear at a public hearing on Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. ``They don't answer anything,'' said Bush's attorney, James Nesland, referring to the latest OTS brief. Nesland noted that the OTS arguments don't address the fact that the proposed order against Bush would be the first against an outside director after the institution has been closed. Nesland and Bush continue to maintain that the regulators' actions are politically motivated.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Heralds Reforms in Ancient Desert Dynasties
DOC.TEXT: The humiliating removal from power of Kuwait's royal family has raised questions about how long other longtime rulers can survive in desert kingdoms carved out by the swords of their Bedouin ancestors. The Iraqi takeover of Kuwait five weeks ago showed the weakness of its emir and, by extension, of the other five conservative dynasties running the region's oil-producing states. Middle East observers say the winds of political change were already blowing and that Iraq's seizure of Kuwait has set in motion forces that will spell the end of the old order _ one way or another. Even the manner in which Saudi Arabia and other monarchies appealed for help as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein gobbled up Kuwait underlined their inherent weakness. The invasion crystalized differences between Arab states and split them into two camps: pro-Iraqi and pro-Saudi. Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and, above all, Saudi Arabia, had no choice but to line up behind Kuwait. After years of playing East against West, they are now irrevocably linked to the West and the United States, which is seen by most Arabs as Israel's protector. That puts them on a collision course with alien ideas and Western political values, including a belief in pluralistic democracy. ``Most people in the gulf expect some democratic changes after this, and most governments are prepared to move. But don't expect them to go the whole hog, establishing parliaments and the like,'' said Brian Pridham, director of Exeter University's Center for Arab Gulf Studies in England. ``These regimes won't even consider it, and I'd hate to think what would happen if they did.'' Saddam's actions also have sharpened the Arab world's focus on economic imbalances _ oil states that sit atop fabulous wealth, while most states are deep in the red. ``The Kuwaiti Revolution of Aug. 2 has sounded the alarm bell for other Kuwait-type regimes. It signaled a radical change of system ... a new political era in the Arab Gulf region,'' the official Iraqi News Agency declared. Even if Iraq is forced out of Kuwait and the deposed al-Sabah family restored, it would be the status quo ante. ``It will not be possible for Western democracies to reinstall a demonstrably non-democratic system in Kuwait,'' said Pridham. ``There will certainly be changes, some checks and balances, some forms of democracy in an Arab style which will vary from state to state,'' he said. Democracy is rare in the Arab world. Of 17 Arab states, including Kuwait, six are secular dictatorships and six are aboslute monarchies. Only five have introduced some minimal elements of pluralism. Political evolution in the Arab world is slow. Neither Islam nor Arab nations have democratic traditions. The six gulf kings are remnants of the emirs, shieks and shahs who ruled throughout the region for centuries. Libya, Egypt, Iran, Yemen and Iraq were all ruled by monarchs who have been killed or ousted by coups since 1952. All, like the dynasties of the gulf, had ruled with the support of Britain and other colonial powers. Some were even hand-picked in London. But the gulf dynasties have hung on to power. Several can trace their roots back more than 300 years. The emirs rule more or less benevolently. Some of the kingdoms, observers say, are among the best governed nations in the Middle East. Thanks to oil revenue, people enjoy a high standard of living and a measure of personal freedom. The press may be censored, but reporters are not hanged. Gulf sheiks wield power with an 18th century sense of noblesse oblige, but no concessions to the democratic reforms sweeping much of the rest of the world. They rule by edict, forbid political parties, and reject popular governing bodies. Blessed with huge oil reserves and small populations, the rulers have shown enough social concern and material largesse to keep most subjects happy. Bahrain and Kuwait experimented with popular assemblies, but they didn't last long. Elections and parliaments in an Arab context are often looked upon as foolhardy steps toward chaos. ``Just look at Lebanon,'' Pridham said, ``That's what they think democracy looks like in the Middle East ... These regimes were horrified at the changes that swept Eastern Europe.'' Moreover, recent elections in Jordan and Algeria saw Islamic fundamentalists make significant gains, a specter that haunts gulf rulers who have embraced many aspects of Western life.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Curbing Industrial Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators are reporting the first breakthrough in drafting a compromise clean air bill with a tentative agreement between the House and Senate on the control of smog-causing pollution from industry. Congressional sources emphasized, however, that there remained major differences that have yet to be resolved despite mounting time pressures. Congress plans to adjourn in early October. The sources, who demanded anonymity, said staff negotiators agreed Monday on measures to be taken against industry to control urban smog. They opted for tougher House provisions that would require even small businesses to install new control equipment in areas with severe pollution. The staff agreement was reached with the knowledge of lawmakers on the House-Senate conference committee, although committee members must still formally sign off on it, said one source close to the negotiations. The committee has tried since June to resolve differences in separate clean air bills that were approved by wide margins in the House and Senate early this year. The agreement on so-called Title I, which includes the industrial smog-control provisions and general air quality goals for communities, was considered a major step forward in the discussions. ``This is one of the major hurdles,'' said Daniel Weiss, who has followed the clean air debates for the Sierra Club, an environmental group. The massive and complex legislation calls for steep cuts in acid rain, tougher emission controls on automobiles, requirements that oil companies produce cleaner fuels and controls on toxic chemical releases. The new requirements are predicted to cost industry $25 billion a year when all take effect at the end of the decade. The price tag has caused industry to intensify its lobbying against portions of the bill in view of skyrocketing oil prices and the increasing prospects of a recession. The Bush administration had opposed the stronger industrial smog controls tentatively agreed to Monday, saying that if small companies are required to install new control equipment the legislation will become too expensive. Environmentalists argued that small polluters account for nearly half of the smog in many urban areas. Under the agreement, factories and businesses that release as little as 25 to 50 tons of pollution annually would be required to comply with new controls. The Senate bill had exempted facilities that release less than 100 tons of pollution per year. Meanwhile, other controversial parts of the bill remain to be worked out, including whether to provide financial assistance to workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. Some lawmakers have also suggested that parts of the bill should be re-examined in light of the Mideast crisis and the latest oil shocks. ``We may have to begin to reassess what is realistic,'' said Democratic Rep. Mike Synar of Oklahoma, a leading oil state. He suggested that some pollution control requirements on the petroleum industry and a mandate for cleaner fuels might have to be delayed. Nevertheless, the agreement Monday on industrial pollution represents the most significant progress yet in crafting a final bill. The staff agreement also includes deadlines on when communities must comply with federal air quality requirements. Both the House and Senate versions had similar deadlines, giving most cities five to 15 years to bring their air into compliance with federal health standards. Los Angeles was given 20 years. But the agreement goes along with a House provision that would continue to require the federal government to impose air pollution control plans if cities fail to do so. The Senate version would have ended that federal requirement.

DOC.HEAD: Voters to Evaluate Norton's Tax Dilemma
With PM-Political Husbands, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congressional candidate Eleanor Holmes Norton received an apology from her husband as he explained at a news conference that he ``simply procrastinated'' by not filing local tax returns since 1982. ``It was always a situation where I said, `I'll do this tomorrow,''' Edward Norton, an attorney, told reporters Monday. ``I'm the villain in this ... and I apologize to my wife and the citizens.'' Mrs. Norton was flanked at the news conference by her husband and their two children. ``This matter, having been laid before the public ... (means) the voters of the District of Columbia have all they need to decide whether I should be the next congresswoman,'' Mrs. Norton said on the eve of the city's Democratic primary. Her husband said he ``simply procrastinated'' in not filing the joint tax forms his wife signed. Mrs. Norton said she even asked her husband, ``Are the taxes in, and he said, `Yes.' If I had knowingly done this, why would I be running?'' The candidate's husband said he handles the family's finances. However, he did not reveal why he failed to inform his wife of the tax problem after she entered the race or why he did not file the forms in the first place. The couple filed no local returns between 1982 and 1989. Norton and her three opponents are vying for the non-voting U.S. House delegate seat held by Walter Fauntroy, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for mayor of District of Columbia in today's primary. The tax conflict has helped breath new life into the campaigns of Norton's three opponents, all of whom trailed her by 10 points or more in opinion polls taken before the controversy began. Local political observers suggest that veteran city councilwoman Betty Ann Kane stands to gain most from Norton's problems. The Washington Post endorsed Kane on Monday after revealing that it scrapped a planned Norton endorsement once the stories about her tax situation surfaced. ``I am in this race to stay,'' Norton said at a campaign rally. ``Those that think they could chase this woman out of this race ... don't know a fighter when they see one.'' Norton headed the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission during the Carter administration.

DOC.HEAD: Bedouins Fear Holy War Could Imperil Their Way of Life
DOC.TEXT: The Bedouins of Jordan, hearing Holy War in the wind, pray to Allah that a modern clash of wills will not make their ancient desert life vanish in the sands. Among the Bedouins, for centuries guided more by water and whim than by lines on a map, any conflict threatens to restrict movement, further threatening a way of life already in danger. ``War will damage the whole world,'' said Mohammed Salim, squatting on his heels in a burlap-rag tent near this city north of Amman. ``And the Bedouin will suffer, especially.'' He wonders if he can go to Saudi Arabia _ or if he wants to _ under a climate of hostility over Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. He worries about market shortages in Jordan. Far to the south near Petra, Ali Salim Bedol watched the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein on a television set in the concrete block shelter given to him when Bedouins were evicted from the 2,000-year-old ruins, now a major tourist attraction. ``Saddam is a great man,'' he said, ``but we do not want war. No one can win if there is fighting. We want only peace, to take our goats and camels where we want and to live among Arabs.'' About 150,000 Bedouins live regularly in Jordan, under black goat-hair tents or in tumbledown hovels, making up 5 percent of the total population. Some stay put, but most pick up and roam at will. Another 9,000 are nomads, drifting back and forth toward Saudi Arabia, whence Bedouin tribes came when the Hashemite royal family settled in Jordan after World War I. The family had left the Hejaz _ Saudi Arabia's Arabic name. Despite the Bedouins' warlike reputation, and their deep sense of honor, most seem to reject Saddam's call to arms. Instead, they follow events by radio, newspapers passed from hand to hand, or the occasional word from travelers. They discuss the crisis endlessly around campfires at night. ``They are hit hard by the crisis,'' said Rebecca Salti, who runs a Save the Children crafts project for Bedouins in the desert east of Amman. ``Many are afraid Israel will attack and overrun their grazing lands.'' Bedouins once bolstered the political and military power base behind Jordan's King Hussein. Camel-mounted troops of the fabled Arab Legion enhanced their prestige and mystique. But severe drought in the 1970s killed their animals and brought many Bedouin families to the outskirts of towns. Army service paid high wages, which inevitably meant changes in the old way of life. Today, many families live precariously at the edge, still fiercely loyal to the king but marginal to life in Jordan. A Bedouin who would identify himself only as Salam keeps his two wives, 19 children, two camels and small herd of goats in a tent compound on a barren hillside near Zarqa. With no income beyond what his animals produce, he survives by the curious Third World mathematics which defy all accounting. If the crisis continues, he said, his delicate balance will tilt. ``Never mind,'' he said. ``For a poor man, there is no fear in death. A Bedouin needs nothing. We make clothes from our goats. We have yogurt, meat. That is enough.'' But his sons are in school, and he thinks of the future. They may be engineers or doctors by day and Bedouins when they return at night, he said. He supports Saddam but wants no war. ``Every country will be different if there is war,'' he said. ``We will not escape.'' Pressed for his full name, he chuckled and said, ``Salam Yachak el Haya.'' It wasn't his name. In Arabic it means Salam loves life. Ali Salim Bedol is already suffering. He once earned a modest living selling souvenirs to tourists at Petra. Now, the tourists are gone. ``We will go to the desert if crisis comes,'' he said. ``There will always be a Bedouin way.'' His 17-year-old son, wearing a Mickey Mouse T-shirt and captivated by the television, looked doubtful.

DOC.HEAD: ACT Scores Unchanged From Year-Ago Levels
DOC.TEXT: Scores on the ACT college entrance exam were stagnant for the fifth straight year, but blacks and other minorities continued to show gains. The average composite score on the ACT, the predominant college entrance test in 28 states mainly in the Midwest and West, was 20.6 on a scale of 1-36, according to American College Testing of Iowa City, Iowa, which administers the exam. The average among students taking the test in 1989-90 was unchanged from the previous year and has shown virtually no movement in five years, ACT said Monday. The 817,096 students who took the exam last year were given a new version, and therefore results were not directly comparable to previous years. But ACT officials calculated that the 1990 scores and the 1989 averages were unchanged. The scores offered school critics fresh evidence that nearly a decade of reform has brought little genuine improvement. Two weeks ago, the College Board, which sponsors the SAT, the predominant college entrance test in the 22 other states, reported scores on the verbal section had sunk to their lowest levels in a decade, and math scores were unchanged for the fourth straight year. ACT spokeswoman Patricia Farrant stressed in an interview that ``reform changes take a certain amount of time'' to show up in test scores. ACT officials also insisted that the public should take heart from the fact that 45 percent of students taking the test in 1990 took a solid core curriculum in high school, compared with 36 percent in 1987. Students taking at least four years of English,and three or more years of math, social studies and science averaged 22.3 on the exam. Students taking less than that amount of coursework averaged 19.1. The ACT also found strong year-to-year gains among virtually all minority groups. Blacks' average scores rose 0.4 points to 17.0. Mexican Americans scored 18.3, up 0.2. American Indians and Alaskan Natives averaged 18.0, up 0.5. Puerto Ricans and other Hispanics scored 19.3, unchanged from the previous year but up 0.3 from 1986. By contrast, white students averaged 21.2, or 0.1 lower than a year ago and down 0.3 from 1986. The ACT is a four-part exam testing English, math, reading and scientific reasoning. Both the SAT and ACT are supposed to test a student's readiness for college. But the ACT is generally considered a broader test of high school mastery. The new version of the ACT included new measures of writing ability, new advanced math questions and a new reading test stressing reasoning skills. The SAT also is being revised, for 1993. ACT officials have consistently declined to release state-by-state test data, arguing it would invite inaccurate comparisons. The College Board issues a similar caution each year but nonetheless releases such data.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Pulse: Steady For Now With Sporadic Flutters
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: Americans are finding down-home ways to rally around the flag. But uneasiness over the prospect of a Persian Gulf oil war is generating rumblings of protest. An ex-Marine in Virginia is mailing gift packs to troops in the Persian Gulf. A North Carolina farmer mowed a giant ``U S A'' into his bean field. An Indiana woman with three sons in the 82nd Airborne Division founded Mothers Against Saddam Hussein, or MASH. On the other hand, 700 marchers in Seattle this weekend chanted: ``Hell, no, we won't go, we won't fight for Texaco.'' ``There is a national consensus for now, but I think it's thin,'' says Robert Karl Madoff, director of the Center for War, Peace and the News Media at New York University. ``There's a sense of foreboding. Bush stuck a stick into a hornet's nest.'' When it comes to backing U.S. soldiers in the merciless Arabian desert, David Heard of Manassas, Va., says color him ``true blue.'' He and his wife, Jean, have started Operation Something From Home with donations from around the country. Packages to soliders include gum, Lifesavers candy, lip balm, liquid soap, playing cards, dominoes, letters from school kids, Kleenex and toilet paper. ``They'll perform a lot better knowing the country is behind them and that no rotten vegetables will be thrown at them when they return home,'' said Heard, 55, a veteran of Korea and Vietnam who has two sons serving in the Persian Gulf and a daughter and son-in-law on active duty in Europe. Anna Goodwin of New Castle, Ind., has three sons in the 82nd Airborne. She founded MASH as a support group for families who have sons and daughters in the Middle East. Tom Herring, 51, sowed his feelings with a flag-bedecked tractor. He carved ``U S A'' in a 75-by-300-foot patch to salute pilots flying from Pope Air Force Base near Fayetteville, N.C. ``I'd like to take every inch of that dirt and shove it down Saddam's throat,'' he said. How long the national mood remains steadfast is another matter as America's attention is diverted to baseball stretch drives, the opening of football season and the return to school. Blitzkrieg has turned to sitzkrieg while a U.N. embargo tries to make Saddam back down in Kuwait. It could take months to wreck Iraq's war-hardened economy. That's time for the U.S. economy to sputter, for gas and heating oil prices to rise and for the price tag on Operation Desert Shield to mount while the country presses it allies to pay their fair share. The administration's line in the first post-Cold War crisis came from Secretary of State James A. Baker: ``Stand firm, be patient and remain united so that together we can show that aggression does not pay.'' But some on the Republican right urged caution. When President Bush said ``our way of life'' was threatened, some saw it not as a reference to democracy but to big cars and air conditioning. ``There are lots of things worth fighting for, but an extra 10 cents for a gallon of gas isn't one of them,'' wrote columnist Patrick Buchanan. He said a war with Iraq ``has quagmire written all over it.'' Conservative Tom Bethell of the American Spectator wrote: ``It is hard to understand why Americans are supposed to become outraged _ and pay more at the pump _ because Kuwait's oil is now controlled by a tyrant in a military uniform rather than oligarchs in traditional attire.'' The Nation magazine, a bellwether of liberal thought, called the U.S. deployment ``naked imperial intervention'' and compared the policy to ``many of Hollywood's disappointed summer blockbusters that started out big but shriveled after a few weeks.'' Elsewhere, the pulse of patriotism is strong. Students at Daniel Webster Elementary School in Logan, Ind., wrote 4,000 messages to mail to soldiers. One said: ``Everyone loves you. We hope you won't have to fight. Be careful.'' JoAnn McGrath has made 3,000 red, white and blue bows for folks living near Fort Leonard Wood, Mo. KRST-FM in Albuquerque, N.M., adorned its billboards with a giant yellow ribbon for U.S. hostages in the Mideast. There were different signs that the standoff may be a long one. The USO will have comic Jay Leno entertain troops at Thanksgiving. ``We're all seeing that the enemy the troops are fighting right now is boredom and loneliness,'' said Kevin McCarthy, executive producer for the USO. Meanwhile, a peace vigil has entered its third week at a Seattle park. Participants have replaced each other in shifts since Aug. 26, and organizers say the vigil will go on until a peaceful solution is achieved.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Produce Wheat, Tomatoes, Milk Under Desert Sun
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: AL-KHARJ, Saudi Arabia (AP) _ Waves of grain that will eventually provide U.S. soldiers with bread spring from the same scorching reclaimed desert the troops were sent to protect. Saudi tomatoes, on the other hand, have it easier: they are pampered in air-conditioned greenhouses. Agriculture experts say Saudi Arabia's drive to food self-sufficiency is being pushed even harder by the Persian Gulf crisis. Saudi Arabia, with annual rainfall averaging 4 inches, produces all its own wheat and most of its milk and vegetables. ``It's an amazing thing that they have done,'' said one Western diplomat. The kingdom is confident it can retain its position as the world's sixth largest wheat exporter despite the loss of markets in Iraq and Kuwait. The two countries bought 450,000 tons annually. In all, Saudi Arabia exports 1.9 million tons to 42 countries. ``It won't hurt,'' said Mohammed Al-Basher, deputy director general of the Grain Silos and Flour Mills Organization. ``To sell Saudi wheat is not difficult.'' The once desolate land that produced 3,000 tons of wheat in 1975 is expected to yield 3.2 million tons this year. Critics charge that the project hemorrhages cash and guzzles water from under the desert at a rate that will dry up the precious resource. However, government officials say the quantity of food grown and its distribution mean any Iraqi attempt to attack one region or blockade food imports could not interrupt supplies. ``We don't need to buy food in an emergency,'' said Al-Basher. An extremely costly subsidy program underwrote the achievement. Interest-free loans up to $5 million or more are available to purchase land, machinery and irrigation equipment. The dairy herd you want is in Holland? No problem, the government will pay for the shipping. ``Basically, farming is a license to make money,'' said another Western diplomat, speaking like his colleague on condition of anonymity. The government buys all the wheat produced for $400 per ton from large corporate farms and $533 per ton from smaller producers. That same ton sells for about $186 on world markets. The wheat milled into flour goes at the bargain-basement rate of $117 per ton. Caterers supplying the estimated 100,000 U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia buy their supplies from the government. The 1990 budget allocated almost $2 billion for subsidies, most of that for agriculture. The government started to gently apply the brakes on subsidies during the oil price drop of the late 1980s. It would like to see production gradually concentrate less on wheat and more on crops like flowers and vegetables, government officials say. But wheat still accounts for more than 65 percent of agricultural production. While petrodollars were producing huge cash reserves, everyone supported the agricultural development idea, said Omar S. Bagour, a professor of economics at Abdul Aziz University in Jiddah. ``Now we are asking if we should have done it on such a massive scale, whether this was the best approach.'' Critics worry that the center pivot method of irrigation will suck underground aquifers dry within 15 years. They think drip techniques would be preferable to the trundling sprinklers that allow so much to evaporate. Diplomats say the subsidy program will never be eliminated because it was a political rather than an economic decision from the beginning. It helped spread the kingdom's wealth in the central Najd region, which had neither the oil deposits of the east nor the trade and annual income from the vast Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca in the west. The program also keeps the countryside populated in a country bigger than Western Europe. Although most of the laborers, like everywhere in Saudi Arabia, are Asians, the subsidies have even tempted Bedouins to settle down. Among other projects, the subsidies spawned the largest dairy farm in the world at Al-Kharj, 54 miles south of the capital, Riyadh. The cows are sprayed with a fine mist most of the day, because duping them into thinking they are in some drizzly northern climate brings forth more milk. The 115-degree temperatures outside would curdle the milk within hours. But a special cooling system on the high-tech farm keeps the milk around 37 degrees as it is processed. Cucumbers and tomatoes grow in greenhouses that cover more than an acre each. The windows are whitewashed, and air conditioners blow cool air. Crop yields are about three times what they were in the fields. The agriculture projects are widely viewed as a miracle in the kingdom. Flying overhead, the harsh landscape is suddenly interrupted by mile after mile of green. The sight is known to be a special favorite of the king. Said one diplomat: ``He's made the desert bloom _ at a price. But it's a price he can afford, so why not?''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,604.66, down 476.24 points, or 1.90 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: For The Moment, Life Improving In Refugee Camp
DOC.TEXT: With aid finally arriving and fewer people crossing the Iraqi border, officials say they may be turning a corner in this desolate refugee camp _ at least for now. Tens of thousands of destitute Asians and Egyptians are still stuck in baking, dusty refugee camps throughout Jordan, with an estimated 500,000 reported waiting to cross the border from Iraq. But after nearly three weeks of dealing with overwhelming numbers, officials at the largest and most notorious of three border camps said Monday that the number of residents had tapered off. About 30,000 were at Shaalan I on Monday, compared with 45,000 late last week. And Jordanian officials say the ratio of arrivals to departures from the border area has improved. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have crossed the Iraq-Jordan border at the nearby Ruweishid checkpoint since Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 _ and more than 110,000 are stranded in Jordan as attempts are made to get them transportation home. Most have been forced to make do in Shaalan I and the two other squalid camps between the Jordanian and Iraqi checkpoints. They wait up to two weeks to return to the home countries they left to seek a better life in Kuwait. The International Organization for Migration said in Geneva on Monday there are still 500,000 foreigners who want to leave Iraq _ so the refugee situation in Jordan could rapidly deteriorate with a massive influx. Still, relief officials have had a respite from the chaos of those first weeks. ``It is five or six times better than before,'' said Dr. Almadin Azim, a physician at Shaalan I. ``In the beginning, you're not ready to do all the things they ask of you.'' Azim said he is still without medicines to treat the 60 to 70 scorpion stings that occur each night. There is also a shortage of antibiotics for those allergic to penicillin. ``We need blankets, tents, milk,'' said Kriam Al-Hadid, the Red Crescent official in charge at the camp. ``All the world must help us.'' Even more crucial is transportation. Most of the refugees are stuck where they are because officials simply don't have enough vehicles to move them. The International Organization for Migration said ``the situation looks more optimistic'' a week after the start of an airlift and a worldwide appeal for aid. But it said the aid was still insufficient. Pledged contributions of $30 million have enabled the agency to schedule 107 flights that would repatriate more than 31,500 stranded people over the next 10 days, it said. On Monday, more than 10,000 people had crossed the border into Jordan by 6 p.m. And 8,000 people had left, the official news agency Petra said. Those figures compared favorably with last week, when arrivals far outnumbered departures. Al-Haddid said there have been three births and one death from natural causes since the camp opened almost three weeks ago. There were noticeably fewer people in the camp Monday than last week. Many of their makeshift tents had been replaced by a sea of aqua-colored plastic water bottles and other debris mingling with the ochre dust stirred up by motor vehicles and desert whirlwinds. Several thousand had been moved down the road to a camp called Rahima, Arabic for mercy. Tents were set up there for 5,000 to 6,000 people and more shelters were en route, said Jim Nuttal, coordinator for Save The Children. Nuttal said aid from the Jordanian government had improved. ``Right now, it's enough. We've got enough water. Everybody's being fed,'' he said. At Azraq, 125 miles to the southwest toward Amman, a new camp is being erected to replace another that was moved because it threatened the capital's water supply. Workers sweated to complete a tent city there with a high-pressure water pipe connected to the Amman-Azraq line. It will be a temporary home to 30,000 people, many of whom now are at Ruweishid. ``This is a camp. There it's just a gathering of people,'' said Yves Etienne, a Red Cross engineer supervising construction of a water tank. And how long would the refugees be housed at Azraq, he was asked. ``Only Allah knows,'' he answered.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Move Deepens Regional Split Over Iraqi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Arab foreign ministers and senior officials are moving the Arab League's headquarters from Tunisia to Cairo, a move that signals a deepening of existing regional divisions. The decision was approved Monday by 12 of the league's 21 members _ the same majority that at an Arab summit earlier this month condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq and its supporters, including the Palestine Liberation Organization, boycotted Monday's meeting. Iraq said it would not abide by the decision, indicating a further split between Baghdad and its supporters and Egypt and the 11 Arab states that back the transfer. ``I have faith that the return of the headquarters to its site in Cairo is necessary to maintain the role and essence of the Arab League,'' Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid said in his message opening the meeting. ``Egypt will cooperate and coordinate with all Arab friends and will continue the effort to keep the Arab League a home for all Arabs at all times, based on its conviction that the league is above all passing conflicts among the Arab states.'' The message was read by Osama el-Baz, the deputy foreign minister. Abdel-Meguid was unable to attend the session because of minor injuries suffered during a car crash Friday. The league said its major departments would move by Oct. 31 from the Tunisian capital of Tunis to its old site in Cairo. It said other departments should be moved from Tunis to Cairo by Dec. 31. Announcement of the relocation is a formality to complement a decision made in March in Tunis at a regular meeting of the Arab League council. The league headquarters was transfered from Cairo to the Tunisian capital in 1979 in retaliation for Egypt's signing of the Camp David peace treaty with Israel. Egypt's membership in the Arab League was reinstated in 1989, about a year after most Arab counties resumed diplomatic ties with Cairo. Relations had been severed in reaction to Camp David. The Arab League's attempt to project Arab unity was shattered after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Egypt, Morocco and Syria sent troops to Saudi Arabia to help defend it against possible Iraqi attack, and most Persian Gulf nations condemned the seizure of oil-rich Kuwait. But other nations, including neighboring Jordan and the PLO, did not join the criticism. Pro-Iraqi demonstrations have been held in Yemen, Tunisia, Mauritania, Libya, Jordan and the Israeli-occupied territories. The nine Arab states or organizations that boycotted Monday's meeting were: Algeria, Iraq, Jordan, Libya, Mauritania, the PLO, Sudan, Tunisia and Yemen.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo, Stocks Dip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Tuesday, while share prices fell in moderate trading. The dollar closed at 139.85 yen, 0.42 yen above Monday's finish. After opening at 140.05 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 139.55 and 140.25 yen. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 476.24 points, or 1.90 percent, to 24,604.66. An estimated 400 million shares were traded on the market's first section. On Monday, the Nikkei index advanced 1,118.83 points in its sixth largest daily gain. On the bond market, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds jumped to 8.365 percent from Monday's close of 8.225 percent. Their price fell to 82.01 from 82.57. Traders said the Nikkei index slid mostly due to the yen's fall against the dollar, as well as a fall in the price of government bonds. ``First was the yen exchange rate. Second, bonds got cheaper,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst at Nomura Securities. Profit-taking after Monday's big gain and the overnight rise in oil prices also were factors in the falling stock market, traders said. On the currency market, the U.S. unit regained strength in Tokyo as Japanese investors started selling the yen to make up their oversold dollar positions following recent substantial selling, said Akiko Baba, a customer dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. She noted the overnight hike in oil prices in New York also encouraged the dollar's strength, but added, ``The dollar's increase is just a temporary move as part of technical adjustments, because there are more negative elements to encourage dollar selling than buying.'' Ms. Baba said there is a growing market expectation that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board will ease its monetary policy to cope with a slowdown in the U.S. economy, a factor that would encourage dollar selling.

DOC.HEAD: Six More Past or Present Legislators Implicated in Pay-for-Votes Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Five more legislators and a former representative who is now a judge have been implicated in a Statehouse scandal in which three of five lawmakers previously indicted have pleaded guilty to selling their votes. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel filed court papers Monday that said the six conspired to obtain money for their votes on a bill that would legalize dog and horse racing. The bill was never put to a final vote. None of the six has been charged, although they have acknowledged being questioned by the FBI in connection with the 16-month investigation. All six are black. Some blacks, including Democratic gubernatorial nominee Theo Mitchell, have questioned why so many blacks have been implicated. ``Certainly it's a disproportionate number of black legislators that were targeted,'' he said last month. Nineteen of the Legislature's 170 members are black. Four of the five lawmakers indicted in August are white. The U.S. attorney has strongly denied any racial motivation. During the investigation, FBI agents videotaped lawmakers taking cash from lobbyist Ron Cobb, a former House member working undercover for the FBI. Named as conspirators Monday were: Democratic Reps. Larry Blanding of Sumter, James Faber of Eastover, Ennis Fant of Greenville, B.J. Gordon of Kingstree, and Frank McBride of Columbia. Also named was Circuit Judge Tee Ferguson, a former Democratic House member from Spartanburg. He was suspended from hearing cases. Also Monday, former Sen. Rick Lee, a Republican from Boiling Springs, pleaded guilty to a bribery charge. Last week, former Reps. Robert Brown, D-Marion, and Danny Winstead, R-Charleston, entered similar pleas. No sentencing date has been set. Lee faces up to 20 years in prison, as do Brown and Robert Kohn, a Republican from Charleston who has pleaded innocent. Winstead faces 30 years. The fifth lawmaker indicted last month, Luther Taylor, a Democrat from Columbia, faces 120 years. The filings Monday came in response to a request by Taylor's attorney that prosecutors list the unidentified conspirators referred to in the indictment against him. In the papers, Daniel also said Taylor took $2,800 from Cobb in 1988 and 1989 for voting to uphold a $2.8 million computer contract won by National Advance System with Clemson University. The final payment of $300 was filmed by the FBI, the papers said. Daniel said Taylor is on videotape saying that payment of legislators has been business-as-usual for years. Taylor has not been charged in the computer case, but Daniel argued that evidence about the case should be admitted in court.

DOC.HEAD: Time Stands Still as Beijing Awaits Asian Games
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Bitter memories linger, but the scars of tank treads and bullet holes have been patched up as Beijing residents await the Asian Games. China remains, as always, the center of its own universe. Daily news broadcasts bring alarming reports from the Persian Gulf that barely seem to touch this city of 10 million. There is no stock market to plummet; no troops are being sent. Visitors to Beijing find the city at its best. Old apartment blocks and courtyard houses facing the streets have been plastered over and painted. Pink rose bushes and shrubs have been planted in preparation for the Sept. 22-Oct. 7 Asian Games. Crimson banners proclaim: ``Warm welcome to our guests.'' Beijing citizens have been instructed to kill pet and stray dogs to reduce the risk of rabies and keep the city clean. Stern-looking men and women in yellow hats and red armbands are stationed on street corners for bicycle traffic control and to discourage littering and spitting _ a prevalent habit in this dusty city _ with the threat of 5 yuan ($1) fines. There are few physical reminders of the violence of the spring of 1989, when hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed as the military cleared central Beijing of pro-democracy demonstrators. A year ago, the city was still subdued and foreign tourists scarce. Soldiers armed with automatic rifles stood ominously at major intersections and in the diplomatic quarters. The rifles have disappeared. This year, Beijing's posh international hotels are filling up with foreign business executives and tourists. Beijing in late summer seems a city suspended in time. ``No one expects anything to happen, no top leaders are likely to drop from favor or die until the Asian Games are well out of the way,'' said one Western diplomat. But the appearance of calm on twilight sidewalks crowded with card players and watermelon vendors masks deep political undercurrents. Video surveillance cameras stare down on evening strollers, discouraging all but the most businesslike contacts between foreigners and Chinese. ``You should never quote a Chinese person by name,'' one Chinese journalist told a Western reporter. ``It's just too dangerous for them.'' Intellectuals ask foreign friends to call from public phones or to just drop in to help skirt surveillance. ``Things look like they have improved,'' said one researcher. ``But for many of us, they are still pretty bad.'' Despite a few gestures aimed at restoring its international image, such as lifting martial law in Beijing and allowing dissident astrophysicist Fang Lizhi to leave his year-long refuge in the U.S. Embassy to travel abroad, the political noose is still tight. The media is tightly controlled. Writers and artists must have ``a firm belief that only socialism can save China. ...'' propaganda official He Jingzhi said in a recent speech. A steady stream of local reports blames rising crime rates and materialism on ``unhealthy Western influences.'' The Communist Party refuses to budge from one-party rule, although leaders acknowledge that they must stem widespread corruption and improve living conditions to reclaim public support. The Asian Games _ aimed so clearly at repairing China's tarnished image abroad _ appear to have done little to enhance the government's image at home. A resident of one crumbling compound hidden by a fancy new gray plaster wall called the renovation a ``sham.'' Longtime foreign residents of Beijing say the leadership's obsession with the Asian Games has done little to win public support among residents who were asked to make ``contributions'' to the $53 million fund needed to stage the games. ``We have a bad government,'' said one Chinese salesman. ``We're poor, but they took even more money away from us to pay for the Asian Games. It doesn't do us any good.'' The government has tightened security in the city to gird against possible terrorist attacks or protests by students and workers seeking to take advantage of the large foreign presence during the Asian Games. Some taxi drivers said they had stopped working nights because they didn't like being stopped by police. Few observers expect the public, memories of last year's violence still sharp, to be defiant. But glimmers of hope remain. ``Chinese people are very patient. They know that their experiences helped the revolutions in Eastern Europe and they are just waiting to see what will happen next,'' said one intellectual. ``There's alot of suspense,'' said one young Chinese man. ``You just have to wait and see. In a way, it's exciting.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Suburb Approves Nation's First College Tuition Tax
DOC.TEXT: The City Council in this Chicago suburb has approved the nation's first tax on college tuition, voting to charge students at Northwestern University and three other schools up to $60 a year. Mayor Joan Barr immediately said she will veto the measure, and Northwestern threatened to take the city to court. ``I do not believe Evanston should be the very first community in the United States to tax education,'' the mayor said. ``Evanston has always taken pride in its educational excellence.'' The measure was approved 10-8 Monday night to make up for the property taxes from which the schools are exempt and to give tax relief to homeowners who saw higher bills in this community of 73,000 because of reassessment last year. The council could override a veto by a two-thirds vote. The tax of $15 per semester _ or per quarter, depending on how the school's academic year is set up _ would generate an estimated $500,000 a year toward the city's budget, which totaled $77.3 million in 1990-91, officials said. The measure would apply to three other schools _ Kendall College, Garrett Evangelical Theological Seminary and Seabury-Western Theological Seminary. But the debate Monday centered on Northwestern and its unwillingness to pay the city for police and fire protection. The university has its own security force but occasionally asks for assistance from Evanston police. ``All we are asking for is a basic principle, and that is a fair share,'' said Alderman Jack Korshak, who proposed the measure. ``Five dollars a month. Each of you can judge for yourself the extent to which this represents an insuperable burden to a student.'' University President Arnold Weber argued Northwestern students couldn't handle the extra $60 because more than half already receive extensive financial aid. Most of the school's nearly 10,500 students are undergraduates who pay tuition of $13,725 a year. Weber called the tax ``anti-education'' and ``anti-business'' and said it would destroy the relationship between the city and its educational institutions. Northwestern, which owns 242 of the 5,400 acres in the community, has said it is typical for such institutions to be exempt from property taxes. ``We have focused on Northwestern _ the big, the bad, and apparently, the ugly,'' said Alderman David Nelson, who voted against the tax. ``There are apparently going to be others caught up in the maelstrom.'' Northwestern officials have promised a court fight. They have pointed out that the school brings about 500,000 visitors a year to the city, pumps millions of dollars into the local economy and adds many cultural advantages. No other U.S. city has a tuition tax, said Sheldon E. Steinbach, vice president and general counsel of the American Council on Education in Washington. The council represents 1,500 colleges and universities nationwide. Bob Goritz, an Evanston resident and a lawyer, argued the tax would not stand up in court. ``No matter what verbiage you put on the measure, it's a tax on the occupation of being a student,'' he said. ``All you're going to buy yourself is about five years of litigation that will result in this being overturned.''

Evanston has always taken pride in its educational excellence.'' _ Mayor Joan Barr, saying she will veto a measure passed by the City Council that would make Evanston, Ill., the nation's first community to tax college tuition.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Arts Awards Winners Helped Make America a `Cultural Giant'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says the 13 latest recipients of the National Medal of Arts help define America and make it ``a cultural giant.'' Those at the East Room ceremony Monday included legendary Broadway director George Abbott, a frail 103-year-old, and dapper Hume Cronyn, who took a bow when the president revealed that Barbara Bush was ``secretly in love'' with the 79-year-old actor. Among the other medal winners were painter Jasper Johns, soprano Beverly Sills, blues guitarist B.B. King, choreographer Merce Cunningham and actress Jessica Tandy, Cronyn's wife, who missed the event. Also, landscape architect Ian McHag and painter Jacob Lawrence, as well as art patrons David Lloyd Kreeger of Washington and Harris and Carroll Masterson of Houston. The Southwestern Bell Corp. was honored for its corporate sponsorship of the arts. Mrs. Bush helped present the silver medals, nestled in walnut boxes, to each artist and patron. It was the sixth year the White House has bestowed the honors, which are organized by the National Endowment for the Arts.
DOC.HEAD: Chileans Charge U.S. Officials Contaminated Grapes
DOC.TEXT: The Chilean Exporters Association is accusing the U.S. Food and Drug Administration of contaminating two Chilean grapes with cyanide and setting off a public health scare in March 1989. A report issued by the association in Washington and Santiago, Chile, concluded that, based on scientific studies, the grapes could not have been tampered with in Chile or at the port of Philadelphia where the poisoned grapes were found. ``The grapes were contaminated at the FDA laboratory in Philadelphia,'' the report said. ``The manner in which the contamination took place could have been accidental or intentional.'' FDA officials have said repeatedly that they believe the grapes were poisoned in Chile before the ship left on its two-week voyage to the United States. Of the report's conclusion, FDA spokesman Bill Grigg said: ``We think that's preposterous.'' The FDA went looking for the grapes after the U.S. Embassy in Santiago received an anonymous telephone threat March 2, 1989. After it found the two tainted grapes, the FDA urged that all Chilean fruit be removed from U.S. markets while more tests continued. The association estimated the FDA's action cost the Chileans more than $330 million as more than 6 million cases of fruit in the United States were destroyed. The association said research at the University of California at Davis showed that if the two grapes had been contaminated with cyanide, other grapes in the same case also would have contained the poison. However, none was found, the FDA has said. The studies also showed that because cyanide was found at such high levels, it would have to have been introduced in the grapes more recently than two weeks before, when the ship was in Chile, the report said.
UPI Confirms Bureau Closings In Three States

United Press International is closing its bureaus in New Mexico, Wyoming and Montana, says a spokesman for the news service. Spokesman Milt Capps confirmed on Monday a report on the closures in The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune, but declined to specify how many layoffs were involved. The Tribune said UPI's single-person bureau in Santa Fe was closing on Sept. 21 as part of shutdowns in the three states. Capps said the newspaper's account was ``essentially correct as far as it goes.'' He said UPI would not, however, be leaving the three states uncovered. ``We are expanding our stringer network in those states and exploring a number of joint ventures at the state and regional level,'' Capps said. Last month Capps confirmed a Washington Post report that 31 UPI reporters and editors were being laid off, but he declined Monday to provide an up-to-date account of how many have lost their jobs nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose strongly in European trading this morning, pushing through an important support level against the German mark. Gold prices were sharply lower. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 139.85 yen, 0.42 yen above Monday's finish. Later, in London, it was quoted at 140.32 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.5910 German marks, up from 1.5808 _1.3290 Swiss francs, up from 1.3197 _5.3300 French francs, up from 5.2985 _1.7844 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7822 _1,187.00 Italian lire, up from 1,180.50 _1.1670 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1703 In London, the British pound was quoted at 1.8430 dollars, compared with 1.8565 dollars late Monday. Traders in Milan, Italy, said the dollar's rise above 1.5900 marks was important but they doubted whether the U.S. currency had the underlying strength to move past 1.600 marks. Dealers added that uncertainty about the Gulf crisis had lately encouraged some dollar buying. Despite the U.S. currency's rise, ``people are still thinking the trend is to go lower,'' said Masato Hayashi of the Bank of Tokyo. In gold trading, London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $378.40 at midmorning, down from $384.75 Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $378.60, down from $387.00 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $4.90 an ounce today, to close at $379.66. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.74 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $4.78.

DOC.HEAD: Drizzle in Texas, Fog in South and Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Texas received drizzle early today, while fog was scattered throughout the South and Northeast. Skies were cloudy in the Midwest. Most of the East expected sunshine, low humidity and temperatures in the 80s today. Showers were possible in West Virginia and Florida. A band of thunderstorms was forming from Texas to Mississippi. The other Southern states looked for partly sunny skies and highs in the 90s. Thunderstorms were expected in Minnesota, and sunny skies were forecast for the rest of the country. Hail and thunderstorms caused minor damage and flooding in Arkansas on Monday night. Hail also fell in Oklahoma and Kansas. Temperatures in the 60s and 70s were expected for the Pacific Northwest, the 80s for the Midwest and central Rockies, and the 100s for the Southwest. Seventeen Western cities, 12 in Utah, reported record highs for the date Monday. The high for the nation was 117 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exile Pleads Guilty in Slaying of Former Chilean Diplomat
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 4th graf, ``Letelier had xxx to CORRECT spellin of Salvador
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban exile who had been a fugitive for 12 years has pleaded guilty to conspiring to murder former Chilean Ambassador Orlando Letelier by helping bomb the ex-diplomat's car. Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel, a member of the Cuban Nationalist Movement, admitted in federal court Monday that he gave a blasting cap to former Chilean intelligence agent Michael V. Townley, who pleaded guilty to building the bomb that killed Letelier and an associate on Sept. 21, 1976. Letelier, an outspoken critic of the right-wing military government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, and the associate, Ronni Moffitt, died after the bomb exploded beneath Letelier's car on Embassy Row. Letelier had been his country's ambassador to Washington from 1971 to 1973. He also served briefly as foreign minister in the leftist government of President Salvador Allende, who died in a bloody military coup that overthrew his government in 1973. Two top military officials, including the head of the Chilean intelligence agency, DINA, have been charged with participating in the murder. But the Chilean government, which returned to civilian control earlier this year, has refused to extradite the officials. Pinochet remains head of the Chilean army and military courts retain jurisdiction over the two officials, Gen. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda and retired Lt. Col. Pedro Espinoza Bravo, the former head of DINA. Under the deal approved by U.S. District Judge Aubrey E.
