Robinson Jr., Suarez, 51, who was arrested April 11 in St. Petersburg, Fla., cannot be sentenced to more than 12 years in prison even though the charge to which he pleaded guilty carries a maximum life sentence. Prosecutors also agreed not to prosecute his wife, Elizabeth Gongora Suarez, for concealing a fugitive from authorities. Suarez also admitted that he, Townley and others went to Letelier's residence two days before the bombing knowing that Townley was to place an explosive device on the former diplomat's car. Townley, an American-born DINA agent, pleaded guilty in 1978 to building the bomb and putting it beneath Letelier's car. He served a 40-month prison term and has cooperated with the government's investigation. Former Chilean army Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios defected in 1987 and pleaded guilty to being an accessory after the fact to the conspiracy. Fernandez implicated his superiors in DINA and Pinochet in the coverup of the Chilean military's involvement in the killing. Fernandez and Townley had been expected to testify against Suarez, who was scheduled to go to trial next week. The government agreed to drop four other charges against Suarez as part of the deal. Investigators believe that Suarez may have detonated the bomb with a remote electronics device from a car that he and Virgilio Paz Romero, still a fugitive, used to follow Letelier, said a source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Defense attorney Paul Goldberger said Suarez's primary motivation for pleading guilty was to help his wife avoid prosecution. ``He's got a wife and a baby,'' the lawyer said. If Suarez is sentenced to 12 years, he would be eligible for release after serving nine years of the prison term, Goldberger said. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said that Suarez would have been eligible for parole after 10 years even if he had received a life sentence. ``We believe this is a substantial disposition, given his relative degree of culpability,'' Stephens said. Washington lawyer E. Lawrence Barcella, who investigated the case as a federal prosecutor, praised the plea bargain. ``While I think they had a good case, and I think they would have prevailed, it would have been a very difficult effort given the passage of time and the vagaries of a jury,'' Barcella said. ``You simply can't tell what is going to happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostages Say Kuwait Terrorized by Iraqi Soldiers
With PM-Gulf-Desert Dynasties, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Another planeload of Western hostages arrived from Iraq, with evacuees from Kuwait telling of food shortages, nighttime gunfire and Iraqi roundups of young people suspected of involvement in the resistance. The flight arrived Monday from Baghdad via London with 164 evacuees, 90 of them children. ``There is no law and order,'' said Thuraya, who would not give her last name. ``A soldier can rape a father's daughter in front of him and he can't do anything about it. And that is what really is scary. You don't know if a soldier is going to crawl over your wall at 5 o'clock in the morning.'' Thuraya, 19, said people in their late teens and 20s are being rounded up under suspicion they are part of the resistance movement. Those who talked Monday at Baltimore-Washington International Airport did not want to be identified by their full names for fear of retaliation against their families in Kuwait. About 20 of the hostages were not U.S. citizens. One woman kissed the ground upon arriving. ``This is America, my home,'' said Diane, who is headed for Milford, Conn., where she has family. She brought along her 4-year-old son, but her Kuwaiti husband chose to stay behind. She said fresh food is nonexistent. People have been reduced to eating staples, such as rice, lentils, sugar and bread. At night there is gunfire between the resistance and Iraqi soldiers, Diane said. ``You can't leave the house,'' she said. ``The Iraqis are destroying everything.'' An exhausted Philadelphia woman, who was visiting her brother and was trapped by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, said Kuwait is a ``a ghost town.'' ``Everything is broken down. They (the Iraqis) stole everything. Supermarkets, there is no food,'' said Angel. Angel said Kuwaitis fear electricity and water will be shut off. They are waiting for the United States to take some action. Angel said she went into hiding for five weeks after the invasion. ``I could not even go to the window,'' she said. The evacuees were part of a group of 438 who arrived in London on Sunday night after a 6{-hour flight from Baghdad. Debbie Edelen Hadi, of Louisville, Ky., said she escaped Kuwait because U.S. Embassy officials there managed to smuggle her into a group of 170 women and children of various nationalities who left the country last week. She declined to provide more details of her escape ``because there are others that we're trying to get out and we don't want to jeopardize them.'' Rene Hariri, a native of Rossville, Ind., was among more than 300 U.S. evacuees who landed Sunday at Charleston, S.C. She gave birth Sept. 2 to a boy and left Kuwait with her other sons, ages 4 and 2, but left behind her husband. In Baghdad, Iraqi soldiers demanded travel documents for the newborn, and Hariri, 33, worried she'd be separated from her children. ``I guess I stupidly remained somehow confident that it really wasn't going to happen, and it didn't,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fined, Ordered to Work at Humane Society in Dog's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd graf, `Gary Rall...' to add comment; pickup 3rd graf pvs., `Witnesses said.
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of using a bow and arrow to kill a poodle he caught rooting through his trash was fined $2,000 and ordered to work 150 hours at the local Humane Society. Gary Rall, 42, also was placed on a year's probation Monday by Judge Howard M. Fender after pleading no contest to cruelty to animals. Fender specified that Rall not be allowed to put animals to sleep. ``This is intended to be instructive to him,'' Fender said. ``I don't want this to become a farce. I want to make sure he's not involved in any dog killing at the humane society.'' Witnesses said the postal worker shot the dog on March 12. The animal, named Taffey, limped back to its home, where its owners found it collapsed on the front porch, an arrow in its side. The dog died in surgery. ``I can't see anything positive by sending him to jail even though that's what we wanted at first,'' said the dog's owner, Tommy Davis. ``Nothing's going to bring Taffey back.'' Defense attorney William Harris said that Rall had received death threats and that someone placed a fake bomb in his mailbox over the incident. ``There's been a lot of cruelty visited on Mr. Rall as a result of this,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan's Dream of Walk Through Wall Takes Place Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan had a light schedule in Berlin today, a day before he is to fulfill a dream of walking through the now-crumbling Berlin Wall. Reagan, 79, and his wife Nancy arrived just after midnight Monday to start a 10-day trip through Germany, Poland, the Soviet Union and Italy. The Berliner Morgenpost daily greeted the Reagans with a story recounting his speech June 12, 1987, before the wall, where he challenged Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to ``open this gate ... tear down this wall.'' The wall now has been open since last November, when the Communists then ruling East Germany, in a desperate attempt to retain power, granted freedom of travel to its citizens. The Communists have lost all power, and the two Germanys are to unite into one country on Oct. 3. Reagan has a busy schedule Wednesday, when he is to walk through the landmark Brandenburg Gate in the former area of the wall and meet with democratically elected officials in East Berlin. He also is to give a speech Wednesday on the future of united Germany. On Thursday he travels to Bonn, the West German capital, to meet Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and on Friday he is to be given a ceremonial sendoff by U.S. military units at Tempelhof Airport in central Berlin as he departs for Warsaw. Reagan was resting today after the long flight from California, and had a dinner scheduled with Berlin community leaders in the evening.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rejects Prime Minister's Reform Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev presenting new plan, new quotes, background on prime ministers. Pickup 9th pvs, ``There is...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went before Parliament today and rejected the moderate economic plan his prime minister had just presented to the body, instead endorsing a more radical program. The stunning statement reflected dwindling confidence in Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and put Gorbachev closer to the position of radical reformers such as Boris N. Yeltsin. Yeltsin, the Russian republic president, asked the republic's parliament last week to approve a radical reform plan drafted by Stanislav Shatalin, a Gorbachev aide. Shatalin's plan would transfer enormous authority from Parliament to the legislatures of the republics, which would then have the power to scrap centralized economic planning, introduce market mechanisms and legalize private property. Gorbachev rejected Ryzhkov's plan but said elements of it would be combined with Shatalin's plan. He said the Shatalin program appeals more to him because it integrates ``the ideas of constituent republics.'' ``If there is a real plan to stabilize finances, money circulation, the ruble and the market, then we should adopt the Shatalin idea,'' Gorbachev said. ``We should try and work out a single document, and we are nearing it.'' Gorbachev's remarks were reported by the state news agency Tass. He has avoided explicitly expressing a lack of confidence in Ryzhkov, a close ally, but his statements sparked new speculation that Ryzhkov would step down soon. Gorbachev said he would present a plan on Wednesday that would be very close to the more radical plan proposed earlier by Yeltsin. A commission with members appointed by the two men has been trying to draft a common document for several weeks. Ryzhkov's speech drew fire from lawmakers in the national legislature, and Gorbachev responded with a warning against ``shaking up all the political institutions in the country,'' Tass said. ``This is unacceptable. In this case, we shall bury everything we have achieved over these five years,'' said Gorbachev, who became general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party in 1985. No prime minister in 73 years of Soviet history has been forced to resign because parliament refused to endorse his program. However, the Communist Party leader traditionally has been able to force the retirement of the head of government. Several Russian parliamentarians rose to urge the body to call for Ryzhkov to step down, but Yeltsin urged caution and stressed first the adoption of the Shatalin plan by the legisatures of the national and the republic governments. Ryzhkov's proposal today differed little from one tossed back at him for reworking last spring. ``There is no principal difference. It's centralized leadership, centralized prices, it's not possible to sell land,'' said Estonian economist and legislator Siim Kallas. Leningrad mayor and national legislator Anatoly Sobchak on Monday called for a vote of no-confidence in Ryzhkov, charging he was unable to offer a realistic solution to the country's economic crisis. The impasse increases the forces pulling the Soviet Union apart, with 13 of the 15 republics already pressing for independence or sovereignty. Shatalin said he expected his plan to be approved by the Russian parliament. Since Russia is the largest republic by far, with three quarters of the Soviet Union's land and half its population, conflicting decisions by the Russian and Soviet governments would be impossible to ignore. Shatalin, in an interview with the Interfax news agency, said the central government would not support his plan because it would undercut Kremlin power. ``There has never been a government in the entire world that would voluntarily give up power and land,'' he said. The plan also calls for superiority of republics' laws over national ones. Ryzkhov sharply criticized the Shatalin plan, saying it would lower the living standard by 30 percent and force one of every four collective farms into bankruptcy. He said only 25 percent of basic consumer products would remain price-controlled under the Shatalin plan. Soviet studies have found that less than 10 percent of 2,000 everyday products are readily available in stores. The Ryzhkov plan called for a much slower transition to a market economy. The latest version drops a controversial proposal to double and triple the price of food, but retains drastic price increases set for Jan. 1 for expensive consumer goods like televisions, radios and refrigerators. Ryzkkov said the economic situation was worsening rapidly. He said Western banks were growing reluctant to lend more hard currency to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Brush Fire Damages Five Homes Near San Diego
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The fire...', to add how shooting can lead to fire.
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters working in rugged terrain today battled a brush fire, apparently started by target shooters, that damaged five million-dollar homes and forced the evacuation of about 175 people. Aided by parched undergrowth and stiff coastal winds, the blaze had charred more than 2,640 acres and was 35 percent contained by early today, the California Department of Forestry reported. The fire, which began about noon Monday, is believed to have been started by target shooters at an illegal shooting site off a back road, said department spokeswoman Audrey Hagen. A fire can start when a bullet hits a rock and sets off a spark that ignites dry brush, the department said. It quickly burned across canyons and hillsides about 30 miles north of downtown San Diego, forcing overnight evacuations of homes south of Escondido. Volunteers brought trailers to help evacuate about 50 horses and other animals. ``I have never seen a fire going down a hill so fast,'' Ruth Preston said as she watched firefighters protecting her hilltop home. ``They told us they didn't think the fire would reach us, that we didn't have anything to worry about, but then the fire chief told us there was a wall of fire coming up and we that we had to get out of there.'' Forestry Department spokeswoman Carol Stein said the blaze still threatened barns, sheds and maybe some homes, but officials estimated the fire would be contained by evening and residents were expected to be allowed back today. More than 600 firefighters on the ground, including inmates, set back fires and bulldozed fire breaks to prevent the blaze from reaching more populated areas and Interstate 15. Three helicopters and six air tankers dropped water and retardant until the aircraft were grounded for the night. ``The difficulties of fighting this were the terrain was extremely steep and inaccessible and it had very heavy fuel,'' firefighter Chris Fall said. ``This particular area had not burned in 20 or 30 years and the brush was 6 feet thick.'' Four homes sustained scorched roofs or other minor damage, and the roof of a fifth home collapsed, Stein said. Three vehicles also were burned. The lone reported injury was to a firefighter, who suffered a knee injury, officials said. Trish Demopoulos, who also had to flee her hilltop home, said, ``Living in this area, we know there's always fire hazards, but you think it will happen to everybody else, not you. This brings it pretty close to reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Restaurants, Theaters Say: Leave Those Phones At The Door
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fredd cq 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Got a cellular phone, dude? Better check it in at the counter. Theaters, restaurants and other businesses are increasingly banning the portable phones, as customers complain of the impolite user. ``They say they need them. Suddenly everyone's a doctor,'' said manager Fredd Selgas of the Coconut Grove Playhouse, where patrons are urged to check their phones at the door. Complaints about people taking calls in the middle of movies led to a ban on the phones at all 18 Florida theaters owned by Wometco. ``Let's face it,'' said Wometco general manager John Wray. ``You're in the middle of a tense love scene and someone's phone rings, and a guy says, `Hi, sweetheart. How're you doing?' ``We feel that it's a disturbing effect to the patrons and, as a courtesy, they should not bring their phones in.'' With the use of cellular phones increasing, cities may take legislative action. In the Florida Statehouse, the phones are banned from Senate and House floors, as well as in the public galleries above. People who do not carry cellular phones don't like them in public places, said Sheldon Brown, a manager at BellSouth Mobility. But people who carry them disagree. ``If your livelihood depends on that telephone, and that's how you support your family, understandably you want to take that phone with you everywhere you go,'' said BellSouth marketing director Leslie Girolamo. But dealing with them is another matter, and the problem in the future could get out of hand. ``It could be like smoking _ they'll have a phone section and a non-phone section,'' said Alfonso Blanco, manager of a cellular phone store.

DOC.HEAD: Father Who Set Boy on Fire is Back in Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to add detail, UPDATE with prosecutor's comment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man sent to prison for setting fire to his son in 1983 is back behind bars today on charges of violating his parole, authorities said. Charles Rothenberg, 50, allegedly slipped away from a parole agent who had been following him Monday morning. He was in San Quentin Prison by dinner. He will receive a hearing within 60 days on the alleged violation and could get up to year in prison, said Corrections Department spokesman Tipton Kindel. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder for pouring kerosene over his son, David, and setting him afire in a Buena Park motel room during a dispute with his estranged wife in New York. The boy, then 6, was rescued by motel guests but was burned over 90 percent of his body. He was severely disfigured. Rothenberg served six years and five months of his 13-year sentence before being released on three years' parole in January. The same conviction today could bring a life sentence. The parolee, who described himself as ``the most-watched man in America'' after he left prison, always had at least one parole officer watching him. He had been living in Alameda County; the exact location was not revealed. California officials called the parole the most restrictive in state history and said it costs taxpayers $18,000 a month. Besides the 24-hour-a-day surveillance, it also includes strict rules on travel, weekly psychiatric counseling and other requirements. On Monday, Rothenberg went into an doughnut shop and apparently snuck out through a window or back door, Kindel said. Rothenberg telephoned another agent to say he would go to a scheduled job interview. He was taken into custody when he arrived there. ``He's always been under surveillance and he knows that. It's part of the program,'' Kindel said. ``Up to this point, he'd been doing what he was supposed to do. He'd been abiding by the rules, keeping a low profile and trying to obtain employment.'' Rothenberg's prosecutor wasn't surprised to see him back in prison. ``It was predictable with Rothenberg,'' Orange County Deputy District Attorney Tom Avdeef said. ``It was my feeling that he wouldn't make parole, that he would violate it in some fashion because of his background.'' David Rothenberg, who lives with his mother and stepfather in Orange County, said just before his father was paroled that he kept a BB gun by his bed. ``I'd shoot his eye out if he ever came over. I'd blind him,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Explodes, Killing Moslem Militants
DOC.TEXT: Twenty Moslem militants were killed when their bus exploded during a shoot-out with a government patrol on a lonely country road in northern India today, official sources said. One paramilitary policeman also died, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. When news of the deaths reached Srinagar at midday, shopkeepers in the downtown area _ a center of the Moslem separatist movement _ closed in protest, blaming the government for the killings. There were no immediate statements from the Moslem groups that have been waging a violent campaign for independence from predominantly Hindu India. The military sources said a patrol party encountered the bus at 3 a.m. near Thune, about 30 miles northeast of Srinagar, 400 miles northwest of New Delhi. A constable ordered the bus to halt because it was violating a curfew that is supposed to keep all private vehicles off the roads in Kashmir after dark, the sources said. Gunmen inside the bus opened fire, killing Singh instantly, and the rest of the patrol party returned fire, the sources said. They said the bus exploded because it was loaded with ammunition and hand grenades. Sixteen bodies were recovered from the bus and four other militants were gunned down by the patrol when they jumped from the burning bus, the sources said. They said there were no survivors. Meanwhile, at the other end of Jammu-Kashmir state, thousands of Hindus demonstrated against the Moslem secessionist movement. The protesters boarded buses to leave Jammu town for Srinagar late this afternoon, but state officials said they would not be allowed to complete their journey. A bomb blew up the railroad tracks near Jammu this morning just 15 minutes before the scheduled arrival of a train carrying top leaders of the protest, officials said. There were no injuries, state officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The train, which normally carries about 1,500 people, was late. When the bomb exploded, the high-speed express was sitting at a station 12 miles to the south, the officials said. They said they did not know who was responsible for the explosion, which was heard more than two miles away. Members of the Hindu group, in telephone calls to news offices in Jammu and New Delhi, blamed Kashmiri Moslem militants who are fighting to secede from predominantly Hindu India. About 1,200 people have been killed in Kashmir, the Moslem-dominated part of Jammu-Kashmir state, since last January when the government started its heaviest crackdown to date on the secessionists. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, making it the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Most of the Hindus, who comprise 32 percent of the state's population, live in the Jammu region. Nationwide, 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus while Moslems account for 12 percent.

DOC.SECOND: Kent State University Recalls Catalog With Klansmen on Cover
DOC.TEXT: Kent State University has recalled 4,000 mailed catalogs and will destroy 16,000 others because the cover features hooded Ku Klux Klan members. Beneath the hooded and robed Klansmen the cover of the catalog, listing books being published by the university press, bears the message, ``Kent State University Press Celebrating 25 Years of Excellence.'' The fall catalog never mentions that its cover is a duplicate of one of its offerings, ``The Steel Valley Klan _ The KKK in Ohio's Mahoning Valley,'' a book by Youngstown State University professor William D. Jenkins. The Kent State University Press publishes scholarly works and its catalog is sent to other colleges and universities around the nation. Its catalog cover traditionally features a cover from one of its books. ``The picture on the book makes sense because it's in the proper context,'' Kent State University president Michael Schwartz said. ``However, the picture is totally inappropriate on the catalog cover,'' he said. ``I certainly apologize to anyone who was offended. I know I certainly was. KSU has always made multicultural awareness a top priority.''

DOC.HEAD: Police In Gainesville Sifting Through 500 Clues, Using DNA Tests
DOC.TEXT: Authorities say more than 500 pieces of evidence collected in the killings of five college students mostly involve a single suspect, and genetic testing is under way on blood and semen. Steve Platt, head of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement's Jacksonville crime lab, indicated Monday that police were investigating whether the slayings involved sexual assault. He refused to say whether the blood and semen were taken from the crime scenes or from 18-year-old Edward Lewis Humphrey. Humphrey is one of eight suspects but ``he's the one we've received the most information about,'' Gainesville police spokeswoman Sadie Darnell said. ``I think that's why early on, he's become the focus _ rightly or wrongly _ we still don't know yet.'' Only about half the evidence has been processed at the crime lab, where 17 technicians are working full time on the case, Platt said. ``It's a slow, painstaking effort,'' he said. Genetic testing is a technique first used in courtrooms in 1986 to identify people by using deoxyribonucleic acid, the unique DNA code everyone has duplicated in their body tissue, bone, hair roots and various bodily fluids. A congressional study last month found that it is reliable courtroom evidence if proper standards are followed in the tricky lab tests done to match DNA taken from a person or a crime scene. ``We're not going to let time dictate this investigation,'' said Lt. Spencer Mann, spokesman for the Alachua County sheriff's department. ``We have to be right. We can't guess. We can't take chances.'' Police repeated warnings that the killer may still be on the loose, and said no arrests are imminent. Humphrey remains jailed on $1.1 million bond in the Aug. 30 beating of his grandmother, an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County, and an Aug. 25 assault on two male University of Florida students. Investigators have said a shrewd and methodical killer late last month stabbed four young women and one young man who were students in this college town. The killer reportedly arranged body parts at the slaying scene for maximum shock value. At the students' apartments, investigators finished their searches over the weekend and landlords were preparing to find new tenants. ``We'll renovate and then we'll rent it out,'' said Carol Hyde, manager of the Gatorwood Apartments, where the bodies of Manny Taboada and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found Aug. 28. ``There's still blood on the walls.'' Ms. Hyde said she would tell prospective tenants about the gruesome murders. But Johanna Yarborough, manager of the apartments where the mutilated nude bodies of Christina Powell, 17, and Sonya Larson, 18, were found Aug. 26, said: ``If somebody asks, I'll tell them, but it's not like I'm going to say, `Oh, by the way, two girls were murdered here.''' Monday also marked the last day students could drop classes. Administrators calculated 500 left the university as a result of the killings, but interim registrar Steve Pritz said some students regretted their decision and want to come back for spring semester.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Students, Monks Stoned Police During Burma Rally
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 protesters including students and Buddhist monks destroyed a fire station in central Burma, then stoned security personnel, injuring 11 of them, a military official said today. Two monks were arrested after the clash in Mandalay on Monday, Col. Than Tun, deputy chief of military intelligence, told a news conference. Mandalay, about 350 miles north of Rangoon, is the country's second-largest city. Than Tun said six soldiers and five policemen were injured while dispersing the crowd. Some demonstrators used stones and slingshots against the security forces, he said. At the same news conference, the chief of military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, warned people and political parties against confronting the authorities. Anti-government unrest has grown in recent months after the military government's refusal to hand over power to the pro-democracy party that won the May 27 general election. The poll was Burma's first free vote in 30 years. The National League for Democracy took 392 of the 485 contested parliamentary seats, but the government has given no indication when it will convene the new Parliament and step down. Mandalay has been the scene of much of the recent unrest. It was a major focus of the 1988 pro-democracy uprising, which the military crushed when it seized power in September that year. On Aug. 8, two monks and two students were killed during a demonstration in Mandalay, according to Western diplomats in Rangoon. Days earlier, a student was reportedly bayoneted in the face by a soldier. The government has denied the reports. On Friday, the government announced the arrest of six leaders of the National League for Democracy, including its acting leader, Kyi Maung, and his deputy, Chit Khaing. Arrested with them were four senior league leaders from Mandalay accused of inciting the August protests. The two main leaders of the league, Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo, were placed under house arrest in July 1989. At today's news conference, government spokesman Col. Ye Htut said the administration planned to consult with the political parties and convene a national conference to seek opinions on the drafting of a new constitution. The government has said a new constitution must be approved before a new administration is formed. Western diplomats say this a delaying tactic, since it could take years to draw up a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush: Saddam Should Consider Children
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 17th graf, bgng, ``I think... to restore dropped word `of'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says if Saddam Hussein is concerned about Iraq's children, he should pull his troops out of Kuwait and end the crisis threatening to plunge the region in war. Asked Monday what she would tell the Iraqi president if she had the chance, the first lady said, ``I'd rather send a message to our soldiers and tell them we want them home and that we're doing everything we can for peace.'' Hussein has charged that the United Nations embargo is jeopardizing the lives of children in his country and throughout the region. ``That's not what's killing the children of Kuwait or Iraq or Egypt or anyplace else,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``He went into a country and attacked it. We can't forget that.'' In a voice fraught with emotion, she said in an interview, ``I hope he'll take into consideration these children.'' Mrs. Bush said the Persian Gulf situation is the worst crisis her husband has faced in his 20 months in office, but he was bearing it well. ``I don't think it's ever off his mind, but does he dwell on it? No,'' she said. ``He does what he can. He's got a wonderful, wonderful disposition.'' She said she was not at all bothered by criticism of Bush's proceeding with his Maine vacation while American servicemen were being dispatched to the Saudi Arabia ``because I knew he was working.'' Mrs. Bush said she has not been offering the president advice on the gulf crisis. ``I think wives in my case, under our system, do very well to aid and comfort their husband and keep trying to make life as peaceful as you can at home _ not needle, not give suggestions,'' she said. She charged that her son, Neil, has been singled out for scrutiny in the Silverado savings and loan scandal only because he is the president's son. ``It's darn unfair that they're only doing it to hurt George Bush ... and they have succeeded,'' she said. Their 35-year-old son is a former outside director of the Denver thrift, which collapsed, costing taxpayers $1 billion. Mrs. Bush revealed that Millie, her 3-year-old English springer spaniel which had been hobbling earlier this year, has lupus but ``she's in complete remission.'' Millie's rambunctious pup Ranger has taken up permanent residence in the White House, having outgrown the suburban yard of son Marvin Bush and family. ``Millie has not been supplanted,'' insisted Mrs. Bush, patting the dog throughout the interview. The dog is the star of a new as-told-to ``autobiography'' about life in the White House. Mrs. Bush, the ghost writer, is devoting the royalties from ``Millie's Book'' to her literacy foundation, which just last week awarded $500,000 in grants. ``I think it's very easy reading,'' she said of the $17.95 hard cover book, replete with scores of pictures of Millie with her pups, the president, Britain's Queen Elizabeth II and other VIPs. Asked if she expected Bush to seek re-election in 1992, the first lady said, ``I don't doubt that he'll run again. But if he didn't, I certainly wouldn't be surprised _ nor would I be frightfully disappointed. ``Twelve years is a long time,'' she said, counting his eight years as vice president and four as president. She added with a laugh, ``I'm sort of looking forward to seeing if I know how to tie my own shoelaces anymore.'' But when they do leave the White House, ``we will miss that jumbo jet,'' she said, referring admiringly to the spacious new $133 million Boeing 747 put into service last week as Air Force One. ``I haven't seen anything like it.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Increases Chemical Decontamination Training
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Pentagon coverage rules prohibit the disclosure of exact locations of military deployments or of troop numbers.

The U.S. military is training more personnel to work in chemical decontamination wards at field hospitals, which would likely be overwhelmed if Iraq were to unleash a major poison gas attack. The training, taking place in at least one major U.S. base camp in Saudi Arabia, comes as doctors and others who work in the decontamination units question their ability to handle a steady patient load over a lengthy period. Americans also are training Saudis in how to decontaminate people who come in contact with chemicals. At one base, such training is being conducted every other day with groups of 10 to 12 Saudis from military medical facilities. ``Even though Iraq is their neighbor and has had these chemical weapons for years the Saudis were really unprepared,'' one Air Force officer involved in the training said. Most commanders discount the likelihood of any Iraqi attack and have expressed confidence that their forces could intercept any missiles or planes carrying chemical weapons into Saudi territory. But as a precaution, the United States has set up a series of field hospitals, each with a separate area for decontaminating troops who come under chemical attack. Iraq has a large stock of chemical and nerve agents, Western intelligence sources have said. Saddam Hussein boasted in April that Iraq has developed binary weapons, warheads or shells in which two chemical agents are housed in separate compartments. These mingle on impact to form deadly gases. The Iraqis used chemical weapons _ mainly mustard gas and blister agents _ against Iranian troops during their eight-year war, which ended in cease-fire in 1988. These did not prove especially effective. Western analysts believe that in military terms, the casualties were low _ less than 300 killed and possibly 20,000 injured. However, the gas attacks had a considerable impact on Iranian morale, forcing infantrymen to wear the heavy protective suits and gas masks and thus reducing their fighting efficiency by about one-third. Most of the U.S. field hospitals in Saudi Arabia have permanent staffs of about 20 people, with a goal of treating 30 casualties an hour provided two- thirds of the patients are walk-ins. ``It's a bit optimistic in this weather,'' Capt. James T. Walker, an Air Force doctor in charge of one of the field units, said of the treatment targets. Walker said the units likely would need additional personnel in the event of heavy casualties because the treatment staff would have to work in bulky, protective clothing and wear gas masks, a problem in the sweltering Saudi temperatures. ``We will need to rotate people because it's quite strenuous,'' he said. The facility Walker runs is training additional people from the base's combat support group. A similar facility at another large American installation already has added 19 people to its regular staff of 15, and has contingency plans to draw more help from that base's support group if necessary. ``It's going to be hard but I think it can be done,'' Air Force Sgt. Keith Tucker, who runs that unit, said Monday when asked if his staff could meet the treatment goals. He said it would not be difficult to train additional help quickly: ``Anything that we do here can be taught to anybody.'' In most cases, soldiers who come into contact with chemical agents would be hosed down, then have their protective suits stripped or cut off. If the agents had seeped through to their inside uniforms, those too would be removed and any exposed skin treated, Tucker said. The British have provided the U.S. forces with scanners that detect most chemical agents, and those would be used to scan patients before they are sent to the field hospital for treatment of other injuries. The decontamination tents are not air-conditioned, although some can be equipped with cooling systems. Walker and Tucker said it can get stifling hot inside the tents when they are filled with staff and patients. But Col. P.J. Pettijohn, the commander of Air Force personnel at one large U.S. base camp, said it was unlikely the tents would be air-conditioned because most chemical agents break down faster in heat. ``Heat is not necessarily an enemy in this case,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Drug Agent's Wife Pleads Guilty To Income Tax Charge
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a former Drug Enforcement Administration agent accused of selling confiscated narcotics pleaded guilty to failure to file an income tax return under a plea bargain. Barbara Jackson, 42, of Claremont entered her plea before U.S. District Judge Terry J. Hatter Jr. on Monday. Mrs. Jackson originally faced eight criminal counts, including money laundering and tax evasion. Under the agreement with prosecutors, she pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor for failing to report about $28,000 in income for 1987. Her husband, former DEA agent John Jackson, 41, pleaded guilty last month to stealing cocaine and heroin from the agency's evidence vault in Los Angeles, drug trafficking and money laundering. He had originally been charged with 16 counts. Both are awaiting sentencing; Mrs. Jackson could receive up to a year in jail and a $25,000 fine, Jackson up to 45 years in prison and fines of more than $4.5 million. The Jacksons were among five people indicted by a federal grand jury in 1988. Another former DEA agent, Wayne Countryman, 47, of Walnut, has pleaded guilty to narcotics conspiracy and tax evasion. A third, Darnell Garcia, 43, of Rancho Palos Verdes, faces trial Oct. 9 on six counts, including drug trafficking. The three former agents were accused of taking confiscated drugs and selling them to drug dealers. A fifth person, Sherman Lair, 40, of Alta Loma, has pleaded guilty to participating in a narcotics conspiracy. He was a Jackson business associate.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Fighting Reported in Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with heavy fighting in capital, interim government saying it is sending envoys.
DOC.TEXT: Troops of the dead President Samuel Doe bombarded rebels in Monrovia with shells today in a desperate stand from the roof of the fortified presidential mansion. An interim government named Aug. 30 in Gambia by a unity conference said it was sending envoys to Monrovia in preparation for taking over the country. But rival rebel forces control various sectors of the country, and Charles Taylor's mainstream rebel National Patriotic Front pledged Monday to keep fighting until a 3,000-strong West African task force sent to end the war withdraws from the capital. Doe died after being wounded in fighting with a breakaway rebel faction that captured him Sunday. The U.S. State Department confirmed Doe was dead. The British Broadcasting Corp. quoted witnesses who visited a rebel camp near Monrovia as saying Doe's mutilated body was on display there. They did not say how he died but that they watched rebel leader Prince Johnson interrogate Doe about the disappearance of millions of dollars of state funds during his 10-year rule. Shells exploded and gunfire crackled in the ravaged capital today as Johnson's fighters searched the city for Doe loyalists. Doe's elite presidential guard, which includes the feared Israeli-trained Special Anti-Terrorist Unit, turned heavy artillery on the roof of the multistory executive mansion on the rebels. West African soldiers sent to end the 8{ months of fighting were ordered to intervene. The chairman of the Economic Community of West African States said he told the force to protect loyalists and family members of Doe who remained in the clifftop presidential residence. ``I think it is now urgent to try and do something about protecting these 230 or so Doe supporters from factional or tribal revenge,'' the chairman, Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara, said in Harare, Zimbabwe. Johnson said Monday he would lead Liberia until the transitional government is set up. But representatives of the government can expect a hostile reception from Taylor, whose 10,000-strong rebel army is the biggest in the country. He has called the interim government a ``puppet'' administration of the West African economic group. A statement issued today in Banjul, Gambia, by the government's president, Amos Sawyer, said the delegation's first priority would be to distribute relief supplies and food in the capital, where people are dying of starvation. Sources close to Sawyer said he was urged to send envoys by Johnson and Brig. Gen. David Nimley, whom Doe loyalists named acting president shortly after his capture. Liberia has been without effective government for months, and Monrovia has been torn by fighting involving the two rebel armies and Doe loyalists since mid-July. Taylor said Monday his movement would ``intensify its efforts to bring this crisis to an end by moving into Monrovia at any expense.'' He spoke in a broadcast over the state radio, which is behind his lines. He has made similar threats before, but his army of mainly untrained peasant youths, who have overrun most of Liberia, has been bogged down on Monrovia's outskirts for nearly three months. Some of the heaviest fighting has occurred since the West African task force sailed in Aug. 14 to try to enforce a cease-fire. Taylor started the war when he invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Johnson, who was one of Taylor's top commanders, quarreled with him in March and formed a splinter group. The three warring factions have slaughtered more than 5,000 of this country's 2.3 million people, often because of their tribal affiliations. Half a million Liberians have fled to neighboring states or are displaced within their country. Doe was a Krahn, one of 14 small tribes in Liberia. Johnson is the son of a Gio, and Taylor is of mixed Americo-Liberian and native ancestry. About 2,100 U.S. Marines are based on ships off Monrovia and assigned to guard the U.S. Embassy and residential compound. They have evacuated hundreds of foreigners from the city but have orders not to intervene in the war.

DOC.HEAD: Hydrochloric Acid Leaks At Chemical Plant
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 gallons of hydrochloric acid leaked at a chemical plant today, forcing an evacuation of about 150 people. The leak in a plastic pipe at the Midwest Ralumac plant was reported about 1:45 a.m. and plugged about 4 a.m., fire officials said. No serious injuries were reported, and a cloud caused by the spill dissipated late in the morning. A hazardous-materials team used a snow blower to spread about 15,000 pounds of soda ash to soak up the corrosive chemical, fire Battlion Chief Randall Higgins said. Police Sgt. August Sims said the evacuees were mostly plant workers in the industrial area on the city's southeast side. Fewer than 30 were local residents, he said. The Midwest Ralumac plant and at least one other were closed for the day. Higgins said the cause of the leak was under investigation. The plant makes asphalt emulsifier.

DOC.HEAD: Carrying Guns To Hunt Could Put Impeached Judge Back in Prison
DOC.TEXT: Federal parole officers are recommending that former U.S. District Judge Walter L. Nixon, who was impeached and removed from office, be sent back to prison for carrying guns on a turkey hunt. Herb Lepchenske, one of two officers who conducted a parole revocation hearing Monday, said he will recommend Nixon serve 10 months of the remaining three years of his five-year sentence. Nixon, 61, was paroled in November 1989 on a conviction of lying to a federal grand jury. The seven-member Parole Commission in Atlanta will review the recommendation, and could give Nixon as little as a reprimand or as much as the full remaining three years of the sentence. At the hearing, Nixon said he was carrying guns in cases when he was arrested April 25 for hunting wild turkey over a baited field. Nixon, who is appealing his conviction on that state offense, testified he had changed his mind about hunting that day and never took the guns out. Chester Diaz, a state Department of Wildlife investigator, testified that Nixon asked him to pretend he wasn't carrying a rifle and a shotgun. Nixon knew the guns he had were illegal for a felon and asked if he could switch them for an old-fashioned muzzleloader, Diaz said. ``I told him `No, sir,''' said Diaz. ``I'm very, very remorseful for what I've done,'' Nixon said Monday. ``I haven't slept much since this happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Give $2 Billion to Three Persian Gulf Nations
DOC.TEXT: Japan, chided for moving slowly to aid the international campaign against Iraq, is considering giving $2 billion to the three nations hit hardest by the economic sanctions on Iraq, an official said today. The aid would go to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, said Hiroyasu Horio, an official with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. He would not elaborate. Local news reports said the aid would be extended through the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, and $600 million would be sent as early as mid-September. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said figures were not decided, but the government was moving to set them quickly. On Friday, U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady visited Tokyo on a world tour seeking $10.5 billion to help the three nations withstand the U.N.-imposed economic embargo on Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Japan has already promised a $1 billion aid package for multinational peacekeeping forces in Saudi Arabia, including food, water, vehicles and prefabricated housing for non-military uses. But critics in the United States have complained that Japan should do more since its economy depends heavily on oil from the Middle East. Japan imports 99 percent of its oil. ``I hope that when the total shape of our contribution is clearly shown, this kind of criticism will be greatly reduced,'' Watanabe said at a news briefing. ``Some of them (criticisms) are based on a lack of knowledge about what we are doing and some of them are affected by previously held perceptions of Japan.'' Japan's constitution bans the use of force in settling international disputes and Japanese law restricts the military to Japanese territory, except for participation in ceremonial occasions overseas. But Horio said the trade ministry is considering chartering foreign airplanes to send provisions ``as soon as possible'' for the multinational forces, possibly next week. ``The pressure from abroad is getting so strong,'' Horio said. Citing the constitution, Japanese airlines and unions have demanded the government limit items they carry to non-military goods, and refused to fly over dangerous areas. When Japan last week sent a Panamanian ship loaded with 800 vehicles and other equipment for the international peacekeeping effort in the Middle East, its departure was held up for hours by negotiations with a seamen's union that had refused to enter the troubled region. Horio said the government plans to send more vehicles, 2,000 trucks and 100 buses for the gulf forces. But he refused to provide details or the date of departure ``to eliminate unnecessary trouble before the departure.'' Kyodo News Service, quoting unnamed sources, said the government is considering sending military personnel overseas by temporarily transferring them to a new ``peace cooperation team'' to support United Nations activities. Watanabe said nothing has been decided on that yet, but the government hoped to have legislation ready by the end of this month for presentation to Parliament. ``What we have determined is we should come up with a decision to change the law so that we can send some people in addition to money in this kind of juncture,'' he said. They might not be from the defense forces, he said. Japan already has said it will send 100 medical personnel to help the international forces in the Gulf. Watanabe said the first group of 20 may be announced before the end of the week. He said that because of legal problems with sending personnel abroad in such cases, ``we cannot fully establish ourselves as a kind of initiator of (world) policy as we wish.''

DOC.HEAD: Lt. Gov. Quits Governor's Race After Palace Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Dukakis had...', to CORRECT that Dukakis left Thursday not Friday. SUBS 13th graf, `Murphy said...' to add that Murphy's name still will be on ballot.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy walked the plank and dropped out of the governor's race after staging a mutiny the minute Gov. Michael Dukakis left her at the helm to take part in a trade mission to Europe. Murphy quit the race Monday, days after she ordered cuts in state spending in Dukakis' absence _ and against his orders. Her maneuver was blasted as a desperate stunt to rescue her bid for the Democratic nomination. But she denied those accusations and said she was simply looking out for the state while Dukakis was away. ``Now there can be no confusion,'' she said Monday in dropping out. ``This is not a political ploy. It is an honest and necessary act of leadership.'' Her campaign said the main reason for her withdrawal was that she could not win. Campaign strategist Michael Goldman said weekend surveys showed her support growing, but not enough to land her the nomination in the three-way primary Sept. 18. However, a poll released Sunday by The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV said her unfavorable rating rose from 38 percent to 49 percent. On Friday, Murphy unveiled plans she said would save the state up to $150 million and help overcome a deficit. She issued executive orders to fire an estimated 1,000 workers and cut salaries for others. She also asked agencies to cut their 1992 budgets 10 percent. ``Today it is even more clear to me that these disputes are necessary,'' she said Monday. ``It is also clear that the political dispute about my decisions is diverting attention away from the very serious problems that made them necessary.'' Dukakis had postponed his trip for five days waiting for Murphy to unveil her fiscal plans. He finally left on Thursday with a warning not to take any drastic action. In a statement released in Boston on Monday, he was conciliatory. ``I know something about disappointment in politics,'' he said. ``Evelyn Murphy ran a strong and progressive campaign and she put her heart into it.'' Dukakis is scheduled to return Friday. Murphy said she would help former Attorney General Francis Bellotti, who leads in the polls for governor. However, some Murphy backers could still vote for her because she left the race far too late to have her name removed from the ballot. Bellotti predicted he would gain from her withdrawal because ``many of the people who were with Evelyn Murphy are people who would normally be with me.'' John Silber, the other Democratic candidate, countered, ``Her endorsement of Frank Bellotti means Frank Bellotti has precisely one vote more than he had before.'' Silber, on leave as Boston University president, has staked out conservative Democrats and independent voters. Murphy, who strongly backed Dukakis in his presidential bid in 1988, admitted he could undo her orders. On Monday she reviewed those plans with Finance Secretary L. Edward Lashman, who said the projected savings were highly inflated.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Rejects Plea for Marcos' Remains to be Returned for Burial
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino refused today, the birthday of her ousted predecessor, Ferdinand Marcos, to allow his remains to be buried in the Philippines. Meanwhile, a bomb exploded at a parking lot inside the suburban Philippine army headquarters, but no one was injured, army spokesman Col. Benjamin Enrile said. There were no suspects, he said. It was the 20th explosion in the capital since Aug. 13. Police believe most bombings were carried out by right-wing extremists. About 1,000 of Marcos' supporters marked his 73rd birthday by marching through through Manila's streets. Marcos' widow, Imelda, appealed to Mrs. Aquino on Monday to allow her to bring home her husband's remains from Hawaii. Marcos died there last Sept. 28. ``(The return of Marcos) has to await a more propitious time,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement read by Press Secretary Tomas Gomez. ``Prudence dictates that additional occasions for debilitating and distracting activities be avoided.'' Marcos was ousted in February 1986 and driven into exile by a popular revolution. Mrs. Aquino consistently refused to let him return, citing security concerns, and she continues to bar Mrs. Marcos from the Philippines. After a Roman Catholic Mass today for Marcos, House of Representatives minority leader Rodolfo Albano read a statement praising the achievements of the former leader. Albano said Marcos was a ``good man judged at a wrong time by the wrong minds,'' apparently referring to Mrs. Aquino's government. ``Everyone has human faults, for who has none?'' the statement added. ``It is said that when a man is gone, only his misdeeds are often remembered, no matter how few, forgetting all his good deeds.'' The statement also appeared as a full-page advertisement in several Manila newspapers. Among those who attended the Mass were some former members of Marcos' Cabinet, several congressmen and retired generals. Mrs. Marcos said Monday in Honolulu that she was would do ``everything to support'' Mrs. Aquino and begged her to reconsider her ban. Mrs. Aquino replied: ``Sincerity is subject to proof.'' She said she would make no deals with Mrs. Marcos until the former first lady returns money allegedly taken from the Philippines. The Aquino government has accused the Marcoses of stealing up to $10 billion during 20 years in power. The Marcoses face 35 civil suits in the Philippines. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted in the United States of racketeering charges. Marcos died before he could be arraigned.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop of Canterbury: No Shortcuts to Hostages' Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The Archbishop of Canterbury said today there were signs of progress in efforts to free his envoy, Terry Waite, and other Western hostages in Lebanon. The Most Rev. Robert Runcie, however, said he did not plan to travel to Lebanon to try to speed any release. Runcie was speaking a day after released Irish hostage Brian Keenan said Waite was ``definitely alive'' and the European Community announced plans to normalize relations with Tehran. Iran has helped to negotiate the release of several Western hostages. Waite's cousin, John Waite, had suggested that Runcie was ``the obvious choice'' to travel to the Middle East to seek freedom for the remaining 13 Western hostages. Runcie told a news conference that while he ``grieved'' for Waite, a hostage for more than 3{ years, this was ``not the time for gimmickry or the pursuit of tempting shortcuts.'' Keenan, 39, is the first released hostage to report contact with Waite. During an interview Monday with Independent Television News, Keenan said he had been held in the same Beirut apartment as the 51-year-old Waite and that the Anglican envoy had been ill. Runcie said he was heartened to have ``clear confirmation'' that Waite was alive. He said he was also encouraged by signs of a diplomatic breakthrough in relations between the European Community and Iran. ``We, too, have maintained our own direct contacts with Iran and will continue to do so,'' he said. Full relations between the EC and Iran were suspended last year when Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for the death of Salman Rushdie, the British author of ``The Satanic Verses.'' Khomeini said the book was blasphemous. Runcie said while the Iranians do not hold the hostages, ``they undoubtedly have considerable influence with the captors.'' ``They have demonstrated that influence three times this year with the release of (Americans) Robert Polhill and Frank Reed and Brian Keenan. Waite disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his west Beirut hotel to negotiate with Islamic Jihad, an extremist Moslem group, for the release of two U.S. hostages Six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian are still missing in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Unidentified Gunmen Kill Eight, Injure Six in Uganda
DOC.TEXT: Eight passengers died and six were seriously injured when unidentified gunmen ambushed a bus in northeastern Uganda, it was reported today. New Vision newspaper said the ambush occured Monday near Soroti, a trading town 190 miles northeast of Uganda's capital, Kampala. Anwdine Makoha, the driver, told the newspaper that the bus, carrying 60 passengers, ``was showered with bullets from the attackers who were hiding on the road side.'' Makoha managed to drive the vehicle with the dead and wounded to Soroti. Monday's attack came a day after rebels reportedly killed nine civilians and wounded five others in attacks on vehicles along Uganda's eastern border southeast of Soroti. The estimated 150 armed men in Monday's attack were believed members of the rebel Uganda People's army. The loosely knit insurgency is led by Peter Otai, defense minister in the administration of former President Milton Obote, said Munno newspaper. Obote was ousted in a 1985 military coup. Sporadic rebel attacks continue despite intensified army efforts to squash insurgencies in eastern and northeastern Uganda.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Upholds California's Assault Rifle Ban
DOC.TEXT: In a case closely watched by both gun-control advocates and opponents, a federal judge dismissed a challenge by the National Rifle Association on California's ban on automatic weapons. U.S. District Judge Edward Dean Price said Monday that the Second Amendment, which gives citizens the right to bear arms, does not apply to laws passed by state governments, as the NRA contended in their case. He also ruled that Californians' constitutional right of privacy does not equate with the right of self-defense. The NRA and the Fresno Rifle and Pistol Club filed the lawsuit in February to stop enforcement of California's ban on automatic weapons. The ban took effect Jan. 1. ``We conclude that the Constitution has left the question of gun control to the several states,'' Price wrote. ``There are no federal constitutional provisions that have been offended by this (state) act.'' The decision quickly drew response from both sides of the gun-control issue. ``The court's decision is a tremendous victory for public safety,'' California Attorney General John Van de Kamp said. ``This is just another step in the ongoing situation ... the hysterical reaction instead of making good laws,'' said Diana Weeks of the Fresno Rifle and Pistol Club. Under the Roberti-Roos Assault Weapons Control Act of 1989, it is illegal to sell, advertise, manufacture or import more than 50 specific types of semiautomatic rifles, pistols and shotguns. The bill was passed in the wake of a schoolyard shooting in Stockton in January 1989 that left five children dead.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Guardsman Found After Training Jump into Lake
DOC.TEXT: A National Guard training exercise in which guardsmen jump from a low-flying helicopter into a lake killed one soldier and injured five others, one critically, authorities said today. The body of Sgt. Chet May of Fulton washed ashore from Grenada Lake on Monday night and was found by park rangers, Sheriff Weston Birdsong said. The accident occurred Sunday. ``The six guardsmen were undergoing a helicasting operation where they jump from a low-flying helicopter from 10 to 15 feet above water,'' said Staff Sgt. Sandy Switzer of the Mississippi Military Department in Jackson. ``They're outfitted with swim trunks and inflatable life preservers.'' Switzer said it was not known what caused the death and injuries. Investigators from the Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Ala., began reviewing the circumstances Monday. The exercise was a training drill for the Mississippi National Guard's 2nd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group. It was not related to the Persian Gulf crisis, a guard spokesman said. Cpl. Ronald S. Kelly of Jackson remained in critical condition today at the Memphis Regional Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. Four other soldiers were treated for minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: New Fuel Pumps Installed; NASA to Test Leaky Shuttle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with 1 graf to UPDATE with no leaks found in Columbia's removed pumps; SUBS grafs 9 through end bgng ``Meanwhile, a' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with NASA recommendation to fly with leaky ammonia boiler in Discovery.
DOC.TEXT: NASA mechanics trying to beat a launch deadline installed new fuel pumps in the leaky shuttle Columbia in hopes of getting the spaceship aloft next week. Columbia, whose liftoff with the $150 million Astro observatory has been delayed twice by fuel leaks and once by problems with one of its telescopes, must take off next week or wait until after the October launch of Discovery. Discovery will have to be delayed until late 1991 if it misses its launch window. NASA planned to test Columbia's new pumps today by flushing the system with helium. In the pumps that were removed earlier, helium tests failed to find leaks, and officials planned to try again with supercold liquid hydrogen to simulate actual fueling conditions, agency spokesman George Diller said today. The space agency hasn't sent up a shuttle in more than four months because of fuel leaks in two of its three shuttles that forced a grounding of the entire three-vehicle fleet. Columbia's aft compartment flooded with hydrogen during fueling for a launch attempt last week, and engineers suspected a bad fuel pump. The leak was in a different area from the one that earlier affected Columbia and Atlantis. ``It's been peaks and valleys, and we're in a little bit of a valley with Atlantis and particularly Columbia right now,'' said Dick Richards, commander of Discovery's upcoming flight. ``But I'm hoping ... that this thing will turn around and two years from now we won't even remember these hydrogen leaks. I think they'll be a little bit of a footnote in shuttle history.'' Meanwhile, a leak in Discovery's cooling system has preparations for that flight several days behind schedule. Its mission is to deploy a satellite scientists hope will become the first spacecraft to orbit the sun's poles. Discovery must be launched between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23. Otherwise, its $750 million mission will have to wait until 1991, when Earth is aligned properly again with the sun and Jupiter. The sun probe, called Ulysses, will use Jupiter's gravity to be whipped into the proper orbit around the sun. Engineers have traced Discovery's leaks to a vent in the ammonia boiler, which is losing about 1 percent of its Freon contents each day. Mission managers are recommending NASA fly with the leaky boiler as long as the leak remains small, Diller said. Minor leakage will not jeopardize Discovery's flight because there still would be enough coolant for the four-day mission, Diller said. The boiler is needed to cool the shuttle during landings. ``The leak's not big enough to bother with, and it doesn't look like it's going to change,'' Diller said. ``They don't think it's worth the impact to go change it.'' If the part had to be replaced, Discovery still could lift off by Oct. 23, but ``it's going to make it a lot harder,'' Richards said.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Capital Awash in Heavy Rain, at Least 30 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE dead, missing figures, MOVE higher Roh quotes and property damage estimates; DELETES 17th, penultimate grafs pvs to CONFORM. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: Record torrential rains soaked South Korea today, causing massive landslides and widespread flooding that left at least 30 people dead and 46 missing and forced 50,000 to evacuate their homes. The Central Disaster Relief Center said the Seoul area was swamped by 15 inches of rain in 24 hours. Hardest hit was Suwon, a city immediately south of Seoul, which had 16.8 inches, the center said. The rainfall was the most in a single day in 70 years, and property damage was estimated at $15 million. The center said 30 people were dead and 16 missing. News reports said at least 35 people were killed and as many as 46 were missing. About 50,000 people were homeless and in shelters in the capital and surrounding areas, the reports said. The torrential rains were expected to continue until Wednesday, and flood warnings were issued for Seoul and central provinces. ``This is the worst weather disaster in memory,'' President Roh Tae-woo said after being briefed on the situation. ``Protecting people from this rain is like fighting a war.'' Two cruise ships tied to a pier in Seoul's Han River sank in the storm after the mooring ropes loosened and the boats capsized in swift currents, police said. Ten crewmen were missing and 20 crewmen were rescued, police said. At the port of Inchon, west of Seoul, nine houses collapsed in a mudslide and 20 people were missing, police said. A Buddhist temple was buried in a mudslide with five monks inside, and a factory dormitory collapsed, killing six sleeping employees, news reports said. The disaster center provided the overall figures on dead, missing and evacuated. The national news agency Yonhap said the dead included a 9-year-old girl swept away by raging flood waters and a 3-year-old sleeping in her parents home. U.S. and South Korean military helicopters and army trucks evacuated schoolchildren and shopkeepers stranded on housetops and buildings in rural areas outside Seoul. After nightfall, panic prevailed in many flooded areas without electricity or telephones, news reports said. One hospital on the outskirts of Seoul evacuated its patients, and witnesses reported seeing some patients wading through waist-high flood water with belongings held over their heads. Korean soldiers used rubber boats to rescue people stranded in low-lying areas around Olympic Park, site of the 1988 Olympic Games. Traffic in the city of 10 million people was at virtual standstill early in the day, but by nightfall many trucks, cars and some buses were standing in gullies of water, abandoned by drivers. About 25,000 people were homeless and being sheltered in school auditoriums and public buildings in areas around Seoul, relief officials said. U.S. fighter planes based at Osan, 30 miles south of Seoul, were moved and sandbagged after the airfield was flooded. About two dozen Koreans in makeshift boats floated over a submerged fence onto the runways and were rescued, a spokesman said. The water supply for the U.S. base was flooded and contaminated and bottled water was trucked in for drinking, a spokesman for the 7th Air Force said. The wide Han River, which bisects Seoul, was above flood stage at nightfall and rising, officials said. Water tanks, pieces of machinery and parts of buildings were seen bobbing in the raging waters. Roh ordered a mobilization of the military and all government agencies to help minimize the loss of life and property damage. Government offices were told to remain open around the clock. U.S. General Robert W. RisCassi, commander of the 43,000 American troops based in South Korea, offered to loan bulldozers, sandbag fillers, road graders and large earth-moving equipment as well as labor to assist rescue efforts. The largest single day rainfall in Seoul had been 13.9 inches in 1920. Record keeping began in 1907.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline for Zhivkov Indictment Passes
DOC.TEXT: Authorities failed to meet a deadline to file an indictment against former Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov, his lawyer said, and it was unknown whether prosecutors planned to renew the case or drop it. Zhivkov, who is under house arrest, has been accused of abuse of office, misappropriation of state property and incitement of national hatred _ a term used to describe his persecution of ethnic Turks. Reny Tsanova, Zhivkov's lawyer, said in a television interview Monday that prosecutors must now seek another extension or discontinue proceedings for lack of evidence. So far, they have done neither. The investigation of Zhikvov, who was arrested in January, was to have been completed by July 18 and a trial held by this fall. The prosuection had asked for an extension to complete its work, but did not do so before Monday's deadline. There has been speculation that Zhivkov may be never tried for lack of enough evidence. In the TV interview, Ms. Tsanova was asked why Zhivkov refuses to appear before parliament after he offered in a letter to address it. She said Zhivkov had not gone back on his commitment ``but the question is at what moment.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Tear Gas to Prevent Serbian Rally in Bosnia
DOC.TEXT: Police used tear gas and truncheons to disperse a rally by Serbs and head off clashes with Moslems in a central Yugoslav town today, the state Tanjug news agency and witnesses said. At least four people were injured and 22 detained after stone-throwing protestors clashed with police, Tanjug said. The incident in the Bosnian town of Foca, 30 miles southeast of Sarajevo, occurred when thousands of Serbs gathered for a rally to air grievances against the Moslem population that had been banned by local authorities. Tensions between Orthodox Serbs and Moslems living in Foca were raised three months ago after a local transport company strike polarized the two ethnic groups. Serb employees have demanded the sacking of the company's Moslem director, while Moslem workers have opposed the move. Serbs in Foca say they are being harassed by Moslems and scheduled the rally to draw attention to their complaints. But police riot squads, fearing clashes between Serbs and Moslems, dispersed the crowd with tear gas and truncheons, witnesses and Tanjug said. Later, a strong police presence ensured an uneasy peace, witnesses said from Foca. On Sunday, police used force to prevent clashes between Serbs and Moslems in the Serbian town of Novi Pazar, 110 miles south of Belgrade. Moslems comprise more than 20 percent of Yugoslavia's 24 million population. Considered a separate nationality within Yugoslavia, they are showing increasing solidarity with pan-Islamic trends in the world. In recent years there has been a resurgence of historic ethnic rivalries in Yugoslavia, a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Should Answer Questions on Abortion, Senate Chairman Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with NOW quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr. said today Supreme Court nominee David Souter should answer specific questions on abortion and other politically volatile issues at his confirmation hearings. ``At this fateful moment in our history we have a right to know'' the answers to such questions, said Biden, D-Del. As Judiciary Committee chairman, he will preside over the hearings on Souter's nomination scheduled to begin Thursday. Meanwhile, the president of the National Organization for Women charged that Souter's nomination is part of a right-wing campaign to stack the court with justices hostile to the rights of women and minorities. NOW President Molly Yard told a news conference Souter is ``almost Neanderthal'' and said his record indicates he would vote to overturn the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade ruling that legalized abortion. ``You're literally talking about women's lives,'' she said. ``That's what at stake.'' Biden brushed aside any notion that it would be wrong to force a Supreme Court nominee to give his views on such matters as abortion, civil rights, and freedom of religion that will come before the court. ``All signs point to the need for very extensive, detailed questioning of this nominee,'' Biden said. He said he has not decided yet whether the federal judge from New Hampshire should be confirmed. But he did acknowledge that ``a number of questions have been raised in my mind.'' He called the nomination ``the most important business to come before the Senate this year'' and said Souter's impact on the court would linger ``long after (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein has bitten the dust, long after the current budget crisis has been replaced by some other fiscal dilemma.'' He said he was ``not looking for promises'' as to how Souter would decide controversial cases but added that Supreme Court candidates in the past had often been questioned about their opinions on major issues. He said that was especially true in the cases of nominees ``such as Judge Souter with very limited records that give rise to almost total uncertainty.'' Biden dismissed a statement by Souter that his judicial philosophy is that of an ``interpretivist.'' ``Many scholars and jurists travel on this common banner,'' Biden said. He said some of Souter's comments in the past ``could place him among the more rigid of these interpreters.'' The only way to determine precisely what the label means in Souter's case will be to ask how he views specific issues, Biden said. ``There's nothing wrong with putting to Judge Souter some rather specific questions relating to constitutional issues, including religion, free speech, civil rights and abortion and expect some ... specific answsers,'' Biden said. ``What little we know of Judge Souter, and it is quite tentative, emphasizes how important it is that we thoroughly question him,'' Biden said. Ms. Yard said the nominee interprets the Constitution according to its original intent in 1787, ``a time when all blacks were slaves and women were the property of their husbands. We cannot and will not as women accept such a stacking of the court on behalf of right-wing zealots.'' Eleanor Smeal, head of the Fund for a Feminist Majority and former NOW president, predicted that Souter, if confirmed to the high court, would be ``a consistent roadblock to the advancement of women and minorities.''

DOC.HEAD: Minister Protests Use Of Women Soldiers In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A minister led a group of about 50 protesters today who gathered at the gate of Fort Hood to press the Pentagon to stop using women soldiers in the Persian Gulf. The Rev. W.N. Otwell of Fort Worth said he has planned protests at a number of military installations in Texas to oppose using mothers in combat areas. Fort Hood spokeswoman Liz Crossan said about 50 people, including women and children, participated in the hour-long demonstration at the post's main gate. The protesters were asked to leave after they moved just inside the main gate shortly after 7:30 a.m., said Ms. Crossan. Bell County deputies and state troopers were at the scene, but there were no arrests, she said. Fort spokesman Lindsey R. Neas said under defense department policy, women are not assigned to front-line units. But they may be assigned to support units that are near combat areas and could therefore be at risk, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Meets de Klerk, Says Peace Process `In Distress'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela comments after meeting. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: At least 25 people died today in black faction fighting, and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela said the government's failure to halt the carnage put the peace process ``in distress.'' Mandela led an ANC-delegation that met with President F.W. de Klerk to discuss violence that has plagued black townships near Johannesburg since Aug. 12, claiming more than 650 lives. ``The government came under heavy attack (during the meeting) for its failure to take visible measures to deal with the situation,'' Mandela told journalists, adding that he accused the government of waging war against the ANC. He said the ANC would do everything possible to continue talks with the government on a new constitution to give the black majority political power. But there was no doubt ``the peace process is in distress,'' Mandela said. There was no immediate government comment on the meeting. Police said 22 people were killed early today in fighting in Katlehong township and two were killed in Vosloorus. Rival bands of Zulus and Xhosas fought with axes, spears and knives. At least one black man was hacked to death today and several injured on a train in Johannesburg by men with machetes who rampaged through carriages attacking passengers, police said. The fighting has largely pitted Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC against Zulus tied to the conservative Inkatha party. Both factions oppose apartheid but differ over leadership and plans for a future South Africa. Constitution Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen attacked Mandela for his criticism of police during the fighting, and charged the ANC was not helping to end violence. It was the strongest attack on Mandela by the government in recent months. ``Mr. Mandela lays all responsibility for curbing violence on the shoulders of the government. All political organizations have a duty and responsibility actively to contribute towards calming excited emotions and restoring peace and stability,'' Viljoen said in a statement Monday night. ``The ANC ... must cease claiming total innocence for themselves and their followers, and laying blame on their opponents, or the police,'' he said. Mandela and the ANC, the country's largest black opposition group, have repeatedly charged that police instigated violence or aided Inkatha fighters. Police and government officials have rejected the charges. Mandela told a weekend meeting of the Organization of African Unity in Uganda that South Africa would be ``drowned in blood'' unless the government took steps to end the violence. He also said the growing violence threatened to derail talks between the ANC and the government on ending white minority rule. The ANC and the government are preparing for talks, expected early next year, on sharing political power with the black majority. De Klerk has promised to end apartheid. In other developments, a bomb exploded early today outside a Johannesburg cinema where a liberal newspaper is holding a film festival, police said. The bomb caused little damage and there were no injuries, they said. The Weekly Mail is holding an annual festival of progressive films at the cinema. Police said no group claimed responsibility for the blast, but officers said it could be the work of whites opposed to ending apartheid.
