Six political prisoners, all members of the ANC, were released today in Cape Town. The men were freed under a recent agreement between the government and the ANC on freeing political detainees.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow, Bonn Agree on Sum For Departing Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to upgrade attribution on amount of money. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Also Monday...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and West Germany have reached a compromise on how much money Bonn will pay Moscow for the pullout of Red Army troops from East Germany. West Germany's finance minister put the figure at $7.6 billion. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, in an interview with wire service reporters, refused to specify how much money or say how the ``compromise agreement'' was reached Monday, but he said it was ``something that will satisfy us and our partners.'' ``A compromise is a compromise. The main thing is we have an agreement,'' he said. ``This issue is no longer an obstacle.'' Finance Minister Theo Waigel cited the $7.6 billion figure at a meeting of conservative Christian Democrat and Christian Socialist members of parliament in West Berlin today, the finance ministry press office said. The West German television network ZDF said President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl had reached an agreement ``in principle'' on the money during the 30-minute telephone call. Also Monday, German officials announced a $636 million deal with Moscow to help troubled East GermThey are motivated by profit, greed and avarice,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``Theirs is an attitude that I think really is repugnant.'' To express displeasure with the level of support, the Senate on Monday adopted a resolution threatening a deterioration in U.S. relations with any nation that doesn't contribute enough. In Tokyo today, a Japanese official said Japan was considering giving $2 billion to the three nations hardest hit by the economic sanctions against Iraq. That would be on top of $1 billion the country has already pledged to support the military effort against Iraq. Hiroyasu Horio, an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said the $2 billion would go to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. News reports in Tokyo said the money would be extended through the World Bank and International Monetary Fund with the first $600 million being sent as early as mid-September. The Senate resolution, attached to a spending bill for the Postal Service and other agencies, directed the president to present Congress a detailed report on the administration's cost-sharing efforts by Nov. 30. ``During his consultations with other international leaders,'' Bush ``should consider stressing ... that failure by any country to actively contribute in the most appropriate manner for that country could have a detrimental impact on its bilateral relationship with the United States,'' the resolution said. The approval of the measure, the first such congressional action since Bush ordered U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia, reflected lawmakers' reaction to complaints by voters that the United States is shouldering too much of the burden. The United States ``cannot play Uncle Sugar to the world,'' said Sen. Dennis Deconcini, D-Ariz., one of the primary sponsors. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., called Japan's $1 billion pledge only a ``few token shillings.'' He contended that a more adequate response, given Japan's economic standing, would be an $8 billion pledge. ``The contemptible tokenism of the actions of the Japanese government to date merit nothing but the world's contempt and American hostility,'' McCain said. ``If combat arises, it will not be Japanese boys whose lives are at risk, it will be American boys.'' Japan, which ran up a $49 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, was singled out for the bulk of the criticism. But senators said they also were unhappy with the response so far by West Germany, which has agreed to supply air and sea transport but turned down a U.S. request for more help in defraying the costs of keeping troops in the Persian Gulf. West Germany and Japan both contend that their post-World War II constitutions bar them from sending troops to the Persian Gulf. The United States is seeking approximately $28 billion through the end of 1991 for the gulf campaign. Of that amount, $10 billion would go to supply aid to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan and the remainder would pay for the U.S. military buildup. While Brady had little luck getting much more than words of encouragement from France, Britain, South Korea and Japan last week, Secretary of State James A. Baker III reported more success on a similar fund-raising mission to oil-rich Middle Eastern nations. Baker said Monday that Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the exiled government of Kuwait had pledged $12 billion, split between the military effort and the economic assistance package. But some critics charged that consumers from America and other countries were in reality footing the bill through higher energy prices. Edwin Rothschild, head of the consumer group Citizen Action, said the Saudis stood to make an extra $3.2 billion monthly from the crisis based on a $10-a-barrel rise in oil costs since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a 2 million-barrel per day increase in Saudi production. Their share of the U.S. military costs was reportedly only $500 million a month. The administration has been stressing the need for a united front against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, something analysts say is not helped by the lukewarm reception by some allied countries.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Opposes Anti-Obscenity Curbs on Arts Endowment Grants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout to include reaction.
DOC.TEXT: An independent study commission, created amid furor over government funding of controversial art, urged Congress today not to impose anti-obscenity curbs on works subsidized by the National Endowment for the Arts. It also called on the arts agency chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, to scrap a requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge not to use federal funds to produce works that might be deemed obscene. The bipartisan 12-member panel, established by Congress last fall, also proposed overhauling the grant-making machinery of the endowment. ``Maintaining the principle of an open society requires all of us, at times, to put up with much we do not like, but the bargain has proved in the long run a good one,'' the commission said. The House is preparing to begin debating soon legislative proposals to extend the life of the embattled arts endowment, with restrictions on the kinds of art that can receive federal funds. The NEA's statutory authority expires Sept. 30. Rep. E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., a key figure in House negotiations on the endowment's future, said the report could serve as the possible framework for a compromise. But he said Congress probably will insist on including some anti-obscenity restrictions in its final bill, even if it only reaffirms Supreme Court rulings on the issue. Jeffrey Chester, a spokesman for the National Campaign for Freedom of Expression, a non-profit artists' organization, praised the proposal to eliminate Frohnmayer's anti-obscenity pledge for grant recipients. But Chester expressed concern that the report, if endorsed by Congress, would turn the NEA chairman into a ``new arts czar'' with sole authority over final grant-making decisions, while diminishing the traditional role of NEA peer-review panels in selecting grants for approval. ``The commission is tightening the vise of censorship,'' Chester said. The NEA has been buffeted for more than a year by criticism from conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists over its support for works that some regarded as pornographic or sacrilegious. At the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Congress amended the endowment's current $171 million budget last fall to include a ban on support for works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including homoerotic and sadomasochistic images. The commission unanimously urged Congress not to hobble the NEA with anti-obscenity restrictions and, in effect, to trust the endowment chairman to approve grants for works of artistic excellence that are not obscene or otherwise illegal. ``Insuring the freedom of expression necessary to nourish the arts while bearing in mind limits of public understanding and tolerance requires unusual wisdom, prudence and, most of all, common sense,'' said co-chairmen Leonard Garment, a Washington lawyer, and John Brademas, president of New York University. At a news conference this morning, the study commission recommended diminishing the role of the NEA's ``peer review panels'' which select grant applications for approval, and giving the NEA chairman sole, explicit authority to make final grant decisions without restrictions by Congress. The report urged reviving a system under which committees of the National Council on the Arts, the endowment's advisory body, would review peer panel selections before final grant awards are made. With the aim of increasing the NEA's accountability to the tax-paying public, the commission said the peer panels _ which consist of outside artists and arts managers _ should be expanded to include ``persons knowledgeable about the arts but not earning their living in them.'' The report declared that ``obscenity is not protected speech'' and that the NEA ``is prohibited from funding the production of works which are obscene or otherwise illegal.'' But it said the endowment should stay out of the business of defining what is obscene, leaving that as a legal matter for the courts to decide. Likewise, the panel said it unanimously opposed ``legislative changes to impose specific restrictions on the content of works of art supported by the endowment.'' It added: ``Content restrictions may raise serious constitutional issues, would be inherently ambiguous and would almost certainly involve the endowment and the Department of Justice in costly and unproductive lawsuits.'' The commission suggested that Congress instead approve a ``preamble'' to legislation reauthorizing the NEA, which would declare that the arts ``belong to all the people of the United States'' and should foster ``mutual respect for the diverse beliefs and values of all persons and groups.'' The obscenity ban approved by Congress last fall was prompted by criticism of past NEA support for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, which contained sexually graphic images, and by artist Andres Serrano, which some critics denounced as blasphemous. After Congress acted, Frohnmayer instituted the anti-obscenity pledge for grant recipients, which has caused widespread protests in the arts community. By the NEA's latest count, nearly a dozen artists and arts organizations have refused to sign the anti-obscenity pledge and have forfeited their endowment grants. The pledge also is being challenged on constitutional grounds in federal lawsuits in New York and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Paris Parking Ban Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: A ban on parking along 17 miles of major Paris streets went into effect Tuesday, part of a campaign to ease severe traffic congestion. The restrictions prohibit parking at any time along a series of designated ``red roads'' that form the major east-west and north-south routes. A special force of 120 police and traffic officers was assigned to enforce the new rules. On Tuesday, they limited themselves to verbal warnings, but starting Thursday will tow away the cars of offending motorists. Violators face fines of $85. The affected routes include some of Paris' best-known streets, such as the Rue du Rivoli and the Boulevard Saint Michel. Even delivery trucks are barred from stopping in some areas. Mayor Jacques Chirac said the restrictions are part of a plan to limit the use of private cars in central Paris and give priority to public transport. He said the city intends to compensate for the ban by providing thousands of new parking spaces in proposed underground garages. Some environmentalist groups have criticized the ban, saying it will backfire by attracting more motorists with the prospect of less congested streets.

DOC.HEAD: Robert E. Lee Letter Going to Museum
DOC.TEXT: A letter said to have been written by Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee was withdrawn from sale and will be donated to a museum, an auctioneer said Tuesday. Michael Shortall of M. Shortall Auctions said the letter, which belongs to the American de Krafft family, was taken off the market ``because of the great interest it aroused.'' He would not say where the de Kraffts live in the United States because the family wants to protect its privacy. The letter of thanks for a gift of a uniform and blankets was to have been auctioned Monday along with other items from Heronden Hall in Tenterden, Kent County, which belongs to the de Krafft family. The family is selling the house and contents. ``The family now feels the letter is of such interest that it should be in a museum,'' said Shortall. ``They are talking to representatives of a British museum which exhibits American items.'' He declined to name the museum. Shortall also declined to say whether the letter had been authenticated. The letter is dated April 22, 1864, a year before the Civil War ended with Lee's surrender at Appomattox. It was sent from Lee's headquarters to a Maj. L.B. Ferguson in England. It acknowledges ``the uniforms and blankets you so kindly sent me. We have, partly owing to your efforts and partly to the exertions of our people, everything we actually want. All else we can dispense with.''

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Riot Over Crackdown on Possessions
DOC.TEXT: About 200 prisoners rioted at a Sydney jail over a planned crackdown on the personal items they can keep in their cells. A spokesman for Bathurst jail said two prison officers and eight inmates required medical treatment after the Monday riot but were not seriously injured. The new policy prohibits all items except televisions, radios and books in cells. It was implemented after a prison officer was stabbed with a syringe filled with AIDS-infected blood. The officer subsequently tested positive for the AIDS virus. A spokesman for the Prison Officers Association, Dick Palmer, said Bathurst inmates refused to leave the prison's main square Monday afternoon to protest the new policy, which is being implemented next week. They began smashing windows and destroying prison property. Officers fired tear gas on the prisoners, who finally returned to their cells after negotiations with prison officers. Palmer attacked the state government for the severity of the new policy, saying his group was not consulted.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Orders Investigation Into Murder of Priest
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered a ``thorough investigation'' into the ax murder of a prominent Russian Orthodox priest, a presidential spokesman said Tuesday. Father Alexander Menn, a writer who was persecuted for his evangelical activities, was bludgeoned to death with an ax while on his way to church, according to media reports Monday. His body was found Sunday near his house in Zagorsk, 50 miles east of Moscow, Tass said. Presidential Spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said at a news conference that Gorbachev had expressed ``profound regret'' over Menn's death. ``Gorbachev gave instructions to law and order officials to conduct a very thorough investigation into this case,'' Ignatenko said. Ordained a priest in 1961, Menn was a theologian and a church historian. He published several books and articles, as well as a children's book. His popular history of comparative religion was published in several volumes in Belgium. Authorities detained him for questioning several times, but he was never held for long periods, according to a spokesman for Keston College in Britain, a research center for religion in communist countries. In 1988, with the easing of restrictions on religious activities, Menn was one of the first priests to be invited to visit schools and talk to children about the church.

DOC.HEAD: Athenians Hit By Public Transport Stoppage
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of stranded Athenians tried to hitch rides Tuesday as public transport unions staged a six-hour walkout to protest the government's cost-cutting policies. It was part of a wave of strikes this week protesting a government austerity plan aimed at overhauling state-run health and pension plans. The governing conservatives want to reduce the number of social insurance funds in operation, increase contributions by individuals, tighten eligibility requirements and raise the pension age. The national trade union federation has called a general strike for Thursday amid separate walkouts by teachers and power, construction, telecommunications and post office workers. The general strike will be the fifth this year.

DOC.HEAD: `Copy Cat' Suicides Lead to Calls for Media Self-Censorship
By VICTOR L. SIMPSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A series of copy-cat suicides in Italy has led to calls for the media to limit coverage of such deaths. One major newspaper said it would publish only scant reports from now on, and the state-run RAI-TV said it was limiting coverage to late-night newscasts, which have the fewest viewers. Since the beginning of September, 10 people have taken their lives in a similar fashion _ running a tube from the exhaust pipe into their car and turning on the ignition. Newspapers have paid considerable attention to the suicides, examining the victims' pasts and editorializing on the ills of modern Italian society that might lead someone to commit suicide. In one of the cases, police said they found a newspaper opened to the story of a previous suicide on the seat next to the victim. After the ninth suicide last weekend, the Rome newspaper Il Tempo announced in a front-page editorial that it would limit further reporting on suicides to a few lines on an inside page. ``The information blackout ... can help to break the tragic and repetitive chain,'' Il Tempo said. Indro Montanelli, editor of the Milan newspaper Il Giornale, disagreed. ``In principle, there is no news that shouldn't be published. To write about suicides is dangerous? In that case, we won't write about rapes, robberies, murders, smoking, terrorism,'' Montanelli said. ``If we follow that logic, we won't put out newspapers anymore.'' Gianni Rocca, deputy editor of La Repubblica of Rome, agreed with Montanelli. ``For how long would we have to be silent about such news? For a day, a week, for our whole life?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Legislature Elects New Premier
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's first democratically elected legislature, signaling the high priority given economic problems, named the top price control official as premier, China's official news agency reported Tuesday. In a dispatch from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, Xinhua said the legislature Monday confirmed President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat's nomination of Dash Bambasuren as premier. Bambasuren, 58, was chairman of the State Price and Standardization Committee and is a graduate of the Soviet Economic Statistics College, the report said. He replaces Sharavyn Gunjaadorg, 54, former minister of agriculture. Gunjaadorg became premier in March during a shakeup of top Communist Party and government ranks forced by pro-democracy demonstrations. The demonstrations also led to elections in July for a new national legislature, the 430-seat Great People's Hural. The Communists, who have ruled Mongolia since 1921, retained power, but most of the leaders of newly legalized opposition parties won legislative seats. As a group, the Communist deputies are better educated and more reform-minded than in the past. The party maintains it shares most of the opposition's goals, including shaking up the long-stagnant economy with market-style reforms and ending human rights violations.

DOC.HEAD: Norway To Give Environmental Aid to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The government has earmarked $50 million in aid to help clean up Soviet industries that are polluting the arctic regions of both countries, news reports said Wednesday. ``We are not doing this to solve a Soviet problem, but to solve a Norwegian problem,'' said Prime Minister Jan P. Syse. Pollution from outdated Soviet smelters drifts into northern Norway, damaging the fragile arctic environment. Syse made the announcement late Monday at an Oslo concert held to benefit the Norwegian ``Stop the Soviet Death Clouds'' movement. The grant will be distributed over five years. It requires parliament's approval, and NTB reported that it has broad support across party lines.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Lotto Goes to $90 Million; $100 Million Possible
DOC.TEXT: Florida's weekly Lotto jackpot was raised to $90 million today as sales continued at a pace that could send the game past the $100 million mark before Saturday night's drawing. The overnight $10 million increase in the prize money was announced by Susan Nefzger, spokeswoman for the lottery. On Saturday, there were no winning tickets in a $50 million lottery. The next day, the jackpot for the coming Saturday was set at $75 million; on Monday, it was raised to $80 million. For the jackpot to reach $100 million, lottery officials calculate that the state will have to sell $98 million tickets this week. The previous record was $56 million in sales in one week, set in April. Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul said Monday's sales raced well ahead of the record pace. ``It's a little crazy here right now,'' she said. ``It's a really hard issue for us because this is so outside of the norm.'' April Fanaken of Fort Lauderdale was playing for the first time. ``I have never played. I am a teacher, and all my kids all day long have been talking about `you never know,''' she said, referring to the slogan used by the lottery. Extra maintenance people were added this week to keep terminals working across the state and additional phone lines were installed at lottery headquarters to handle increased telephone traffic, Mrs. Paul said. The national record for a lottery prize is $115 million, which was awarded in Pennsylvania to 14 ticket-holders, some of them individuals and some groups. But the U.S. record of the largest single lottery prize still goes to Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs, who won a Florida Lotto jackpot of $55.1 million two years ago. Lotto jackpots roll over when no one picks all the winning numbers. The Lottery Department then estimates the size of the next week's jackpot based on sales projections. The odds of someone picking the winning numbers are about one-in-14 million. Another concern for lottery officials is the design of the billboards announcing jackpot estimates, which don't have space for a nine-figure jackpot. ``The boards were not originally prepared for the extra digi,'' said Bernie Torra, spokesman for Ackerley Communications of Miami, lottery billboard handlers in South Florida. ``We're working on it.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Tell Congress of `New World Order;' Follow With Message to Iraqis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with plans to tape message to Iraqis; picks up 5th graf pvs, The address...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will tell Congress tonight that the Persian Gulf crisis has forged ``a new world order'' in which the superpower adversaries of the Cold War now stand united to reverse Iraq's conquest of Kuwait. Bush will follow up the address with a televised message for the Iraqi people declaring that the world is united against their government's invasion of Kuwait. Bush, fresh from his one-day summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Helsinki, will go before a joint session of the House and Senate with a nationally broadcast address at 9 p.m. EDT. Aides said the president will seek the nation's support for his decision to send more than 100,000 troops to the gulf region to put pressure on Saddam and deter a possible invasion of oil-rich Saudi Arabia. ``He's going to be very candid with them about exactly what we're doing there and why and what our purposes are,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``It's going to require a commitment of resources and time and energy by the American people.'' Then, on Wednesday morning, Bush will tape a television message in the Oval Office, with Arabic subtitles and voice translation, to spell out why much of the world has united against Iraq's conquest of Kuwait. Fitzwater said the tape was being made as a counter-offer to Iraq's proposal to send a team of interviewers to question Bush. Fitzwater said it was irrelevant that Bush had chosen a forum different from the one that Iraq suggested. ``The issue was, the president said he would like to have equal kinds of access to the Iraqi people that the United States has granted to Saddam Hussein, and we assume that is the essence of the invitation,'' the spokesman said. If Iraq declines to broadcast the tape, Fitzwater said, it will be made available to other Arab countries, as well as nations around the world. ``The Iraqi government has not been forthcoming in telling the people of that country what's happening,'' Fitzwater said. He said the people of Iraq are generally unaware of resolutions at the United Nations and the Arab League condemning the invasion or the flood of refugees that it has created. The address marks the third time that Bush has addressed lawmakers during his 20 months in the White House. While Congress has been largely supportive of his gulf policy, many of its leaders have urged him to go before the nation with a speech spelling out U.S. objectives and the risks in protecting the region's vast supplies of oil. The occasion presents Bush with an opportunity to prod lawmakers to conclude a long-stalled agreement with the White House to cut the budget deficit by slashing spending and raising taxes. Fitzwater told reporters the gulf crisis ``points up the need to put our domestic house in order and reach a budget agreement, on defense as well as other domestic issues.'' ``We're going to need all our strength to see us through in the Persian Gulf,'' he said. Bush, in the last two weeks, has been promoting the thesis that the United States and Soviet Union have moved even closer together because of their joint opposition to Iraq's aggression. Fitzwater said the president would expand on that theme tonight. ``First of all, he'll report to the Congress on the summit meeting with Gorbachev,'' the spokesman said. ``Then he wants to lay out to the Congress and the people the overall situation in the gulf, the status of our forces, the role of the U.N. ``He will use the summit (in Helsinki) and the gulf situation to talk about the changing East-West relations, a new world order in which the superpowers join together in the U.N. auspices to establish certain responsibilities for world stability,'' Fitzwater said. Despite their agreement on forcing Iraq to retreat from Kuwait, the United States and Soviet Union still have differences on whether military force might eventually be needed. Gorbachev is pressing for a political solution in the gulf while Bush has left military options open. Gorbachev did not make any commitment to remove all of the Soviet trainers who are helping Iraq's military, although Bush said their withdrawal would be helpful. On the other hand, the two leaders moved toward agreement at the summit to give Moscow a major role in Middle East peace efforts, reversing a longstanding U.S. policy against Kremlin involvement. ``Under existing circumstances, we feel they can be helpful,'' Fitzwater said. However, he said the idea of a Middle East peace conference, as espoused by Moscow, ``should not be linked to the existing situation.'' On the eve of today's speech, Fitzwater said Saddam was ``grasping at any straw he can find'' by mending relations with Iran, once a bitter enemy, and by offering free oil to Third World nations. ``The man is desperate, reaching out wherever he can,'' Fitzwater said. Bush, meanwhile, asked Congress for $14.2 million so the government-financed Voice of America can broadcast its radio programs 24 hours a day in the Persian Gulf and throughout the Middle East. Currently, VOA broadcasts only 7{ hours a day. To pay for increasing the Arabic service, Bush proposed cutbacks in radio programs beamed to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Also on Monday, Bush called the leaders of France, Egypt, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Canada to brief them on Sunday's summit with Gorbachev. ``The response has been overwhelmingly supportive and almost euphoric in many cases in terms of the Soviet Union and the United States being able to come together this way,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Accident in India Kills Up to 150
DOC.TEXT: A boat carrying about 175 people capsized Tuesday in the Mahava river in northern India, killing at least 60 of the passengers, Press Trust of India reported. Another 90 people were missing and presumed drowned after the accident near Sehatwar village, 125 miles southeast of New Delhi in Uttar Pradesh state, PTI said. It was not immediately known where the boat was traveling. PTI said the boat was overloaded, but did not say what its capacity was.

DOC.BYLINE: Mike Wallace Says Will Keep Working Until His ``Toes Turn Up'' ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: Mike Wallace, at 72 the senior citizen of CBS News' durable ``60 Minutes,'' said Tuesday he'll retire only when he dies _ or, as he put it, his ``toes turn up.'' ``When, if retire?'' he asked, repeating a question about when or if he'd ever retire. ``Toes turn up _ retire. As long as you have a good time and as long as you can do the job, why retire?'' Wallace, who with Harry Reasoner was on the staff of ``60 Minutes'' when it began 23 years ago this month, spoke at a breakfast to publicize ``Mike Wallace, Then and Now, A CBS News Special.'' The one-hour program, scheduled for Sept. 26, is a retrospective of his 40-year career in news, of which 31 years have been spent at CBS. The program includes old black-and-white clips of his smoke-wreathed ``Night Beat'' one-on-one series of the mid-1950s. The show, which began on local TV in New York and then appeared on ABC, was responsible for first gaining Wallace fame as a hard-boiled interviewer who rarely gave his subjects any slack. In those days, he said, ``interviews by and large were virtual minuets. ... Nobody dogged, nobody pushed.'' That's why, he theorized, ``Night Beat'' ``got attention that hadn't been given to interview broadcasts before.'' As a result of one interview on that show, Wallace said, he was sued for libel. Then-Los Angeles Police Chief William Parker sued because of remarks about him by mobster Mickey Cohen. Wallace said ABC settled the lawsuit for $44,000. Wallace said it was the only time money has been paid to a plaintiff in a suit in which he was involved. The most publicized lawsuit against him was by retired Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who sought $120 million for a 1982 ``CBS Reports'' documentary, ``The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception.'' Westmoreland dropped the libel lawsuit in February 1985 after a long trial. Lawyers for each side later said legal costs of the suit totaled $12 million, of which $9 million was paid by CBS.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Confirms Amount Paid for Soviet Troop Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: West Germany will pay $7.6 billion to the Soviet Union to help finance the pullout of Soviet troops from East Germany, the Finance Ministry confirmed Tuesday. Finance Minister Theo Waigel cited the figure at a meeting of Christian Democratic and Christian Socialist members of parliament in West Berlin. He was confirming news reports Monday that West Germany would pay that sum to help repatriate the 370,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany. The Soviets are to be withdrawn over the next four years. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze announced agreement on Monday evening without naming a figure. He called the terms of the accord a ``compromise.'' The two governments had been deadlocked over the costs of the withdrawal of the Soviet troops and their dependents. In particular, Soviet military officials had expressed concerned about the housing shortage Red Army forces face when they return home. The West German contribution will go toward housing for the returning Soviet soldiers and their families, as well as training programs for the troops.

DOC.HEAD: 76-Year-Old Woman Goes Wild Over Hulk Hogan
DOC.TEXT: A 76-year-old admitted ``Hulkamaniac'' says she gets so excited about professional wrestling that she occasionally throws a hold on her 82-year-old husband. ``We've gotten on the floor and I try to have him get out of it,'' said Martha Hersch Gertson, whose husband, Chris, indulges his wife's interest. Mrs. Gertson's prized possession is a card from television wrestler ``Hulk'' Hogan. She sent Hogan a get-well card after he was injured. In reply, Mrs. Gertson got a card that read: ``It is because of you and millions of Hulkamaniacs like you that I have decided to return to the ring. (Signed) Hulk Hogan.'' ``I think I'll frame it,'' Mrs. Gertson said. She takes professional wrestling seriously. ``I get as excited about it as I can and watch it at 2 p.m. most afternoons and on Monday nights. I close the shades and take the phone off the hook,'' Mrs. Gertson said. She said she doesn't think the matches are staged, and prefers professional wrestling to television soap operas. ``If there is anything fake it's a soap opera?'' she asked.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Sees `Some Increase' in Iraq Military Activity
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has detected ``some increase in military activity'' inside Iraq near its borders with Turkey and Syria, but a spokesman said today that there seems little indication that hostilities in the areas were imminent. At a briefing, spokesman Pete Williams declined to offer much detail about the movements. However, asked whether the movements involved air or ground troops, Williams said that as a general matter _ and not necessarily in this case _ such military activity could involve ``flights, training flights, that kind of thing.'' Asked whether the movement indicated increased forces, he said, ``not necessarily.'' ``We are aware of some increase in military activity near the Syrian and Turkish borders, but there is nothing to indicate imminent hostilities, and beyond that I cannot characterize that activity for you,'' Williams said. Williams said that the number of Iraqi forces in and around occupied Kuwait remained stable at about 265,000 troops and about 2,200 tanks. The spokesman said the status of the forces has not changed substantially over the past week, and that while their military posture remained defensive, it could become offensive ``very quickly.''

DOC.HEAD: American Legionnaires Don't Like Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Saddam Hussein is a frequent topic of conversation at American Legion Post 133, where the talk is as hot as Old Glory on fire. ``I think we should drop an atomic bomb on his doorstep,'' said Haley Rhoden. ``I think we should get in there and whip them and get out.'' Others favored assassinating Saddam, whose soldiers invaded Kuwait last month. The Russell Barrett Legion Post has been in operation for 70 years. It was named for a soldier killed in World War I. It has 300 members, most of them World War II veterans. Legionnaires must have served in the military during wartime, and the members here know the cost of war. Near the entrance is a bronze plaque listing the town's World War II dead, and a sheet of paper under glass listing the Vietnam dead. Each meeting ends with a 30-second pause to remember the departed. This is a place where men brag about how many relatives have gone to war, where patriotism is fashionable, and where the word ``peacenik'' is spat rather than spoken. T-shirts for sale behind the bar feature an American flag and say: ``Just Try To Burn This Flag.'' The legionnaires in this Yakima Valley farm town of 3,300 look upon Saddam as a sort of ultimate flag-burner. ``He appears to me to be a little Hitler,'' said Del St. George, an apple grower who served in the Navy in World War II. ``I still have a boy who is 21, and grandsons coming up, and I don't want to see those boys getting shot at,'' St. George said. ``But if they stomp him quick it won't take that long.'' His opinions were shared by several legionnaires after a recent monthly business meeting. The men gathered in the dark bar, with its neon jukebox, television and games, were unanimous in their support of President Bush and the U.S. military effort against Iraq. ``Most veterans would be supportive of what the president is doing,'' said adjutant Jack Yearout. ``I would hope that the American people would have the patriotism and guts to stand behind the president.'' Yearout compared Saddam to Hitler or Stalin. ``Anybody that would gas his own people and use gas against his enemy in spite of the U.N. charter, has to be stopped,'' he said. Ron Butler, a former policeman who is post commander, said the United States was morally obligated to support Kuwait. ``We will lose men, no doubt, but they would be crazy to start actual combat with us,'' Butler said. Farley Bennett, a Coast Guard veteran, said it is important for the nation to make sacrifices to stop Saddam now. ``I had two brothers in Korea and two sons and a brother in Vietnam,'' Bennett said. ``We are hero-happy boys. ``I don't think this is going to end without conflict. There are going to be some boys die on both sides, but at least we've got world support.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NORWALK, Conn.-dated 4th item in rdp to DELETE erroneous reference in last graf to Masons being a Christian group.
DOC.TEXT: Swing Era band leader Lionel Hampton welcomed a service bringing together members of black and white Masonic lodges as a strong step toward racial harmony. He said the event highlighted his 52 years as a Mason. ``This is love, peace and harmony _ breaking down prejudice and kicking it in the pants,'' said the 82-year-old musician, keynote speaker at the service Sunday. ``I've finally seen it come to pass that the black and white brothers can meet together.'' The two lodges, one with 28,000 whites and the other with 2,000 blacks, last year became the first in the United States to grant mutual recognition and certain membership privileges to each other. Recognition allows a Mason to participate in activities in another jurisdiction. The Masons are a fraternal group with 3 million members in the United States and 6 million worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Brandeis and Holy Cross Establish Joint Program in Comparative Religions
DOC.TEXT: Holy Cross and Brandeis University announced Tuesday a joint studies program designed to improve understanding between Christians and Jews and serve as a model for other schools. The Kraft-Hiatt Cooperative Program in Comparative Religion involves the establishment of a professorship in Christian Studies at Brandeis and a professorship in Judaic Studies at Holy Cross. The announcement was made by the Rev. John E. Brooks, S.J., president of Holy Cross and Evelyn E. Handler, president of Brandeis.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leader Calls for `Political Revolution' to End Budget Crisis
With AM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: The president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Tuesday called for a ``political revolution'' to solve the nation's budget problems. ``It's an issue of over spending,'' Richard L. Lesher told reporters at a briefing on the chamber's legislative agenda. ``We've said so many times that to balance the budget, you don't have to cut spending below current levels. You need to cut the growth in spending ...'' Bush administration and congressional negotiators met throughout the weekend but were unable to meet their Monday deadline for reaching agreement on a deficit-reducing package for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Without an agreement, next year's shortfall could surpass $250 billion, the highest ever, and result in severe spending cuts on most federal programs under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. Lesher said ``the whole process is so politicized that it's time for a political revolution, hopefully led by the business community, to demand that the problem be solved the same way all of us solve domestic budget problems or corporate budget problems _ by keeping spending in line with revenue.'' Among the items on the chamber's legislative wish-list are a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution and enactment of line-item veto authority for the president. Under current law, the president must accept or reject in their entirety each of the 13 appropriations bills. Line-item veto authority would permit him to throw out specific portions of the bills without vetoing the entire legislation. Lesher said the chamber is concerned about the effects of forced budget cuts on an economy that the organization predicts will fall into recession later this year. ``We think that ($100 billion in cuts) would be a lot to swallow,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Have Orchestra, Will Travel
DOC.TEXT: The ad said it all _ ``Major Symphony Orchestra. Illustrious History. Will Consider Relocation.'' Members of the beleaguered Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra say the ad is meant to be a tongue-in-cheek gesture to get attention, but it's also a serious offer. Moving, the musicians say, would solve their problems with the orchestra's management and board of directors. Orchestra officials said Monday that the Philharmonic may not open its fall season on time Sept. 22 because the musicians are refusing to negotiate cost savings. The orchestra, which has been running a $2.2 million deficit, asked its musicians in July to agree to a wage freeze, a smaller orchestra size and a shorter season to help cut $1.3 million in operating expenses. Musicians took up a collection last week to run the $300 classified ad in Friday's edition of USA Today. ``We're going to entertain any offers that come as a result of the ad,'' says Frances Morgante, a violinist and chairwoman of the musicians' negotiating team. ``We're a superb orchestra, and everybody admits that. But we constantly have to justify our existence, and we're tired of it,'' added Susie Myers, an English horn player. Management and the Orchestra Committee, which represents the musicians, have not met in two weeks, said Wilfred J. Larson, the orchestra's chairman. ``If there are no talks, we've got to shut the thing down,'' Larson said. The musicians blame bloated front-office spending for the orchestra's problems. Administrators blame the budgetary shortfalls on delayed and reduced funding from the state, county and city, and stalled development efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Refugees' Plight Remains A Nightmare
DOC.TEXT: For each refugee who clears the Jordanian border from Iraq to wait for a flight home, another drags into the makeshift camps in no man's land. Authorities predicted a turn of the tide Monday, with the proviso that they could not predict the flow from Iraq. On Tuesday, Maj. Sabri Rubeihat, the Jordanian spokesman at the border, said 3,000 Asians were processed but 3,000 more arrived. Perhaps 50,000 are backed up at the border, but officials admit they are guessing. One of those still trapped in the refugee camps is Mohammed Sana Ullah from Bangladesh. ``This is a prison camp,'' he said Tuesday, tears streaming down his dusty cheeks as he spoke at the Shaalan III Camp. ``We're dying in this desert.'' ``It's still a nightmare,'' said Jim Nuttal of Save the Children. ``People think it'll all go away, but it won't. This will go on for months.'' Nuttal manages this latest encampment, a cluster of tents on raw, scorpion-infested desert. The Shaalan I and Shaalan II camps also receive refugees _ mostly Asians _ who have made their way Kuwait, where food shortages and scattered shooting are driving out hundreds of thousands of foreign workers. Shaalan III is also called Mercy Camp, but many of the 5,000 Bangladeshis brought here over the past few days from overcrowded Shaalan I say that is a bitter misnomer. Ullah, who left the Bangladesh Air Force to work as a contract sergeant in Kuwait, cornered Nuttal to demand action. First he talked tough, detailing his 15 days' wait in what he called hell. Nuttal was sympathetic. ``We will stop it,'' he said. ``I promise you, every bit of energy ... '' That was as far as he got. Ullah's nerves cracked, and he wailed out his anguish. Sobbing, shaking, he waved an arm toward the tents and trucks and strewn garbage and shouted: ``I'd like to burn all these bloody damned things!'' Around him, a crowd of gesticulating refugees added their own pleas. They said they had seen buses taking people directly from Shaalan I to Amman, meaning later arrivals were getting out first. Even more than the scarce food and water, or the lack of shelter, the camp dwellers railed at the uncertainty. No one knows when they will leave. Ullah suffers from a thyroid condition and is out of medicine. Camp doctors want him to see a specialist, but he's afraid of missing the bus that might take him a step closer to home. He said he has been here 15 days. Friends listened to his complaints and nodded. One just shook his head and observed, ``Kuwait was much better than this.'' When the wind blows, Shaalan III is obliterated by dust. The new latrines stink from 100 yards away. But the most desperate refugees describe Shaalan III as luxurious compared to Shaalan I, which still houses about 30,000 Indians, Bangladeshis, Sri Lankans, Filipinos and other penniless refugees. Camp shelters are marked with bits of cardboard torn from boxes with inscriptions noting arrival dates going back to late August. The bare ground is ankle deep in powdery dust and filth, nearly carpeted with smashed plastic water bottles, rotten tomatoes and rubber shoes too worn out to save. On Tuesday, lunchtime meant a three-hour wait in the sun for two flat pieces of Arab bread, a few small tomatoes and a plastic cup of yogurt. Dinner was another wait for similar fare. ``We wait for everything,'' said Tajdeen Rajmuhammed from Madras, India. ``One hour for a liter of water. Can you wash in one liter? We walk a kilometer to go the bathroom where no one can see us.'' Mostly, they wait for hope. Each new outsider is besieged with questions: about buses, about other camps, about the whereabouts of consular officers. International contributions are in the tens of millions of dollars, and up to 30 special flights a day carry refugees home. Aide workers blame the huge backup on a combination of factors: a proud kingdom that called too late for help; a United Nations tangled in red tape; impoverished home governments; and rich nations worried about other aspects of the Persian Gulf crisis. Most of the refugees have begun appealing directly to television news crews that make the seven-hour round trip from Amman. At Shaalan II, regarded as a model camp next to the others, refugees have painted messages on sheet of cardboard affixed to tents. Filipinos wrote a message to President Corazon Aquino: ``We need airplanes, not sardines.'' Next to it, another reads: ``We don't need promises. Just get us out of here!''

DOC.HEAD: Southerners Say Y'All, But in Baltimore It's Hey, Hawn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CORRECT spelling to diphthong sted dipthong.
DOC.TEXT: Owe-ree-owes are not cookies, hawn. In the city that natives call Bawlmer, Owe-ree-owes are Orioles. Baltimore has a curious mix of Southern, Northern, Pennsylvania Dutch, Appalachian and various immigrant speech patterns. And Bawlmerese is most apparent in its stressed ``o'' sound, heard in words such as oweshun and awl _ that's ocean and oil. ``It's not fully Northern and not fully Southern,'' said Allan Metcalfe, executive secretary of the American Dialect Society. ``For example, Baltimore is on the border of where `cot' and `caught' are said the same,'' he said. Hon becomes hawn and the Highlandtown neighborhood is known as Hollandtown. Speech pathologist Linda Katz Wilner, who helps people rid themselves of accents, said the peculiar ``o'' sound is produced by the forced, constricted method Baltimoreans use to produce vowel sounds. ``People speak with a very closed mouth, a lot of tension in the lips,'' Wilner said. ``They're really not even rounding their lips. It's almost a pumping of the jaw. ``Certain other sounds are reduced,'' Wilner said. ``Like the `oi' sound in boil. People say `ball the water.' It's a diphthong. It's supposed to be two sounds and they make it into one. For example, instead of `my mother,' they say `mamother.''' So, next time a Hollandtown hawn asks what you want with your crab cake, say, ``I'll have a Cowe-oke, but make it quick because I'm going downy oweshun.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Dissidents Hope to Form Government-in-Exile
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0577 for all needing.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of exiled Iraqi opposition groups are meeting in Syria to develop a strategy for toppling Saddam Hussein and hope to form a government-in-exile, dissident sources said Tuesday. About 12 parties and organizations were represented at the meeting, which began in the Syrian capital of Damascus in late August and is expected to conclude in late September, the sources said. ``We're basically trying to produce a political alternative to the present regime,'' said a member of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, one of the two main Kurdish organizations, in an interview from London. The dissident sources, all speaking on condition of anonymity from Paris and London, said they hoped the meeting would conclude with the formation of an Iraqi government-in-exile. A leader of the Iraqi Islamic Labor Party, Abdel-Ameer Kassem, told the Saudi Arabian newspaper Al-Yawm that opposition factions had also ``agreed on a joint plan to overthrow the regime of Saddam Hussein.'' But in interviews, other dissidents said they wanted substantial international support before beginning an internal war against Saddam. ``Kurds and others would love to open up an internal front against Saddam, but this is not yet it. This is not a declaration of all-out war inside Iraq,'' a Paris source said. ``We're fearful of incurring his wrath, having him turn his army against us without having any outside support.'' For decades, Kurdish guerrillas in northern Iraq waged a fierce battle for autonomy against Saddam's troops. But in 1988, shortly after Iraq and Iran ended their eight-year war, Saddam launched an offensive against the rebels that included chemical weapons. It was the first time any government had been reported to have used chemical weapons on its own people, and it forced the rebels to pull back somewhat. The various Kurdish groups opposed to Saddam have an estimated 20,000 armed men. The Patriotic Union member said from London the Kurds were ready to face even the horrors of chemical warfare again, ``if we have some guarantees that after Saddam is gone we'll have a role in the new government.'' One source said ``there's a lot of potential for making trouble'' for Saddam while his attention is turned to his standoff with other nations resulting from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``It's not a question of numbers. These are trained and experienced guerrillas and they could tie up a lot of Iraqi troops if they chose to do so. They have not chosen to do so _ yet,'' the source said. But the sources said the opposition inside Iraq is fragmented, weak and deep underground, and much of the 16 million population has been cowed. During a break in the Syrian meeting, Patriotic Union leader Jalal Talabani visited Iraqi dissidents living in Arab, European and U.S. cities in a renewed effort to organize the opposition. ``These are groups holding very diverse political ideas, and the circumstances are not easy. It may take a little while to produce the basic framework of the government we'd like to see,'' another source said.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Sentenced To Maximum In Attack On Jogger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to move up youths' protestation of innocence; add quote from defense lawyer, explain acquittal on attempted murder charge. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `She battled...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers who continued to profess their innocence received maximum prison sentences of five to 10 years today for the rape and assault of a woman jogging in Central Park. ``Give me the max,'' one of the defiant youths, Yusef Salaam, told Judge Thomas Galligan before sentence was passed. ``Sooner or later the truth will come out.'' Galligan, in turn, denounced the three for showing no remorse, ``only defiance.'' On the night the jogger was attacked, he said, ``Central Park was turned into a torture chamber by mindless marauders seeking a thrill.'' Although the youths were tried as adults because of the seriousness of the charges, Galligan had to sentence them as juveniles because they were under 16 when the jogger was attacked on April 19, 1989. An adult would have faced up to eight and one-third to 25 years in prison. Salaam and Antron McCray, both 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, were convicted Aug. 18 of attacking the woman and assaulting two men the same night. They were acquitted of the top count of attempted murder and a lesser count of sodomy. ``The intensity of the violence that occurred that night is something no rational mind can explain,'' the judge said. He denied motions to have the three sentenced in Family Court, asking, ``Is sexual brutality of a woman something that's acceptable or tolerable because it happens at the hands of a 14- or 15-year-old? The answer is obvious.'' At the hearing, William Kunstler, an attorney for Salaam, called the proceeding ``a legal lynching.'' ``I don't expect anything to happen here other than the judge to sign the maximum,'' he told Galligan. ``I'm so sure of it I've already filled out appeal papers.'' The teens were accused of raping and trying to kill the jogger, then 28, during her nightly run in Central Park. She had lost at least three-fourths of her blood and spent two weeks in a coma, a doctor said. Jurors said later they acquitted the youths of the attempted murder charge because they were unsure the teens intended to kill the woman. She battled back from her near-fatal injuries, eventually returning to her Wall Street firm, where she is now a vice president. She has resumed jogging. The woman, whose name has been left out of news stories, testified at the trial about her continuing vision, balance and other problems; she has no memory of the attack. Each defendant spoke briefly before sentence was passed. Salaam read a rambling, rap-style poem he had composed in jail before he was bailed out; during the reading, he stopped once to glare at prosecutors. ``I have not yet begun to fight,'' he concluded. ``This is only the beginning.'' McCray told the judge, ``I'm not going to let this stop me. I'm going to make it.'' Santana, who struck the meekest tone of the three, said simply, ``Everyone knows I'm innocent of the crime. I never did it.'' After the sentence was passed, they were quickly moved from the courtroom by corrections officers as some spectators in the room raised their arms in support. The attack horrified New Yorkers because of its randomness and brutality, but it also became an inspiration to people who followed accounts of her recovery. During the trial, a detective testified that Santana told him he counted 33 youths who entered the park shortly after 9 p.m. the night of the attacks to ```wild' some joggers ... beat up and rip off joggers and cyclists.'' Their first victim was Antonio Diaz, a man they referred to as ``the bum.'' Diaz was kicked and pummeled senseless before the group accosted several bicycle riders. The bikers escaped injury. Statements made by the defendants figured prominently in the trial. Defense lawyers argued that the statments were coerced. In a videotaped statement to police, McCray said that when the youths saw the jogger on the East 102nd Street crossdrive during her nightly six-mile run, ``We all charged her.'' The defendants told detectives the naked woman was struck with a metal pipe, bashed in the head and face with a brick, cut on the legs with a knife and sexually attacked in a frenzy of violence, prosecutors said. Later, the rampaging youths attacked several other people _ teacher John Loughlin, hospitalized for two days with his injuries; banker David Lewis, who escaped serious injuries because of his speed; and John Goode, a British Airways employee who was punched. The three defendants were convicted of assault and robbery in the attack on Loughlin and of assaulting Lewis. They also were convicted of first-degree riot. On Monday, Galligan on Monday set a trial date of Oct. 11 for two other defendants, Kharey Wise, 18, and Kevin Richardson, 15. The teen-agers will be tried together in Manhattan. Another defendant, Steve Lopez, 15, will be tried separately, probably not until next year.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Vie for Chance to Take on Unpopular Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 9 p.m. EDT; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Three Democrats bid for the prize of Rhode Island's Democratic nomination for governor Tuesday, buoyed by indications that any of them could defeat Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete. The three were Providence Mayor Joseph R. Paolino Jr., Warwick Mayor Francis X. Flaherty and businessman Bruce G. Sundlun, who lost to DiPrete in 1986 and 1988. DiPrete also faced a primary, but the challenge by former radio talk show host Steve White was considered minor. DiPrete, who two years ago enjoyed voter approval ratings topping 70 percent, is reeling in the polls. His approval now hovers around 20 percent and is sinking in concert with the New England economy. ``I think it would take almost a miracle for him to come back,'' said Professor Darrell M. West, who conducts polls for Brown University's A. Alfred Taubman Center for Public Policy. In the 2nd Congressional District, Democrat Edward P. Beard, a former hosuepainter whose trademark was the brush he carried in a coat pocket on Capitol Hill from 1975-80, tried to win his old seat back. He faced a stiff challenge from state Sen. John F. Reed, who had the Democratic endorsement, lawyer Charles Gifford III and state Rep. Rodney Driver. In the Republican 2nd District primary, accountant David Gingrella tried to portray environmentalist Trudy Coxe as an opportunist who ran only at the governor's urging. The seat is open because Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider is challenging 30-year veteran Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell.

With the Democrats smelling DiPrete's blood, they spent $6 million by Labor Day in one of the nastiest primary campaigns ever waged in a state known for its down-and-dirty politics. Flaherty cast himself as the campaign's conscience while Paolino and Sundlun tangled like Roman gladiators. Sundlun accused Paolino of being a machine politician beholden to contributors. Paolino shot back that Sundlun just hadn't won anything, and that he had run the Outlet stores into the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Russian Parliament Endorse Far-Reaching Economic Reforms
LaserPhotos MOSB4,5
DOC.TEXT: Russia's parliament voted overwhelmingly Tuesday for a radical economic reform program, and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he favored it over a moderate plan proposed by his prime minister. Gorbachev's surprise statement undercut the authority of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and added momentum to calls for Ryzhkov's resignation. It also increased the chances that the radical plan, drafted largely by economist Stanislav Shatalin, will go into effect throughout the Soviet Union. Shatalin's plan calls for transferring most economic authority from the national government to the country's 15 constituent republics. The republics could then move rapidly to free prices, privatize government industries, legalize private ownership of land and take other steps toward a market-based economy. The national Supreme Soviet legislature and the parliament of Russia, the largest of the 15 republics, met separately Tuesday to consider the competing proposals. Ryzhkov addressed the national legislature in a cavernous marble hall at the Kremlin, the centuries-old walled fortress that is the seat of communist power. He charged that the Shatalin plan would lower living standards by 30 percent, force one out of every four collective farms into bankruptcy, and cause rapid inflation by decontrolling prices on about 75 percent of basic consumer products. Ryzhkov called for retaining central control over the economy and making a much slower transition to a market-based system. He recommended keeping price controls on most food and household products while raising the cost of some major items, such as televisions, radios and refrigerators. He also said imports of consumer goods and medicines would have to be cut by one-third because of a shortage of hard currency, and he warned that the government budget would have to be cut to prevent the $96 billion deficit from ballooning. Ryzhkov's speech caused commotion in the hall as some delegates, led by Anatoly Sobchak, the reformist mayor of Leningrad, demanded copies of the Shatalin plan and the opportunity to adopt it. ``If you ask me, I like the Shatalin plan better,'' Gorbachev told the delegates in an animated, 15-minute speech about the need to stabilize the Soviet economy, which is plagued by shortages of bread, meat, paper, gasoline, tobacco and other ordinary goods. ``If there is a real plan to stabilize finances, money circulation, the ruble and the market, then we should adopt the Shatalin idea,'' Gorbachev said. Pounding the back of his hand on the lectern, the 59-year-old Soviet leader defended the concept of a free market, which is little understood and much feared by ordinary Soviet citizens. When price controls are gradually lifted, he said, ``we'll have real prices that will estimate who is worth what. Then powerful stimuli will be released for structural changes. ``Of course these will be painful changes. But so be it,'' he said. In an auditorium 1{ miles away, the Russian parliament voted 213-1 with four abstentions to adopt the Shatalin plan and warned that if the national legislature did not follow suit, Russia would proceed on its own. ``These are two programs that cannot be combined and cannot even supplement each other. They proceed from completely different political and economic assumptions,'' said Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic. ``And if the (Soviet) Union does not follow this program, we, Russia, as a sovereign state, will take this route ourselves,'' he said. Russia is one of 13 Soviet republics that have declared independence or sovereignty, defined as the right to overrule national laws. The debates in both the Russian parliament and the national legislature were punctuated by calls for the resignation of Ryzhkov, 60, and his entire Cabinet. There appeared to be strong support for such a motion in the Russian parliament, especially after Yeltsin alleged that ``the current government will not implement this (radical reform) plan. They will sabotage it.'' However, Yeltsin persuaded the delegates to wait to see whether the Supreme Soviet adopts the Shatalin plan. In the national legislature, the moves against Ryzhkov were derailed for the day when the chairman, Anatoly Lukyanov, asked for a vote on whether to put the prime minister's resignation on the agenda. The motion failed, 328-28 with 30 abstentions. But a delegate claimed that if Lukyanov had phrased the motion differently _ to call for a vote of no confidence rather than resignation _ it would have passed. Ryzhkov indicated that he might step aside if his plan is defeated. ``I take responsibility for it before the people and the Supreme Soviet,'' he said. Leading economists and politicians, including Sobchak, have urged Ryzhkov to step down because of his failure to deal with the nation's economic problems. The prime minister's standing also was hurt Tuesday by a front-page article in the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda that said he had recently bought a luxurious country home, or dacha, from the government for 47,000 rubles, a fraction of its real worth. In parliament, Ryzhkov denied the story, saying he did not own a dacha but uses one owned by the government.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOP 11 grafs new with House beginning debate on defense bill, Pentagon comment; picks up 3rd graf pvs, bgng, The defense...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today threatened a veto if Congress approves a $283 billion defense budget that slashes strategic progobert Cummings, Deanna Durbin, Greer Garson, Olivia DeHavilland, Don Ameche, Gene Kelly, George Burns, Bob Hope, Dorothy Lamour, Joan Fontaine, Red Skelton, Paul Henreid, Sylvia Sidney, Claire Trevor, Hedy Lamarr, Luise Rainer, Jean Arthur, Joan Bennett, Donald O'Connor and Jackie Cooper.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed AMs, Sept. 19

DOC.HEAD: Friends Say They Could Have Averted Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Friends of a man who shot himself on the roof of a high-rise building after a five-hour standoff with police say the suicide could have been averted had they been allowed to talk with him. Police disagreed. At least five people said they approached police during Friday's standoff and asked to speak with Paul Fisher but weren't permitted to do so. ``If they let one of us up to see him, the guy would be alive now,'' said Dave Dietz. ``I feel it in my heart.'' Police Chief Mayer DeRoy said Fisher didn't want to talk to anyone but DeRoy and the police officers who were on the roof trying to persuade him to surrender. Allowing friends on the roof could have aggravated the situation and endangered the friends, the chief said. ``Paul Fisher didn't want anyone up there to talk to,'' DeRoy said. ``He made that eminently clear.'' Fisher, 30, of Pittsburgh, fired at least 11 shots into the air from the top of the apartment building during the standoff but no one else was struck. He left a suicide note saying he hoped to draw fire from police. Fisher's friends, speaking Monday at a pub frequented by Fisher, said he would not have hurt them or anyone else. The friends added they could have spoken to Fisher by cellular phone without being endangered.

DOC.HEAD: Three Whites Charged in Beating Death of Black Youth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Three white teen-agers have been charged with murder and ethnic intimidation in the clubbing death of a black Detroit teen-ager who returned a shouted insult while riding through a suburb. Charles Gibson, 19, was a passenger Saturday in a car driven by a white friend when a group of whites pulled along side in a pickup truck, the friend said Monday. The white teen-agers yelled, ``Hey, nigger,'' and Gibson shouted back, `Hey, honkie,'' said Timothy Lange, 20. He said Gibson and the whites got out of the vehicles at a red light and a fight broke out. A witness reported seeing Gibson hit about 25 times on the head with a long wooden stick, said William Lucas, a police detective in Roseville, a mostly white, lower-middle class suburb. Gibson died Sunday at the University of Michigan Medical Center. Raymond C. Morris, 17, of Fraser and John J. Whitman, 19, of Roseville appeared in court Monday and were ordered jailed without bond until hearings set for Sept. 20. A 14-year-old from Roseville was returned to the county youth home, with bond set at $110,000. Morris and Whitman face life in prison if convicted as charged; the other youth could be committed to the state Department of Social Services until age 19. Gibson's mother said her son neither sought nor ducked trouble. ``He didn't like violence, but yet he didn't want people to push him around and call him names,'' Jama Gunn said. ``He named his left fist Smith & Wesson. He named his right fist .38.''

DOC.HEAD: Pizza Hut Comes to Moscow: `A Piece of America,' Says Happy Diner
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: A slice of American life was served up to hungry Muscovites Tuesday as Pizza Hut opened two restaurants in a city that is no stranger to shortages. While housewives queued nearby for scarce foodstuffs and consumer goods, hundreds of curious young people and families waited patiently in line in cool weather for hours to sample deep-pan pizzas, garlic bread, Pepsi and fare from what was billed as the first Soviet salad bars. ``It's a piece of America,'' gushed Georg Tsukonov, a 20-year-old student, outside the new Pizza Hut on Kutuzovsky Prospekt, the main road leading west from downtown. ``It looks like a museum,'' marveled sailor Yevgeni Gerko, gazing at the bright red furnishings, brass trim, fake tropical plants and smiling young waitresses. A large, deep-pan Super Supreme pizza with everything on it _ pepperoni, ham, spicy pork, beef, mushrooms, onions, black olives and green peppers _ emerged from an oven at the restaurant at noon, marking the official opening. Waiting customers clutching Pizza Hut flags emblazoned with the company's red roof logo, the Stars and Stripes, and the hammer and sickle, oohed and ahhed, then excitedly tried to rush the door. Throughout the day, Pizza Hut officials kept the doors locked and struggled to limit entrance to only a handful of people at a time. The Kutuzovsky site has two identical dining rooms, for ruble-and dollar-paying customers, and a takeout counter. Located near a large foreigners' compound on the wide boulevard that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev takes to work every day, it expects to make 5,000 pizzas a day. The smaller Pizza Hut on Gorky Street, minutes from the Kremlin, has a takeout window selling slices of pizza for rubles. The Moscow menus are similar to those in the West, with the addition of local favorites like borscht and a Moscow seafood pizza: salmon, smoked sardines and onions. Only nine combination pizzas are offered and no substitutions are allowed. ``People don't know what the products are,'' said regional operations director Andy Rafalet. ``Let's make the choice a little easier.'' The choice was easy at the salad bar: no lettuce, but lots of cabbage, a Soviet staple. Pizza Hut claims it's the first Moscow restaurant to serve coleslaw, as opposed to pickled, cooked or raw cabbage. Student Irina Shushukina said beer was being limited to one bottle a person, and wine to one bottle per couple. Despite chronic food shortages and a poor food distribution system in the Soviet Union, Pizza Hut said it hopes to buy most of its raw ingredients locally, including flour for the dough. The restaurants' 300 young employees were hired from 3,500 applicants who replied to an ad in the Moscow Communist Party youth newspaper. Besides learning how to make and serve pizzas, most had to be taught to smile at customers, not snarl or ignore them like many Moscow restaurant workers. ``You'll never see so many smiles elsewhere in Moscow,'' Tsukonov said. ``Maybe they're pretending, but it's fantastic when you see people really smile. You understand that you are something in the world, not part of a crowd.'' The restaurants are the result of three years' negotiations, even though Pizza Hut's parent company Pepsico Inc. has been doing business in the Soviet Union for decades. Pepsico chairman Don Kendall cajoled then-Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev into tasting Pepsi at a 1959 trade fair. Photographs of Khrushchev and then-U.S. Vice President Richard Nixon sipping Pepsi from paper cups were published in newspapers throughout the world. Pizza Hut said it expects to serve 50,000 customers a week, roughly seven times the turnover of any of its American outlets. McDonald's, which introduced American-style fast food to the Soviet Union in January, still sells about 5,000 burgers an hour. The restaurants are part of a $3 billion trade deal, the largest ever signed between the Soviet Union and a U.S. corporation.

DOC.HEAD: Prisons Will Temporarily Keep Inmates Away From Dog Training
DOC.TEXT: The practice of inmates wrestling and fighting with tracking dogs at the end of training exercises was temporarily halted Tuesday by the state prison board. Members of the Texas Board of Criminal Justice unanimously approved the recommendations of a board subcommittee that the ``contact'' practice be suspended until inmates have more protective gear and policies are in place to ensure that only volunteers are used for the exercise. Inmates still would be used in other aspects of dog training. Until now, an inmate would be given a head start and go into hiding or climb a tree, and then, when the inmate was located by the dog, he would briefly fight with the animal. Several prison board members said there was no evidence that the dog training exercises had been conducted improperly. The dog training came under fire after board Vice Chairman Jerry Hodge took two companions on an inmate hunt for sport. Hodge later had jackets made for them that dubbed the trip ``The Ultimate Hunt.'' He has since apologized for the jackets but has defended the practice of using inmates in the exercise. The board approved a formal selection system for inmates who want to get involved with the dog program, with assurances that the inmates are not being coerced. The prison system has about 1,000 dogs at various units.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Fatalistic at Daughter's Sentencing Trial
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys for a woman whose murder of a teen-ager was videotaped had difficulty getting even her mother to convince the court she should not be sent to the electric chair. Carol Hunt testified she doesn't want her 21-year-old daughter, Deidre, to be executed but ``if it happens, it happens.'' The defense testimony Monday was followed Tuesday by prosecutors' presentation of psychologists to address Deidre Hunt's emotional stability. Earlier in the sentencing hearing, Gainesville psychologist Clifford A. Levin testified for the defense that Ms. Hunt is an emotionally damaged person who was threatened and controlled by her former boss and lover, Konstantinos Fotopoulos, 31. Ms. Hunt has been convicted of first-degree murder in the shooting deaths of Mark Ramsey, 19, and Bryan Chase, 18. Police say Chase was betrayed and killed after shooting Lisa Fotopoulos, who survived her wounds and divorced her husband, Konstantinos. Circuit Judge James Foxman and the court last week viewed a 57-second videotape showing Ms. Hunt on Oct. 20, 1989, shooting a teen-ager tied to a tree. Assistant State Attorney David Damore said it was the execution of Ramsey, filmed by Fotopoulos. The judge also saw a videotape of Ms. Hunt's confession to police when she was arrested in November. In it, she also admitted to the murder-for-hire plot against Lisa Fotopoulos, which led to Ms. Hunt's conviction for attempted murder and conspiracy, and pending charges against Fotopoulos. The testimony of Ms. Hunt's mother and that of several aunts, uncles and cousins focused on emotional and physical trauma they say Deidre Hunt suffered. This included being raped at 11 by a neighbor and being rejected by her biological father. Carol Hunt, 43, admitted shaking and hitting her daughter as a youngster whenever she felt like it. ``It depended on my mood _ whether I hit her or hugged her,'' Mrs. Hunt testified. ``I ignored that she told me a 30-year-old man raped her at 11,'' Carol Hunt testified.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Tight-lipped on Helping Iraq Beat Sanctions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran's leaders are tight-lipped about whether they will help their old adversary Iraq break U.N. sanctions. But analysts believe Tehran won't risk international outcry even though it wants an agreeable Iraq on its border. After talks with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, the first senior official to visit Tehran in 15 years, the government announced Monday it would revive full diplomatic relations with its former war foe. Aziz is believed to have requested that Iran allow food, medicine and other essential commodities to move across its 730-mile border with Iraq in violation of the international embargo imposed on Baghdad for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iranian newspapers have argued that the country would not violate the sanctions by supplying food and medicine because humanitarian aid is permitted under the U.N. Security Council resolution imposing the embargo. Unconfirmed reports from Baghdad said the Iranians already have allowed rice, flour and wheat across the northern border. Western analysts believe Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani is keeping everyone guessing on what Iran will do in hopes of striking a bargain with the West in return for adhering to the embargo. Such a deal could include financial aid for Iran, they say. A diplomat in Tehran, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``Whenever we've tried to analyze their situation logically we found we were invariably on the wrong track.'' However, a Western economic expert in Tehran, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said smuggling along the frontier was difficult to control and was certain to pick up as Iranians cash in on Iraq's burgeoning black market. ``Anything more substantial than that would be politically and economically dangerous for Iran because it would give the international community the idea that they were subverting U.N. sanctions,'' he said. Shaul Bakhash, a professor of history at Washington's George Mason University, said in a telephone interview: ``It defies logic that the Iranians would do anything to help Iraq consolidate their hold over Kuwait.'' Bakhash, an Iranian exile and former Tehran newspaper editor, has written extensively on Iran. Aziz's visit and the restoration of full ties came three weeks after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, under increasing pressure from the buildup of U.S.-led forces in the gulf, caved in to Iranian conditions to formally end the nations' 1980-88 war. Iraq granted Tehran partial control of its sole access to the sea and withdrew its troops from Iranian territory seized during the war. ``The Iranians have followed a clever policy of taking everything that came their way since the invasion of Kuwait,'' said another diplomat in Tehran. ``But they're fully aware that if Saddam were to survive this crisis he would not want to share his power in the gulf with anyone and that they could be next on his hit list.'' He cautioned against forming hard conclusions on Iranian intentions because it was impossible to speculate on behind-the-scenes maneuvering among members of the country's ruling theocracy. Before Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, Iranian foreign exchange earnings, desperately needed to revive its moribund economy, were expected to fall short by at least one-third of the $17 billion needed in 1990, according to Western estimates. But this was revised sharply upward after the price of oil, Iran's principal export item, soared following the Iraqi invasion. Experts now say revenues could reach $19 billion this year. That would strengthen Rafsanjani's hand against Iran's radicals, his political rivals, who are bitterly opposed to his reforms and efforts to re-establish ties with the West.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainer Shirley MacLaine Plans More Singing, Less Dancing
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Shirley MacLaine says she is scaling down her dancing and adding more singing to her repertoire as age takes its toll. ``It's real life that's a problem. I can't run for a cab in the rain in the streets of New York anymore,'' the 56-year-old Miss MacLaine said.
