After 40 movies, five TV specials, six books and a half-century of dancing, Miss MacLaine said on the new syndicated TV show ``Personalities'' that it was time to limit her activities. ``I think I'll just scale down the dancing,'' she said in the interview broadcast Monday. ``It isn't that direly necessary to me. At this stage, I think it's bombastic because of my age you can still do this stuff. ``But I think I'll just pare down as age creeps up. I'll sing more. I'll bring acting to song and acting to dance. I've got it mapped out so I won't be a blithering idiot if I can't dance anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Called in to Search Woods for Evidence
DOC.TEXT: Investigators seeking the killer of five college students called for military help Tuesday to comb 10 square miles of woodland where a suspect reportedly went on nighttime ``reconnaissance missions.'' Authorities would say only that they have a ``good idea'' of what they are looking for, and that the search could strengthen or weaken the case against 18-year-old University of Florida freshman Edward Lewis Humphrey. ``This is based upon some information that he enjoyed being in the woods, that he may have camped out, and enjoyed being solitary in wooded areas,'' said police spokeswoman Lt. Sadie Darnell. ``We don't want any information to go unchecked.'' Several hundred members of the Florida National Guard, along with reserve Army and Navy units, were being called up to assist in the search of several heavily wooded, marshy areas around Humphrey's apartment in southwest Gainesville. Alachua County Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann said the search could begin as early as Thursday. Metal detectors, dog teams and deep-woods experts also will be used. Mann again emphasized that Humphrey is only one of eight suspects in the five gruesome slayings of the students. Four were enrolled at the University of Florida, the fifth victim was a student at Santa Fe Community College. ``This search does not denote that Edward Humphrey is `the' suspect, and the only suspect,'' he said. ``A lot of resources have been poured into suspects just as important as him.'' Humphrey became a suspect in the slayings through a canvass of the off-campus student apartment areas where the victims lived. People told investigators Humphrey was a volatile person with emotional problems who wore military fatigues, had a fascination for knives and went into the woods on nighttime ``reconnaissance missions,'' police have said. Humphrey was jailed in lieu of $1.1 million bail in Brevard County on charges in the Aug. 30 beating of his grandmother, an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County, and an Aug. 25 assault on two male UF students. Genetic tests were being run on blood and semen samples. The DNA analysis could take weeks, police said. Police balked at saying the semen indicated the victims had been sexually assaulted. The nude, mutilated bodies of Sonya Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26 in their apartment. The next morning, Christa Hoyt, 18, was found decapitated in her nearby duplex. Manuel Taboada, and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found dead Aug. 28 in another nearby apartment. Investigators have described the killer as shrewd and methodical. They have reportedly said he left taunting ``messages'' to them, arranged body parts at the slaying scene for maximum shock value, and enjoyed the power he's had over the life of this college town.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Opposes Anti-Obscenity Curbs on Arts Endowment
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan study commission on Monday urged Congress not to impose new anti-obscenity restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts, declaring that Americans must ``put up with much we do not like'' to preserve freedom of artistic expression. The 12-member panel also urged NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer to scrap a controversial requirement that grant recipients sign a pledge that they will not use federal money to produce works that might be deemed obscene. Frohnmayer has repeatedly resisted demands that he eliminate the pledge, which has created a furor in the arts community, until federal courts rule on lawsuits challenging its constitutionality. He refused comment on the commission's report. At the same time, the commission proposed a major overhaul of the endowment's grant-making procedures to ensure that the NEA serves the interests of the American public and not a narrow constituency of artists. The panel concluded that ``the endowment is not, in setting policy and making grants, adequately meeting its public responsibilities at the present time'' as steward of taxpayer funds. It proposed that the NEA chairman be given sole, explicit authority to make final grant decisions and that the growing power of ``peer review panels'' that select grant applications for approval be diminished to an advisory role. The 94-page report of the commission, established by Congress last fall, drew mixed reviews from lawmakers trying to negotiate a compromise bill that would extend the endowment's life beyond Sept. 30, when its statutory authority expires. Rep. Tom Coleman, R-Mo., applauded the report as a possible framework for a compromise, but criticized the panel for rejecting his proposal to shift as much as 60 percent of federal grant money to the control of state arts agencies. Coleman also served notice that the House probably will ignore the commission's plea and approve some sort of ban on federal subsidies for pornographic or blasphemous art, even if it only embraces the Supreme Court's guidelines on obscenity. The commission, appointed by President Bush and the House and Senate leadership, said it unanimously opposed legislative curbs on the content of works financed by the arts endowment. ``Content restrictions may raise serious constitutional issues, would be inherently ambiguous and would almost certainly involve the endowment and the Department of Justice in costly and unproductive lawsuits,'' the panel said. Instead, it suggested that Congress approve a ``preamble'' to the NEA reauthorization bill declaring simply that the endowment ``serves all of the people'' and ``reflects the high place the nation accords to the fostering of mutual respect for the disparate beliefs and values among us.'' The commission added: ``Maintaining the principle of an open society requires all of us, at times, to put up with much we do not like, but the bargain has proved in the long run a good one.'' The independent panel was created in October to examine NEA operations. At the same time, at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Congress amended the endowment's $171 million budget to prohibit using federal funds for works that ``may be considered obscene.'' Conservative lawmakers and religious fundamentalists were angered by NEA grants for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, which contained sexually graphic images, and by artist Andres Serrano, which they denounced as sacrilegious. The commission's report concluded with an appeal for a dampening of the emotionalism and partisan sniping over the endowment, which co-chairman Leonard Garment, a Washington lawyer, called ``an American treasure very much worth preserving.'' ``There are many individuals on both sides of the current debate who think the endowment a convenient and newsworthy vehicle to advance their own objectives,'' the panel said. ``Some do not care a great deal about whether the agency survives. America has had more than enough of this uncompromising kind of behavior.''

DOC.HEAD: Lobbyist Defends Role in Bluebonnet S&L Deal
DOC.TEXT: A lobbyist on Tuesday defended his efforts to help a client win a lucrative government-subsidized takeover of 15 savings and loans and said he was under attack chiefly because he used to work for George Bush. ``I am proud of my service in the public and private sectors,'' Robert J. Thompson told the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on business rights. ``I would do nothing to dishonor this record. I have done nothing to dishonor this record.'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, chairman of the subcommittee, said lobbyists' practice of selling access to government officials ``goes directly to the heart of the simmering frustration people are feeling about Washington and its ways, as well as the boiling outrage they are expressing about the savings and loan debacle.'' Metzenbaum and other senators questioned Thompson about what he did to help James Fail, a Phoenix investor, take over the 15 Texas savings and loans for a $1,000 cash outlay and win well over $1.8 billion in federal subsidies. As a result of those subsidies, Metzenbaum said, the Bluebonnet Savings Bank of Dallas that grew out of the takeover is the nation's most profitable savings and loan. Metzenbaum suggested Fail bought Thompson's assistance because of Thompson's associations with high officials. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, asked whether there was anything out of the ordinary in how he dealt on behalf of Fail. ``No, sir. Nothing at all,'' Thompson replied. ``The process that resulted in the creation of the Bluebonnet Savings Bank was conducted with and supervised by officials of the federal government and I fully followed all rules of propriety.'' He added: ``I feel very strongly one reason I am here was that I used to work for George Bush.'' Thompson was an adviser to Bush when he was vice president, and also served for a time as an assistant to President Reagan. If Bluebonnet continues to prosper, Thompson and his company stand to gain, in addition to their retainer and hourly fees, 2 percent of Fail's earnings from the savings and loan plus a $160,000 bonus. The subcommittee began looking into Fail's takeover after disclosures that he was able to do it with only $1,000 cash out of pocket and $70 million of loans from insurance companies he controlled. During the investigation, the panel learned that Fail had not disclosed that he had entered a guilty plea to a fraud indictment against one of his corporations. Federal regulators have testified since that the plea should have disqualified Fail from taking over the savings and loans. Those regulators, led by M. Danny Wall, who headed the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said they did nothing special for Thompson. ``We've learned enough about the Bluebonnet deal to know that all was not negotiated on the up and up,'' Metzenbaum said. If regulators subjected other takeover deals completed in 1988 to the same scrutiny given Bluebonnet and took appropriate action, he said, ``billions of dollars will be recouped for the U.S. treasury.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Hijacker Sentenced to Four Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A district court on Tuesday sentenced a 19-year-old Soviet hijacker to four years in prison. Mikhail Mokretsov had surrendered to police after forcing a domestic Soviet airliner to Stockholm in July. The prosecutor asked that Mokretsov be expelled to the Soviet Union after serving his sentence. The court rejected the plea, saying Mokretsov was only 18-years-old at the time of the hijacking and that it was unlikely he would commit other crimes in Sweden. Thomas Rothpfeffer, Mokretsov's attorney, said he was ``satisfied and relieved'' that the court decided not to expel his client. But he said the sentence was too harsh considering his client's age and the circumstances. Mokretsov was one of three young Soviets who hijacked airliners to Sweden in June and July. Courts extradited the other two Soviets, saying Sweden should not become a haven for hijackers. For humanitarian reasons, Mokretsov was not sent back. He had gone on a hunger strike, saying he would rather die in Sweden than be jailed in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Jogger Convict: `Give me the Max'; Gets his Wish
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Three defiant teen-agers, including one who challenged the judge to ``Give me the max,'' received maximum sentences Tuesday of five to 10 years in prison for the rape and assault of a woman jogger in Central Park. Judge Thomas Galligan denounced the three for showing only defiance. He described them as ``mindless marauders seeking a thrill'' who turned the park into a torture chamber. Although the seriousness of the charges allowed the youths to be tried as adults, Galligan had to sentence them as juveniles because they were under age 16 when the jogger was attacked. An adult would have faced up to eight and one-third to 25 years in prison. If their appeals fail, the youths will be eligible for parole in five years. Yusef Salaam and Antron McCray, each 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, were convicted Aug. 18 of attacking the woman and assaulting two men during a ``wilding'' spree that night. They were acquitted of the top count of attempted murder and a lesser count of sodomy. The jogger, an investment banker, was attacked on April 19, 1989, while running in a relatively isolated section of Central Park. Race _ she was white, her alleged attackers were black or Hispanic _ and the city's growing concern with street crime made the case a sensation. The woman, then 28, suffered brain damage, lost at least three-fourths of her blood and spent two weeks in a coma, doctors said. The woman, whose name has been left out of news reports, testified that she has continuing vision, balance and other problems, and has no memory of the attack. She battled back from her near-fatal injuries, eventually returning to her Wall Street firm, where she is now a vice president. She also has resumed jogging. Each of the youths addressed the court before Galligan sentenced them. Salaam was the most defiant. He read a rambling, rap-style poem he said he had composed in jail before he was bailed out. ``I look upon this legal lynching as a test by my God Allah,'' he told Galligan. ``I and many others know I told the truth. I would never disrespect my own religion by lying.'' ``Give me the max,'' he said. ``Sooner or later the truth will come out.'' McCray told the judge: ``I'm not going to let this stop me. I'm going to make it.'' Santana, whose tone was the mildest, said simply: ``Everyone knows I'm innocent of the crime. I never did it.'' Before he announced the sentence, Galligan said that ``the intensity of the violence that occurred that night is something no rational mind can explain.'' He denied motions to have the three sentenced in Family Court, saying: ``Is sexual brutality of a woman something that's acceptable or tolerable because it happens at the hands of a 14- or 15-year-old? The answer is obvious.'' Salaam had a new attorney at the sentencing: William Kunstler, who implied that the defendants' videotaped confessions were coerced: ``We all know what black youths in back rooms will say to white cops.'' ``I don't expect anything to happen here other than the judge to sign the maximum,'' he told Galligan. ``I'm so sure of it I've already filled out appeal papers.'' During the trial, a detective testified that Santana told him he counted 33 youths who entered the park the night of the attacks to `` `wild' some joggers ... beat up and rip off joggers and cyclists.'' McCray said on videotape that when the youths saw the jogger during her nightly six-mile run, ``We all charged her.'' He said she struggled and screamed while several teen-agers dragged her down a wooded slope into the darkness. On his tape, Santana admitted holding and kicking the woman and feeling her breasts while others raped her. McCray said he kicked her, then held for the others. When it was his turn, McCray said, he feigned the sex act to impress his buddies. The defendants told detectives the naked woman was struck with a metal pipe, bashed in the head and face with a brick, cut on the legs with a knife and sexually attacked in a frenzy of violence, prosecutors said. Galligan has set a trial date of Oct. 11 for two other defendants, Kharey Wise, 18, and Kevin Richardson, 15. Another defendant, Steve Lopez, 15, will be tried separately next year.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn to Shut Down East German Nuclear Power Plants
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's nuclear power industry costs too much to run and has little chance of survival after unification, West Germany's environment minister said Tuesday. The minister, Klaus Toepfer, repeated earlier assessments that East German nuclear standards are below those of the West. He told a Bonn news conference it would be an expensive and long procedure to bring the East German plants up to European standards. The Soviet Union had supplied East Germany with the technology to build nuclear power plants. East Germany has one operating reactor at a plant at Greifswald, in the northern part of the country. Construction at another nuclear power plant has been halted. Faulty design and human error were responsible for the 1985 Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union. It caused extreme panic in West Germany, where the anti-nuclear movement is very strong. East Germany derives 10 percent of its electricity from nuclear power.

DOC.HEAD: Charles Rothenberg in San Quentin as Parole Violator
DOC.TEXT: A boy whose father set him on fire in 1983 said Tuesday he was glad his father was thrown back into prison on parole violation charges eight months after his release. ``I was just glad they caught him and he was a couple hundred miles away,'' said 14-year-old David Rothenberg. He learned of Monday's news when his mother picked him up from the high school he attends. ``If they didn't catch him, I'd be scared, but I think after this he should be put in prison for life,'' David said. Charles Rothenberg was headed to a job interview in Oakland on Monday when he ducked out of a doughnut shop and eluded a parole agent who was watching him. Rothenberg was picked up without resistance four hours later. ``He deliberately violated his parole,'' said Tipton Kindel, a spokesman for the California Department of Corrections. ``We don't know why he would jeopardize what freedom he had to live on the outside ... but it was a big mistake on his part.'' Rothenberg, 50, will remain at San Quentin prison until a hearing, which must be held within 60 days, Kindel said. If it is found there was a violation, he could be sentenced to 30 days to a year. Rothenberg was placed on three years' parole after he served six years and five months of his 13-year sentence. He was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges for pouring kerosene over his son and setting the boy on fire. David, who was 6 at the time, was severely disfigured from third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. The 1988 ABC-TV movie ``David'' depicted the attack. Rothenberg and the boy's mother were living separately in New York. Rothenberg took the boy to California for a vacation and set fire to David after his wife told him in a telephone conversation that he would not be able to see the boy again. After Rothenberg left prison in January, at least one parole officer followed him at all times. He described himself as ``the most-watched man in America.'' Kindel said Rothenberg had not caused any problem during his parole before Monday. ``He'd been abiding by the rules, keeping a low profile and trying to obtain employment,'' Kindel said. After slipping out of the doughnut shop, Rothenberg phoned another agent to say he would go to a scheduled job interview. When he arrived, about 11:30 a.m., he was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Added Tension for Congressman: Son Is a Paratrooper in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Jerry Costello finally heard from his son last week. It was a note about the sun and sand on the other side of the world _ in Saudi Arabia. The Illinois Democrat's 21-year-old son, Army paratrooper Jerry Costello II, is a member of the U.S. military force in the Middle East, a job that makes the Persian Gulf crisis a personal one for the congressman and his family. In advance of President Bush's speech to Congress Tuesday on the Mideast situation, Costello said he would be listening with special interest. ``I'll be thinking about one soldier over there in particular,'' Costello said. His son has been abroad for more than a month, but like many other families the father heard from the son only a few days ago. ``Basically the message was the conditions are not the greatest,'' Costello said. ``But he's doing as well as the other soldiers. He spent 95 percent of the letter telling us not to worry. ``When he sleeps, the soldiers try to get to the closest piece of concrete because the concrete is cooler at night. It took him a little while to get adjusted to the heat,'' Costello said. ``While they're working long hours,'' he added, ``it's still very boring. The major problem they are confronting right now is sitting in limbo not knowing what's going to happen.'' Costello's son is in the Army's 82nd Airborne, based at Fort Bragg, N.C. The congressman said the Army had refused to confirm his son's deployment, but when thousands of paratroopers were sent to the Persian Gulf in early August, he was certain Jerry II was part of the group. The letter reached the family's Belleville, Ill., home Thursday. Costello said his daily routine hasn't changed much, but he and his wife, Georgia, watch a lot of news as they try to catch the developments in the Middle East. Constituents in his district have given him and his family ``a very warm response.'' ``On Labor Day, I walked in two parades and it was very touching for me to hear the support,'' Costello said. ``In a grocery store, a gasoline station _ people just want us to know they're keeping our son in their prayers.'' Although he's in Congress, Costello said his position doesn't give him an advantage over others worried about sons, daughters or spouses sent to the region. Several lawmakers have visited the soldiers in Saudi Arabia, but Costello said he did not ask them to do any favors for his family. As a courtesy, however, he was invited two weeks ago to a White House briefing held by Bush. Costello recently bid farewell to about 200 soldiers deployed from Scott Air Force Base, which is in his district. ``It was important for the parents to know they are not the only ones affected,'' Costello said. ``Their U.S. congressman is, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Violence Flares in Lobstermen's Territorial Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Lobstermen are feuding again in the rich lobster-fishing areas of Casco Bay, and in one dispute two fishermen were tossed in the harbor, a gun was brandished and a boat damaged. ``It's a territorial dispute,'' Maine Marine Patrol Lt. Joseph Fessenden said Tuesday. ``It's a situation where there's a limited area of space to fish. ``The lobstermen are competing for the same area and we've had a situation where they've been cutting each other's traps,'' he said. ``There have been several lobstermen who've lost several thousand dollars worth of traps. This has been happening throughout the summer.'' Discontent has been high among Maine's estimated 4,000 full-time lobstermen. Strikes throughout the summer protested prices being paid for lobster catches. Softshell lobsters often have sold for as low as $1.75 to $1.85 a pound wholesale this summer, said Bob Brown, president of the Maine Import-Export Lobster Dealers Association. He said this price resulted from supply and demand. Maine harvested about 22 million pounds of lobster in 1988, 24 million in 1989 and this year's prediction is 26 million pounds. Under pressure to maintain their income, the dozen boat crews feuding in Portland Harbor have been suspicious of others taking more than their fair share, Fessenden said. ``They call this area `the Bay of Pigs' and this is one of the reasons,'' he said. Lobstermen have their own specially marked buoys attached to a line of lobster traps. Every day, they travel through their territory, stopping at each of their buoys to haul up their lines, empty the traps, put in new bait and dump them back in the water. On Monday, a dispute between the captains of two boats, the B&B and the Rambler, turned violent in what Fessenden described as the worst confrontation he has seen in 15 years as a Marine Patrol officer. Fessenden said the B&B pulled alongside the Rambler as its captain, Matthew Chipman, 28, of Portland, was trying to pull up a string of traps that had been cut. Norman Solak, 52, a longtime lobsterman from West Buxton, and one of his crew, Edward Mains Jr., 36, of Gorham, boarded the Rambler, Fessenden said. The two crews struggled, he said, and Solak and Mains were thrown into the harbor. Fessenden said the Rambler's crew charged later in a radio call to the Coast Guard that one of the B&B's crew brandished a gun. The Marine Patrol and the Coast Guard confiscated three weapons from the B&B: a .30-caliber rifle, a .22-caliber handgun and a .38-caliber handgun. One of the boats also was damaged in the confrontation, said a Marine Patrol officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Fessenden said the Marine Patrol is investigating whether to file criminal charges against the crews involved. ``It's highly illegal to molest another man's gear,'' said David Dow, executive director of the Lobster Institute, a cooperative research program at the University of Maine at Orono. ``It's an automatic, three-year license suspension for anybody caught doing it. ``But territoriality has been around for as long as anybody can remember,'' Dow said. ``It's rare that you see a territorial dispute flare up in this overt fashion. Most of the territorial disputes are only handled in the thick fog and the black of night.''

DOC.HEAD: Germanys Agree to Limit Western Intelligence Control of Stasi Records
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's intelligence agency cannot freely pore over the files of 6 million East Germans compiled by the former Communist regime, both nations agreed Tuesday. However, officials did not decide if the files could be moved to what is now West Germany, an issue that has obsessed East Germans as they prepare to unite with their Western neighbor Oct. 3. About 22 activists, some of whom helped lead the peaceful revolt that toppled the Communist regime last autumn, have been occupying the building where the files are kept. They are demanding that East Germans get to see information kept on them by the former secret police, known as the Stasi, and that the files remain in East German territory. Top officials from both Germanys agreed Tuesday only that the records will not be merged with those of the West German secret service. ``The Stasi files may not be used as regular working materials by the secret service,'' said Guenther Krause, top aide to East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Krause spoke after a meeting with Rudolf Seiters, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief of staff, and West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaueble. A treaty laying the groundwork for unification calls for the fate of the files to be decided by a united parliament being elected Dec. 2. Critics say that ultimately will mean that West Germans, who will dominate the new government, will have the final say over the secret records of East Germans. East Germany's Parliament has yet to vote on the unity treaty, and many lawmakers are demanding a change in that provision. Any rule allowing East Germans to look at files must also apply to West Germans, Krause said, since 2 million Western citizens are believed to have files in the Stasi archives. Krause said the possibility of destroying files also must be discussed and that he believed an overall agreement could be reached this week. The files give a glimpse of a nation in the grip of a paranoid, oppressive regime and contain intimate details of the personal lives of both prominent people and average citizens. Because each file on one individual could contain up to 60 other names, some officials are worried that granting someone access to a file will give him or her information about many others. Western intelligence agencies are believed to be anxious to disseminate the information compiled by the Stasi, which of all Communist intelligence agencies was second only to the Soviet KGB in skill and global reach. There have been reports, however, that some of the most sensitive records were destroyed by the Stasi in the waning days of the former Communist regime. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel, constantly under fire for the scores of former Stasi employees still working in his agency, fired eight ex-secret police officials on Tuesday, according to the East German news agency, ADN. Six of them were on a list published during the weekend of 150 reputed former Stasi agents still working in the government. The list was published by the West German tabloid Bild. Fourteen people on the list purportedly worked in the East German press center and the office of government spokesman Matthias Gehler. Gehler said Tuesday that four are no longer with the press department and 10 have been given leaves of absence.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Bank to Guarantee Portion of City Loan
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss bank will guarantee part of the $375 million Philadelphia is seeking to keep from going broke, but not as much as city officials had hoped. Swiss Bank Corp. said Monday it will back $50 million of the temporary loan notes the administration of Mayor W. Wilson Goode is trying to sell to raise cash. ``We could be willing to take $50 million, and to the extent we got other banks (to guarantee other portions of the loan), the amount of the letter of credit would go up from there,'' said John P. Chamales, Swiss Bank first vice president. The bank was prepared to issue a letter of credit for as much as $225 million if other banks assume the risk for the other $175 million, he said. A letter of credit would guarantee the notes will be repaid and would aid the city in marketing the loan notes. The city would have to pay higher interest on notes issued without a guarantee. City officials and a financial team headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets were trying to persuade at least two other banks to guarantee additional notes. Quoting unidentified sources, The Philadelphia Inquirer said Tuesday city leaders are talking with Union Bank of Switzerland and National Westminister Bank of London about joining Swiss Bank. Four local banks last week rejected a city request that each of them guarantee $15 million in notes. The mayor has said the city will be out of cash by late this month unless it receives a cash infusion. The notes would be repaid from property and business tax receipts expected early next year. Even with the temporary notes, the city projects a $206.4 million deficit in the $2.1 billion general fund budget by June 30, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Praises Kitty Dukakis for Writing `Painful' Book
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush says Kitty Dukakis would have made ``a great first lady'' and deserves credit for writing so frankly about her personal struggle with drugs and alcohol. Mrs. Bush praised the Massachusetts governor's wife for writing ``a very painful book'' with ``no meanness.'' The first lady said she read Mrs. Dukakis' autobiography, ``Now You Know,'' cover to cover in a day-and-a-half on her Maine vacation. ``She tried to write about a really big problem she had ... very honestly and very sincerely'' without casting blame on her politician husband or anyone else, Mrs. Bush said. Dukakis was the Democrats' losing candidate in the 1988 presidential contest against Bush. ``She loves her husband,'' said Mrs. Bush. ``She looked all around for someone to blame and she blamed herself, and she says it would have happened win or lose, with any little thing that had come up.'' ``I think she would have made a great first lady,'' said Mrs. Bush, who has sent Mrs. Dukakis a note expressing those sentiments. The book ``makes you also think he's a pretty nice fellow,'' she said softly. ``People wonder how he could not have not known,'' she said. But defending Dukakis, she added, ``I've known a lot of people who had this problem and the truth is men or women don't want to know. And the other truth is that addicted people hide. Alcoholics can hide it.'' ``People have to understand that those things are not just obvious to the person who's married to them. It should be, but isn't,'' said Mrs. Bush. She said Kitty Dukakis' story puts the lie to the notion that ``an addicted person can't produce.'' ``I remember George had someone work in his office a thousand years ago that he discovered was an alcoholic. He'd produced for years,'' said Mrs. Bush. ``It was one of the nicest things George Bush ever did. First of all he went home with the man to tell his wife, which was over and above and beyond the line of duty,'' she said. ``His wife said, `Thank God somebody noticed. For 10 years I've been expecting the shoe to fall.''' Bush ``also went with him to A.A. (Alcoholics Anonymous) meetings, got him started,'' she recalled. ``The man is a big George Bush backer 25 years later.'' The first lady made the comments in an interview late Monday with news agency reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Tomatoes From Space Seeds? Nope, State Fair First Prize!
DOC.TEXT: Seeds that some had feared might produce mutated killer tomatoes after nearly six years in space have been vindicated _ they produced fruit that won first prize at the Kansas State Fair. Six tomatoes grown from seeds that were part of a National Aeronautics and Space Administration experiment beat more than three dozen other entries. Kansas Cosmosphere planetarium director Roger Hoefer grew the tomatoes. The space museum in the central Kansas town of Hutchinson received seeds from NASA to show teachers how to do class projects with them. ``I've grown tomatoes all of my life and I've never grown tomatoes as pretty as these were,'' Hoefer said. When he entered the plate of six Rutgers tomatoes, he noticed some other entries dwarfed his. Rutgers, named after the university where the variety was developed years ago, is an old, stable but small tomato. But the judge looked not for size but for conformity, uniformity of shape and ripeness and freedom from skin blemishes and defects. Hoefer's space tomatoes were among the 10 plates of entries the judge separated immediately from the rest. Closer examination put Hoefer's entry in first in Saturday's judging. Hoefer didn't learn of the results until Monday. ``I couldn't believe it,'' he said. ``I looked down and they had a blue ribbon on them.'' More that 12 million seeds were on a satellite sent into orbit in 1984 for 10 months of exposure to the radiation of space. The idea was to test the durability of possible space station building materials and to see if the radiation would cause mutations in the tomatoes. But instead of 10 months, the satellite wasn't retrieved until after nearly six years. The seeds were distributed to 4 million students and others nationwide for planting. Controversy erupted when a NASA contractor warned there was a remote possibility the seeds might produce toxic fruit. Some teachers dropped the plant project. NASA suggested the tomatoes not be eaten. But Hoefer said Cosmosphere employees and volunteers have been eating the tomatoes all summer. Hoefer and Chuck Marr, a Kansas State University horticulturist who supervised the tomato competition, agreed that growing conditions and care had more to do with the prize tomatoes than the fact their seeds spent time in space. Hoefer grew his in a greenhouse. Hoefer said control plants grown from seeds of the same variety that stayed on Earth yielded equal quality fruit. He said two plants showed abnormalities. One had unusual blossom clusters and produced small, elongated tomatoes. The fruit had poor flavor and few seeds. Another plant also had odd blossoms and in one instance produced a pea-size tomato that never ripened. Hoefer is keeping the odd plants alive in case scientists at NASA or Park Seed Co. of Greenwood, S.C., want to do tissue tests to looked for genetic damage.

DOC.HEAD: Guns in Town Bring US-Saudi Disputes to Surface
DOC.TEXT: The Saudi government has complained to the U.S. military about the growing number of American troops visiting Saudi towns toting weapons, officials said Tuesday. Saudi and U.S. officials sought to play down the significance of the formal complaint, but it came amid growing signs the American presence is causing cultural strains. ``We of course welcome the Americans and appreciate their assistance, but there needs to be more sensitivity,'' a Saudi official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There is no need to carry weapons into town, and we are asking that they not do this.'' A military spokesman, Navy Capt. Michael Sherman, said all American military personnel had been instructed to, when possible, wear civilian clothes while visiting Saudi towns and not to carry weapons. He said the instructions will be circulated again in light of the Saudi complaint. But Sherman said it is inevitable that some troops sent into town suddenly or on certain official business would bring their weapons. ``There is a terrorist threat and these people should be able to defend themselves,'' he said. ``But we want to keep that to a minimum.'' For the first few weeks of the American deployment, it was rare to see uniformed U.S. military personnel in Saudi towns. But in the past 10 days many units have sent troops into a few towns for supplies they have been unable to get from the military. Those soldiers often wander through streets and shops carrying M-16 rifles and other weapons. That prompted a number of recent complaints from Saudis to the government of the kingdom's Eastern Province, the northeastern sector of the country where most American troops are deployed. Some shopkeepers say the armed Americans scare people away, and officials say the constant presence of weapons is heightening fears that war is imminent. ``We have asked that they leave their machine guns behind when they go into town,'' said the Saudi official. Another Saudi official said the Eastern Province government also has been questioned in recent days about American military women driving in the streets. Women are prohibited from driving in Saudi Arabia. ``They are inquiries rather than complaints,'' said the official, who also spoke on the condition he not be identified. U.S. military officials have said women would be confined to driving on military installations and in their camps, but there have been occasions when women have been seen driving military vehicles in Saudi towns. The complaint and inquiries were not entirely unexpected. Saudi and American officials have said some conflicts are inevitable as about 100,000 American troops, deployed since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, begin living in an Islamic culture. These officials said they have been pleasantly surprised that such incidents have been kept to a minimum. But in recent days there have been other signs of strain as well in the relations between the American military and their Saudi hosts. Many military decisions are deferred to the Saudis because of their sovereignty. But Americans have been irritated by a few public statements by Saudi officials that the Americans have viewed as bragging about controlling the U.S. troops. American field commanders are irate that they have not been allowed to conduct live-fire testing of major weapons systems such as M-1 tanks and Hellfire anti-tank missiles. These and other systems are untested in combat and commanders believe some field firing is essential to determine if desert conditions will affect their weapons-guidance systems. The Saudis, according to U.S. military sources, have discouraged the live firing because they do not want to upset or endanger local residents, particularly desert-roaming Bedouins, or face criticism within the Arab world for allowing the United States to show off its military might. This dispute appears headed for resolution. The Saudis have given permission for test firing of lighter weapons, perhaps as early as this week, and say they are seeking to resolve concerns over firing the heavier weapons. In another incident that prompted private criticism from Saudis, a M-16 rifle leaned against a wall in a hotel restaurant slipped and fell to the floor, startling Saudis and Kuwaitis in the restaurant. Sherman said military personnel have been asked to leave their weapons at a military office at the hotel if they are going into the restaurant.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Uninsured Got Less Heart Disease Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Uninsured patients and those on Medicaid were less likely to receive three common treatments for heart disease than those with insurance, a study of 37,994 people in Massachusetts has found. The study examined the care of heart disease patients admitted to more than 100 Massachusetts hospitals in 1985. Researchers looked at three common but expensive treatments: angiography, used to diagnose heart disease; and bypass grafting and angioplasty, procedures to treat blocked coronary arteries. ``We found that the odds that privately insured patients received angiography were 80 percent higher than uninsured patients; the odds were 40 percent higher for bypass grafting and 28 percent higher for angioplasty,'' the authors wrote in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``Medicaid patients experienced odds similar to those of uninsured patients for receiving angiography and bypass, but had 48 percent lower odds of receiving angioplasty,'' they wrote. ``This is very disturbing,'' Dr. Mark Wenneker, a health policy researcher at New England Medical Center in Boston, said Tuesday. ``It's very possible that the uninsured and Medicaid people needed these procedures and didn't get them, but we don't know that,'' said Wenneker, the lead researcher. ``On the other hand, equally disturbing is the possibility that there may have been no difference in what happened to insured versus the uninsured, which raises the question of whether these procedures were actually even necessary,'' Wenneker said in a telephone interview. In an angiography, dye is injected into coronary arteries to determine if there is any blockage. If blockage is found, an open-heart bypass operation may be done, grafting a vessel from another part of the body to bypass the blockage and allow enough blood to reach the heart. Angioplasty is an alternative operation in which a small balloon is inflated inside the blocked vessel to push the clot into the vessel wall and reduce the blockage. Angiography and angioplasty each generally cost more than $1,000, while bypass operations usually cost several thousand dollars, Wenneker said. The three are considered ``definitive procedures necessary to diagnose'' and treat heart disease, Wenneker said. The researchers, however, did not examine the patients' outcomes to see if any of them might have died or their conditions worsened after not receiving the procedures, Wenneker said. They also did not determine whether it was the decision of the physician, hospital or patient to forgo the procedures. Their study did conclude that the patients' insurance status was a major factor, and that the procedures were done less often on those with lower incomes. And it suggests that quality of care may depend on a patient's insurance status. ``Although the central mission of many hospitals was once the provision of charity care, rising costs and an increasingly competitive health care marketplace have influenced the willingness of hospitals to care for uninsured patients,'' the researchers wrote. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. James Todd, the AMA's executive vice president, said changes are needed in the financing and delivering of health care to make sure treatment does not depend on economics. ``Many hypotheses could be advanced to explain these differences but all would raise the issue that the volume and location of care seem related to the availability of funding,'' Todd wrote. ``The medical profession stands ready to participate in any program that brings equity to the system,'' he said. ``It does not stand ready to abandon its advocacy for patients in the name of expediency.''

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Up Only Slightly but Worse Figures Predicted
DOC.TEXT: The deficit in the country's broadest measure of foreign trade rose slightly in the April-June quarter to $21.84 billion, still the second-best showing in six years, the government reported Tuesday. However, private economists forecast that the deficit will head sharply higher in the months ahead as the Persian Gulf crisis boosts America's foreign oil bill and cuts into Americans' overseas earnings. The Commerce Department report showed that the nation's current account trade deficit was up a slight 0.8 percent from a first quarter gap of $21.67 billion, which had been the best showing since a $21.2 billion deficit in the first three months of 1984. The current account is the most important trade statistic because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also in services and investment flows between countries. The strong showing in the second quarter resulted from a record level of U.S. merchandise sales balancing a deterioration in investment earnings, which went into deficit for the first time in a year. Analysts forecast that the deficit for the rest of this year would rise as a result of the crisis in the Middle East. Under their scenario, higher oil prices will boost America's import bill while slower worldwide growth as a result of the turmoil will cut down on American export sales as well as dampen overseas earnings by U.S. companies. ``Our economy is now tied more than ever to foreign growth. Slower growth overseas will reduce demand for U.S. exports and reduce our earnings on overseas investments,'' said Stephen Cooney, director of international investment for the National Association of Manufacturers. David Wyss, senior financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, said the trade deficit could widen by 25 percent in coming months because of the fallout from the Persian Gulf. That forecast would represent a blow to Bush administration hopes for a continued strong trade performance to bolster a weak domestic economy. Wyss predicted the trade deficit would start narrowing again by the second half of next year as oil prices begin to come down but he said this estimate was dependent on events in the Persian Gulf. ``If shooting starts, then oil prices go higher and the trade deficit gets a lot worse,'' he said. For the second quarter, the merchandise trade deficit narrowed a sharp 14.1 percent to $22.6 billion, reflecting a big drop in oil prices and a record level of exports. The surplus in the services account, which reflects such things as tourism and payments for services running from architects to lawyers, totaled $6.08 billion, up 1.3 percent from the first quarter. However, these improvements were offset by the fact that the investment category moved into deficit for the first time in a year. The deficit in the second quarter was $637 million, compared to a surplus of $2.0 billion in the first quarter. The other category in the current account, unilateral transfers such as foreign aid and pension payments to Americans living overseas, showed a deficit of $4.71 billion in the second quarter, 39 percent larger than the first quarter deficit. Even with the improvement in the first six months, the United States started the 1990s in a vastly different position from a decade earlier. Then, America was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings on its overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners to pay for imported merchandise, the investment cushion eroded and disappeared altogether in 1985 when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. That means that foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas, a development which has led some to fear America is losing control of its economic destiny to foreigners. At the end of 1989, the country's net debtor position was put at $663.7 billion, up a sharp 25 percent from the previous year. Many analysts believe it will hit $1 trillion before beginning to improve.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A veteran prosecutor forgot which side of the bar he was on when he pleaded innocent Tuesday to three charges that he knowingly received stolen antiques and burglarized a house. ``Your honor, at this time the people ... '' Santa Clara County assistant District Attorney Alan W. Nudelman began, apparently forgetting he was the accused. ``Pardon me,'' he told Municipal Court Judge Jean Westenkamp. ``I would enter a plea of not guilty to all charges.'' The judge set Oct. 10 for the next court appearance for Nudelman. A date for a preliminary hearing will be set at that time. Nudelman was arrested Aug. 26 in a parking lot in Los Gatos after allegedly buying a sink and a desk from a suspected burglar. The transaction was secretly videotaped by officers. Nudelman, 45, has said he didn't know the items were stolen. ``The only comment that I have is that Alan Nudelman has committed no crime and therefore expects to be completely exonerated,'' said his attorney, Kenneth W. Robinson. Police said they obtained Nudelman's permission before they searched his Los Gatos home and found more than 70 allegedly stolen items. Deputy Attorney General Michael O'Reilley contended that about 50 of those items belong to an 87-year-old woman whose home and storage building were raided by burglars.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Immigrant Number 100,000 Honored
DOC.TEXT: Israel on Tuesday welcomed its 100,000th immigrant this year, the latest newcomer in a flood that has proved a mixed blessing for the Jewish state. The immigrants, almost 90 percent Soviets, are helping to build Israel's Jewish population and fulfilling the national goal of ``the ingathering of the exiles.'' But the wave of immigration, the largest since the early days of the state, is severely straining resources. Just slightly larger than New Jersey and with a population of about 4.5 million, Israel is grappling with how to resettle the 150,000 Soviet Jews expected this year and the 1 million who could arrive by the decade's end. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz on Tuesday predicted that a total number of immigrants this year may reach 200,000. Housing shortages already have developed, unemployment is rising and the budget deficit is soaring. Michael Kleiner, chairman of the Parliament's absorption committee, estimates Israel will need to spend $30 billion over the next four to five years to resettle the newcomers. ``We will have to readjust our national spending, tap world Jewry and Israel's other foreign friends, take out loans, anything we can think of to cover the costs,'' Kleiner said. Peretz went to Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport to greet the 100,000th immigrant of 1990. He was Yitzhak Krasiltchik, 80, a native of the Soviet city of Leningrad, who arrived on a flight with 140 other Soviet Jews via Warsaw. Krasiltchik, who walks with a cane, was helped into a limosine at the foot of the jet's ramp and ferried to the arrivals lounge, where he was serenaded by Israeli children carrying colorful balloons. About 88,000 of the newcomers this year have been Soviets, the government says. Immigration from the Soviet Union in August was a record 17,484, said Yehuda Weinraub, a spokesman for the Jewish Agency. He said 1,340 arrived from other countries. To many in Israel, the importance of the immigrant wave is in building the Jewish population in the Arab-dominated Middle East. Jews already constitute a substantial majority in Israel, numbering more than 3.7 million compared with 850,000 Arabs. But the Arab birthrate remains nearly twice that of the Jewish rate, and there are 1.7 million Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which Israel controls through a military government. With the exception of Egypt, Israel remains the enemy of the Arab states that surround it. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, in Moscow to encourage more immigration, said there was strength in numbers. ``Peace depends on the number of Jews who come to Israel,'' he said. In addition to contributing to security, the arriving Soviets could greatly increase Israel's pool of talent. The government estimates that nearly one-quarter of the new arrivals are doctors, engineers, scientists, teachers and other professionals. Still, absorbing the immigrants carries a high price tag and Israel is increasingly looking for help abroad. The Jewish state has budgeted $2.3 billion over the next three years for immigrant absorption and recently approved a new housing construction program that will cost $400 million this year alone. Help from abroad includes more than $740 million funneled this year through the Jewish Agency, a quasi-governmental organization that assists in resettlement. The international Israel Bond campaign has pledged to raise a record $1 billion this year for the immigrants. Israel also is seeking $400 million in loan guarantees from the United States to build new housing. The guarantees have been held up by U.S. demands that Israel ensure none of the funds goes to settling the newcomers in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Figures Will Be Increased, Census Director Says
DOC.TEXT: Local government officials complaining that preliminary 1990 census figures are too low will soon see the numbers rise, the director of the U.S. Census Bureau said Tuesday. ``The census count will increase in practically every jurisdiction throughout the country because of ongoing coverage improvement programs,'' said Barbara Everitt Bryant. ``We expect to add millions of persons before the count is delivered to the president.'' The deadline for getting the count to President Bush is Dec. 31, according to federal law. The census bureau is now in its ``post-enumeration survey'' stage to recheck the preliminary U.S. population figure of 245,837,681. Bryant described to a House subcommittee the methods the bureau is using to recheck the figures. They include: _Recounts in areas where the preliminary numbers have been challenged by local governments. _Addition of probationers and parolees not counted at their home addresses. _Addition of people at the address they report as their usual residence, if at first count they were somewhere else. _Recanvassing based on information obtained by the bureau through calls to its 800-numbers, construction permits, media reports and other sources. _Addition of people answering ``Were You Counted?'' forms. _Reinterviews. _Addition of overseas military and civilian federal employees and their dependents. Bryant said that over 39,000 cities, counties and other local governments received preliminary housing unit counts in August. Each has three weeks to challenge the figures. A challenge could lead to a recount. By Oct. 15, all late census interviews must be completed. After analyzing the data, the secretary of commerce will decide by next July 15 whether to adjust the census for under-counts or over-counts, Bryant said. Rep. Thomas Sawyer, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Post Office and Civil Service subcommittee on census and population, said ``accuracy has never been more important than in 1990 when operational problems have raised many questions about the thoroughness of the count.'' Several members appearing before the subcommittee said their districts were miscounted. Some questioned the categories into which people were placed as inevitably resulting in the United States appearing more white than it actually is. Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif., said Asian and Pacific Islanders were being categorized as Caucasians. ``To group the Asian-Pacific Islanders with the group most likely to be over-counted is a disservice,'' said Mineta. Rep. Robert Matsui, D-Calif., called it ``continued insensitivity toward Asian-Americans as a minority group.'' Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, criticized preliminary figures for his state that showed the predominantly white, suburban counties had more population in 1990 than in the census bureau's 1988 projection, while the heavily Hispanic counties showed less. ``Are we to believe that the Census Bureau consistently found more whites than they estimated, but was unable to find even the number of Hispanics that they had estimated in 1988?'' he said. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., saying ``almost everything that could have gone wrong with the census in New York, did,'' criticized the post-count review for not addressing inhousehold misses _ those people who weren't counted as part of a household in which all the other members were counted.

DOC.HEAD: Time Not Right for Mideast Peace Conference, U.S. Official Says
With AM-Baker-Soviets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III have revived talk of a Mideast peace conference, but a senior U.S. official said Tuesday the idea is premature. ``This is not the time,'' said the official, who is here with Baker for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials on a variety of issues. First, the official said, the basis of negotiations between Israel and Palestinian Arabs would have to be worked out. And, he said, even if there is a conference the negotiations would be carried out between the two sides. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, tried to soften the impact of the statements by Bush and Baker at last weekend's Helsinki summit meeting the Soviet Union. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who the Americans want to induce to negotiate withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza, is opposed to an international peace conference. He is concerned that the Soviets and the Arabs would use such a gathering to collaborate on terms unfavorable to Israel. ``We will not participate in such an international conference,'' Shamir said last week after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze raised the idea. But Bush and Baker, eager for Soviet cooperation against Iraq, said subsequently that a conference on the Middle East would be appropriate under certain conditions. The official concurred. ``At the appropriate time, we`d be in favor of it,'' he said. ``It can be helpful.'' But, he stressed, the United States would be the judge of when conditions were right. First, he said, the basis for negotiations would have to be ``substantially developed.'' And, he said, ``the conference would have to be properly structured, moving toward negotiations in a bilateral way.'' The idea that the United States would judge the timing, and that the negotiations would remain in the hands of Israel and its Arab neighbors, is bound to please Jerusalem. Shamir has said he is willing to negotiate with Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza after leaders are chosen in an election and after a trial period of limited self-rule. Gorbachev, however, on Sunday described the Arab-Israeli dispute as being of ``even more'' concern than Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: 21 People Killed in Shootout between Police, Militants
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants opened fired on police at a car checkpoint Tuesday and 23 people were killed, including 17 militants aboard a bus that exploded in the shootout, the government said. It said two police were among the dead. The account could not be independently confirmed. Government officials, who cannot be indentified under briefing rules, said police stopped the bus at a Border Security Force checkpoint early Tuesday near Thunu, about 30 miles northeast of Srinagar, because the bus was defying a curfew. When the bus stopped, four men jumped out of the vehicle and began firing at the policemen, the officials said. The policemen returned fire and two police and four militants from the bus were killed. A stray bullet hit a pile of ammunition inside the bus, triggering the explosion and fire, the officials said. They said the bodies of all 17 militants inside were charred beyond recognition. A government statement said security forces recovered a large quantity of ammunition, grenades and rocket launchers from the bus. It did not explain how the ammunition survived the blast. There were no immediate statements from Moslem militant groups that are fighting for the secession of the Moslem-dominated Jammu-Kashmir state from the predominantly Hindu India. At the other end of the state in Jammu town, about 6,000 Hindus demonstrated against the Moslem secessionist movement. Prior to the demonstration, a bomb blew up the railroad tracks near Jammu, just 15 minutes before the scheduled arrival of a train carrying top leaders of the protest. There were no injuries and no one claimed responsibility, state officials said. The train, which normally carries about 1,500 people, was late and the bomb exploded when the train was at a station 12 miles from Jammu. About 1,200 people have been killed in Kashmir, the Moslem-dominated part of Jammu-Kashmir state, since January, when the government started its heaviest crackdown to date on the secessionists. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people follow Islam, making it the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Most of the Hindus, who comprise 32 percent of the state's population, live in Jammu region. Nationwide, 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus while Moslems account for 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Closing Bureaus in Six States
DOC.TEXT: United Press International is closing bureaus in six states as part of a general restructuring of the news service, a UPI spokesman said Tuesday. Spokesman Milt Capps confirmed that one-person bureaus in Grand Rapids, Mich.; Bismarck N.D.; Syracuse, N.Y. and Santa Fe, N.M. were being closed, as were offices in Montana and Wyoming. Capps denied, however, what he said was the ``erroneous impression that we are doing anything but increasing our coverage in these states.'' He said UPI would rely more on stringer networks and its joint venture partners, which include TV's Financial News Network, States News Service and Financial World Magazine. Asked if other bureaus had been closed, Capps said, ``I have no further announcements.'' He declined to give details on future closures or how many bureaus UPI now operates in the United States, but said ``a change up and down in staffing will be continuing for several months.'' Last month he confirmed a Washington Post report that 31 UPI reporters and editors were being laid off. He said UPI was realigning staff throughout the organization this summer and fall with a shift toward specific fields such as business and finance and sports. ``The upshot is that virtually every bureau in the system worldwide is affected either by increases or decreases.'' ``We are developing what we think is a new role for UPI after 83 years which entails not only strong general news service but increased emphasis on focused news reports that can command a premium in the market place, including media and corporate subscribers,'' he said. ``The bottom line is we can now say we have more people writing for UPI across the board than a year ago,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Accuses Government of Waging War Against ANC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with ANC statement, violence continuing; Pickup 10th, `Mandela also...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela accused the government Tuesday of waging war against his African National Congress and said failure to halt black factional fighting threatened talks on ending apartheid. Mandela held an urgent meeting with President F.W. de Klerk as vicious black factional fighting left at least 24 people dead. Police said unrest in black townships around Johannesburg continued into the night, with shacks burned in Tokoza and running clashes between black factions in Katlehong. ``We will do everything in our power to ensure that the peace process remains on track, but the government has to do its part,'' Mandela said in Pretoria after Tuesday's meeting. ``If it is dragging its feet as it is doing now, then the peace process is definitely threatened.'' De Klerk said in a brief statement the growing sense of urgency in the country demanded that leaders get the chance to complete talks on a new constitution. He offered no new steps on ending the violence. About 700 blacks have died since clashes pitting Xhosa and other blacks linked to the ANC against Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement erupted a month ago in Johannesburg-area townships. The fighting spread from eastern Natal Province, where the ethnic and political warfare has killed more than 5,000 blacks in five years. Mandela said the government had failed to take ``visible measures'' to halt the fighting, such as sending in its powerful military. The government sent military units to the black townships almost two weeks after the violence erupted Aug. 12. The fighting raged on. The government ``cannot be allowed to talk peace and negotiation while it conducts war against the ANC,'' Mandela said. An ANC statement issued later noted that the government had established the Kwazulu homeland in Natal, and it alleged that Kwazulu leaders were using the power they received from the government to carry out warfare against political opponents. Mandela has previously warned the violence threatened negotiations on ending apartheid and political power for blacks, but the talks with the government have continued. Mandela also has appealed for his supporters to lay down their arms. The continued violence indicates he lacks control over the townships. ``If the government fails to take action, and if the violence continues to rise, and if the people continue to demand to be armed, we will find it difficult to oppose that demand,'' he said Tuesday. The ANC lacks a significant arsenal, however. It suspended its mostly ineffective armed struggle against the government this year as a prelude to peace talks. Most of the street fighting has involved crude weapons such as axes, machetes, clubs, spears and gardening tools. De Klerk's statement said ending the violence depended on a political solution as well as possible steps by the government. It said recommendations from Mandela's delegation would be considered. Police said 20 people were killed early Tuesday in Katlehong, while one person died in Tokoza and three were killed in Vosloorus. At least one black man was hacked to death Tuesday and several injured on a train in Johannesburg by men with machetes who rampaged through carriages attacking passengers, police said. Mandela and the ANC, the country's largest black opposition group, have repeatedly charged that police have instigated violence or aided Inkatha fighters. Police and government officials have rejected the charges. Random attacks on blacks in the past week have also led to allegations that right-wing whites are involved in a secret campaign to instigate violence. The government has said it was investigating reports that whites with blackened faces took part in some attacks. The ANC and Inkatha blame each other for the fighting, but the ANC has refused to meet with Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on the shape of a future South Africa. The ANC claims Buthelezi spread the violence from Natal to the Johannesburg area to broaden his constituency. Inkatha accuses the ANC of launching a terror campaign to monopolize power among black opposition groups.

DOC.HEAD: Profile of Academician Who Drew Radical Economic Plan
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stanislav S. Shatalin, who drew up the economic plan approved by the Russian parliament Tuesday, supports private ownership of property, a multiparty system and cuts in military spending. Although a member of the Communist Party since 1963, the frail economist who looks older than his 56 years says he is inclined toward the party's social democratic wing. He says he even considers President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, head of the Soviet Communist Party, to be a social democrat at heart. Shatalin was appointed in March to Gorbachev's advisory group, the Presidential Council, with the responsibility of formulating socio-economic policy. When asked in April by an interviewer for the radical weekly Moscow News whether he and Gorbachev were like-minded, Shatalin said they were in the sense that both were willing to listen to people ``who don't hold our views.'' An academic secretary with the Economics Department of the Soviet Academy of Sciences since 1989, Shatalin has been studying economic science for more than 30 years. ``For me, socialism first means real pluralism in the economy, including private ownership in its modern form,'' primarily stocks, he said in the interview. ``Second, it is progressive profit taxes. Third, it's social protection, including unemployment benefits, retraining benefits, etc. These mechanisms work well in many civilized countries.'' ``Fourth, it is social justice,'' he said. ``Not the demagoguery about social justice that was practiced in this country for decades, but social justice based on an efficient economy.'' While not a close confidante of Gorbachev, he said he likes the Soviet leader's ``honesty, benevolence (and) quickness of mind, free from dogmatism. Perhaps he, too, discerned in me some qualities that we have in common.'' ``I regard myself as a Russian intellectual,'' Shatalin told Moscow News. ``Russian intellectuals used to take to heart and do take to heart the misfortunes and hopes of the Russian people and all Soviet citizens.''

DOC.HEAD: Florida Ups Jackpot to $90 Million
DOC.TEXT: The jackpot for the next Florida Lotto drawing was set at $90 million Tuesday and fast ticket sales meant prospects were improving for a $100 million prize, lottery officials said. ``If we have an incredible day today, it's possible,'' said Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul. ``I probably need another 24 hours to know for sure.'' Mrs. Paul said 75 percent of a week's Lotto tickets are usually sold Thursday, Friday and Saturday, when the drawing is held. The $90 million figure is a projection that includes estimates for those three days. ``Sales through 11 a.m. Tuesday are about 100 percent higher than the best week on record,'' she said. But she didn't think Florida would be able to top Pennsylvania's record $115 million jackpot, shared by several winners on April 26, 1989. ``I don't think there's enough time for the jackpot to go that high,'' Mrs. Paul said. With no winner in the last three weekend drawings, the Lotto has reached its highest total since the game began in Florida in 1988. ``It's created a great deal of interest'' she said. Lotto jackpots roll over when no one picks all the winning numbers. The Lottery Department then estimates the size of the next week's jackpot based on the rollover and sales projections. On Saturday, there were no winning tickets in a $50 million lottery. The next day, the jackpot was set at $75 million; on Monday, it was raised to $80 million. Florida's best previous week in lottery sales was in April when a $58.3 million jackpot was shared by several winners. The world record of the largest single lottery prize still goes to Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs, who won a Florida Lotto jackpot of $55.1 million two years ago. Players select six numbers from one to 49 and must hit on all six to collect the grand prize, which would be paid out over 20 years. Multiple winners would share equally in the jackpot. The odds of someone picking the winning numbers are about one in 14 million.

DOC.HEAD: NIH Approves Gene-Therapy Experiments
DOC.TEXT: The National Institutes of Health on Tuesday approved the human gene-therapy trials, experiments that scientists say will begin a new chapter in medicine. Approval was given to use gene therapy to treat a rare immune disorder in children and a lethal form of skin cancer. The agency's green light, which was expected, follows the NIH Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee's July 31 recommendation that the tests be approved. The experiments still must be approved by the Food and Drug Administration before they can begin. In the trials, patients would be treated with cells that had been altered by the addition of new genes. Genes, which direct the actions of cells, will cause the treated cells to produce special proteins that will either amplify a biological action or replace proteins that were missing. In the protocol for treatment of severe combined immune deficiency disease, a human gene that instructs a cell to make adenosine deaminase, or ADA, would be inserted into the patient's white blood cells. The disease is caused by a deficiency of ADA. The other experiments would involve patients with melanoma. A gene for the cancer-killing tumor necrosis factor would be inserted into a patient's tumor infiltrating lymphocytes, which are cancer-killing white cells.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Boy Points To Alleged Attacker, Tells Tale of Torture
DOC.TEXT: The 12-year-old boy set ablaze by a neighborhood bully in an abandoned building pointed out his alleged attacker in court Tuesday and told a tale of kidnapping, torture and immolation. David Opont also testified that the attacker laughed at him when he rolled in the snow to put out the fire. David attracted national sympathy after the March 7 attack with reports he resisted efforts by his attacker to make him take drugs. ``He tried to put what he was smoking in my mouth,'' David said, speaking in Creole through a translator. ``I shook my head because I didn't want to take it. He set fire to my shirt.'' David, a native of Haiti, suffered massive burns. Doctors initially gave him a 50 percent chance of surviving. After numerous skin grafs he left a hospital last month. Celebrity hospital visitors included former President Reagan, Bill Cosby and baseball star Dwight Gooden. A 14-year-old boy is on trial in Brooklyn Family Court on charges of attempted murder, assault, kidnapping, attempted robbery, robbery and possession of a weapon. David said he fled the basement with his clothes on fire after his attacker went upstairs. ``When I came out there was snow on the ground and I rolled on the floor so the fire stopped,'' David said. ``I saw him laughing. He was laughing, Ha! Ha! Ha!'' Assistant Brooklyn District Attorney Deborah Lashley asked the boy, ``David, do you see the person who burned you on March 7?'' He pointed and stared straight at the defendant, who sat motionless. The accused teen-ager, whose name is being withheld because of his age, faces three years' confinement if convicted in the non-jury trial. David told the judge the attack began with a shakedown by a boy who he said had robbed him and others the day. The attacker, who David thought was about 20 years old, went through the other boy's pockets and then told him to leave, David testified. ``He said he was a detective and he was looking for kids who were taking drugs,'' David said. ``I felt like I've never taken drugs, so why would he come to me? ``I was about to run, but he said he was a detective. That's why I didn't run,'' he said, adding he was then led into the basement. ``He said he puts people who use drugs in there,'' David said. David said his hands were tied behind his back and he was sandwiched between two loose doors discarded in the basement. ``I heard something like paper being ripped. Then I felt something hot on my back. I got up and started crying,'' David said. David said the boy repeatedly asked him if his parents used drugs, ``I told him no one in my family took drugs. He told me I was lying and he hit me with a shovel and then he tied me to a metal pole. He tied my feet and he asked me again: Did my mother take drugs? Did my father take drugs?'' David said the boy then tried to force him to smoke something, but he wasn't sure what it was. The attacker picked up the shovel again and set something on it ablaze. The attacker then put it against David's shirt, setting his clothing on fire, David testified.

DOC.HEAD: Borough Hopes To Say `Bye, Bye, Blackbirds'
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this southeastern Pennsylvania town have declared war on some loud, messy visitors. Droves of blackbirds swarm into the east end of Windsor each day at dusk to roost in a stand of trees, and residents want relief from the mess, the smell and the loud chirping. In retaliation, the people plan to ``bomb'' the birds with some manmade noise of their own. The Windsor borough government plans to buy 100 rocket bombs and set them off, 20 at a time, five nights in row, in the birds' roosting area. Borough engineer Gordon Brown hopes the birds will cry foul and leave. The anti-bird ammunition will cost about $30. Local resident Bill Hollar said the east end has been plagued by the roosting blackbirds all summer. ``It is solid with birds,'' Hollar said. ``The ground is covered (with droppings), and it's so bad the kids can't go out to play.'' This isn't the first time the borough has had a problem with some not-so-fine feathered friends. Ten years ago, borough officials tried driving a flock of starlings away from the water company pump house by spraying water, blowing sirens and firing shotguns into the air. When that failed, the city finally cut down two acres of trees around the pump house.

DOC.HEAD: Tony Department Store Issues Annual Holiday Catalogue
DOC.TEXT: There's one rare black mink coat for a mere $50,000, a gem-encrusted butterfly brooch for a quarter million, and a New Orleans Mardi Gras excursion for about six grand. For less extravagant shoppers, how about the lead item in this year's Neiman Marcus Christmas catalogue: His and Hers 1990 ``chairpersons.'' Straight-backed wooden chairs designed by artist Philip Grace become life-size portraits of your choice. At $6,000 each, they're art you can really use. ``People are always interested in seeing what we have for the His and Hers gifts. Every year we look for something that hasn't been done before,'' said Jan Roberts, Neiman vice president of public relations in New York. ``Some years they're really expensive gifts, some years they're animals. It doesn't always have to have the same feel,'' she said. The tony, Dallas-based department store on Tuesday began sending out 3 million copies worldwide of its holiday wish book famous for items ranging from the silly to the sublime. This year there's the usual Russian caviar packed in gold-lined tins at $295 per gram, as well as knickknacks, clothes, food and other things, many at regular department store prices. In the one-of-a-kind category is an original Gypsy house trailer, ornately carved and painted, supposedly ``once both home and transportation to an important English Gypsy.'' Ms. Roberts said the caravan, obtained from a Midwestern collector is ``really spectacular ... a little museum on wheels.'' ``We will probably sell it,'' she said. She said the company already has received inquiries about another singular item _ Napoleon's spectacles. The gold-rimmed reading glasses used by the French emperor, possibly for occasions of state, are priced at $90,000 and come with a certificate of authenticity and leather case. The 1991 Mardi Gras trip offers ``a special cachet to join the elite inner circle'' of New Orleans revelers. It includes five days and four nights of debauchery for $5,898 for one person, $600 each additional person. ``And there's a lot of stuff in this book that's just for you and me,'' Ms. Roberts said. ``Things that are still whimsical and unique, but aren't necessarily expensive. ``One of my favorites is the gold Slinky. It would make a great executive gift,'' she said. The gold-plated toy, which is a large spring that ``walks'' down stairs, is $55. Also for executive-level children is a dollop of Silly Putty in its own engraved sterling silver egg for $95 to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the novelty.
