And for the family pet there's a Pooch Palace, described as ``a canine dream home.'' It's 6 feet tall with an AstroTurf base and a car door window permanently rolled down. All for only $3,220.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Many Seriously Mentally Ill Not Getting Treatment
DOC.TEXT: More than 250,000 seriously mentally ill Americans have been left untreated and are living miserable, sometimes violent lives on the streets and in shelters and jails, according to a report Tuesday by two advocacy groups. In all, one researcher said, about half of the estimated 2 million people who have a serious mental illness are not receiving treatment. The report lays much of the blame on psychiatrists and psychologists, many of whom the groups say were trained with public funds but have abandoned the public system for more lucrative private practice. The advocacy groups, Public Citizen and the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, also fault the priorities of many public programs that they said spend too much of their resources providing such services as stress management instead of treating people with severe mental illnesses. ``Care for the seriously mentally ill is a national disaster,'' said Laurie Flynn, executive director of the alliance. Dr. Sidney Wolfe, who heads the health research group of Public Citizen, founded by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, said some communities have built ``great model programs.'' Therefore, he said, ``it becomes more and more intolerable when (others) don't adopt them.'' The American Psychiatric Association objected strongly to the report's ``snide, scapegoating'' statements about psychiatrists, saying they have had ``a historic commitment'' to providing services for the severely mentally ill who rely on the public system. Twenty percent of psychiatrists work in the public sector, which the APA said is a higher percentage than in any other area of medicine. APA spokesman John Blamphin said psychiatrists would not be opposed to donating an hour of their time a week to public programs, as the report recommends, ``if that's also required of others'' working in the health field. The report, ``Care of the Seriously Mentally Ill: A Rating of State Programs,'' evaluates the services provided by each state and scores them accordingly. The groups began this biennial review in 1986. The report assesses hospital services, outpatient and community support services, vocational rehabilitation, housing services and programs for seriously emotionally disturbed children. Vermont ranked highest, scoring 17 of a possible 25 points. New Hampshire and Rhode Island each scored 16; Connecticut and Ohio, 15 each, and Colorado, 14. Hawaii finished last, as it did in the 1986 and 1988 reports, with 2 points. Idaho and Wyoming each scored 3; Mississippi and Montana, 4 each; and Nevada and Texas, 5 each. Overall, the New England states tended to score among the highest while more Western states were at the bottom of the list. ``We think that there is kind of a culture of caring that has grown up in some states and not in others. Clearly this is strongest in New England and weakest in the West,'' said Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a psychiatrist with Public Citizen's health research group. ``In the West, with Texas as a good example, it's kind of a macho mentality. You're supposed to take care of yourself,'' he said. All told, he said, as many as one million seriously mentally ill people nationwide are not actively receiving treatment. The report said one of the major reasons the public system is so lacking is that mental health professionals, many of whom were trained with the help of government funds, don't want to treat the seriously mentally ill. Rather, the report said, most psychologists and psychiatrists spend their time in their offices, counseling people with relatively minor mental health problems, Torrey said. Since the federal government began subsidizing training of mental health professionals in 1945, the number of psychiatrists has grown from 3,000 to 40,000, the report said. The number of psychologists has risen from 4,200 to 70,000 and psychiatric social workers, from 2,000 to about 80,000. To illustrate his point, Torrey said that while Princeton, N.J., has one psychiatrist for every 250 people, Jersey City, N.J., has one for every 13,600 people. ``The professionals who have been trained with public funds have gone off to private practice and left the seriously mentally ill in the public sector without any care,'' he said. The gap is being filled by foreign medical students, who now constitute about two-thirds of the psychiatrists in public psychiatric hospitals and clinics in the United States, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Winger Starts Coping With Life During Shoot In Sahara Desert
DOC.TEXT: While shooting her new film ``The Sheltering Sky'' in the middle of the Sahara Desert, Debra Winger began to cope with the emotional toll of the last five years of her life. ``I have to admit that the last few years weren't so good for me, that I got overwhelmed by life _ marriage, a baby, a house _ overwhelmed,'' the 35-year-old actress told Vanity Fair in its October issue. ``But somewhere in the middle of the desert in Niger, I met up with my nerve and took it back.'' In the last several years, Winger ended her relationship with Bob Kerrey, then governor of Nebraska and now a U.S. senator, married actor Timothy Hutton, had a baby, divorced Hutton, reunited with Kerrey and watched her red-hot career turn lukewarm. She starred in two box-office disappointments, ``Betrayed'' and ``Everybody Wins.'' Her earlier credits included ``Terms of Endearment,'' ``An Officer and a Gentleman'' and ``Legal Eagles.'' Her latest movie, ``The Sheltering Sky,'' is based on Paul Bowles' existential novel about an American couple who travel through North Africa to save their marriage, only for one to lose life and the other sanity. The movie, directed by Bernardo Bertolucci and also starring John Malkovich, was shot in six months, beginning in Tangier and ending in the Sahara Desert. Bertolucci said Winger has ``a terrible reputation'' among directors, and he originally wanted Melanie Griffith and William Hurt for the starring roles. But he also called the actress ``a Stradivarius which can play itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Relaxed Environmental Rules On Drilling Proposed For U.S. Forests
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Forest Service staff has drawn up suggestions for relaxing environmental protection to boost production of oil and gas from national forests, officials said Tuesday. The four-page ``Proposed Strategy for Mitigating Persian Gulf Situation'' cites estimates of almost 7 billion barrels of undiscovered, recoverable oil on Forest Service lands, but says environmental regulations are slowing or blocking exploratory drilling to find the oil. It cites the loss of about 4.5 million barrels of oil per day from Iraq and Kuwait because of a worldwide embargo. ``We have been considering some things the Forest Service can do,'' said Tom King, the service's geology program manager. ``We at no time intended to imply that we're going to go out and commit environmental rape and ruin. We're not in that business.'' He referred to the proposal as an ``idea document'' which has not been approved by senior agency officials. King said he was designated to respond to queries about the proposals Tuesday in the absence of the service's director of minerals and geology. The Forest Service proposals were reported in Tuesday's Washington Post. David Alberswerth, public lands director of the National Wildlife Federation, told the Post he considered the document ``one of many similar ill-conceived initiatives that we will see form the oil industry and its allies in government.'' The Forest Service controls 191 million acres of public lands, of which about 14 million acres are leased to oil and gas producers, down from 35 million acres in 1983. The staff proposal said 40 environmental impact statements on drilling leases in the national forests were scheduled for completion between 1992 and 1995. ``Given the Persian Gulf situation, consideration should be given to expediting the schedule,'' it said, adding that perhaps some of the impact statements could be replaced by more expeditious environmental assessments. The paper said requests to drill should be dealt with as quickly as possible. ``We need to act on these wells if, in our professional opinion, the impacts to the environment are within acceptable limits,'' it said. ``If lawsuits are filed, perhaps the courts will be lenient given the national interest that is at stake.'' Other proposals in the document do not call for relaxed environmental standards, but for mobilizing forest service personnel to deal with existing regulations more quickly. ``In the event that a forest cannot ensure an immediate response to a request to drill, specialized teams should be assembled from other forests,'' it said. ``Drilling should be given the same urgency and management attention as fire.'' The proposals also suggest that Congress might act to streamline current environmental regulations, ``since there is a perception that federal lands possess good drilling prospects in areas that have been overly protected.''

DOC.HEAD: Troop Ceilings May Be Omitted From Conventional Forces Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union, eager to conclude a conventional forces treaty by year's end, may drop provisions limiting troops in Europe, a senior U.S. official said Tuesday. Such a move would leave only one stumbling block to finishing the accord _ a prospective ban on non-nuclear aircraft. The official said that provision may be dropped as well. ``We have the clock ticking,'' he said. ``We're getting to the point where we are going to have to wrap this up.'' A 35-nation summit conference to sign the treaty is being planned in Paris in mid-November. The pact is being negotiated in Vienna between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The official spoke to reporters, here with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, one day before the victorious World War II allies take a historic step to reunite the Germany they defeated 45 years ago. A dispute over missile launchers in what is now East Germany _ which threatened to delay eventual German sovereignty, was resolved on the eve of the ceremony, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said without providing details. The conventional forces treaty would set limits on tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear weapons _ and on non-nuclear aircraft unless they are dropped from the treaty. ``Aircraft and manpower have been very difficult,'' said the official, who requested anonymity. ``So we are considering removing limits on aircraft as well.'' The Soviets have argued that some of their planes the United States wants scrapped have defensive missions and should not be limited. The Soviet Union already is withdrawing thousands of troops from Eastern Europe and has agreed to remove the 350,000 men based in East Germany within four years of German unification, due Oct. 3. The United States agreed in February to limit U.S. forces in Europe to 225,000, with a ceiling of 195,000 on Soviet troops. But the Soviet pullout from East Germany will leave Moscow with far fewer troops. Consequently, Soviets negotiators want to lower the U.S. ceiling. Baker discussed the issue briefly with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, representing the British at Wednesday's ceremonies, in separate sessions here. Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew has been conducting negotiations on the troop question with the Soviets here since Monday. If omitted from the treaty, troop reductions would be governed by events in Europe and by budget decisions in Washington and Moscow, the official said. As for the issue of eventual German sovereignty, Genscher told reporters that there was still disagreement over the kind of military maneuvers that could be held in what is now East Germany. At issue in the missile question is whether launchers capable of packing nuclear-tipped missiles could be deployed in East Germany. Earlier Tuesday, a U.S. official said the matter was ``a tough question of definition.'' A way, he said, must be found to delineate the kind of missile that would not carry nuclear weapons and therefore would be acceptable in Moscow for basing in the area. The launchers would be under NATO control but could be operated by Germans, who have forsworn having nuclear weapons of their own. Baker, Hurd, Genscher, Shevardnadze and the foreign ministers of France and East Germany will sign on Wednesday an accord known as the Two-Plus-Four agreement on the reunification of Germany. While reunification is set for Oct. 3, final German sovereignty requires the four World War II victors to relinquish their joint postwar powers, including control and access to Berlin, which once again will be the German capital. This week, the Soviets and West Germans compromised on the money Bonn would pay for the withdrawal of the troops. The Soviets had demanded about $12 billion while Bonn offered nearly $4.5 billion. On Monday, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze announced the compromise, which West German television placed at about $7.7 billion. Moscow has said that the returning Soviet troops will need housing and job training _ a considerable burden for the ailing Soviet economy.

DOC.BYLINE: With AM-Illinois Execution, Bjt ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Here is a state-by-state breakdown of executions carried out since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty. Texas: 37. Florida: 23. Louisiana: 19. Georgia: 14. Virginia: 9. Alabama: 8. Nevada: 5 Missouri: 5. Mississippi: 4. North Carolina: 3. Utah: 3 South Carolina: 3. Indiana: 2. Arkansas: 2. Oklahoma: 1

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Faults Pipeline Company for Fishing Boat Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The failure of a natural gas pipeline company to make sure a 16-inch pipeline was securely buried beneath the Gulf of Mexico caused a fiery accident last year that killed 11 crew members of a fishing boat, the National Traffic Safety Board said Tuesday. The safety board also said that the failure of the Office of Pipeline Safety to require pipeline operators to inspect and maintain submerged pipelines contributed to the accident in shallow waters a half-mile off Sabine, Texas. But it said the pipeline safety office needs more personnel and resources to accomplish its mission. The board said that while the fishing boat, the Northumberland, was either very close to or penetrating the sea bottom at the time of the accident on Oct. 3, 1989, the ship was not responsible because it was operating in its normal area and at a reasonable speed. The accident, the board said, ``would not have occurred'' had the Natural Gas Pipeline Co. of America ``maintained the pipeline at the depth required by the permit issued by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.'' A spokesman for the company, which has headquarters in Lombard, Ill., said there would be no comment until officials had a chance to review the safety board's conclusions. In more than 20 recommendations, the safety board, an arm of the Department of Transportation, urged a program be put into operation to inspect the company's submerged pipelines and to maintain them in accordance with permits requiring them to be safely buried. The board has no enforcement powers, but can only make recommendations to governmental agencies and private companies for safety improvements. The board urged safety programs be established to warn vessels of the dangers of submerged pipelines and said navigation charts should be revised to warn mariners that submerged pipelines may not be safely buried. In discussing the accident, safety board members said there are more than 18,000 miles of submerged pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico alone but that the exact length of the system or the precise location of all of its components is not known. ``There are no records to verify how many miles of pipeline are out in the gulf,'' said board member Susan M. Coughlin. She questioned whether actual inspection of the pipeline system should begin before promised technology is developed to do the job without the costly and time consuming use of divers. But other members said the board has an obligation to the safety of seafarers to urge that work begin now to see that submerged pipelines are in fact safely buried. The safety board said that inspection by divers after the accident showed that while the pipeline should have been buried some nine feet below the sea bed, it was in fact lying on its surface. When the Northumberland hit and ruptured it, the safety board said, ``natural gas from the high pressure pipeline was released and ignited, engulfing the vessel in flames within seconds.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Faces Primary Test; Democrats Vie to Challenge Boschwitz
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich sought the Democratic nomination for a record fourth term Tuesday in the face of a strong primary challenge from his former commerce commissioner, Mike Hatch. Six Independent-Republicans, including state Auditor Arne Carlson, sought the GOP gubernatorial nomination. The state's other big race was between state Agriculture Commissioner Jim Nichols and Carleton College political science professor Paul Wellstone for the Democratic nomination to challenge Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who faced token opposition in the GOP primary. A third Democrat in the race was Gene Schenk. Perpich had the Democrat-Farmer-Labor endorsement over Hatch and Kent Herschbach, while the Independent-Republicans endorsed businessman Jon Grunseth over Carlson and four other candidates, including Doug Kelley, a former aide to U.S. Sen. Dave Durenberger and a former federal prosecutor. The other GOP candidates were Beatrice Mooney, Mary Jane Rachner and Samuel A. Faulk. In the Senate race, the Democrats endorsed Wellstone. Boschwitz was opposed by John Zeleniak.

Perpich, 62, has served 10 years as governor, longer than anyone in Minnesota history. Hatch, 41, campaigned in part on the theme that the incumbent has been around too long and has become distracted. Perpich had banked on the hope that voters would focus on achievements such as Minnesota's improved economy and the June visit of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Dubbed ``Governor Goofy'' in a Jan. 22 Newsweek magazine article, the governor referred to the moniker in one television ad while saying his successes prove otherwise. Hatch's campaign contrasted his abortion-rights stance with Perpich's anti-abortion stand, and said providing affordable health care to all Minnesotans was a top goal. Wellstone actively campaigned for the Senate in a repainted school bus. Because he continued working as agriculture commissioner, Nichols limited his campaigning to nights and weekends. Wellstone, a member of the Democratic National Committee, led the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 presidential campaign in Minnesota. Nichols is a former state senator.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Use Glasnost to Improve Image
DOC.TEXT: A new public relations department in the KGB is using a film titled ``The Secret War'' to wage a very open campaign of its own to improve the security agency's tarnished image. ``We are having troubles because the Soviet public doesn't understand what we do,'' said the head of the new section, Maj. Gen. Alexander Karbainov. Since the advent of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, the Soviet press has been filled with accounts of terror by the secret police in the early decades of Communist rule. Millions died and millions more were sent to labor camps, particularly under Josef Stalin, whose bloody rule lasted from the 1920s until his death in 1953. ``Stalin turned the Cheka (secret police) into a virtual organ of personal power,'' Karbainov told a news conference for Soviet and foreign reporters in the Lubyanka, the drab downtown headquarters of the security service. The Soviet foreign and domestic intelligence operations are combined in one service, the KGB, unlike the United States, where the functions are divided between the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. During the news conference, Karbainov disclosed little new about the internal workings of the KGB, arguing it was necessary to preserve secrecy about operations, budget and the number of employees. ``Everything relating to the aims, directions and results of KGB work should be open to the public, while methods, forms and techniques used to perform specific operations and security agents should remain hidden from public view for the time-being,'' he said. Karbainov, a 44-year-old former satellite communications engineer, sketched out an ambitious public relations program he is running from a labyrinth of rooms that includes the offices of Felix Dzerzhinsky, founder of the Soviet secret police, and Yuri Andropov, the former KGB chairman who headed the country in 1982. The KGB is releasing a long-delayed film, ``The Secret War,'' on its battles with Western intelligence agencies, as well as television specials on its efforts to fight terrorism, ethnic violence and black-marketeering. KGB officers showed reporters an exhibition of photographs and newspaper clippings of various Western intelligence operations against the Soviet Union; all had been reported in the Soviet press. Karbainov said the KGB also is starting a promotional periodical, and will issue accreditation to a limited number of journalists to enter the Lubyanka to view the exhibitions and sip coffee in a newly created ``press bar.'' ``We're trying to fight the stereotypes of old,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch No Earlier Than Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: NASA expects to be ready for another attempt to launch Columbia on Tuesday at the earliest and will have only a few days to get the shuttle off the ground, officials said Tuesday. If Columbia fails to lift off next week, the mission will have to wait until after Discovery is launched next month, said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of Columbia's prelaunch operations. ``We're doing the best we can,'' Murrah said. ``It's a tough business.'' Columbia's astronomy mission with a $150 million observatory called Astro has been delayed twice by hydrogen leaks and once by problems with a telescope aboard the shuttle. The latest scrub occurred last week after hydrogen flooded the aft compartment. NASA installed a new set of recirculation pumps Monday and planned to test them late Tuesday and early Wednesday by flushing helium through the system. In the pumps that were removed earlier, helium tests failed to find any leaks, said NASA spokesman George Diller. Officials planned to try again with supercold liquid hydrogen to simulate actual fueling conditions. Murrah said Columbia will be ready for launch no sooner than Tuesday. NASA hoped to announce a launch date on Wednesday. Complicating matters for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is the Air Force's plans to launch a Titan 4 rocket with a secret military cargo early next week from nearby Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. One to two days are needed between launches because of range safety requirements. Also looming over NASA's flight plans is the need to launch Discovery between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 with a satellite that will explore the sun's polar regions. If NASA misses that deadline, Discovery's $750 million mission will have to be postponed until late 1991, when Earth is aligned properly again with the sun and Jupiter. The satellite, called Ulysses, will use Jupiter's gravity to be whipped into the proper orbit around the sun. It will be the first spacecraft to circle over the sun's poles. Preparations for Discovery's flight have been running several days behind because of a leak in the shuttle's cooling system, but launch managers are juggling the work schedule to make up for the lost time. The problem has been traced to a vent in an ammonia boiler, and mission managers have recommended that Discovery fly with the leaky boiler as long as the leak remains small. Given the amount of leakage _ about 1 percent a day _ there would be more than enough coolant to last the four-day flight, Diller said. The boiler is needed to cool the shuttle during landings.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominee Assailed For Association With All-White Club
DOC.TEXT: An Alabama professor urged a Senate committee Tuesday to reject President Bush's nominee to a federal appeals court because of his wife's current and his own previous membership in an all-white country club. George Munchus III, associate professor of business at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, said confirmation of U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina to a seat on the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals would have ``a double chilling effect'' on civil rights litigation in Georgia, Alabama and Florida. Munchus, who is executive director of the Center for Human Rights in Birmingham, argued in testimony before the Judiciary Committee that Dubina's resignation from the Montgomery Country Club and his wife's subsequent membership ``is subterfuge of the highest order and most reprehensible.'' ``If non-whites and women are expected to have full faith and confidence in our federal judicial... system, this country can ill afford the Joel Dubina types to serve,'' Munchus said. The committee last month unanimously approved a non-binding resolution which said that belonging to exclusionary clubs is ``inappropriate for persons who may be nominated in the future to serve in the federal judiciary.'' Dubina testified that his wife joined the club in 1986, shortly after he had resigned his membership prior to his nomination as a U.S. District Court judge. But Dubina said he has not visited the club nor enjoyed any club privileges since resigning, and he said his wife has promised to resign if the club ever rejects a qualified black applicant. During questioning by Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., prior to Munchus' testimony, Dubina said the club does not bar members on the basis of race or religion, but he acknowledged that it has no black members. He said no black has ever applied for membership. After he resigned, Dubina said his wife was offered ``a lady resident membership'' and she accepted. He said her grandfather was a member, her father is a member, and she ``grew up in that club.'' Two black lawyers from Montgomery, Kenneth Thomas and Circuit Court Judge Charles Price, both testified in support of Dubina, who was nominated to the seat that was left vacant when U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance was killed in a mail-bomb explosion last December. The all-white membership at another Birmingham Country Club, Shoal Creek, threw professional golf into turmoil earlier this month as some commercial sponsors threatened to withdraw from televising the PGA Championship there. Shoal Creek later admitted a black member.

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Revisited: Reagan Wins Cheers Where He Was Once Jeered
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan, once lambasted by angry demonstrators in divided Berlin, was hailed Tuesday as a returning hero. On Wednesday, Reagan is to cross into East Berlin at the Brandenburg Gate, where he gave a speech in 1987 challenging Moscow to tear down the Berlin Wall. That visit was marred by demonstrations by 25,000 people opposed to U.S. foreign policy. Now that East and West Germany are to reunite in October, the atmosphere is transformed. On Tuesday, the 79-year-old saw only cheerful faces in his brief contact with the public. About 100 Germans and foreign tourists gathered outside the Bristol Kempinski Hotel to see Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a diplomatic dinner. They applauded and called for autographs. The Berliner Morgenpost daily welcomed Reagan's visit with a headline saying his walk through the Brandenburg Gate will mean ``Reagan's Dream Fulfilled.'' Reagan and his wife arrived in Berlin early in the day to open a 10-day European trip. During his 1987 visit, Reagan voiced skepticism about reforms started by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He said the one thing Moscow could do to advance the cause of peace would be to dismantle the Berlin Wall. ``Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate,'' Reagan said. ``Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.'' The former Communist rulers of East Germany opened the wall in November in one of their last, desperate acts to stay in power. On Wednesday, Reagan will travel about a mile into East Berlin to meet with officials there _ now democratically elected.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Countries Hail Agreement Among Warring Cambodian Factions
DOC.TEXT: Communist Vietnam and pro-Western Asian nations on Tuesday welcomed an agreement among Cambodia's warring factions, but cautioned of further obstacles before peace comes to that war-torn nation. The official Vietnam News Agency quoted a Foreign Ministry statement as saying the agreement Monday in Jakarta, Indonesia, ``is a decisive step leading to the reconvening of the Paris international conference on Cambodia. The peace process, however, still has to overcome numerous obstacles and hurdles.'' ``Together with other countries participating in the Paris international conference on Cambodia, Vietnam will do its best to contribute to the success of the conference in achieving an overall political solution to the Cambodia issue,'' it said. In Paris in July and August of 1989, 19 nations failed to produce a peace accord and concluded there must be substantial progress among the Cambodian factions themselves before the conference could be reconvened. Vietnam has been the main backer of the Phnom Penh government. Most Southeast Asian nations have supported the three-party guerrilla coalition, but also have stepped up mediation efforts in recent years to end the 11-year-old civil war. A Thai government spokesman announced that Premier Hun Sen of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government will visit Thailand on Wednesday to discuss the next step of the peace process with Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, a key mediator. The Cambodian government and the three guerrilla groups battling it agreed in Indonesia to accept as a basis for a settlement a U.N. Security Council plan. The plan calls for a major U.N. role in administering the country until elections are held. The factions also agreed to form a Supreme National Council to represent the country and be the source of authority during the transitional period. Hun Sen also called in Jakarta for an immediate cease-fire, the official Cambodian news agency SPK reported. It did not say how the guerrillas responded, but they have previously supported a truce only in the context of a comprehensive political settlement. The Security Council plan envisions a U.N. peacekeeping force of as many as 10,000 soldiers and 10,000 civilian workers. The operation could cost the United Nations up to $5 billion over one or two years, according to U.S. officials. State-run Radio Thailand reported Tuesday that Chatichai welcomed the Jakarta agreement, and said his country may be willing to join the U.N. peacekeeping force. Thailand gives aid and sanctuary to the guerrillas but also has been a prime mediator since Chatichai took office in August 1988. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke also reiterated his country would be willing to contribute troops to the U.N. operation. He was addressing the Parliament in Canberra. Foreign Minister Wong Kan Seng of Singapore, a major source of arms for the guerrillas, welcomed the Jakarta agreement and said it should be followed by reopening the Paris conference. The Japanese government, which hosted Cambodian peace talks in June where the first consensus on the Supreme National Council was reached, also welcomed the outcome at Jakarta. In the June talks, final agreement could not be reached because of objections from the hard-line Khmer Rouge guerrilla group, which said it was not being treated on an equal status with the government. ``Of course, there still remain several problems, such as how actual suspension of military actions is to be realized, how the United Nations will be involved in the administration of that country in the interim period, and other problems,'' Japanese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Taizo Watanabe said. The guerrilla coalition consists of the Communist Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist forces led by former Premier Son Sann and Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The resistance coalition has been battling the government Vietnam installed in Phnom Penh after it invaded in late 1978 and toppled the Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge had during nearly four years of rule tried to transform Cambodia into a radical agrarian society, causing the deaths of nearly 1 million people due mostly to starvation and executions.

DOC.HEAD: McCandless Retiring From NASA
DOC.TEXT: Astronaut Bruce McCandless II, who will be remembered in history books as the first human to float free in space, has retired from NASA and the Navy. While his name is not well known, his picture is. The photograph of McCandless suspended against the black of space with the blue Earth off to one side is one of the most famous. ``I've been government property since the age of 17,'' said McCandless, 53, in an interview from the Johnson Space Center. ``I've been here for 24 years in the astronaut office. It was time for a little bit of a change of pace.'' McCandless, a Navy captain, remained in the service while serving with NASA. He had to retire under Navy regulations because he was not promoted to flag rank and had 32 years of service. McCandless graduated from the Naval Academy, ranking second in a class of 899. He said he hopes to work as a consultant with contractors involved in the Hubble Space Telescope project. McCandless had a key role, as an astronaut, in developing the telescope and he was part of the space shuttle crew that launched it in April. McCandless helped develop the space agency's Manned Maneuvering Unit, a jet-powered backpack, and was the first to wear it in space on a flight in February 1984. He was the first human to move in space untethered, looking like a helpless teddy bear swaddled in white. ``That may have been one small step for Neil, but it's a heck of a big leap for me,'' said McCandless as he floated out of the cargo of space shuttle Challenger. He was parodying Neil Armstrong's first words when he stepped on the moon on July 20, 1969.

DOC.HEAD: States Claim EPA Not Tough Enough On States Without Toxic Disposal Plans
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Officials of states that claim they are becoming the nation's toxic waste dumps criticized the federal government Tuesday for not penalizing states that fail to take care of their own hazardous poisons. Environmental officials from 13 of the 17 states that receive more toxic waste for disposal than they ship out opened a two-day conference to form an association that could file lawsuits against the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Top EPA officials appeared before the state representatives, who demanded that the EPA get tough on violators of a 1986 federal program aimed at making states deal with hazardous waste. The ``capacity assurance'' program required all states to come up with a toxic waste disposal plan. EPA officials said all 50 states and the District of Columbia met last October's deadline for submitting proposed plans but only 38 were approved by the federal agency. Alabama and South Carolina, with major hazardous waste landfills inside their borders, organized the association of ``net importer states'' to work collectively to make exporter states share the disposal problem. ``If you don't do something pretty quickly, you will force the states to do something we don't want to do,'' Bill Child, representing the Illinois state EPA, told Russ Wyer, director of the Waste Management Division at EPA headquarters in Washington. Leigh Pegues, director of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management, said a lawsuit against EPA was not out of the question. He said EPA Administrator Bill Riley and his deputy, Hank Habicht, turned down invitations to attend the Alabama meeting. Wyer promised to return to Washington with the states' complaints but did not promise EPA would take stronger measures against non-complying states. However, he said the agency would ``evaluate sanctions'' that could be imposed for failure to meet the deadline in the capacity assurance program. The ``net importer states'' claim EPA has failed to withhold Superfund cleanup money from states that have failed to meet the program's requirements. ``They haven't done anything,'' said Pegues, whose state is home to the nation's largest commercial hazardous waste landfill, a toxic dump run by Chemical Waste Management Inc. at Emelle in rural west Alabama. EPA officials blamed regional differences throughout the country and the problems some states have with the staffing of their environmental agencies, which are assigned the job of complying with the federal program. At a luncheon Tuesday, Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt said Alabama and the 16 other importer states ``continue to manage more than our share of the problem.'' Asked about the possibility of a lawsuit against EPA, N.G. Kaul, representing the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, said that would be a ``last resort.'' But he said the EPA has yet to act against New Jersey, which, according to Kaul, has been ``looking for a landfill site almost 10 years.'' Greer Tidwell, director of the Atlanta regional office of the federal EPA, promised the state officials he would try to arrange a meeting next month with top EPA officials in Washington to discuss the state officials' complaints about the agency. Delegates to the coastal conference represent California, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Michigan, Nevada, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Texas, Utah, South Carolina and Alabama, according to Catherine Lamar, a spokeswoman for the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. Arkansas, Colorado, Idaho and Oregon are among the 17 net importer states but did not have representatives at the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Cost Rising Past $1 Billion a Month
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney disclosed Tuesday that the cost of the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East could total $15 billion in the next fiscal year, but promised disgruntled lawmakers ``a significant increase'' in help from Arab nations and other American allies. Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee, giving Congress its first major update on the massive American military deployment that was begun in early August. Cheney's cost figure was above the $1 billion-a-month estimate generally used by government officials, and he added that costs ``would multiply many fold'' if U.S. troops become involved in combat. Several senators used Tuesday's session to show their distress over the amounts of military backing supplied by Arab nations in the region, and financial support from U.S. allies heavily dependent upon Persian Gulf oil supplies. ``There's something missing here,'' protested the committee chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., complaining that no Arab military forces with heavy armaments such as tanks or artillery were on the ground in Saudi Arabia. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, criticized both the West German government and the Japanese for offering little support to an operation that was vital to keeping oil supplies flowing to their economies. ``I find it appalling,'' Cohen told Cheney and the general. ``This kind of cooperation from the allies ... is not going to stand well with me and I hope with a lot of other members'' when it comes time to consider the amount of U.S. funding that will go to U.S. military forces helping provide for the defense of Western Europe and the Far East. In his testimony, Cheney told the senators that by Sept. 30, the end of the 1990 fiscal year, ``we will have spent more than $2.7 billion in additional costs over and above budgeted funds'' on the new operation in the Middle East. ``We expect these incremental costs to total about $15 billion in fiscal year 1991 if the crisis continues for the entire fiscal year,'' Cheney's statement said. ``If the conflict occurs, these costs would multiply many fold.'' Such costs would wipe out any ``peace dividend'' derived from cuts in Pentagon spending in reaction to easing of tensions in Europe _ absent contributions by U.S. allies to help pay the bill for Operation Desert Shield. Three nations _ Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates _ said this week they would contribute about $12 billion to the Mideast effort against Iraq, including money for nations hurt by their support of the economic embargo. Cheney said he couldn't pledge that the total cost of the U.S. operation would be offset, ``but I think a sizeable amount will be.'' Meanwhile, a Pentagon spokesman said Tuesday the United States had detected ``some increase in military activity'' inside Iraq near its borders with Turkey and Syria, ``but there is nothing to indicate imminent hostilities.'' The spokesman, Pete Williams, said that while the forces' posture remained defensive, it could become offensive ``very quickly.'' On another subject, Williams said the naval embargo operation had logged some 750 intercepts, but he cautioned that those can involve the same ship being contacted more than once. He said some 40 boardings have been conducted, including 35 by U.S. ships. He would not disclose the names of the other nations involved. Also, Williams disclosed that permission has been granted for U.S. troops to conduct live-fire training exercises in Saudi Arabia. The approval was granted Monday for the live firing of artillery and guns up to 105 mm, and approval was being sought for 120 mm weapons, he said. At the Senate hearing, Cheney said the Pentagon was ``taking measures'' to enhance the protection of U.S. troops and civilians overseas and at home, believing that ``terrorism is potentially a significant weapon in the Iraqi arsenal.'' The State Department returned Iraq to its list of states abetting and aiding terrorism on Sept. 4, Cheney said. ``During this period of heightened tension, the terrorist threat to our forces in Saudi Arabia and to U.S. personnel and interests worldwide is, and will remain, high,'' Cheney's testimony said. Cheney disclosed that U.S. officials ``have received bomb threats, death threats, and verbal warnings from international terrorist organizations'' but he added that ``no specific credible threats'' have yet been identified. On the subject of contributions by nations benefiting from U.S. defense of Saudi Arabia, Cheney told the senators, ``I can assure you that is a subject we are working on.'' ``There are in fact forces from other Arab nations en route, or will shortly be en route, a significant increase in the military capability of the allies' forces that are being deployed,'' Cheney said. However, Powell interjected that ``these other forces are still some time from being there.'' Cheney reminded that the Egyptians and Moroccans, as well as ``eight, nine, ten,'' other Arab countries have pledged to increase their commitments to the region. But Nunn dismissed the contributions as ``very small'' in number and ``very light'' in terms of armament. Cheney also noted that few countries other than the United States have the logistical capability of moving heavy forces abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Panel Investigates Contributions to Woman Involved with Archbishop
DOC.TEXT: A Catholic review committee is investigating a Georgia parish's charitable contributions to the woman whose intimate relationship with former Atlanta Archbishop Eugene A. Marino led to his resignation. The Rev. Peter Dora, spokesman for the Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta, said Tuesday that St. Pius X Church in Conyers, Ga., gave Vicki Long $1,000 to $2,000 over several years. Dora said the Rev. John P. Walsh, pastor of St. Pius, turned financial records over to the archdiocese after the review committee was appointed last month. At the time the money was given, Walsh was unaware Ms. Long was receiving money from anyone else, Dora said. ``He certainly was not aware she was involved with anyone in the church,'' he added. Dora said Walsh had been at St. Pius about two years and had served at St. John's in Hapeville, where Ms. Long is a member now, from 1979 to 1983. He said he did not know when the money, which came from the St. Pius parish funds for the poor, was given to Ms. Long. He also said Walsh ``has stated unequivocally that he was not involved'' with Ms. Long. Walsh was not at his church Tuesday and could be reached for comment. Ms. Long's attorney, Gloria Allred of Los Angeles, did not immediately return a phone call. The review committee also is examining the financial records of the archdiocese and two parishes pastored by the Rev. Michael Woods, who resigned Aug. 4, saying he had been intimately involved with Ms. Long.

DOC.BYLINE: Heat and Thunderstorms Continue As Summer Wanes ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Hot, humid conditions combined Tuesday to create showers and thundershowers across much of the nation, particularly the Midwest and South. By early afternoon, such storms extended across west-central Wisconsin, western Kentucky, southern Indiana, southern Illinois, southern Missouri, Arkansas, eastern Oklahoma, southern and eastern Texas, Louisiana, southern Mississippi, southern Georgia, south-central Tennessee, southern Alabama, and parts of Florida. At noon EDT the center of Hurricane Isidore was more than 1,000 miles west-southwest of the Azores, moving toward the north-northwest, and was no threat to any land mass. Highest sustained wind speed was 85 mph. No change in strength was forecast for the next 24 hours. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 at Oak Harbor, Wash., to 110 at Thermal, Calif. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 was 29 at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Differ on Whether Rodney Dangerfield Deserves Respect
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for Rodney Dangerfield said Tuesday comic who complains of getting no respect received none when he was allegedly injured in a steam room accident at Caesars Palace in March 1988. But an attorney for the resort countered that Dangerfield created his own problems, saying the eye injuries he blamed on Caesars were self-inflicted. Caesars' lawyer Louis Meisinger told jurors in U.S. District Court in his opening statement they would know why Dangerfield gets no respect once the civil trial ends. Dangerfield is suing Caesars for $225,000 in lost wages plus damages of $5 million in connection with the accident. Caesars is countersuing Dangerfield for $100,000 plus punitive damages. Dangerfield left Caesars following the March 1988 incident. He now performs across the Strip, at Bally's Hotel. Attorney Barry Langberg said Dangerfield had performed nearly 1,000 shows in Las Vegas without a cancellation until his eyes were burned in the steam room accident March 16, 1988. He said Caesars tried to escape blame for the accident and refused to pay Dangerfield $225,000 for five performances he missed after the accident. Meisinger described Dangerfield as a ``petulant performer'' and said his injuries were ``a figment of his fertile, comedic imagination.'' He called on the jury to ``send a message to peformers like Mr. Dangerfield that they are not special and cannot do things like that.'' Lawyers for both sides huddled for more than an hour before opening arguments began Tuesday, reviewing a series of motions. One issue is whether to allow claims raised by Caesars in court papers filed last month. The resort claimed in the papers that Dangerfield used large amounts of marijuana, cocaine and vodka. Dangerfield denied the allegations Monday. ``Anybody who knows me knows it's untrue,'' he said after jury selection. The drug issue was not raised in opening arguments. Langberg said Dangerfield's eyes were injured by a burst of steam when he entered a steam room. Dangerfield missed shows March 17, 18 and 19, when two shows were scheduled, then performed shows March 20 and 21 while in pain, Langberg said. Caesars officials paid Dangerfield for only three nights on March 22. He went on stage and announced to a packed house that he wouldn't be performing that night, and suggested the audience get their money back, Meisinger said. ``We think this is a simple case that the Caesars that injured Rodney Dangerfield through its negligence should pay him,'' Langberg contended. Meisinger said Dangerfield is attempting to blame Caesars for an eye problem the comic has had since the 1970s. He said Dangerfield's eye problems have been compounded by a medication he continues to use despite doctors' warnings that it could severely damage his eyes. He said Dangerfield applied the medication to his eyes 10 times in one hour the day after the steam room incident. ``Mr. Dangerfield essentially applied poison to his own eyes,'' Meisinger said. ``The injury was a self-inflicted act by Mr. Dangerfield.'' Meisinger said Dangerfield visited doctors in the days after the accident. ``These doctors will testify they thought he could have performed, but they thought he was not motivated to perform,'' Meisinger said. ``This is a case of a performer who got very, very mad when Caesars said `we expect you to live up to your contract.' ''

DOC.HEAD: West African Leader Says Doe's Death Complicates Liberian Situation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 24th graf `Sources close' to give Sawyer's first name, position. Pickup 25th pvs, `Doe took...'
DOC.TEXT: Troops loyal to slain President Samuel Doe bombarded rebels from atop the executive mansion Tuesday, and a West African leader said Doe's death would make it more difficult to end the war. Two days after rebels led by Prince Johnson attacked Doe and his entourage at the headquarters of the West African task force, the late president's men used heavy cannons to beat back insurgents. Throughout Monrovia, shells exploded and gunfire crackled as Prince Johnson's fighters scoured the city for Doe loyalists. Survivors from Doe's elite presidential guard turned heavy artillery, placed on the roof of the seaside executive mansion, onto the rebels and the war-ravaged city. The guns normally face out toward the Atlantic Ocean. Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara said Doe's men had asked the five-nation West African force to help them evacuate the capital. Jawara said aid would be offered on humanitarian grounds. ``I think it is now urgent to try and do something about protecting these 230 or so Doe supporters from factional or tribal revenge,'' said Jawara, chairman of the 16-member Economic Community of West African States. The Community ordered a 3,000-member task force into Liberia last month to help quell the 8{-month-old civil war, often marked by tribal fighting. The soldiers are from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia. Jawara, who was visiting Zimbabwe, said that rather than speeding the war's end, Doe's death Monday likely would increase bloodshed. Witnesses said Doe's mutilated body was on display at Johnson's headquarters outside the city. Johnson had said Doe would be court-martialed, but within a day of his capture Sunday he was reported dead from gunshot wounds. The West African force commander, Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana, said Tuesday that 78 people were killed when Johnson's men attacked Doe's entourage on Sunday. Among the dead was Defense Minister Brig. Gen. J. Boima Barclay. Quainoo said in a statement Doe told him he had come to express his surprise that Quainoo had not paid him a courtesy call. The statement said: ``General Doe talked at length to the effect that he was not ready to submit the sovereignty of his country to any power or indeed regional organization.'' Quainoo said Doe accused the United States of destroying Liberia. Doe said he ``feared no one and would fight to the end.'' The statement said Johnson and about 40 of his men then arrived and protested Doe's visit. An argument ensued that degenerated into a shootout. Quainoo and other West African officers tried to persuade Johnson and his men to stop, ``but failed, except that they did not kill Doe, who was shot in the legs and taken away.'' Doe's removal from power had been the key demand of Johnson's rival, Charles Taylor. But Taylor's spokesman, Tom Woewiyu, said Taylor now was insisting on withdrawal of the West African force before accepting a truce. Plumes of smoke rose Tuesday and sounds of gunfire and shelling echoed from eastern Sinkor suburb, from where Taylor's fighters again tried to move into Monrovia. It was unclear how strong Taylor's forces are. At one point he claimed 10,000 fighters. But reporters who visited his camp said many insurgents have returned to their villages, and those who remain include many young boys with no training. Taylor, a former bureaucrat, overran much of Liberia with little difficulty after leading a rebel army in an invasion Dec. 24. But he has been blocked in the eastern suburbs of Monrovia for more than two months. Johnson, a former lieutenant in Doe's army, broke with Taylor earlier this year and advanced on the capital. In Abidjan, capital of Ivory Coast, a group of Johnson supporters took over the Liberian Embassy. Ambassador Harold Tarr and his staff abandoned the office Monday after they heard Doe was dead. Liberia has been without effective government for months. Since mid-July, Monrovia has been torn by fighting involving the two rebel armies and Doe loyalists. Much of the capital is without food and water. An interim government named at a national unity conference in Gambia on Aug. 30 _ but rejected by Taylor _ said Tuesday it was sending a delegation to Monrovia to prepare its installation. Sources close to Amos Sawyer, who was named president of the interim government at the Aug. 30 conference, said he was urged to send envoys by Johnson and Brig. Gen. David Nimley, whom Doe loyalists named acting president. Doe took power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of freed American slaves who had discriminated against Liberian natives. The rebels accused Doe of misappropriation of state funds and other corruption. But the civil war has been fought largely upon tribal lines. Doe was from the Krahn people, one of 14 small tribes in Liberia. Johnson is the son of a Gio, and Taylor is of mixed Americo-Liberian and native ancestry. Americo-Liberians are the descendents of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Miss America Contest Wins TV Ratings Race
LaserGraphic
With AM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: TV coverage of a superpower huddle to discuss the Middle East crisis and a late-summer premiere proved no competition for the Miss America pageant, which was the most-watched show on television last week. Saturday night's crowning of Marjorie Judith Vincent from Illinois breezed past a CBS update on the Helsinki superpower summit and NBC's debut of ``The Fanelli Boys'' situation comedy, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. NBC's live broadcast of the Miss America pageant grabbed a 17.8 average rating, well ahead of the network's ``The Golden Girls,'' which occupied the No. 2 spot with a 15.9 average. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. In the No. 6 slot was Sunday's ``60 Minutes,'' featuring a segment by Dan Rather in Helsinki, where President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev discussed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Landing in the No. 4 spot was NBC's Saturday night premiere of ``The Fanelli Boys,'' a half-hour program focusing on four Italian brothers in Brooklyn and their widowed mother. NBC again won the overall prime-time ratings war with a 10.7 average. ABC scored a 9.4, barely edging out CBS with 9.3. With the exceptions of ``The Fanelli Boys,'' ``60 Minutes'' and the Miss America pageant, reruns dominated every other position in the Top 10. Finishing third was NBC's ``Cheers.'' In fifth place was ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' CBS's ``Designing Women'' tied for seventh place with ABC's ``Roseanne.'' ``A Different World,'' on NBC was No. 9. NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' locked with the network's ``Unsolved Mysteries'' in a tie for 10th place. Bill Cosby and his family again topped Bart Simpson and his animated clan, as ``The Simpsons'' ranked 53rd in its second week since moving to Thursdays at 8 p.m., opposite ``The Cosby Show.'' ABC continued to trounce the competition in network news wars. The latest ratings showed Peter Jennings and ABC well in front with a 9.8 average. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 8.4 and NBC and Tom Brokaw were last with 8.3. Here are the top 10 prime-time shows, their network and rating: ``Miss America Pageant,'' NBC, 17.8; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 15.9; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 15.4; ``The Fanelli Boys,'' 15; NBC, ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 14.8; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 14.7; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, ``Roseanne,'' ABC (tie), 14.2; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 13.8; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC (tie), 13.7.
