DOC.HEAD: Judge Rebuffs Attempt to Withdraw Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday denied a motion by convicted spy Jonathan J. Pollard to withdraw his 1986 guilty plea to selling a wide range of defense secrets to Israel. U.S. District Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. also rejected allegations by Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz that federal prosecutors improperly supplied the judge with information that influenced the decision to impose a life sentence on the former civilian Navy intelligence analyst. Dershowitz based his allegation on a conversation he says he had last fall with former Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg, who died Jan. 19 at the age of 81, according to court papers unsealed Tuesday by Robinson. Dershowitz said in an affidavit that Goldberg told him of a conversation with Robinson in which the judge explained why he gave Pollard a life sentence. Goldberg quoted Robinson as saying that information from prosecutors that Pollard had sold Israel U.S. spy satellite photos of tests of Israeli-made missiles in South Africa ``weighed heavily'' in the decision to impose a life sentence, according to the affidavit. In his opinion, Robinson denied receiving the information, which he said was false, and added that the claim of improper contact by prosecutors ``is based upon pure hearsay, twice over.'' The judge rejected a defense request that he retire from the case. Pollard received a life sentence in 1987 for his guilty plea to conspiracy to commit espionage. At sentencing, prosecutors said that Pollard had given Israel enough classified documents to fill a large closet. In his motions, Pollard claimed that prosecutors reneged on their promise not to seek life sentence by framing their pre-sentence arguments to ensure that Robinson imposed the life term anyway. Prosecutors denied in court papers that they improperly gave Robinson any information about Pollard's spying that was not produced during the trial. The government noted that the testing of the Israeli Jericho missiles in South Africa did not occur until July 1989, ``and hardly could have formed the basis of a sentencing decision made in 1987.'' ``We think it more likely that, assuming that there was some conversation between Chief Judge Robinson and Justice Goldberg, that they discussed current events, and that their conversation has been distorted in the retelling,'' said a government brief. Dershowitz, who served as one of Goldberg's law clerks in the 1960s, quoted the former justice as saying that he thought that because Robinson is black, he would be ``particularly sensitive'' to evidence of an Israeli-South African connection. Robinson did not specifically say whether he ever talked with Goldberg about the case except to say: ``The court's recollection of events is in stark contradition to that claim.'' Prosecutors dryly noted in their pleadings that it was convenient for Dershowitz to claim he received information from someone now deceased. This argument prompted Pollard's defense attorney, Hamilton P. Fox III, to file a separate affidavit stating that Dershowitz contacted him almost two months before Goldberg's death to relate the details of the conversation. Goldberg was appointed to the Supreme Court by President Kennedy but resigned from the high court when President Johnson named him ambassador to the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Envoy Resigns, Citing Split Among Arabs on Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The envoy of the Arab League said Tuesday he is resigning because he opposes Arab acceptance of the U.S.-led military buildup in the Persian Gulf. It was the second time this month a top official has announced his intention to step down from his post at the 21-nation organization, which is deeply torn by divisions over the gulf crisis. The group's U.N. envoy, Clovis Maksoud, appealed Tuesday that the ``wound inflicted on Kuwait ... not lead to amputation of part of the Arab body politic.'' Maksoud told a news conference he can longer no longer reconcile his own convictions in favor of a larger Arab role with Arab acceptance of the buildup of U.S. and foreign forces in the gulf. He complained that Arab nations were losing credibility because of their failure to act together. He said they were becoming ``marginalized'' because the United States, not an Arab front, was resisting Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He said Arabs must seek a ``third way'' between accepting Iraqi domination of Kuwait and allowing the U.S. military buildup. Hundreds of thousands of U.S. and Iraqi troops are poised on opposite sides of the Kuwaiti-Saudi border in a standoff. Maksoud said he favored ``breathing space'' to permit an Arab solution to what he called an Arab problem, including a significant Arab military force to replace the U.S.-led military operation. In his comments, Maksoud also said the gulf crisis should not deflect Arab states from their fundamental aim of reaching a just settlement with Israel. Maksoud, a Lebanese scholar who has represented the league for 11 years at the United Nations and in Washington, said he had sought unsuccessfully to resign in August because of fatigue and philosophical differences. On Tuesday, he said he would step down but pledged to remain in a caretaker capacity until a successor is chosen. On Sept. 3, Chedli Klibi of Tunisia, secretary-general of the Arab League, resigned his post. Some diplomats said he was upset about the decision to move the Arab League headquarters back to Cairo from Tunis. Maksoud said his own decision had nothing to do with the Cairo move. Egypt took the lead last month at an Arab League summit in Cairo to respond to the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A majority of members decided to send forces to the Persian Gulf to counter Iraq. In his comments Tuesday, Maksoud said that he favors an Iraqi withdrawal, restoration of Kuwait's government, a pullout of foreign forces, and a temporary deployment of an Arab force.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Move For More Tax Collectors
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Tuesday rejected President Bush's request for money to hire 1,050 more tax collectors but approved $80.4 million for a new federal courthouse in Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd's home state. On a 93-6 vote, the Senate approved a $20.7 billion appropriations bill covering spending by the Treasury Department, Postal Service, offices of Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle, and several other agencies in fiscal 1991, beginning Oct. 1. Voting against the legislation were Sens. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; Trent Lott, R-Miss.; Connie Mack, R-Fla., and William Roth, R-Del. The bill slashes the $6.1 billion that Bush wanted to spend this year on buying new computers for the Internal Revenue Service and expanding its enforcement capabilities by a total of $228 million. But it adds more than $170 million for lawmakers' pet projects in the form of new construction for the General Services Administration, the government's landlord, to a version the House approved in July. Included in that amount is the $80.4 million for a proposed new federal building-courthouse in Charleston, W.Va., the capital of Democrat Byrd's home state. By a 65-34 vote, the Senate effectively rejected an effort by Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, to restore Bush's request for $55.5 million to hire 1,050 more IRS agents to try to recover some of the estimated $96 billion in uncollected taxes and penalties owed the government from 1989 alone. Opponents said the amendment would violate the budget law without cuts in other areas. ``This is not a budget buster; it's a revenue raiser,'' Glenn retorted, citing estimates by congressional auditors and the IRS that the new agents would raise at least $2 for every dollar spent on hiring them. However, neither Glenn nor any other lawmaker mentioned the proposed new West Virginia courthouse or other senators' pet GSA projects in the legislation. The bill now go to a conference between House and Senate negotiators. By a 63-36 vote, the Senate rejected an effort by Helms to put it on record in firm opposition to abortion as part of a United Nations convention on the rights of children. Helms wanted to attach his measure to an amendment by Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., urging Bush to sign the U.N. convention on the rights of children and sending it to the Senate for ratification. Bradley's amendment was later adopted on a voice vote. ``The reason we were able to get this convention passed last year by the United Nations ... was that it was neutral on abortion,'' Bradley said, urging defeat of Helms' measure. ``It's left entirely to the laws of the nations.'' Also adopted on a 97-2 vote was a non-binding resolution by Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., saying that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein should be tried as a war criminal if fighting erupts between his and U.S. troops in the Middle East. Voting against the resolution were Sens. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., and Bob Kerry, D-Neb. In addition to the IRS cuts, the Senate also trimmed the request by Bush and the House's appropriation for the U.S. Postal Service by $14 million to $508.7 million. And the Senate trimmed another $50.3 million from Bush's request for running the White House but left intact the administration's recommended appropriation of $626,000 for operating and renovating Quayle's government-provided home in Washington. The House had approved all of the $329.97 million sought by Bush for running the White House and the various executive offices such as the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Environmental Quality directly under the president. Also added to the House version of the bill was a measure sought by government executives over the past five years to revise the federal pay system by linking salaries to comparable private jobs in various cities. While federal pay is higher for many jobs in some low-cost areas, nationwide it is 28 percent below the average paid by private businesses for identical skills, according to government studies. In a major compromise with the administration, the bill would give the president authority to revise the pay system but would also allow him to adjust the appropriate levels downward. The Senate has estimated the cost of catching federal workers up to their private industry counterparts in high-cost cities at $5 billion over the next five years. Another pay amendment by Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., added to the legislation would increase the wages of some 60,000 federal law enforcement officers by $2,000 to $5,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Threatens Veto of Reduced Military Spending Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-14 bgng: ``In action,'' with 7 grafs on rejection of amendment forcing Navy to close base in Staten Island. Should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Tuesday threatened a veto of a $283 billion military spending bill if approved by the House, contending the package would hamper U.S. efforts against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams raised the veto possibility as the House took up the military blueprint for fiscal 1991 in a climate of diminishing concern about the Soviet Union but growing worry about Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``If the House bill is enacted in its present form, then the president's senior advisers and the secretary would recommend that the president veto it,'' Williams said at a Pentagon briefing. The bill, crafted by the House Armed Services Committee prior to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, would slash nearly $2 billion from President Bush's request for the Strategic Defense Initiative, halt production of the B-2 bomber and cut U.S. troop strength by 129,500. Williams singled out those provisions, in particular the troop reduction that far exceeds the 38,000 proposed by the administration. ``That would pose an undue risk to national security, greatly complicate the department's ability to deal with the current crisis in the gulf and also rob the department of the flexibility we need to manage the force draw-down in an effective way,'' he said. The Pentagon spokesman also criticized a provision in the bill that would require the Defense Department to come up with a plan by 1994 to ``dual base'' all military units _ permanently stationing all American troops in the United States and ordering short-term rotations overseas. ``A U.S. withdrawal worldwide would create a potential vacuum and increase the potential for regional differences to turn into major crises,'' Williams said. Rep. David O'B. Martin, R-N.Y., sponsor of an amendment to eliminate the dual-basing provision, said if the measure ``isn't a return to isolationism, I don't know what would be.'' The House planned to take up that issue Wednesday as well as several amendments requiring U.S. allies to share a larger portion of the cost of stationing troops overseas. The main proponent of dual-basing, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said last week that the recent deployment of U.S. troops to the gulf strengthens her argument. ``We're much better off keeping people in the United States rather than these very expensive, forward deployed'' locations, said Schroeder who chairs the House Armed Services subcommittee on military installations and facilities. In action on the bill Tuesday, the House rejected an amendment that would have forced the Navy to close the planned ``home port'' battleship base at New York City's Staten Island, an installation in which the Pentagon has invested more than $230 million. By a vote of 230-188, the House approved a measure that would prevent closure until after a Pentagon plan on naval installations is submitted to Congress. The decision was a victory for Rep. Susan Molinari, R-N.Y., a lawmaker who has served in the House for just six months, and a defeat for Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and chairman of the seapower subcommittee. Molinari, who represents Staten Island, argued that the facility is more than 95 percent complete and singling out one installation for closing would undermine the all-or-none base closure process adopted by the House several years ago. ``Your military installation could be next,'' Molinari warned members always conscious of projects in their home districts. She shared her victory with her father, Guy, a former member and the Staten Island borough president who made a rare appearance in the House to help his daughter. The House also overwhelmingly approved a measure sponsored by Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., to create a professional work corps within the Pentagon to purchase weapons and other defense-related items. Meanwhile, a group of House Republicans reaffirmed opposition to the bill, saying that the $24 billion cut from Bush's request of $307 billion in military spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 ``threatens the security of the United States.'' In a statement issued after a meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the House Republican Policy Committee said the bill's cuts in strategic modernization and personnel ``could seriously jeopardize our nation's ability to undertake military operations similar to Operation Desert Shield now under way in Saudi Arabia.'' Democrats, however, hailed the legislation as an appropriate response to the changing threat to the West. ``The House Armed Services Committee has fashioned a bill that makes real progress toward restructuring United States military forces to meet changing circumstances of the 1990s and beyond,'' Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla. said during debate on the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspected Colombian Drug Traffickers Extradited to U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 11 `In a' to ADD dropped word `not.' Picks up graf 12 pvs, `Under the...'
DOC.TEXT: Two suspected Colombian drug traffickers were extradited to the United States on Tuesday, the first such extraditions since President Cesar Gaviria took office last month. Jose Hilario Ortiz and Raul Hernan Buchelli, who both face drug trafficking charges in the United States, were placed on board a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration plane bound for Miami, national police chief Gen. Miguel Gomez said in remarks broadcast by the RCN radio network. Ortiz faces drug trafficking charges in Connecticut and Buchelli is wanted in Florida, said a police spokesman, requesting anonymity. No further details were immediately available. Buchelli is wanted on charges of conspiracy to smuggle and distribute heroin and money laundering, while Ortiz pleaded guilty to a cocaine trafficking conspiracy charge and fled the country before sentencing, according to U.S. court records. Buchelli's brother, Guido Lucio, also faces drug trafficking charges in the United States. But he was released last week after the government rejected a U.S. request for his extradition, citing insufficient evidence. Colombia has extradited 24 suspected drug traffickers to the United States since August 1989, when the government launched a major anti-drug crackdown after the murder of a presidential candidate. Twelve of those extradited have either been convicted at trial or pleaded guilty; one was acquitted. An additional nine are awaiting trial. The crackdown prompted the Medellin cocaine cartel to declare ``total war'' on the government a year ago. Tuesday's extraditions were the first of suspected drug traffickers to the United States since Gaviria was inaugurated Aug. 7. He has pledged to continue the war against the cocaine cartels waged by his predecessor, Virgilio Barco. Last Wednesday, Gaviria modified the country's extradition policy. In a nationally televised speech, Gaviria said drug traffickers who turn themselves in and confess their crimes would be tried in Colombia and not face extradition to the United States. Under the decree announced by Gaviria, Colombian judges would be also empowered to impose shorter sentences for suspects who confess and cooperate with local investigations. The country's drug barons have so far offered no reply to Gaviria's offer. Gaviria's offer appeared to be, at least in part, a response to repeated offers from the drug traffickers to surrender to Colombian judges in return for a promise to end the extraditions that had been resumed last year by Barco. The drug traffickers have feared extradition to the United States because they would have little influence over the judicial process there. Cocaine cartel members have traditionally been able to either bribe or threaten their way out of Colombian jails. Judges who refuse to be intimidated have often been slain. In his speech last week, Gaviria announced that three Colombians would soon be extradited to the United States, but he said three other U.S. extradition requests had been turned down. The third suspect set to be extradited, Joaquin Oswaldo Gallo Chamorro, was still being held in Colombia on Tuesday. Authorities did not say why he was not sent to the United States with Ortiz and Buchelli. With the latest extraditions, the U.S. Justice Department is still seeking to extradite 14 suspected drug traffickers held in Colombia. Colombia's Cali and Medellin drug cartels supply most of the cocaine consumed in the United States and Europe. Authorities blame the Medellin for killing about 550 Colombians the past year, including three presidential candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Endorses Prosecuting Saddam In Event of War
DOC.TEXT: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a resolution Tuesday saying the United States should prosecute Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi leaders as ``war criminals'' if hostilities break out in the Persian Gulf. The non-binding resolution, passed on a 97-2 vote, declared that Saddam ``has violated standards of civilized conduct by willfully seeking to endanger the lives of foreign civilians in Kuwait and Iraq.'' The resolution was passed just hours before President Bush was appearing before a joint House and Senate session to report on the crisis triggered by Saddam's invasion and occupation of neighboring Kuwait. ``It is the sense of the Senate that in the event of hostilities between the United States and the government of Iraq, it shall be the policy of the United States to pursue Saddam Hussein and other such perpetrators as may be determined responsible in order to bring them to justice as war criminals,'' it said. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., the principal sponsor, told his colleagues ``the most important way that we can safeguard our hostages against any kind of harm coming to them in the future is for the Senate to go on record by a recorded, overwhelming vote.'' ``If Saddam Hussein and his henchmen place the hostages in harm's way in the event of hostilities,'' Heinz said, ``we will see to it that they are tried as war criminals just as surely as the Nazi war criminals were tried, convicted and sent to punishment in Nuremberg.'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. said he shared the frustration of his colleagues over the plight of Americans still in Iraq and Kuwait, but said the resolution was reckless. ``I appreciate this is a sort of an amendment that looks relatively harmless,'' Kerrey said. ``But it seems to be it's possible, given that we've heard over and over and over that there are people in this world that pay attention to our resolutions ... that this sends precisely the opposite message.'' ``I'm concerned for hostages. Everyone is,'' he said. ``But what happens if this, in fact, sends precisely the opposite message. I'm not skilled in the psychology of somebody who takes hostages and holds them.'' Heinz countered that ``this senator does not want to take the chance that, by inaction, by our failure to speak out, that we would run the very considerable risk that he (Saddam) might once again misread the intentions of those of us who have legitimate concerns.'' Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., said he thought the resolution was premature, and asked Heinz whether the administration had requested it. Heinz replied that he had consulted with administration officials and that no objections had been raised. ``In the end, and there will be an end, Saddam Hussein will not prevail,'' he said. ``And it is important for him to know that when he comes to the end of this story, that justice will be done. That message is probably the best message we can send against the kind of mistreatment of our hostages that took place in Iran.'' Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., joined Kerrey in voting against the resolution, which was an amendment to a $20.7 billion appropriations bill financing Treasury Department, Postal Service, White House and other federal agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Gov't Scotches Mohawk Plan to Surrender
DOC.TEXT: The Quebec government on Tuesday rejected an offer from Mohawks holed up in this town west of Montreal to end a two-month impasse by surrendering. In a brief statement by Premier Robert Bourassa, the government called the proposal ``unacceptable'' because it ``contradicts fundamental principles of democracy and our justice system.'' ``There is no question of a special category of individuals receiving treatment under the law different from any other citizen of Quebec,'' the statement said. The Mohawk offer hinged on creation of a special commission that would exercise ultimate authority for determining any criminal charges. The panel would produce a final report within 60 days. The Mohawk proposal called for the commission to be composed of Iroquois, Canadians, Quebecers and international human rights delegates. It would oversee the surrender of about 50 Indians in a drug-treatment center at the Kahnesatake community in Oka, about 18 miles from Montreal, said Oneida leader Bob Antone. The Mohawks, about half Warriors and half women and children, retreated to the center on Sept. 1, when the army moved onto the Mohawk settlement. Mohawks from Kahnesatake have been in a standoff with Quebec police and the Canadian army since July over the attempt by Oka officials to expand a golf course on land the Indians claim as ancestral. On July 11, provincial police tried to storm a Mohawk barricade. One officer was killed, but it is not clear by whose gunfire. Another community of Mohawks had blockaded a key Montreal bridge in sympathy with the Kahnesatake Indians, but that bridge was reopened last week.

DOC.HEAD: Evanston, Ill., Mayor Promises Veto Of College Tuition Tax
DOC.TEXT: A plan to tax Northwestern University students will likely die in coming days. But curing the bad blood that has developed between the city and school probably will take longer, officials said Tuesday. ``I think it's a matter of getting people to talk more,'' said university spokesman Ken Wildes. ``But then, I guess communications is usually the problem.'' In what City Clerk Kirsten Davis called ``an act of desperation,'' the City Council in this north Chicago suburb of 75,000 voted 10-8 Monday to assess a tuition tax on students at Northwestern and three other colleges. It would amount to up to $60 a year per student. Mayor Joan Barr immediately said she would veto the ordinance. The veto message will likely be put before the council at its Sept. 24 meeting and there's little chance the two-thirds majority could be mustered for an override, Ms. Davis said. The measure makes Evanston the first community in the nation to impose a student tuition tax, according to the American Council on Education. Council members said the tax was needed to compensate the city for revenue lost through the schools' property tax exemptions. The measure would apply to three other schools besides Northwestern _ Kendall College, Garrett Evangelical Theological Seminary and Seabury-Western Theological Seminary. But debate has centered on the city's best-known school. And officials say Monday's vote was just a symptom of a longstanding disagreement between the university and the lakefront community, which estimates the tax would generate $500,000 a year. ``This whole tuition tax would have gone away if Arnold Weber had gotten up and promised something _ some little thing,'' Ms. Davis said, referring to Northwestern's president. ``It could be a fire engine, it could be lower tuition for residents, it could be creating a series of management seminars for city department heads. ``Just something to give us the feeling they would be good corporate citizens.'' City officials complain that Northwestern has refused to pay a fee for city services such as police and fire protection. It pays no property taxes on 242 acres of university-owned land and buildings _ including some commercial property _ and has refused to make a financial contribution to its host community, Ms. Davis said. ``There are a lot of little things they could have done,'' she said. ``But everything we've asked, they've said no.'' Evanston officials have estimated the city could have a $2.5 million budget deficit for the fiscal year starting in March. And it's estimated that city residents already pay 25 percent more in property taxes because the schools are exempt, Ms. Davis said. ``This problem has been a subject of discussion for probably 10 years,'' she said, adding that a tax like the one passed Monday has twice been rejected by the council. But Northwestern's Wildes said the last time a tax was considered, the city and university resolved the issue by agreeing to work together toward economic development in Evanston. He said that, since 1983, the university has ``poured $25 million'' into such ventures, including a 26-acre research park that helps fledgling businesses. Wildes said there haven't been any conversations about additional contributions from Northwestern since then. Northwestern officials also have noted that the school is the largest employer in the city and generates millions of dollars in business for local merchants. They also say they pay almost $1 million in utility taxes, plus a tax on sales of tickets to athletic events. At Monday's meeting, Weber called the tax ``anti-education'' and ``anti-business,'' adding that more than 50 percent of the students already receive extensive financial aid. Most of the school's nearly 10,500 students are undergraduates who pay an annual tuition of $13,725.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Offers Farmers Easy Credit On Drought Debt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf: ``We're not,'' with two grafs bgng: ``We're trying,'' to give quote from official and estimated amount due
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is making it easier for farmers to pay back the advance subsidies they received for crops later lost to drought. The Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service had a policy that farmers had to pay the money back all at once unless they proved that would keep them from feeding or sheltering their families. However, the conservation service decided last month to offer installment plans to farmers who can show a one-time payment would ``create an undue financial hardship.'' The payments can be stretched over three years at 9 percent interest, according to the conservation service. County conservation service offices were notified of the policy change on Aug. 22. ``We're trying to find a way so that those who need help can get relief and work it out in three years,'' said Keith Bjerke, administrator of the service. The government has collected more than $500 million of the $840 million in advance payments that farmers must pay back for 1988 and 1989, Bjerke said. Advance deficiency payments for 1988 and 1989 were supposed to be paid back by July 31. Unless the farmer pays the money back or works out an installment plan, the government can recover the money by taking it out of future payments or loans. Farmers and members of Congress had been pressuring the conservation service to relax its repayment policy. The Senate version of the 1990 farm bill contains a provision that is more lenient than the new policy. The conservation service would be required to offer installment plans to any farmer in a county that received a disaster declaration for two of the previous three years. Farmers in adjacent counties also would qualify. However, the farm bill is not expected to become law before October.

DOC.HEAD: Women's Rights Groups Outraged Over Grandmother's Imprisonment
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoning a 77-year-old woman because she failed to tell where her daughter has been hiding with her two children shows the U.S. court system at its worst, women's rights advocates said Tuesday. Superior Court Judge Mark A. Pfeiffer on Monday sent Mary Pigeon to prison for an indefinite term, saying he would release her only if she tells where her daughter and granddaughters are. ``I'm really concerned about the inappropriateness of this type of technique to squeeze information out of a 77-year-old woman,'' said Lynn Heufelder, director of the Women's Resource Center in Newport. The Rhode Island Women's Political Caucus said the incarceration ``shows the judicial system at its worst.'' The judge ``has shown little wisdom, no compassion and dangerous rigidity,'' said Elizabeth Morancy, chairwoman of the caucus. Pfeiffer should have considered home confinement as an alternative, she said. The National Organization for Women's Rhode Island affiliate also objected to the decision, its president, Susan Luckel, said. ``We think it's reprehensible,'' she said, adding the group would discuss the case at its Thursday meeting. Elaine Yates and the children, Kimberly Ann, then 3, and Kelly Ann, then 10 months, left their Warwick home in August 1985 after Mrs. Yates found her husband with another woman on the family boat. Ms. Morancy said Mrs. Pigeon's plight was a family rights issue, a sentiment echoed by Ms. Heufelder. ``It seems to me at this point that the government is preying on the family relationship and to pick on a 70-plus-year-old-woman for a decision made by her daughter is not right,'' Ms. Heufelder said. Russell M. Yates Jr. later acknowledged hitting his wife and cutting her forehead with a diamond ring when they argued about the boat incident. After she left, he sued for custody of the children and won when his wife did not contest the lawsuit. He then sued Mrs. Pigeon, seeking the girls' return. The couple has not divorced. Yates says he does not want to give his wife the legal opportunity to change her and the girls' names. A year ago, Pfeiffer ordered Mrs. Pigeon to tell her son-in-law where his wife and daughters are and to pay $23,000 in damages. No money has been paid. When Monday's deadline came with no disclosure of the family's whereabouts, Pfeiffer said he was left with ``no alternative'' but to send Mrs. Pigeon to jail for contempt of court. ``I have no desire to punish this woman,'' he said. Mrs. Pigeon has maintained she does not know where her daughter took her granddaughters. Pfeiffer says he believes otherwise. ``I feel very sad about it, and I wish Elaine would come home,'' Mrs. Pigeon said after the sentencing. Mrs. Pigeon was working at the Adult Correctional Institutions, spokesman Joseph DiNitto said. ``She's down in our kitchen,'' DiNitto said. ``It's very light janitorial work, sweeping floors, stuff like that.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Senate-IRS
DOC.TEXT: Here is the the 63-36 roll call by which the Senate voted to Tuesday to reject an effort by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to put the United States on record as being opposed to abortion as part of a United Nations convention on the rights of children. On this vote, a ``yes'' vote was a vote to reject adding Helms' amendment to an appropriations bill and a ``no'' vote was to include the measure as part of the bill. DOC.HEAD: Snelling Takes First Step in Comeback Bid; Mecham Also Trying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs with Snelling, Welch nominated in Vermont; pickup 7th pvs bgng ``Three Republican''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: Former Vermont Gov. Richard A. Snelling's comeback bid got off to a fast start Tuesday as he swept to the Republican nomination for the office he once held for four terms. Also trying a comeback was ousted Gov. Evan Mecham of Arizona. In the nation's capital, Jesse Jackson was making his first run for an office other than president. Arizona Republicans were deciding whether to give Mecham another shot at the office he lost 2{ years ago through impeachment. Pre-election polls showed him trailing Phoenix developer J. Fife Symington. Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard was heavily favored to emerge as the Democratic nominee. Incumbents challenged within their own parties included Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota and Rep. Roy Dyson of Maryland, both Democrats. Vermont's lone congressman, Republican Peter Smith, was challenged by conservative Timothy Philbin, who pledged to serve only one term if elected. Snelling, who defeated Richard Gottlieb, will face Democrat Peter Welch, who also overwhelmed his primary opponent, William Gwin. With 3 percent of precincts reporting, Snelling had 2,415 votes or 88 percent and Gottlieb had 345 votes or 12 percent. Welch had 2,051 votes or 93 percent and Gwin had 154 votes or 7 percent. People went to the polls in 10 states and the District of Columbia, but politics had a low priority among Americans whose attention was riveted on events in the Persian Gulf. Three Republican governors _ Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island, and Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin _ had token primary opposition. With polls indicating DiPrete is vulnerable, three Democrats _ Mayors Joseph Paolino of Providence and Francis Flaherty of Warwick and businessman Bruce Sundlun _ were competing to run against him. In the race to succeed Democrat William O'Neill as governor of Connecticut, Rep. Bruce Morrison and state legislator William Cibes faced off in the Democratic primary. After serving four two-year terms as governor of Vermont, Snelling, a Republican, decided not to run again in 1984. He was succeeded by Democrat Madeleine Kunin who announced her retirement this year. Snelling and Democrat Peter Welch had token opposition for their party nominations. The list of politicians attempting comebacks also included former Sen. John Durkin of New Hampshire and ex-congressmen Edward Beard of Rhode Island, Dan Marriott of Utah and 85-year-old John Dow of New York. Perpich, ridiculed as ``Governor Goofy'' by his critics, was challenged by his former commerce commissioner, Mike Hatch, for the Democrat-Farmer-Labor nomination. Minnesota Republicans had an equally spirited contest with Auditor Arne Carlson and businessman Jon Grunseth the front-runners. Carlson led pre-election polls despite the fact Grunseth had the endorsement of the Independent-Republican party leadership. Dyson came under criticism for his ties to defense contractors and recently the hawkish congressman's prospects were further shaken by disclosure that he was a conscientious objector during the Vietnam war. His chief Democratic opponent was state legislator Barbara Kreamer. Eight Republicans were lined up to challenge Dyson in November and a recent poll said any one of them could beat him. Durkin, who served one six-year Senate term and then was defeated for re-election in 1980, was seeking the Democratic nonmination for the seat now held by Republican Sen. Gordon Humphrey. Durkin's principal primary opponents were Nashua Mayor James Donchess and businessman John Rauh. Rep. Bob Smith and lawyer Tom Christo were competing for the GOP nomination to succeed Humphrey. After 12 years in the U.S. Senate, Humphrey announced he was ready to leave Washington to run for a seat in the New Hampshire Senate. But his path to the state legislature wasn't clear. State Rep. Jack Sherburne waged a vigorous campaign for the nomination, calling Humphrey ``a converted extremist'' who was ``largely ineffective'' in the U.S. Senate. In the New Hampshire Democratic gubernatorial primary, former state party chairman Joe Grandmaison was favored to overcome two rivals who have attacked him for his ties to Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis. Beard lost his House seat in 1980 to Republican Claudine Schneider who is running against Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell. Dow last served New York in the House in 1972. His primary opponent, Sean O'Brien Strub, is homosexual. The primary winner would challenge Republican Rep. Benjamin Gilman. Marriott, who served four terms in Congress before losing a 1984 bid for governor, was competing against Genevieve Atwood for the chance to challenge Democratic Rep. Wayne Owens in November. Jackson was running in a Democratic primary for nomination to the symbolic office of ``shadow senator'' from the District of Columbia. Voters in the nation's capital will elect two ``senators'' and one ``representative,'' positions with no official standing and created to lobby Congress to support statehood for the city. Five candidates were competing for the Democratic nomination to succeed Marion Barry as Washington's mayor. Barry, awaiting sentencing on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, has said he plans to run as an independent for an at-large seat on the city council. The race to succeed Walter Fauntroy as the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate in the House was abruptly spotlighted last weekend when front-runner Eleanor Holmes Norton conceded that she and her husband failed to file city income tax returns over an eight-year period. Norton, a law professor and former Carter administration official, said her husband did the family taxes and she signed the returns but he never mailed them.

The day's primaries settled the fall campaign lineups for all but a handful of states. Voters in Massachusets, Hawaii, Florida, Washington, Louisiana and OKlahoma will complete the process in the coming weeks. Jackson's only previous bids for elective office were his two campaigns for president. He moved to Washington a year ago and considered entering the race for mayor, but then announced he would concentrate on campaigning to have the city named the 51st state. In Connecticut, Rep. John Rowland captured the GOP nomination for governor without primary opposition. The two major party nominees face a formidable general election obstacle in ex-Sen. Lowell Weicker who is running as an independent. Opinion polls show Weicker leading either Democrat and Rowland, although he was defeated when he ran for re-election to the Senate in 1988. Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and his Republican challenger, Pierre Rinfret, already had their respective party nominations and were not on the primary ballot. The same was true of Pell and Schneider in Rhode Island. Wisconsin Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus was unopposed for the Democratic nomination to challenge Thompson.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item of AM-People, a0631, to UPDATE with King apology
DOC.TEXT: Talk show host Larry King apologized Tuesday for saying Miss Pennsylvania Marla Wynne was the ugliest contestant in last week's Miss America Pageant. A judge at the pageant in Atlantic City, N.J., he named Ms. Wynne the homliest of the bunch during an appearance Monday on ``The Joan Rivers Show.'' ``She was one of the 10 finalists and she did a great ventriloquist bit . . . The dummy was prettier,'' he said. ``He was kidding,'' said Eileen Murphy, a spokeswoman for ``Larry King Live'' on CNN. ``He was on the show with Joan Rivers. Joan's a comedian. He reacted to her in a comedic way. He regrets the incident and he apologizes. ``In retrospect he realizes it was not funny,'' she said. ``He certainly did not mean to be offensive.'' King sent a dozen long-stemmed red roses and a telegram to Ms. Wynne apologizing for his comments, which he said ``were made in jest with no intention to offend.'' ``You are a bright shining talent,'' King wrote. ``... Half the women in America would kill to be in your shoes. In this case I'm the real dummy.'' After King's remarks, Ms. Wynne's father, Gary Wynne of Easton told WAEB-AM radio Tuesday the family and the Miss Pennsylvania Pageant were considering unspecified legal action. The contestant's mother, Marlene Wynne, said the apology was necessary, but it needed to go further. ``I think he and Marla should talk about it,'' she said. ``He has hurt her very deeply and he has hurt many other people.'' She said the family had spoken to an attorney and was told King had the right to express an opinion. Ms. Wynne was invited to appear on Rivers' show, said Dennis Stewart, chairman of the Miss Pennsylvania Scholarship Pageant Inc. He said they were discussing an appearance later in the week. ``If people get a chance to see her, that's as much as a rebuttal to what Larry said,'' Stewart said. ``She is by far not ugly,'' Mrs. Wynne said. ``For him to attack any girl who was on that stage, in his position as a judge, I think is contemptible.'' Ms. Murphy said King might agree to a meeting. ``His top priority now is to clear the air,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Premier Accused of Sweetheart Deal on Home
With AM-Soviet-Economy
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov denied charges Tuesday that he took advantage of his post to buy a country home for a fraction of its value. The allegations worsened Ryzhkov's problems on a day when he suffered heavy criticism in the national parliament for his economic reform plans. Komsomolskaya Pravda, one of the nation's largest newspapers, said Tuesday that the prime minister had paid 47,000 rubles for a country home, known as a dacha, outside Moscow. The official exchange rate for the ruble is about $1.60 or 16 cents, depending on the transaction. However, in his comments to the Supreme Soviet, Ryzhkov said, ``We do not own a dacha.'' He said he lives in a government-owned dacha reserved for the prime minister. However, Ryzhkov said he had considered buying his own home recently because he was tired of public complaints about special privileges for officials. ``I did have such a thought, in order to live as a free man,'' he said. But he said he could not afford the 300,000-ruble price on his government dacha. Because most Soviets live in cramped apartments with no hope of ever owning their own home, official dachas are a particular sore point. Komsomolskaya Pravda said Ryzhkov was out buying a dacha while vigorously fighting proposals to legalize private land. The proposals would allow millions of Soviets to join him as residents of single-family homes. The newspaper also said that as prime minister, Ryzhkov had unique access to his pick of dachas near Moscow, where demand far outstrips supply.

DOC.HEAD: Three Injured As Shooting Erupts At Texas High School
DOC.TEXT: Gunfire broke out Tuesday at a high school described by students as fraught with gang and drug activity, and three teen-agers were wounded. Students said a feud between two gangs and their offshoot groups led to the shootings. Witnesses reported hearing arguing before the shots and said one boy had been teased for wearing the wrong color of clothing. ``I was diving out of the way,'' said student Ursula Hall. ``I almost got shot. I was scared, I was terrified.'' Police arrested and charged three males in the shootings at Sam Houston High School. The victims and suspects all are students at the school, officials said. ``According to the wounded people, they are accusing the ones who did the shooting of being members of a gang,'' said San Antonio School District Superintendent Victor Rodriguez. He later confirmed that gangs were involved. District spokesman Bobby Zamora said classes were dismissed, and some students went home by bus. Rene Gaines, another school district spokeswoman, said classes would resume Wednesday with extra guards stationed at Sam Houston. Counseling will be available for students trying to cope with the violence, she said. Otherwise, ``it's school as usual,'' Ms. Gaines said. Students and parents described the 1,400-student school as a dangerous place where gangs and drugs are prevalent. Several spectators booed and shouted at the superintendent when he told reporters Sam Houston is as safe as possible. Police arrested an 18-year-old, Kenneth Wolford, and charged him with two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, police Sgt. Paul Buske said. Two others, both juveniles, also were charged with two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, he said. A 16-year-old boy shot in the chest was in fair condition at Wilford Hall Medical Center, said hospital spokesman George Kelling. Another boy was shot in the foot and a third was shot in the thigh and calf, officials said. Both were in fair condition at Medical Center Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Inez Eisazadeh.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 45 Dead, Hundreds of Thousands Evacuated in Korea Floods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 45 dead, river bank bursting, 300,000 more evacuated, damage estimate upped to $25 million, details. DELETES dated material, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: The heaviest single-day rainfall in 70 years drenched South Korea on Tuesday, killing at least 45 people and forcing more than 350,000 to flee their homes. President Roh Tae-woo said relief efforts were like ``fighting a war.'' The Seoul area was swamped by 15 inches of rain in 24 hours. The most rain fell at Suwon, just south of Seoul, which had 16.8 inches, the main disaster relief center said. A 100-yard section of the Han River's bank just west of Seoul burst overnight, sending tons of water into a farming area of rice paddies and villages. Officials said the 300,000 residents were being evacuated. ``No amount of words can describe this situation,'' said Police Lt. Kim Sung-ho from the scene. ``It's hellish.'' Thousands of people were stranded on rooftops, and thousands were ferried to higher ground. Official figures said 45 people were known dead, 31 missing and 66,000 homeless. However, the figures did not take into account the new flooding from the Han or the evacuations there. The Central Disaster Relief Center said the rainfall was the heaviest in the country in a single day in 70 years. Property damage was initially estimated at $25 million. The airfield at the 7th U.S. Air Force headquarters south of Seoul was flooded and F-16 jet fighters were sandbagged. About two dozen Koreans in makeshift boats floated over a submerged fence and onto the flooded runways and had to be rescued, a spokesman said. U.S. and South Korean military helicopters and large army trucks evacuated children and shopkeepers stranded on tops of houses and buildings. One hospital on the outskirts of Seoul evacuated its patients, and witnesses reported seeing patients wading through waist-high water with belongings held over their heads. ``This is the worst weather disaster in memory,'' Roh said after briefings at the Han River Flood Control Center. ``Protecting people from this rain is like fighting a war.'' Korean soldiers used rubber dinghies to rescue people stranded in low-lying areas around Olympic Park. The Olympic Expressway was flooded and nearby riverside park areas were submerged. A Buddhist temple was buried in a mudslide with five monks inside, news reports said. The national news agency Yonhap said the dead included a 9-year-old girl swept away by flood waters and a 3-year-old sleeping in her home. In the port of Inchon west of Seoul, nine homes were buried in a landslide and 20 people were missing, police said. More than 15,000 chickens drowned at a chicken farm. Some Seoul-area subway stations were closed after water poured into them. A major commuter line serving areas west of Seoul stopped completely, stranding thousands of commuters. Schools were closed in the capital. At Suwon, dozens of factories manufacturing electronics, instruments, television sets, footwear and tires were flooded. One factory dormitory collapsed, killing six sleeping workers inside. Two cruise ships broke free from their moorings and capsized on the Han River. Twenty crewmen were rescued but 10 were missing, police said. Railroad lines to areas south and east of Seoul were flooded. Many roads in rural areas and some sections of highways were washed out, and sections of a mountain highway leading to the east coast collapsed, officials said. Rain stopped overnight and the three-day storm was heading southeastward away from the peninsula.

DOC.HEAD: Beleaguered Florida Citrus Growers Gets Good News; Feds Drop Quarantine
DOC.TEXT: Citrus growers eager to bounce back from a subpar harvest got some good news Tuesday when federal agriculture officials dropped a 6-year-old quarantine. Florida's billion-dollar citrus industry, hoping for a sunnier future after a crippling Christmas freeze, also welcomed an optimistic report on increased citrus planting. The U.S. Agriculture Department announced that as of Sept. 18 it will officially remove the remaining citrus-canker quarantine restrictions imposed in September 1984. ``We were pleased to see it,'' said Dan Gunter, executive director of the Florida Department of Citrus. ``This will open up all the markets to Florida. It was time for the USDA to deregulate.'' Federal quarantine restrictions came after an outbreak of a leaf-spotting disease in dozens of citrus nurseries. It was believed to be a rapidly spreading Asiatic strain of citrus canker, which can devastate groves. More than 20 million young trees were uprooted and burned, before scientists determined that the disease was not spreading to mature groves and did not constitute a major threat to fruit or to other citrus-producing states. Restrictions were gradually relaxed after follow-up research showed that the disease was only distantly related to Asiatic canker. Lack of faith in Florida citrus, brought on by the canker quarantine, cost growers dearly, said Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual, the largest growers' trade association in the state. He called it ``a major step forward for the citrus industry. It's been a long six years since the quarantine was first imposed.'' Meanwhile, a biennial survey conducted by state and federal officials showed a 5 percent increase in citrus acreage despite nearly 86,000 acres lost because of the Christmas freeze. ``That's good news _ a very encouraging report,'' Gunter said. Commercial citrus acreage increased to 732,767 acres, 5 percent more than the 697,929 acres reported in 1988, according to the report. Growers planted 120,696 acres in 1988 and 1989. They lost 85,858 acres of trees _ most of it to the December freeze _ leaving a net gain of 34,838. The 1989-90 orange harvest, projected before the December freeze at 130 million 90-pound boxes, came in at about 110 million boxes. It was the decade's second-lowest production. The grapefruit crop of about 36 million boxes was the smallest since the 1967-68 season. The canker scare prompted other citrus states, including Texas and California, to ban imports of Florida fruit that was not inspected and treated before being shipped. Connie Riherd, assistant director of the Florida Agriculture Department's Division of Plant Industry, said she hoped that other citrus-producing states ``take the federal lead and not impose their own regulations against Florida fruit.'' ``The wealth of biological information that has been reviewed (by federal and state scientists) shows that the nursery strain of the disease is not of quarantine significance,'' Mrs. Riherd said. The canker-eradication effort led to some 60 lawsuits by nursery owners who suffered losses because of the destruction of their young trees. At last report, these lawsuits totaled about $200 million and the state was still trying to negotiate with litigants and impose some court-ordered settlements. The cost of the canker-eradication battle to the industry and state and federal agencies exceeded $100 million. ``This shows positive results following a major freeze,'' said Harry Whittaker of the Florida Agricultural Statistics Service, which compiled the survey results. ``We see continued interest by growers in new plantings.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators of Pan Am Bombing Urge Stronger Planes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with comments by Boeing spokeswoman. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Chief Constable...'
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Aircraft could be better designed to survive explosions but there will never be a bombproof jumbo jet, according to a government report released Tuesday on the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The Air Accidents Investigation Branch reported that the Pan Am Boeing 747 broke apart within three seconds of the explosion of a bomb in a forward baggage compartment, leading to the deaths of 270 people on Dec. 21, 1988. None of the 259 people aboard the aircraft appeared to have been fatally injured by the initial explosion or by fire aboard the aircraft, the report said. Eleven people were killed on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. ``It should be possible to limit the damage caused by an explosive device inside a baggage container on a Boeing 747 or similar aircraft to a degree which would allow the aircraft to land successfully, albeit with severe local damage and perhaps resulting in some loss of life or injuries,'' said the report. The report said the plane, which had just reached a cruising altitude of 31,000 feet, rapidly disintegrated following the explosion. The investigators urged that aircraft manufacturers and government regulatory agencies consider various design changes, including skin panels that would blow away cleanly, venting an explosion without leading to the tearing away of more skin. The report was limited to structural and technical issues, and did not address questions of airport security. In Renton, Wash., a spokeswoman for the Boeing Commerical Airplane Group said the aircraft company would review the report's recommendations, even though the company has never specifically studied how to structurally strengthen its planes to withstand a bomb explosion. ``It's Boeing's feeling that the only way to prevent an explosive from destroying a plane is to avoid allowing the explosive to be placed on the plane in the first place,'' said spokeswoman Elizabeth Reese. ``What you're asking the manufacturer to do is respond to unknowns. How do you design a plane to become terrorist-proof?'' The police investigation into the bombing continues. A public inquiry is to open in Dumfries, Scotland, on Oct. 1 to investigate the circumstances that led to the deaths. Chief Constable George Esson of the Dumfries and Galloway Constabulary confirmed in December that Ahmed Jibril's radical Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, had been under investigation. Esson also confirmed investigators' interest in Mohammed Abu Talb, a member of another radical Palestinian group who was convicted in Sweden of being involved in bombings against American and Israeli targets in Europe. Some authorities believe the bombing was carried out by a terrorist group working on behalf of Iran in retaliation for the shooting down of an Iranian passenger plane over the Persian Gulf by a U.S. warship. Scottish police reported in February 1989 that the New York-bound 747 was brought down by a bomb consisting of Semtex plastic explosives hidden inside a radiocassette recorder. They said the recorder was probably checked aboard the flight in Frankfurt, West Germany. The explosive device was inside a luggage container that was loaded in the forward hold, and was about 25 inches from the aircraft's skin, the report said. The explosion blew a large hole in the fuselage structure and shattered the main cabin floor, the report said. Large cracks spread as pressurized air blew out of the rupture. The main body of the aircraft rolled left and down, while the nose snapped off to the right and struck the No. 3 engine, knocking it free, the investigators said. The disintegrating main body of the aircraft, including the fuel tanks, fell on the town of Lockerbie at speeds up to 300 mph, causing fires and a huge explosion, the report said. The investigators, led by D.A. Cooper, chief inspector of air accidents, recommended that aircraft be designed to channel the force of any explosion to sections of the skin designed to burst cleanly without causing further structural damage. The report also suggested strengthening the floor over the baggage compartment and filling internal cavities with energy absorbing materials. Even then, the investigators said, there was no guarantee that an aircraft would survive an explosion. The report said such variable factors as the size of the explosive charge and the location of the bomb make it ``unrealistic to expect to neutralize successfully the effect of every potential explosive device likely to be placed on board an aircraft.'' The investigators also called for new designs for flight data and voice recorders. The ones aboard Flight 103 failed instantly and captured no data about the explosion, the report said.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Here is the advance text of the Democratic response Tuesday night to President Bush's address to Congress. The response was given by Rep. Dick Gephardt, D-Mo., the majority leader of the House of Representatives.

Good evening. I have been asked to give the Democratic response to the President's speech. But tonight, in this crisis, we are not Republicans or Democrats. We are only and proudly Americans. The President has asked for our support. He has it. The effort will not be easy; it involves burdens and bravery, perhaps more of each than any of us can now predict. The end of what John Kennedy called ``the long, twilight struggle'' has not put an end to the darkness of aggression and conflict. Yet as Americans, we enter this new world with a remarkable degree of purpose and confidence. Here at home the sense of unity and the absence of widespread opposition to this action in the Persian Gulf testify to our powerful, instinctive feeling that this is a cause worth standing and fighting for. We are standing _ and if necessary we will fight _ because a vital national interest is at stake. We cannot and will not permit the invading forces of a fanatical regime to control half of all the oil reserves which are the lifeblood of the world economy. Yet more is involved here than national interest, as important as that is. There has been, and there always should be, a moral component of American foreign policy. This has sometimes been criticized as weakness; in truth it is our greatest strength. When our policy has a moral center, we gain the unbreakable resolve that comes from standing for things we believe in. So we are now in the Persian Gulf not simply for oil, or to save emirs and kings _ but to defend the most fundamental values of a more stable and decent world. We defending basic rights _ of families to be safe in their homes, of nations to be secure within their borders, of individuals to travel freely and without fear. The tyrant who rampaged into Kuwait has also murdered his own citizens with poison gas, plotted to acquire nuclear weapons, waged genocide against a minority people, and now taken hostage thousands of men, women and children.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
For release at 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: WASHN: and children.
DOC.TEXT: To watch him on television touching the head of a hostage child stuns and then outrages us. Firmly, clearly and unequivocally, we must say to Saddam Hussein: Let our people go. Let Kuwait go. And if you start a war, know that we will finish it. We have learned before that the large conflicts which engulf the world begin from small and unanswered aggressions. If the civilized world had looked the other way, the Iraqi war machine could have rolled across the Arabian Peninsula. It would be only a matter of time until Iraq had ballistic missiles with chemical, biological and nuclear warheads that could reach Israel, Egypt and Europe itself. But this time, other nations have acted in time. Among them is the Soviet Union, a nation we did not often praise in the years of the Cold War. From the summit at Helsinki, where President Gorbachev and President Bush stood in common purpose, we could see beyond the present shadows of war in the Middle East to a new world order where the strong work together to deter and stop aggression. This was precisely Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill's vision of peace for the post-war period. Their hope, suspended in time for fifty years of Cold War, has come alive in this new, post-Communist era. America is still the leader _ the only power capable of summoning a grand and global alliance on the scale we have seen in Operation Desert Shield. But it is not enough for other nations just to share our commitment. They must also share the burden. When Bangladesh is putting troops in harm's war, so should our powerful and prosperous allies. When Japan, Germany, and other NATO countries depend far more heavily of Mideast oil than we do, they can and should contribute to defend their own vital interests in the Persian Gulf. When countries like Egypt can stand beside us, when young Americans stand on front lines, only miles from the threat of poison gas, the least the Japanese and Germans can do is support us _ and not just with words; they must respond to our potential sacrifice of lives with at least a financial sacrifice of their own.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
For release at 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: WASHN: their own.
DOC.TEXT: We are there because it is right. But it is also right to tell our friends that they, too, have to stand up to international immorality and aggression. The United States will do its part _ and we will also insist that other countries carry their share of the struggle. We have not finished the job, but how powerful are the signs of a new world coming. Today we can see Egyptian or Saudi troops wearing Hungarian gas masks or carrying Russian rifles, standing guard in the desert next to a Pfc from Pittsburgh who is wearing a chemical-proof suit made in Israel. The infamy of Saddam Hussein has made us United Nations in deed as well as name. But ultimately, for America to lead the world, we must put our own economic house in order. For as another American president reminded us, ``We cannot be strong abroad if we are weak at home.'' For a decade America has been left with no real energy policy at all. It is time for energy security _ more production, more conservation, more support for new forms of fuel. But our aim cannot be to make America safe for isolationism. Rather we must secure America's capacity to act overseas without maximum damage from an oil embargo. This nation must not be permanently faced with a choice between standing up against aggression or standing still in gas lines. Economic strength also demands action on the budget deficit. To help the President write a budget, we Democrats have offered cuts in domestic programs while trying to protect the most important ones. But we will never abandon the cause of working families. They benefited the least from the decade of the 80s; they should not have to sacrifice the most in the decade of the 90s. They already pay for government; their student loans have already been cut, and their sons and daughters are at risk in the Persian Gulf. The standard of fairness should also be applied to President Bush's commitment to raise taxes. The working people who got almost nothing from the tax cuts of the past must not be asked to pay most of the tax increases of today. Just as we must ask wealthy nations to pay their fair share to deter aggression, so we must ask wealthy Americans to pay their fair share to prevent recession and reduce our debts. Beyond this, we must be vigorous in shaping the defense policy that we now need _ one that is more relevant and more responsive.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
For release at 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: WASHN: more responsive.
DOC.TEXT: We can and will afford weapons critical to efforts like Operation Desert Shield: tanks, precision missiles and fast sealift. But Star Wars, the B-2 Bomber and the MX Missile are costly systems designed for a Cold War that we have already won. We can and must reduce the part of the Pentagon budget that is nothing more than shadowboxing with the past. But for all of us tonight, our deepest concern is for the most fundamental realities _ the hundreds of American families with a loved one held hostage _ the hundred thousand young Americans in uniform: daughters, sons, husbands, wives and friends, who have been so swiftly sent to Saudi Arabia. A few days ago on a trip to that country, I saw them transforming the trackless desert sand into the frontier of international defense. I spoke with a solider who described telephone lines melting in the Saudi sun. Pilots told me of cockpit temperatures reaching 140 degrees. There was another young man who was supposed to be married next Sunday. But his wedding must wait. Before toasting his bride, he will be drinking six to seven gallons of water each day just to survive the unyielding heat. None of the young men and women I met doubted their mission. They react to such problems as sand blowing into a machine or a gearshift with that remarkable American sense of ingenuity; they respond to frustration with that irreverent American sense of humor. They worry most about their families worrying about them. Randy King of Arkansas handed me a scribbled note for his mother: ``Doing fine. Having no problems. Please write. Love ya, Randy.'' And Ronald Lloyd of Idaho spoke for most of the troops when he asked me to tell his family to ``send stamps and cookies _ and plenty of both.'' Their courage commands our support. We will stand behind them as one, indivisible nation. We will challenge other countries to match their resolve and sacrifice. We will insist that to ignore aggression is to invite aggression. We will try to solve this crisis peacefully, but without appeasement. And if our soldiers have to fight, we will make sure they win. Tonight that is our common purpose and our prayer _ for them _ and for our country.
DOC.HEAD: END GEPHARDT TEXT _ 4 Takes

DOC.NOTE: For release at 9 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: WASHN: is not.
DOC.TEXT: So if ever there was a time to put country before self and patriotism before party, that time is now. Let me thank all Americans, especially those in this chamber, for your support for our forces and their mission. That support will be even more important in the days to come. So tonight, I want to talk to you about what is at stake _ what we must do together to defend civilized values around the world, and maintain our economic strength at home. Our objectives in the Persian gulf are clear, our goals defined and familiar: _Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait completely, immediately _ and without condition. _Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored. _The security and stability of the Persian Gulf must be assured. _Americans citizens abroad must be protected. These goals are not ours alone. They have been endorsed by the U.N. Security Council five times in as many weeks. Most countries share our concern for principle. And many have a stake in the stability of the Persian Gulf. This is not, as Saddam Hussein would have it, the United States against Iraq. It is Iraq against the world. As you know, I've just returned from a very productive meeting with Soviet President Gorbachev. I am pleased that we are working together to build a new relationship. In Helsinki, our joint statement affirmed to the world our shared resolve to counter Iraq's threat to peace. Let me quote: ``We are united in the belief that Iraq's aggression must not be tolerated. No peaceful international order is possible if larger states can devour their smaller neighbors.'' Clearly, no longer can a dictator count on East-West confrontation to stymie concerted U.N. action against aggression. A new partnership of nations has begun. We stand today at a unique and extraordinary moment. The crisis in the Persian Gulf, as grave as it is, also offers a rare opportunity to move toward an historic period of cooperation. Out of these troubled times, our fifth objective _ a new world order _ can emerge: a new era _ freer from the threat of terror, stronger in the pursuit of justice, and more secure in the quest for peace. An era in which the nations of the world, East and West, North and South, can prosper and live in harmony. A hundred generations have searched for this elusive path to peace, while a thousand wars raged across the span of human endeavor. Today that new world is struggling to be born. A world quite different from the one we've known. A world where the rule of law supplants the rule of the jungle. A world where the rule of law supplants the rule of the jungle. A world in which nations recognize the shared responsibility for freedom and justice. A world where the strong respect the rights of the weak. This is the vision I shared with President Gorbachev in Helsinki. He, and other leaders from Europe, the Gulf and around the world, understand that how we manager this crisis today, could shape the future for generations to come.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Democrats Choose Candidate for Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Morrison winning. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `For the first...
DOC.TEXT: Liberal U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison defeated liberal state Rep. William J. Cibes Jr. in the Democratic primary for governor Tuesday in this economically slumping state. He will face former Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican running for governor as an independent, and GOP nominee John G. Rowland, a three-term congressman, in the general election. With 55 percent of the precincts reporting, Morrison had 61 percent, or 41,879 votes, to Cibes' 39 percent, or 26,536 votes. For the first time in a generation, Democrats are heading into the fall elections as clear underdogs, largely because of the state's flagging economy and record-setting tax increases over the past two years. Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill decided in March not to seek a third term. Morrison tried to paint Cibes as an O'Neill crony responsible for the tax increases and has criticized Cibes' call for a state personal income tax. Cibes raised questions about the way Morrison raised money and for the congressman's refusal to present a detailed plan for bailing the state out of the economic slump.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: capital gains.
DOC.TEXT: Second: the Congress should, this month, enact a prudent multi-year defense program _ one that reflects not only the improvement in East-West relations, but our broader responsibilities to deal with the continuing risks of outlaw action and regional conflict. Even with our obligations in the Gulf, a sound defense budget can have some reduction in real terms, and we are prepared to accept that. But to go beyond such levels, where cutting defense would threaten our vital margin of safety, is something I will never accept. The world is still dangerous. Surely that is now clear. Stability is not secure. American interests are far-reaching. Interdependence has increased. The consequences of regional instability can be global. This is no time to risk America's capacity to protect her vital interests. Third: the Congress should, this month, enact measures to increase domestic energy production and energy conservation _ in order to reduce dependence on foreign oil. These measures should include my proposals to increase incentives for domestic oil and gas exploration, fuel-switching, and to accelerate the development of Alaskan energy resources, without damage to wildlife. As you know, when the oil embargo was imposed in the early 1970's, the United States imported almost 6 million barrels of oil per day. This year, before the Iraqi invasion, U.S. imports had risen to nearly 8 million barrels per day. We had moved in the wrong direction. Now we must act to correct that trend. Fourth: the Congress should, this month, enact a five-year program to reduce the projected debt and deficits by $500 billion _ that is, by half a trillion dollars. If, with the Congress, we can develop a satisfactory program by the end of the month, we can avoid the ax of ``sequester'' _ deep across-the-board cuts that would threaten our military capacity and risk substantial domestic disruption. I want to be able to tell the American people, we have truly solved the deficit problem. For me to do that, a budget agreement must meet these tests: _It must include the measures I've recommended to increase economic growth and reduce dependence on foreign oil. _It must be fair. All should contribute, but the burden should not be excessive for any one group of programs or people. _It must address the growth of government's hidden liabilities. _It must reform the budget process, and further: it must be real. I urge Congress to provide a comprehensive five-year deficit reduction program to me as a complete legislative package _ with measures to assure that it can be fully enforced. America is tired of phony deficit reduction, or promise-now, save-later-plans. Enough is enough. It is time for a program that is credible and real. _Finally, to the extent that the deficit reduction program includes new revenue measures, it must avoid any measure that would threaten economic growth or turn us back toward the days of punishing income tax rates. That is one path we should not head down again.
