DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, Sept. 15-16

DOC.TEXT: Americans took out a seasonally adjusted $4.47 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in July, the biggest increase in debt in eight months, the government said. The Federal Reserve said Monday that consumer credit rose 7.4 percent at an annual rate following a revised 0.2 percent gain, or $116 million, in June. The central bank originally had reported the June increase at 0.8 percent.

Energy Department officials cautiously predicted that fuel oil supplies will be adequate this winter _ but only if the weather isn't severe, if refineries avoid operating problems and if Mideast developments don't disrupt oil shipments further. Several congressmen complained Monday that the assessment was based on ``rosy assumptions'' and suggested that it provides little comfort to Americans relying on oil to heat homes and factories.

The Middle East crisis finally has made its way to the domestic oil patch, according to a widely watched index of drilling activity. The rig count _ the number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States _ soared by 27 this week to 1,039, the second highest total this year, Baker Hughes Inc. said Monday.

German officials announced a deal to help troubled East German farmers supply shortage-plagued Soviets with food and precious cigarettes. The contract announced Monday, estimated at $636 million, will allow East Germans to rid their packed storehouses and processing plants of millions of tons in unsold fish, livestock, butter, milk and flour.

Mercedes-Benz doesn't think it will be able to shrink the annual $18 million-plus bill it's been paying for violating federal fuel efficiency regulations, company executives said. Companies selling cars in the United States must pay a penalty if the average fuel economy rating for those cars doesn't meet certain standards. A gas-guzzler tax may also be imposed on the company's least efficient models. Mercedes executives made the comments Monday.

Jury selection began in the federal fraud and racketeering trial of 10 soybean traders from the Chicago Board of Trade after an 11th defendant pleaded guilty to reduced charges. Meanwhile, federal prosecutors prepared to deliver opening statements Tuesday in a similar trial involving 14 Japanese yen traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. In both cases, the defendants are accused of cheating customers while executing their orders on the exchanges' trading floors.

General Motors Corp. and United Auto Workers union negotiators have reached tentative agreements on nearly all non-economic issues four days before the current contract expires, a union source said. The source said Monday that bargaining continued over the most important issue _ job security. Negotiators are making progress, but the source declined to give details.

Government prosecutors plan to file a sentencing report later this week accusing former junk bond financier Michael Milken of a sweep of crimes far beyond those he has admitted. Milken, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department, pleaded guilty in April to six felonies and ageed to pay $600 million in penalties to settle securities fraud and racketeering charges. Attorneys said Monday the government will detail a host of other unproven crimes to try to induce U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood to stiffen Milken's prison term at sentencing Oct. 1.

The Foxboro Co., a multimillion-dollar company recently bought by a British firm, announced it would lay off 1,600 employees worldwide as part of a restructuring. Siebe is a private manufacturer of electrical equipment headquartered in Windsor, England. It purchased Foxboro three months ago for $656.4 million, or $52 a share. The layoffs were announced Monday.

The stock market closed narrowly mixed Monday after a volatile session influenced by wide swings in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average, up about 30 points at the day's highest level, ended with a 3.96 loss at 2,615.59. Bonds fell slightly in light trading. The dollar rose against most major currencies. Precious metal futures prices tumbled; oil prices staged an abrupt reversal late in the session; copper futures sank; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Air Fares Hitting Turbulence In Wake of Kuwait Invasion
Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Jet fuel costs have soared since Iraq invaded Kuwait, but it's anyone's guess whether an airline ticket will cost you more or less in coming months. ``Indications are that they're going up,'' said Raymond E. Neidl, an airline analyst with Dillon, Read & Co. Inc. ``Airlines are getting around that by jacking up the basic fare and then offering various discounts.'' For the time being, some fares are rising and others are falling in a phenomenon that Neidl described Monday as ``turmoil in pricing.'' The latest price changes are a temporary round of cheaper fares to Europe. Trans World and Northwest announced over the weekend that they were offering some special low fares on trans-Atlantic flights, for fall and winter tickets purchased by Sept. 21. On Monday, airlines saying they would follow suit included USAir and Pan Am. Other carriers were studying the overseas fare cut. They are also keeping an eye on what comes from a round of domestic fare increases that were announced recently by Pan Am and Alaska Air Group. Since the Persian Gulf crisis began, the price airlines pay for jet fuel has shot up some 40 percent, from around 60 cents per gallon to between 80 and 90 cents per gallon. That rise puts the sluggish airline industry in a bind. If crude oil maintains its current high price, airlines can expect to pay an additional $4.5 billion per year for fuel, according to an industry group, the Air Transport Association. Finding a way to pay for more expensive fuel is not easy. Any airline that goes out on a limb by raising fares runs the risk of losing business in the highly competitive market. Last month, the major U.S. carriers said they would raise their domestic fares by 5.3 percent in response to the inflated cost of jet fuel, but analysts and industry sources said the higher fares would not pick up the entire increase in the industry's jet fuel tab. Two airlines then decided they would charge fliers more money on domestic flights. Alaska Air announced an additional 4.7 percent fare increase, to take effect Oct. 1, and Pan Am announced an additional 4.4 percent fare increase, to take effect Sept. 18. Neidl said Alaska Air can probably pull off its increase, because it is a regional carrier that serves some Alaska destinations that other airlines cannot reach. He found Pan Am's move intriguing. ``Pan Am is never going to get away with that if other airlines don't match it,'' Neidl said Monday. ``They're going to have a hard time holding that because they're going to lose traffic.'' Domestically, Pan Am is too small to be a price leader, he said. Pan Am spokeswoman Elizabeth Hlinko would not say whether her carrier is concerned about scaring off travelers. ``This is something we're monitoring,'' Ms. Hlinko said. ``At this point, we're planning on putting it (the increase) into effect.'' Other airlines said Monday they were watching Pan Am's move, but none would say whether it was considering a similar increase. ``Before we would strongly consider a fare increase, we would have to see jet fuel costs remain high,'' Northwest spokesman Doug Miller said. ``We certainly don't want to raise fares. You always run the risk of inhibiting traffic.'' Neidl viewed the cheaper fares to Europe as a temporary marketing strategy that airlines often use in an attempt to lure ``discretionary travelers,'' non-business passengers who might decide on a relatively short notice to take an overseas vacation. ``This happens all the time during the slow seasons,'' he said. ``You don't want to fill up all your seats that way.'' After Oct. 1, international flights might start costing more. The International Air Transport Association recently agreed to fare increases of 5 percent to 8 percent that are still being processed by various governments. Some U.S. airlines plan to go along with those increases, while others were not yet ready to say what they will do.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Money Minders Split Over Capital Requirements
DOC.TEXT: Two federal bank regulators say they are still at odds over the amount of capital that banks should maintain to avoid a savings and loan-like debacle in the banking industry. In testimony before a Senate panel Monday, the Controller of the Currency and the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said their dispute has narrowed since January but they still disagree firmly on lowering the capital standards for all banks. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said a drop in federal requirements so that banks must maintain capital standards of at least 3 percent of assets should be limited to only the healthiest of the nation's 12,400 banks. But Controller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke thinks raising the standard any higher would supercede plans to make a risk-based capital standard the primary focus for evaluating the adequacy of a bank's capital. By the end of this year, all banks and thrifts will be required to have 7.25 percent capital to risk-adjusted assets. That ratio will grow to 8 percent by the end of 1992. Seidman told the Senate Banking Committee that he and Clarke ``agree on many more things than we disagree on'' but ``I don't think we can continue with these differences without causing real harm to the system.'' Capital is the basic yardstick for measuring a financial institution's soundness. The more capital a bank has, the more losses it can absorb without failing, conversely the less capital, the more likely losses could force a failure. Legislation passed by Congress last year set minimum capital standards for savings and loans, but there is no minimum set by law for the amount of cash and assets easily converted into cash banks must have to offset the risk of loans and investments. Currently the Federal Reserve Board, the FDIC and the Office of the Controller of the Currency have a gentleman's agreement that banks must maintain a leverage ratio _ capital to total assets _ of 6 percent. The Fed has adopted new standards, effective Dec. 31, that would require the most highly-rated banks to have at least a 3 percent ratio of capital to total assets, with other banks required to have another 1 percent or 2 percent in capital. Seidman said he was willing to go along with that as a compromise although the FDIC chairman preferred the ratio up around 4.5 percent. But the OCC, which oversees some 4,000 national banks around the country, wants to set the requirement at 3 percent for all banks. Seidman said that was too low and would reduce the capital requirements of some 10,000 banks. ``There are three lines of defense in keeping industry losses to a minimum and avoiding a taxpayer bailout,'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., the committee chairman, said at the hearing's start. The first is careful lending practices at banks and thrifts, he said. The second is the capital maintained by financial institutions and the third is the federal deposit insurance fund. Asked by Riegle if the agencies could settle their differences, Controller of the Currency Robert Clarke said ``the differences are extremely minimal.'' But Seidman shook his head during Clarke's answer. ``This disagreement may sound like regulators splitting hairs, 3 percent and 4.5 percent. There's only a 1.5 percent difference but it is a very material difference when one looks at the banking system,'' insisted Seidman. At 3 percent, he said, substantially all smaller banks would have a lower minimum standard, eliminating a check on financial institutions with potential exposure to interest rate risks. Riegle asked Seidman and Clarke, who were joined at the hearing by Fed Governor Wayne D. Angell and Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, to try and work out their differences and report back to him in 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sentencing Report Expected To Include Unproven Charges
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken, who pleaded guilty to six felonies to settle securities fraud charges, is expected to face a slew of new allegations the government hopes will induce a judge to stiffen his prison sentence. The government agreed not to indict Milken for any other financial crimes when it accepted his guilty plea in April. But federal courts have allowed prosecutors to air a range of charges at sentencing that a defendant hasn't been convicted of or pleaded guilty to. Milken, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department, admitted six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties to settle a 98-count fraud and racketeering indictment. Attorneys said Monday the government will detail a host of other unproven crimes before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood as she prepares to sentence Milken Oct. 1. Wood could refuse to consider any new charges outright _ as happened in a case before another judge this year. Or she could scheduled a hearing on the claims that might include testimony by admitted inside trader Ivan Boesky. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll said the government was to present its report to Wood on Thursday. He declined to comment on the contents, but stressed the government's right to go beyond Milken's guilty plea. Under the plea agreement signed by Milken, the government can ``bring to the court's attention'' conduct that was not included in the plea. Milken also agreed not to dispute making the government's final sentencing report public. The Justice Department agreed not to request a specific sentence. Milken faces a maximum 28 years in prison. The charges to which he pleaded guilty were not among the most serious in the indictment. Milken is entitled to rebut any charges the government may make in its sentencing report and can defend himself at a hearing, which either side can ask the judge to hold. Attorneys for former Milken associates who cooperated with the government's nearly four-year investigation said they had been told that prosecutors planned to bring their full case against Milken to Wood's attention. ``We've gotten wind of such a hearing,'' said Aubrey Harwell Jr., who represents former Drexel bond salesman Cary Maultasch. ``We understand the government is contemplating . . . calling numerous witnesses.'' A spokesman for Milken declined to comment. Such hearings, which can include evidence, testimony and cross-examination as at a trial, are rare. Attorneys said a Milken hearing could last up to three months and feature testimony by Boesky, who served two years in prison after settling insider trading charges. Boesky was Milken's chief accuser. Earlier this year, U.S. District Judge Pierre N. Leval refused to admit charges that former Goldman, Sachs & Co. arbitrager Robert M. Freeman committed 20 crimes in addition to a single charge of insider trading he admitted. ``The government, of course, had the opportunity to charge the defendant with those 20 crimes. Instead it made a plea bargain with the defendant agreeing . . . to prosecute this single charge,'' he wrote. But Leval added that it was not necessarily improper for the government to point to other offenses adding to its call for a hefty sentence. The Milken case may qualify because of its scope and the wide public attention it has generated. Attorneys said no matter how devastating the new charges, Milken would be unlikely to request a public hearing because testimony could add to the hundreds of pending civil lawsuits stemming from his crimes. The sentencing report is ``less damaging than having all the evidence laid out,'' said one attorney who asked not to be named. ``It provides a road map to civil plaintiffs. It doesn't give it to them on a silver platter.'' The rationale for allowing unindicted criminal allegations is that a judge should consider negative information at sentencing as well as positive information, such as letters from friends. A federal appeals court in 1980 endorsed the practice in an organized crime case. The decision was upheld by the Supreme Court, even though many lawyers maintain it's unfair to defendants. ``Since when in this country can you go to jail for things a jury hasn't found you guilty of at a hearing where hearsay is admissible and by a standard that is less than proof beyond a reasonable doubt?'' asked Gerald Lefcourt, attorney for former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg, who was indicted along with Milken last year and convicted in a separate case.

DOC.HEAD: Most Non-Economic Issues Wrapped Up Between UAW and GM
DOC.TEXT: Most non-economic national contract issues have been wrapped up by United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. negotiators, leaving tough issues for the last four days of bargaining. A UAW source, speaking Monday on the condition of anonymity, said tentative agreements have been reached on nearly all non-economic issues facing bargainers working against a midnight Friday deadline. ``There's not too much left,'' he said. Bargaining continued over the most important issue _ job security. Negotiators are making progress, but the source declined to give details. While most issues have economic considerations, non-economic issues typically include military leave, legal assistance and union dues checkoff. Frequently, negotiators strive to resolve non-economic issues early so they can concentrate on the tougher economic points, including job security, wages and benefits, time off and pension matters. UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich said last Thursday that about half of the non-economic issues had been resolved, and the pace of negotiations at that point was faster than he has seen in any set of talks. UAW national contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire at midnight Friday. The union is focusing bargaining at GM, which has about 300,000 UAW-covered employees. The union has said that after a contract is ratified at the world's largest automaker, it will be used as a pattern for agreements with Ford and Chrysler. Negotiations between the union and Ford and Chrysler have been put on ice since GM was chosen as the UAW's bargaining target late last month. Ford sent home all of its national negotiators last week to concentrate on local contracts, spokesman Dick Routh said Monday. There are 79 UAW locals at Ford facilities and four have reached local agreements, all of which expire Friday like the national contract, he said. At Chrysler, UAW and company negotiators have been meeting occasionally in subcommittees focused on certain areas of the contract, such as wages, job security or health and safety. Company spokesman Lee Sechler said local agreements at about 60 UAW locals at Chrysler facilities remain unresolved. Expiration dates on those agreements vary, but most of the assembly plant contracts expire Friday. The tone of the negotiations between the union and GM has been quiet. Little public information has leaked out of the fifth-floor negotiating suite at the GM Building just north of downtown Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Profits from Gulf Crisis Help Saudis Pay for U.S. Support
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Windfall oil profits, the result of increased production and higher prices, have given Saudi Arabia a painless way to finance much of the cost of the U.S. military deployment in the Persian Gulf, industry analysts say. An irony of the crisis is that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is effectively paying for the military might that's been arrayed against him. The crisis triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has pushed oil prices up from around $15 a barrel to as high as $32. Prices are higher partly because of the U.N. embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti output, which has taken about 4 million barrels a day off the market. The Saudis and the United Arab Emirates are picking up most of the slack to replace those 4 million barrels. Saudi Arabia alone has boosted production from 5.3 million barrels a day to around 7.5 million without incurring any increased production costs. Almost all the increased production comes from Saudi Aramco, the Saudi government-owned refining and exporting corporation in which the major American oil companies once had a share. But U.S. and Saudi officials said Aramco easily increased its production without spending a dime. ``It still costs only $1, $1.25 to get a barrel of oil out of the ground. Beyond 7.5 million barrels a day they incur extra costs,'' said an American official who spoke on condition he was not identified. The result is a windfall estimated at $100 million a day, more than enough to pay part of the cost of keeping foreign troops on Saudi soil to protect King Fahd's throne. Saudi officials have refused to say how much they will contribute to the U.S. operation. But one said: ``Americans won't be disappointed in what Saudi Arabia's willing to do.'' The ease with which Saudi Aramco boosted production was underscored by the American official, who said: ``They did it on short notice without an increase in marginal cost.'' Furthermore, Nassr Ajmi, Aramco's executive vice president, said the corporation could keep up production levels of 7.5 million barrels a day indefinitely without incurring higher costs. ``Higher prices will be good in the short run,'' said Prince Abdullah bin Faisal, head of the royal commission for the industrial port cities of Jubail on the Gulf and Yanbu on the Red Sea coast. If, however, Saudi Arabia wants to produce even more oil _ it has the largest reserves in the world _ it must pay to do so. Officials say Saudi Aramco's plans to increase its sustainable capacity to 10 million barrels a day would involve substantial new investment in plant and equipment. Estimates are that Aramco plans to spend $10 billion to $14 billion on its expansion. Another variable for Aramco is personnel. About 3,000 Americans are employed by the corporation, many in key techological and management jobs. More than 13,000 other foreigners, mainly Asians on contract work, are employed by the oil giant. The Saudis make up the remainder of 50,000-strong workforce. There have been reports of widespread resignations since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But Aramco officials said only 27 Americans have quit recently. Saudis and American businessmen both say that in boom times, filling even key jobs, is not a problem. But it may cost money in the form of higher salaries and more incentives. ``In a time of crisis one can buy expatriates,'' said Dr. Bakr Abdullah Bakr, rector of the King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals.

DOC.HEAD: Some Figures on the S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With AM-S&Ls on Main Street III. The $50 figure in `actually paid' section is cq. Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a scorecard on the savings and loan situation as of Aug. 1. Information was supplied by the Justice Department, Resolution Trust Corp. and various sources:

COST: $500 billion or more over 30 years. SCOPE: 468 thrifts taken over in 39 states as of July 30. Of these, 211 were either sold or closed. The other 257 are in conservatorship. CHARGED: 328 defendants indicted. CONVICTED: 231 defendants; 5 others acquitted. JAIL TERMS: 1.9 years on average. The average term for a bank robber is 9.4 years. PENALTIES: $56.6 million ordered in restitution, including $25 million in civil settlements. FINES IMPOSED: $1 million. ACTUALLY PAID: Of the $2.5 million ordered in restitution this year in cases prosecuted by the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force, the only one for which statistics were available, $50 has been paid. In the previous two years, $23,700 of $8.9 million ordered in restitution has been paid. PENDING: 84 civil lawsuits against 48 thrifts in an attempt to recover lost money. Also pending, about 40,000 lawsuits in an attempt to recover money from thrift officers.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Block $3 Billion Sale of `Junk' Bonds to Investor Group
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have blocked Columbia Savings & Loan from selling $3 billion of its junk bonds to a group of Canadian and Hong Kong investors. Regulators said Monday that the troubled thrift failed to seek any all-cash bids. Columbia chief Edward G. Harshfield said in a brief statement that the thrift obtained ``the most favorable bid.'' The Office of Thrift Supervision also said it could not approve the sale in its current form, because the troubled thrift neglected to seek an adequate number of bids for the junk bond portfolio. Columbia at one time had the thrift industry's largest portfolio of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds. The thrift is based in Beverly Hills. The Los Angeles Times, in today's editions, quoted unidentified sources as saying L. William Seidman would support a cash deal in which Columbia gets rid of the junk bonds for good. Seidman chairs the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency formed last year to handle failing thrifts. Regulators have held off seizing Columbia while its managers tried to find a buyer for the junk bonds, despite the fact that the thrift is insolvent. Columbia was $350 million in the red according to the latest report, largely due to the declining value of the junk bond portfolio but also because of recent real estate losses. In late July, Columbia agreed to sell the bonds for $3 billion to a partnership assembled by Gordon Investment Corp., a merchant bank based in New York and Toronto. A principal of Gordon Investment is Hong Kong billionaire entrepreneur Li Ka-shing, who could not be reached for comment. Under the proposed deal, Gordon America LP would have paid $300 million down and given Columbia a 10-year note for the remaining $2.7 billion at an interest rate of 10.5 percent. If the value of the bonds fell 10 percent below the purchase price, the buyers could have walked away from the deal, losing their down payment but avoiding further losses. In that case, the junk bonds would have wound up back in the hands of Columbia _ and, if the thrift were seized _ of the taxpayers. In its announcement, the OTS said the proposed 10-year non-recourse note for 90 percent of the purchase price raised ``a significant legal issue'' under the S&L bailout legislation enacted last year. ``I hope additional bids ... will result in a proposal that we can quickly approve,'' OTS Director Timothy Ryan said in a statement. ``We appreciate the manner in which the current management of Columbia ... has dealt with this and other problems inherited from the Thomas Spiegel era.'' Spiegel, the former chief executive officer of Columbia, has been accused by the regulators of breaching his duty to Columbia's shareholders and showing a ``reckless disregard'' for the law that resulted in excessive personal enrichment. Spiegel has denied the allegations. The OTS announced last Thursday that it had added a new allegation against Spiegel, who had earlier been accused of squandering $19 million. The agency now accuses Spiegel of causing a $29.2 million loss to Columbia from the construction of a new headquarters building ``without any attempt to limit costs.'' The new building included a large multi-level gymnasium and ``survival chamber'' bathrooms with bullet-proof glass and an independent air and food supply, the OTS said. Spiegel, who feared a terrorist attack, also has been accused of spending at least $91,000 of Columbia's funds to buy an assortment of about 80 guns. Columbia, which is trying to sell the building, has removed the gymnasium and the elaborate bathrooms. The building cost Columbia more than $54.7 million and has a market value of around $24 million, according to the OTS. The new charge put Spiegel at the top of the list of S&L executives from whom regulators are seeking compensation. He is followed by Charles Keating Jr., the former head of the collapsed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in Irvine.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Bank To Guarantee Portion of City Loan
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss bank will guarantee part of the $375 million Philadelphia is seeking, making it the first institution to risk helping the financially troubled city. Swiss Bank Corp. will back $50 million of the temporary loan notes the administration is trying to sell to raise cash, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported today. City officials and a financial team headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets were trying to persuade at least two other banks to guarantee additional notes. John Chamales, Swiss Bank first vice president, said the bank was prepared to issue a letter of credit for as much as $225 million if other banks subcontract for the other $175 million and assume some of the risk, the newspaper reported. Quoting unnamed sources, The Inquirer said city leaders are talking with Union Bank of Switzerland and National Westminister Bank of London about joining Swiss Bank. The administration of Mayor W. Wilson Goode has said the city will be out of cash by late this month unless it receives a cash infusion. The notes would be repaid from property and business tax receipts expected early next year. Even with the temporary notes, the city projects a $206.4 million deficit in the $2.1 billion general fund budget by June 30, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes Continuing to Pay Fuel Penalties
DOC.TEXT: Relatively stable car sales will force Mercedes-Benz to pay more than $18 million in fuel-consumption penalties next year, company executives say. ``If you build large automobiles, as Mercedes-Benz does, it will be very difficult for anybody to deal with it,'' Albert Weiss, general marketing manager for Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc., said Monday of potentially higher fuel-economy standards. Congress is considering a bill that would boost the corporate average fuel economy standard by 20 percent in 1995 and by 40 percent in 2001. That would push the current 27.5 miles per gallon standard to around 40 mpg by the end of the century. Companies selling cars in the United States must pay a penalty if the average fuel economy rating for those cars doesn't meet certain standards. A gas-guzzler tax may also be imposed on the company's least efficient models. ``You're not going to have a 4,000-pound car with 40 miles per gallon and have performance,'' Weiss said. Mercedes-Benz's corporate average fuel economy in 1990 is 21.2 mpg, which forced the company to pay about $18.6 million in fuel-economy penalties for this year, said Peter Patrone, the company's product planning manager. In 1989, the company paid $20.4 million for an average fuel economy of 21.4 mpg. The decrease in penalty and average fuel economy stemmed from a 0.9 percent drop in sales of Mercedes cars between the two years, Patrone and Weiss said. Through the first eight months of 1990, Mercedes has sold 48,029 cars. Company officials don't expect the 1991 penalty to differ much from 1990 because sales and fuel efficiency should be relatively the same. Comments by Weiss and Patrone came as the company introduced its 18-car lineup of 1991 models. Half of those vehicles will be assessed a gas-guzzler tax ranging from $500 to $1,300, depending on the vehicle. Without the gas-guzzler taxes, base prices for 1991-model cars range from $28,050 for the 190E with a 2.3-liter, four-cylinder engine and a manual transmission, to $89,300 for the 500SL with a 5-liter V-8 engine and an automatic transmission. The two SL coupes, the 300SL with a 3-liter engine and the 500SL, were redesigned for the 1990 model year. Weiss and Patrone said company officials were surprised at the popularity of the 500SL version, despite its higher price tag and lower, 16-mpg average. About 75 percent of the car models sold last year were the 500SL, they said. That indicates that buyers of Mercedes cars aren't worried as much about the fuel efficiency of their automobiles. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait nearly six weeks ago, Mercedes dealers haven't reported any slowdown in sales, Weiss said. ``The cost of fuel doesn't seem to be a problem at this time,'' he said. For the 1990 model year, Mercedes expanded availability of diesel engines, which are more fuel-efficient than same-size gasoline engines. For 1991, the company will offer three cars with turbocharged diesel engines in the United States, except for California. The diesel-powered cars flunk stringent California emissions standards. One diesel car, the 350SD Turbo, is new for 1991. The 190E 2.3 is the only other new car the company is introducing for the 1991 model year. Mercedes is offering two new kinds of traction control devices for its 1991-model cars.

DOC.HEAD: Chileans Charge U.S. Officials Contaminated Grapes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was included in PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Chilean Exporters Association is accusing the U.S. Food and Drug Administration of contaminating two Chilean grapes with cyanide and setting off a public health scare in March 1989. A report issued by the association in Washington and Santiago, Chile, concluded that, based on scientific studies, the grapes could not have been tampered with in Chile or at the port of Philadelphia where the poisoned grapes were found. ``The grapes were contaminated at the FDA laboratory in Philadelphia,'' the report said. ``The manner in which the contamination took place could have been accidental or intentional.'' FDA officials have said repeatedly that they believe the grapes were poisoned in Chile before the ship left on its two-week voyage to the United States. Of the report's conclusion, FDA spokesman Bill Grigg said: ``We think that's preposterous.'' The FDA went looking for the grapes after the U.S. Embassy in Santiago received an anonymous telephone threat March 2, 1989. After it found the two tainted grapes, the FDA urged that all Chilean fruit be removed from U.S. markets while more tests continued. The association estimated the FDA's action cost the Chileans more than $330 million as more than 6 million cases of fruit in the United States were destroyed. The association said research at the University of California at Davis showed that if the two grapes had been contaminated with cyanide, other grapes in the same case also would have contained the poison. However, none was found, the FDA has said. The studies also showed that because cyanide was found at such high levels, it would have to have been introduced in the grapes more recently than two weeks before, when the ship was in Chile, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Norway's July Oil Production Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Norway's daily crude oil flows averaged 1.428 million barrels in July, the month before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, down 7.9 percent from a year earlier and 9.8 percent from the previous month, according to official figures released Tuesday. The latest production results compared with 1.550 million barrels in July 1989 and 1.584 million barrels in June 1990. The Norwegian Petroleum Directorate said total offshore petroleum production in July was 7.7 million tons, down from 8.3 million tons reported in June. July production was divided into 5.9 million tons of oil, 1.6 million tons of natural gas and 200,000 tons of condensate, it said in a news release. Norway's North Sea fields produced a total of 60.7 million tons of oil equivalent during the first seven months of 1990, compared to 59.7 million tons reported for the same period of 1989, it said.

DOC.HEAD: `It Looks Like A Museum,' Gasps Soviet Outside First Moscow Pizza Hut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes typos in 5th, 11th grafs. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Pizza Hut opened its first two Soviet restaurants today, dishing out American-style fast food to wide-eyed customers as perplexed by their spanking clean surroundings as by the menu. ``It looks like a museum,'' said sailor Yevgeni Gerko, one of about 300 Soviets who waited in line for up to four hours for the official opening. ``We want to know the American style of eating,'' he said, gazing through the window at Pizza Hut's restaurant along Kutuzovsky Prospekt, on which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev drives to work. The second, smaller, restaurant is on Gorky Street, a main thoroughfare near the Kremlin that already boasts the only Estee Lauder and Christian Dior outlets in the country. Just after noon, a large, deep pan Super Supreme pizza with everything on it came out of the Kutuzovsky restaurant's oven, the first of 5,000 it expects to serve daily. Waiting customers, clutching Pizza Hut flags emblazoned with American and Soviet symbols, oohed and aahed, then tried to rush the door. Pizza Hut officials struggled to limit entrance to a handful of people at a time. Pizza Hut is selling its meals for both dollars and rubles. The menu is similar to those in the West, except only nine pizza combinations are offered and no substitutions are permitted. A special Moscow Seafood pizza topped with salmon, smoked sardines and onions was created to appeal to Soviet tastes. ``People don't know what the products are,'' explained regional operations director Andy Rafalet. ``Let's make the choice a little easier.'' Choice was easy at the salad bar: no lettuce, but lots of cabbage, a Soviet staple. The Kutuzovksy site, near a large foreigners' compound, has separate dining rooms for ruble- and dollar-paying customers, plus a takeout counter. Gorky Street has a window selling pizza slices for rubles. The restaurants' 300 Soviet employees were chosen from 3,500 applicants. Rafalet said most will earn 300 rubles ($480) a month, slightly higher than the average monthly salary of 250 rubles ($400). Pizza Hut's parent company, PepsiCo Inc. of Purchase, N.Y., has been doing business with the Soviets for more than 30 years, since chief executive Donald Kendall cajoled then-Premier Nikita Khrushchev into tasting Pepsi at a 1959 Moscow trade fair. Three years ago, the Moscow City Council invited PepsiCo to bring its family-oriented restaurants to the Soviet capital. The city has a 51 percent stake in the joint venture which owns the two restaurants. ``We hope to revolutionize the food and restaurant industry,'' Kendall told an opening ceremony. ``My 30 years in dealing with the Soviets has taught me that while initial negotiations can be long and sometimes frustrating, that once you sign an agreement and open your business, the Soviets are equal to any partner in the entire world.'' Pizza Hut originally announced it would open its Moscow restauarants in September 1989, but construction did not begin until January. Pizza Hut says the four ovens in its bigger restaurant can produce 5,000 pizzas daily, and it expects to serve 50,000 customers a week, about seven times the turnover of any Pizza Hut in the United States. McDonald's Moscow outlet still sells 5,000 burgers an hour and the lunchtime lineup is 90 minutes long. The restaurants are part of a $3 billion deal in which the Soviets will build at least 10 ships, mostly oil tankers, for PepsiCo to sell or lease, and PepsiCo's exclusive right to market Stolichnaya vodka in the United States was extended to the year 2000. In return, PepsiCo agreed to double its soft drink production in the Soviet Union.

Stock prices were mostly lower in early trading today as the market remained concerned about rising oil prices and the Iraqi standoff, analysts said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down 7.67 points to 2,607.92 as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Declining issues narrowly outnumbered advancing ones in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 396 up, 481 down and 496 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to a light 14.81 million shares as of 10 a.m. EDT. Trading volume remains thin as investors seem inclined to stay out of the market while the Mideast situation remains unresolved, analysts say. Analysts say stock investors remain concerned about the troubling rise in oil prices. On Monday, stock prices tracked the decline and later rise in crude prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the October contract for crude oil rose $1.26 Monday to close at $31.30 a barrel. The stock market received no help from abroad today. In Japan, the key Nikkei Stock Average fell 476.24 points, or 1.9 percent, closing at 24,604.66. Prices also were lower in midday London trading. Among most-active blue chip issues on the NYSE, AT&T was up [ at 30{, IBM rose \ to 106[, Exxon was up [ at 50{ and General Electric fell [ to 61. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.38 to 176.32. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.03 to 323.18. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a 3.96 loss at 2,615.59. Advancing issues nosed out declines on the NYSE, with 761 up, 726 down and 475 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 119.73 million shares, against 123.80 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Say Hearst in Talks to Buy RJR Nabisco's ESPN Stake
DOC.TEXT: The Hearst Corp. may buy the 20 percent stake that RJR Nabisco Inc. holds in the ESPN sports cable television network, published reports said Tuesday. RJR Nabisco has been exploring its options on its ESPN interest for more than a year. The remaining 80 percent of the cable service is owned by Capital Cities-ABC Inc., the company that owns and operates the ABC Television Network. The Wall Street Journal and the New York Times each reported Tuesday that Hearst and RJR Nabisco were in talks with Hearst about selling the stake. Although no agreement has been reached, the Journal story said people familiar with the discussions said Hearst may pay $180 million to $200 million for the stake, or below the $250 million that it said RJR Nabisco had hoped to get. Officials for Hearst, RJR and Capital Cities-ABC all declined comment. ESPN is one of the largest cable networks, available to about 61 percent of U.S. households with television. It had a pretax profit of about $125 million last year but expects lower results this year because of losses on its coverage of major league baseball. RJR Nabisco has reportedly had trouble finding a buyer for its interest because its stake gives it no management authority over the service and no guarantee of a dividend. RJR Nabisco said in August 1989 that it had hired the investment firm Lazard Freres & Co. to advise it on its ESPN stake, saying several parties had expressed interest in it but that it had not decided what to do with it. The company took that step after being acquired for $24.5 billion in April 1989 by a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Hearst, which owns magazines and newspapers, already has ties to Capital Cities-ABC. It owns several ABC-affiliated television stations and is a partner with Capital Cities-ABC in the Lifetime and Arts & Entertainment cable networks.

DOC.NOTE: $adv17
For release Monday, Sept. 17, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With Graphic
Group Promotes Franchising, Sets Sights On Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: By his own estimate, Arthur Karp has devoted only 30 days this year to running his chocolate-chip cookie business. He says he has a more pressing mission: to sell the world on the concept of franchising. As chairman of the International Franchise Association, Karp spends most of his time leading business groups on international trade missions. The opportunities have been plentiful since the dearth of communism in Eastern Europe, Karp said. The new democracies are hungry for Western-style products and government officials have been bending over backwards to allow U.S. franchises, he said. ``There are opportunities there for people of vision that are just laying around on the street,'' Karp said in a recent interview at the Atlanta offices of his franchised Great American Chocolate Chip Cookie Co. ``In the future, when they talk about the `good old days,' they're going to be talking about the 1990s.'' IFA's push in Eastern Europe comes on the heels of a decade of sharp growth in franchising in the United States. Domestic franchises are expected to account for $716 billion in retail sales in 1990 _ a third of the nation's total retail sales, according to IFA. That's more than quadruple the $160 billion in sales from franchises during 1983, the Washington-based group said. The number of franchises is expected to grow to 533,000 establishments this year, up from 442,400 in 1980, IFA said. It said a rash of gasoline station shutdowns in the early 1980s had offet the establishment of new franchises, but the total number of franchises has risen steadily since 1984. Under a franchise agreement, a company grants a franchisee the right to sell its products or services in a certain area. The franchiser usually provides business guidance, promotional assistance, financing and other benefits in exchange for a percentage of the sales or profits. The support system behind the arrangement provides a safety net for the franchisee that leaves less room for error as a business develops, Karp said. ``You're not reinventing the wheel,'' he said. ``We (the franchiser) have probably run into the problem that that individual is facing 100 times before. And we've learned how to handle it . . . from marketing to construction to purchasing, to whatever it is.'' Economist Al Niemi agreed that Eastern Europe presents favorable opportunities for selling consumer goods, though he cautioned that those going there in search of a quick buck likely will be disappointed. ``It's going to take longer than some people think,'' said Niemi, dean of the University of Georgia College of Business Administration. ``There's a basic infrastructure there that needs to be rebuilt.'' Niemi said the demand for consumer goods in the former communist strongholds is enormous. To suddenly provide a U.S.-style variety of products, he said, ``would be like going to fantasy land.'' John Amos, executive director of Dallas-based I Can't Believe It's Yogurt, said he has made contacts in Eastern Europe from his participation in IFA trade missions. But he said he believes it will be a few years before Poles and Romanians are licking yogurt cones. ``I think there are enormous opportunities in the Eastern Bloc countries, but it will be some time before the logistical system is in place to support the growth,'' Amos said. ``You can take almost any commodity there on the back of a semi and sell it. But there are no systems in place to support distribution.'' In addition to the Eastern Bloc countries, Karp also has led trade missions to Australia, Switzerland, France, Spain and Mexico during his one-year term as head of IFA. Karp's role usually involves meeting with government officials while representatives of the companies seek contacts with local business leaders. Karp said he has encountered no hostility toward the importing of U.S. franchises, and dismissed the notion that the traveling companies would be viewed as moving in to take business away from local entrepreneurs. ``They're not just going in and opening businesses,'' he said. They're seeking local people. ``The McDonald's in Madrid is run by Spaniards. It employs Spaniards and pays taxes to the government of Spain. The American concept of retailing is still the best in the world, and we're exporting that.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday Sept. 17

DOC.HEAD: He Trades TV Time For Carribbean Cruises And More
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Lance Lundberg surveys the businesses in his ``portfolio'' much like a card player eyeing his hand. There have been cable TV companies in need of broadcasting equipment; a cruise line that could use some advertising exposure; and a papermaker with a surplus of baby wipes. The companies' needs were skillfully matched through swaps and trades that Lundberg, a 34-year-old Harvard MBA, arranged under the age-old system known as bartering. Bartering has been around since cave days and continues to be a method of commerce among corporations of every size worldwide. According to the Alexandria, Va.-based International Reciprocal Trade Association, more than 400 ``exchanges'' help an estimated 220,000 businesses _ usually small ones _ trade goods and services. But exchanges account for only a fraction of the pie. When direct swaps among large corporations are considered, industry experts say barter is responsible for up to $12 billion of domestic trade a year. Lundberg's ICON International puts a new twist on what traditionally is a quid pro quo transaction. By footing the bill himself in many cases, Lundberg is leveraged into the transaction, which makes him more of a financier than just a stockpiler of surplus goods and services. Take, for example, a cable televison channel that needs broadcasting equipment. ``I purchase it (the equipment), lease it to them, and over the life of the lease take payment in a stream of 30-second commercial units,'' Lundberg said. Since the price of air time has been increasing at an average 30 percent a year, Lundberg is left ``holding a portfolio much like a portfolio of stocks. I can trade out when I think values have peaked.'' By trading out, he means swapping the commercials for, say, Radisson Hotel rooms. Or, from time to time, Lundberg trades merchandise for cash, like the baby wipes he sold for James River Corp. ``You can't endlessly trade, or you won't have money to pay the light bill,'' he said. Much of ICON's success resulted from Lundberg's apt targeting of once-fledgling cable TV channels like Financial News Network, ESPN and Arts & Entertainment, which had spare capacity at low cost. The cable clients ``got at a very early developmental stage cash-free financing'' while Lundberg cheaply built a foundation from which to trade. Now he's building another base in the travel and accommodation industry. All inventory is computerized and is periodically reviewed so values can be reassessed. Four years into his venture, Lundberg boasts an impressive client list, including 3M Corp., James River, the Raddisson hotel chain, Norwegian Cruise Line, Time Warner Inc. and People magazine. ICON began taking shape in 1985, when Lundberg met John Fentener van Vlissingen, a wealthy Dutch businessman and chief executive of Holland's Noro Group. Noro helped set up meetings with ``sophisticated, substantial individuals,'' as Lundberg refers to them, so he could pitch his idea. Within six months, 60 European investors had anted up $60,000 each for a piece of a mutual fund; another $500,000 was raised through a separate pool of U.S. investors. Lundberg was somewhat surprised at the interest in his new venture. ``Selling a new idea is sometimes easier than selling an operating business,'' he said. ``You're really enthusiastic _ you're in there selling sizzle. When you get going, you're selling steak, and there's a big difference.'' Today, ICON is a $20-plus million company growing at an annual rate of 60 percent. Lundberg now employes a staff of 25 at a midtown Manhattan office so new that the company's name has not yet been stenciled on the front doors. Annual returns have been ``volatile, but never negative'' and have averaged 16 percent a year, he said. Born in Amherst, Mass., Lundberg studied English and administrative sciences at Yale University before moving on to Harvard University. He left the consulting firm Booz Allen & Hamilton to found a company that oversaw a network of cash machines. ``I can't say it was a success, but we preserved our investors' capital and learned a lot,'' he said. So far, the boyish Lundberg has received high marks from clients. Daniel Infanti, a spokesman at Sharp Electronics Corp. in Mahwah, N.J., said his company has dealt exclusively with Lundberg in a handful of deals involving laptop computers, fax supplies and other office goods valued anywhere from $100,000 to more than $1 million. ``The use of barter helps us in times when we have distressed merchandise,'' Infanti said. ``It gives us a good outlet for products that become outdated in a very short period of time.'' But Infanti said that generally ``barter is the type of business relationship that makes most manufacturers uneasy. There is very high turnover in the (barter) companies, and you don't always get what you think you're getting.'' Jeff Stutin, director of marketing services for Norwegian Cruise Line in Coral Gables, Fla., echoed that sentiment. With some barter companies, ``you'll end up with things you weren't exactly expecting _ like prices of TV spots that were double what they normally would be,'' he said. Lundberg said the large capital base he started with ``made it a lot eaiser to deliver'' quality goods. And unlike many traditional barter exchanges, he doesn't do most of his business in distressed merchandise. By the end of the year, Lundberg will decide whether to open a European office, which also could begin by targeting emerging cable TV networks. He said a handful of major companies have expressed an interest in acquiring ICON, and he's not necessarily adverse to the notion. But he's keeping mum on what he wants in exchange for his company.

DOC.HEAD: Economists: State Tax Collections $500 Million Below Projections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with governor, Cabinet seeking budget cuts. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `When July... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez today asked state agencies to cut their budgets 5 percent in the wake of gloomy economic forecasts projecting a more than $500 million shortfall in tax collections. ``Obviously now the budget was adopted based on a forecast that isn't living up to its billing and we're going to have to make that change,'' Martinez said. ``It's never easy to do, but it's the only responsible thing to do.'' The governor and the state's elected Cabinet members will likely make the actual reductions, which could include layoffs and service cuts, at their Sept. 25 meeting after the agencies report back with recommendations, sasid state Budget Director Patti Woodworth. State economists Monday night came up with a new tax collection forecast for the fiscal year that began July 1 showing a reduction of $521.8 million from the estimate made in the spring. That amount would be cut from the $11.4 billion in general state revenues that fuel the $27.4 billion budget. When July collections came in $48.8 million below projections, the governor and Cabinet imposed a freeze on hiring, purchases and some travel. The new cuts are likely to go much further. Woodworth said she couldn't predict whether agencies would have to lay off workers but that some services would have to be pared. ``We've got to take a look at our priorities and see what we need to fund and what we can put off until next year,'' she said. ``I think some services are going to be affected.'' The Legislature approved some $1.5 billion in new taxes during the spring session, but it wasn't enough to make up for the lagging collections in existing taxes. The major culprit is the sales tax, which will come in some $300 million below the original projection.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Dip
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell this morning as traders realized there was no truth to the Mideast rumors that pushed crude futures contracts into a late afternoon surge on Monday. Light sweet crude dropped 60 cents to $30.70 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange in late morning trading of October contracts. ``The main reason was that Europe traded down, because they realized the rumor wasn't true. That was the one on Jordan,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Oil prices had shot up late Monday on a rumor that Iraq had moved troops into Jordan. The markets had also been moved by unfounded rumors that Saudi Arabian oil facilities had been attacked and that shots had been fired in the Persian Gulf standoff. Unleaded gasoline and home heating oil futures were down for October contracts this morning, while natural gas was unchanged. Gasoline fell 1.07 cents to 93.65 cents per gallon, while heating oil fell 1.59 cents to 84.30 cents per gallon. Natural gas was unchanged at $1.525 per 1,000 cubic feet. Futures contracts for later months were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans, Corn Gain On Crop News
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and corn futures prices rose modestly this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department reported further deterioration last week in the condition of those crops. Wheat and oat futures were narrowly mixed in early tradeing. The USDA said Monday in its weekly crop-progress report that 52 percent of the soybean crop was in good to excellent condition as of Sunday compared with 58 percent a week earlier. Dry weather has placed stress on soybean plants in the Southeast and Mississippi Delta regions, although current rainy conditions are believed to be easing those problems. In the corn fields, the USDA rated 76 percent of the crop good to excellent compared with 79 percent a week ago. A National Weather Service forecast for cool, dry weather in the Midwest during the first half of next week was also supportive, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.66} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.40 a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with September at $1.08 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4\ cents higher with September at $6.21{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after rising on Monday. Live cattle were unchanged to .25 cent higher with October at 78.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .33 cent higher with September at 87.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .18 cent higher with October at 50.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .32 cent lower to .70 cent higher with February at 52.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: JAL To Invest In Lockheed Aircraft Maintenance Center
DOC.TEXT: Japan Air Lines will be the first customer at Lockheed Corp.'s new aircraft maintenance center and will make an equity investment in the maintenance subsidiary, the company said. JAL will have roughly 10 percent equity in the Lockheed Commercial Aircraft Center Inc., Skip Bowling, a Lockheed vice president, said Monday. The center is a Lockheed subsidiary created earlier this year at Norton Air Force Base in San Bernardino County. The company plans to use hangars the U.S. Air Force will abandon when it closes the base in 1994. JAL's work will account for about 15 percent of the operation's business, Bowling said. The center will maintain and modify Boeing 747 jetliners. JAL has the world's largest 747 fleet. It operates 65 aircraft and has commitments for another 69.
