DOC.HEAD: US-Japanese Relations Seen Headed for Bumps Over Gulf Support
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf pvs bgng, The resolution... with 3 new grafs to provide details of new Japanese offer, picks up 8th graf pvs, ``During his ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-Japanese relationship, which has been strained in recent years because of a huge trade imbalance, could be headed for more bumps in the road over the issue of support for the campaign against Iraq. Members of Congress were using strong words such as ``greedy'' and ``contemptible'' to described their feelings Monday about Japan's failure to be more generous in response to President Bush's request for the allies to bear a greater share of the burden in the Persian Gulf crisis. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady met with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu last Friday to ask that Japan more than double the $1 billion contribution it has proposed making to support the Persian Gulf effort. Brady, however, left Tokyo without any commitments for increased aid. ``They are acting totally within the character that they usually do. They are motivated by profit, greed and avarice,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``Theirs is an attitude that I think really is repugnant.'' To express displeasure with the level of support, the Senate on Monday adopted a resolution threatening a deterioration in U.S. relations with any nation that doesn't contribute enough. In Tokyo today, a Japanese official said Japan was considering giving $2 billion to the three nations hardest hit by the economic sanctions against Iraq. That would be on top of $1 billion the country has already pledged to support the military effort against Iraq. Hiroyasu Horio, an official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said the $2 billion would go to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. News reports in Tokyo said the money would be extended through the World Bank and International Monetary Fund with the first $600 million being sent as early as mid-September. The Senate resolution, attached to a spending bill for the Postal Service and other agencies, directed the president to present Congress a detailed report on the administration's cost-sharing efforts by Nov. 30. ``During his consultations with other international leaders,'' Bush ``should consider stressing ... that failure by any country to actively contribute in the most appropriate manner for that country could have a detrimental impact on its bilateral relationship with the United States,'' the resolution said. The approval of the measure, the first such congressional action since Bush ordered U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia, reflected lawmakers' reaction to complaints by voters that the United States is shouldering too much of the burden. The United States ``cannot play Uncle Sugar to the world,'' said Sen. Dennis Deconcini, D-Ariz., one of the primary sponsors. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., called Japan's $1 billion pledge only a ``few token shillings.'' He contended that a more adequate response, given Japan's economic standing, would be an $8 billion pledge. ``The contemptible tokenism of the actions of the Japanese government to date merit nothing but the world's contempt and American hostility,'' McCain said. ``If combat arises, it will not be Japanese boys whose lives are at risk, it will be American boys.'' Japan, which ran up a $49 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, was singled out for the bulk of the criticism. But senators said they also were unhappy with the response so far by West Germany, which has agreed to supply air and sea transport but turned down a U.S. request for more help in defraying the costs of keeping troops in the Persian Gulf. West Germany and Japan both contend that their post-World War II constitutions bar them from sending troops to the Persian Gulf. The United States is seeking approximately $28 billion through the end of 1991 for the gulf campaign. Of that amount, $10 billion would go to supply aid to Egypt, Turkey and Jordan and the remainder would pay for the U.S. military buildup. While Brady had little luck getting much more than words of encouragement from France, Britain, South Korea and Japan last week, Secretary of State James A. Baker III reported more success on a similar fund-raising mission to oil-rich Middle Eastern nations. Baker said Monday that Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the exiled government of Kuwait had pledged $12 billion, split between the military effort and the economic assistance package. But some critics charged that consumers from America and other countries were in reality footing the bill through higher energy prices. Edwin Rothschild, head of the consumer group Citizen Action, said the Saudis stood to make an extra $3.2 billion monthly from the crisis based on a $10-a-barrel rise in oil costs since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a 2 million-barrel per day increase in Saudi production. Their share of the U.S. military costs was reportedly only $500 million a month. The administration has been stressing the need for a united front against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, something analysts say is not helped by the lukewarm reception by some allied countries.

DOC.HEAD: Hormel Acquires Specialty Foods Firm
DOC.TEXT: Geo. A. Hormel & Co. said Tuesday it has purchased the name, inventory and certain other assets of Gourmet America Inc. Terms of the agreement and the sale price were not disclosed by Hormel, a meat and food processing company. Gourmet America is a Massachusetts-based specialty foods importing company that operated as a wholly owned subsidiary of Wilson Foods Corp. and its parent, Doskocil Companies Inc. ``Our acquisition of this growing firm moves Hormel into this specialty food market and provides significant other opportunities for us to integrate this into our own retail and foodservice distribution system as well as business gift and sales incentive programs developed through our mail order catalog business,'' said R.L. Knowlton, Hormel chairman and CEO. Under Hormel, the Gourmet America organization ``remains unchanged,'' Knowlton said, adding that C. Ronald Johnson continues as president and its headquarters will remain in Hingham, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Extend Loan for Mexican Electric Power Project
DOC.TEXT: The Export-Import Bank of Japan said Tuesday it has signed an agreement to extend an loan totaling $369.9 million to finance construction of an electric power plant in Mexico. The bank said the agreement was signed Monday in Tokyo. It said the loan will be used to finance the construction of a steam-powered electric power plant with a total generating capacity of 700 megawatts. The plant will be completed by January 1994 at an estimated cost of $500 million, the statement said. It said it was the Ex-Im Bank's first credit to Mexico since a new debt strategy plan for the Central American nation took effect in March.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Reports Efforts to Defy Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 5-8 to UPDATE with Romanian denial; picks up 5th graf pvs, The compilation... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cuba and Romania have struck oil deals with Iraq and companies elsewhere are trying to continue trade with Baghdad, all in defiance of United Nations sanctions, a State Department survey finds. Some Eastern European countries also are trying to maintain their military sales to Iraq, said the report, made available to The Associated Press. It said Cuba, facing a substantial oil deficit because of reduced Soviet deliveries, has received a shipment of Iraqi petroleum since U.N. sanctions were imposed five weeks ago. The report added that Romania expects to receive oil indirectly from Iraq. ``I'm authorized to deny most categorically this allegation, which is absolutely false and without foundation,'' Virgil Constantinescu, the Romanian ambassador to the United States, said today. ``Romania has adhered strictly to the U.N. resolution imposing sanctions against Iraq and is determined to carry out this policy despite the hardships it faces as a consequence of the embargo and the blockade.'' Constantinescu said Iraq had offered to ship about 1 million metric tons of oil worth $120 million since Aug. 2, and the Romanian government had rejected it. The compilation of efforts to circumvent the embargo was made available as concern increased that the sanctions might jeopardize the well being of innocent Iraqis. Shortages of goods are said to be increasingly widespread. At their Helsinki summit, President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed it was appropriate to allow food shipments to Iraq and occupied Kuwait ``in appropriate circumstances.'' But they said any such shipments should be subject to careful monitoring by appropriate agencies. Bush is banking on the sanctions to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. The updated State Department study and previous reports strongly suggest that the willingness to comply with the sanctions is less than unanimous. Before the summit, China and Iran indicated a desire to send food and medicine to Iraq and several other countries said they wanted to send humanitarian shipments to their citizens stranded in Iraq. The State Department report indicated that two unidentified Western European companies have been attempting to ship food clandestinely to Iraq. Syrian farmers are trying to take advantage of the country's long border with Iraq for the same purpose, it said. The report added that private entrepreneurs in East Asia and Africa also were pursuing trade with Iraq. Because of the growing political acceptability of selling to Iraq goods needed for survival, these transactions are regarded as somewhat less serious than others mentioned in the report. The document said some unnamed East European countries are attempting to continue military trade with Iraq and that several Western European countries are bidding for a share of the Iraqi market for manufactured goods. Cuba has had friendly ties with Iraq for some time but had nonetheless refrained from supporting Saddam in the U.N. Security Council, where it holds one of 10 rotating seats. Cuba has either supported the council majority or abstained on votes applicable to Iraq. ``Cuba has taken delivery of Iraqi oil,'' the State Department report said. Just two weeks ago, Cuba announced drastic energy conservations measures to compensate for a 2-million-ton shortfall in deliveries from the Soviet Union. Romania's interest in buying Iraqi oil could be related to that country's concern over the fate of its citizens in Iraq. It has indicated a desire to send food and medicine to Romanians trapped in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell Tuesday on the London Stock Exchange. Traders said the market was dull, and stifled by uncertainty over the Middle East and the U.S. economy. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 2.7 points, or 0.12 percent, at 2,144.3. The day's high was 2,151.6, and the low was 2,137.5. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 4.1 points to 1,651.0. The Financial Times 500-share index dropped 1.47 points to 1,149.80. Volume was 338.8 million shares, up from 296.4 million shares on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Vancouver Stock Exchange Falls on Worries
DOC.TEXT: The Vancouver Stock Exchange slumped to a record low Monday following word that a critical report on the exchange was being prepared by the ABC Television Network. The exchange's index, tied heavily to mining and other resource development stocks, plunged 12.20 points to 674.20, surpassing the previous record low of 685.85 on Aug. 23. The Vancouver market has been generally soft in recent weeks, but many analysts blamed the latest decline on nervousness over a report believed to be set for broadcast on ``PrimeTime Live,'' which has a weekly audience of 10 million to 13 million viewers. Exchange officials said last week that ``PrimeTime'' staff, posing as members of a New York investment club, used a hidden camera to film three promoters making what were said to be false claims and leaking insider information. A promoter is someone who hypes a stock to investors. ``The ABC thing has got everyone upset,'' said promoter Murray Pezim, who was interviewed with his consent by ``PrimeTime'' chief correspondent Chris Wallace. ``I could tell right away they were trying to take shots,'' Pezim said. Severe repercussions followed critical reports on the exchange last year in Forbes and Barrons. ``The Forbes article came out of the blue, but there's some anticipation with respect to this report,'' said Max Meier, president of Pacific International Securities Inc. ``I would think the damage is being done now rather than later.'' John Wheeler, a director of McDermid St. Lawrence Ltd., played down the impact of the prospective ABC program. ``This market is down for lots of good reasons,'' he said. ``Precious metals have been beaten up badly, it's the end of the drilling season in the north, and recent results in Eskay Creek (a major gold source in northwestern British Columbia) have been disappointing. ``But probably more than anything we are in a global bear market, and junior stocks all over the world have been beaten up,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Proulx Named CEO at Lear Siegler Seymour
DOC.TEXT: Norman R. Proulx has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Lear Siegler Seymour Corp., the maker of ironing boards said Tuesday. Proulx, 43, resigned recently as president and CEO of Wilkinson Sword, Inc., North America. He succeeds John P. Deters, who resigned. During his five years at Wilkinson, Proulx developed the Ultra Glide shaving system for its shaving products division. He also expanded the self-sharpening cutlery business and engineered the formation of Wilkinson's lighter division with the acquisition of the Cricket disposable lighter line in 1988. He worked for the Gillette Co. for nine years, leaving in 1978. He also spent six years at Scripto, where he was senior vice president and general manager. Lear Siegler, based in Seymour, has about 85 percent of the ironing board market in the United States and Canada. It had about $100 million in sales last year.

DOC.HEAD: Two Commodity Fraud Trials Under Way in Chicago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with opening statement in yen traders' trial and jury selection in soybean traders' trial; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen traders engaged in ``systematic cheating of customers'' in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Japanese yen pit, a prosecutor said today, as two more commodities fraud trials got under way. ``You will be hearing about whispered conversation after whispered conversation,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Lisa Huestes told jurors in opening statements. ``This case is about systematic cheating of customers in the Japanese yen pit,'' she said in the courtroom of U.S. District Judge William T. Hart, in a trial stemming from an FBI sting investigation at the world's two largest futures exchanges. Meanwhile, jury selection was completed this morning in the other trial _ being held in the courtroom of Judge George Marovich _ for soybean traders from the Chicago Board of Trade. Huestes said the government would attempt to show systematic collusion between brokers and yen traders at the Merc to defraud the broker's customers. She said the motivation was ``plain and simple greed.'' Huestes spent most of the first hour of her opening statement explaining what the commodities pits are and what futures contracts represent. In both cases, the defendants are accused of cheating customers while executing their orders on the exchanges' trading floors. The charges stem from an unprecedented undercover investigation in which FBI agents posed as corrupt traders. They secretly tape-recorded conversations among traders at the two commodity exchanges. A federal grand jury indicted 48 people in connection with the probe. Twenty have pleaded guilty and one pleaded no contest. In the first trial to result from the investigation, a U.S. District Court jury in July convicted two Swiss franc traders of relatively minor trading violations and acquitted a third. The jury could not reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one of the three defendants. The men are scheduled to be tried again on those charges early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Key Provisions of The Shatalin Plan
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Key provisions of the economic plan drawn up by economis Stanislav Shatalin and approved Tuesday by the Russian republic's parliament:

POWERS OF THE REPUBLICS: Shatalin's plan, which amounts to a new political structure of the Soviet Union, calls for creation of a voluntary economic union of the 15 republics of the Soviet Union. According to an early draft obtained by The Associated Press, each republic: _ would be sovereign, and have many of its laws would supercede those of the national government. The draft did not state whether this referred to all issues or only economic ones. _ would be given broad economic authority that could enable it to move rapidly to free prices, privatize government industries, legalize private ownership of land and take other steps toward a market-based economy. _ would control its own finances. _ would own its natural resources. _ would be entitled to a share of the national gold and hard currency reserves. _ would control its own decisions on trade with other republics, with prices and volume of trade set in contracts.

POWERS OF THE CENTRAL GOVERNMENT: The national government would retain control of: _ defense. _ economic forecasting. _ the money supply. _ national scientific research. _ the space program. _ nuclear energy program. _ the railroads. _ communications. _ those prices the republics allow it to regulate.
TAXES: The national government would have no power to tax citizens and companies. Instead, the republics would pay dues based on their share of national income.

Stock prices slipped today as the market remained concerned about higher oil prices, the Iraqi standoff and interest rates, analysts said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down 8.91 points to 2,606.68 as of 2 p.m. EDT. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 529 up, 828 down and 534 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to a light 80.19 million shares. The market continued to show concern about higher oil prices, analysts said. On Monday, the Dow closed 3.96 points lower after oil prices spurted upward. The October contract for crude closed at $31.30 a barrel Monday, up $1.26, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The price was up a further 22 cents today after reversing direction from an early decline. Investors also remain wary about interest rates, analysts say. Rumors over the past few days have said the Federal Reserve was about to ease rates, but the central bank failed to act. The market received no help from abroad. Stock prices closed lower in Japan and London. Among most-active blue chip issues on the NYSE, AT&T was up { at 30~, Philip Morris rose [ to 45 and IBM rose ] to 106\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.50 to 176.20. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.33 to 322.88.

DOC.HEAD: Ad-Killing Video Recorder Earning Mixed Reviews
DOC.TEXT: A major Japanese company has begun marketing something consumers have long awaited _ a videocassette recorder that automatically cuts out commercials. Even the maker's own. And while sales have been good, the product has raised the ire of television networks, which argue that the possibility of fewer people viewing commercials may prompt advertisers to pay less for air time. Advertisements for the VCRs, which are made by Mitsubishi Electric Corp. and are priced from $600 to $1,200,boast that ``with this convenient function, you can automatically cut commercials ... and enjoy the programs you want to watch without the ads.'' The technology is aimed mainly at producing uninterrupted recordings of Western movies, which are often broadcast on two audio channels _ a main channel for the Japanese-language soundtrack and a sub-channel for the original language. The bilingual programming was introduced on major network schedules in 1978, after being developed by the Japan Broadcasting Corp. about a decade earlier. Special signals during these broadcasts, which are usually reserved for movies, news and foreign-made programs, serve as a ``cue'' for the new machines, telling them when to start and stop recording. Such programs, however, account for only a fraction of the total broadcasting fare, rendering Mitsubishi's ``auto-cut'' capability useless for much of the day's programming. Even so, the idea has made television networks nervous. Two months after Mitsubishi's videocassette recorder hit the market in April, Japan's largest privately owned network, the Tokyo Broadcasting System, began mixing electronic static with its signal to foil the ``auto-cut.'' ``If viewers want to edit out commercials themselves, they are free to do so,'' said TBS spokesman Akitsuna Furuya. ``But we believe that, if taping is to be done, it should accurately reflect what we broadcast.'' Furuya added that the technology doesn't just edit out commercials. ``It also cuts out the movie reviews that come at the beginning and end of the broadcast.'' The National Association of Commercial Broadcasters, a federation of Japan's commercial stations, also expressed reservations. ``Commercial television is based on advertising, so we obviously are against the idea of cutting out ads,'' said an official with the association, who requested anonymity. ``They don't have much of a share in the market yet, so we haven't really been forced to take any position either way. But if other companies started making similar machines, we would probably have to protest,'' the official said. Mitsubishi spokesman Masahiro Suekuni said that when developing ``auto-cut,'' Mitsubishi was also aware that it, too, could be the victim of ad-editing. ``But we decided that was something which couldn't be avoided.'' He added that Mitsubishi doesn't expect ``auto-cut'' to have much effect on broadcasters. ``Most people will continue to watch TV as it is broadcast,'' he said. The Japan Video Association says nearly 70 percent of all Japanese homes have a VCR, one of the highest ratios in the world. While not giving exact figures, Suekuni said Mitsubishi has a double-digit share, but still lags behind other home electronics giants like Matsushita, which makes Panasonic and National brand products. Because of the high percentage of homes that already have VCRs, producers are finding it increasingly difficult to keep sales up and have had to seek out new options, such as ``auto-cut,'' or lower prices. ``It's a slow market in general,'' Suekuni said. ``But sales of videos with the `auto-cut' function have been better than average for a new product.''

DOC.HEAD: Company to Appeal Ruling in IBM Copyright Suit
DOC.TEXT: A computer services company said Tuesday it would appeal a judge's ruling that it violated an IBM copyright for a key component needed to run IBM's largest computers. U.S. District Judge Thomas N. O'Neill Jr. in Philadelphia ruled Friday that Allen-Myland Inc. violated IBM's copyright for the ``microcode'' needed to operate its 3090 series mainframes. O'Neill is scheduled to determine damages at a later date. Allen-Myland, based in Broomall, Pa., reconfigures International Business Machines Corp. computers for customers, such as splitting large computers into smaller versions. O'Neill found that the company, in dividing a computer, copied IBM's microcode for one of the two computers that resulted. Microcode is the circuitry in a computer's central processor that translates programming commands into language recognized by the processor. Under a contract with IBM, Allen-Myland was required to obtain the second set of code from IBM, said IBM spokesman Brian Doyle. The judge also found that Allen-Myland misrepresented to customers that this second set of code came from IBM, Doyle said. Allen-Myland's president, Larry Allen, said his company contends that microcode ``is part and parcel of the machine and that customers should be allowed to alter that.'' He said the copied code was used solely in computers owned by the same customer from which the copy was made, and that Allen-Myland did not sell the copied code to other customers. In a blow to IBM, O'Neill also ruled that IBM's pricing of the microcode violates a 34-year-old consent decree IBM entered into with the Justice Department relating to competition. Doyle said IBM would appeal that ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chief of Dalkon Shield Maker Blames Timing
DOC.TEXT: A.H. Robins Co. was ``in the wrong place at the wrong time'' in manufacturing the Dalkon Shield, the former head of the company said Tuesday. But E. Claiborne Robins Jr., who was president of the company until it was acquired by American Home Products Corp. in December, stopped short of admitting a mistake in putting the intrauterine device on the market in 1971. It was withdrawn from sales in 1974 after questions arose about its safety. Robins spoke to a breakfast meeting of the Friends of the Industry of Agriculture in Virginia. It was the first time he has spoken publicly about the Dalkon Shield since A.H. Robins filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in August 1985 as claims mounted against the IUD. At the time of the filing, Robins said, the company was spending $15 million a month on Dalkon Shield-related legal fees and the corporate treasury had fallen to $9 million, not enough to meet the monthly payroll. Robins referred to the Dalkon Shield as an ``unfortunate incident'' in an otherwise successful history for the firm, which was founded in Richmond by his grandfather in 1866. Robins called the business ``the most successful bankrupt company in the world'' that grew to annual sales of almost $1 billion when it was taken over as part of a court-approved reorganization. A.H. Robins introduced Robitussin cough syrup to the market in 1949, Dimetapp cold medicine in 1961 and acquired Chapstick lip balm in 1963, Robins said. He said the company never had a layoff, and he praised its employees for sticking by during the bankruptcy proceedings. The company's reorganization, which received final court approval late last year, included the creation of a $2.5 billion fund to pay almost 200,000 Dalkon Shield claims. Claims are still being processed by a trust organization that is independent of A.H. Robins and its new parent. Since leaving the company, Robins has gotten involved in the wine business and has applied for a state wholesale wine and wine importer license. He described the new venture as an effort to turn ``a hobby into a business.''

DOC.HEAD: NECO President Resigns; David LaRoche Renamed To Post
DOC.TEXT: David LaRoche reassumed his role as head of NECO Enterprises Inc. on Tuesday, only 2{ weeks after stepping down from the real estate holding company. LaRoche gave up the position on Sept. 23 to Paul E. Buff, who was appointed president and chief operating officer. At the time, Buff said the change was made because ``LaRoche did not have sufficient time to handle day-to-day operations.'' That was much the same reason Buff gave Tuesday when he announced he would step down to become vice president. He said his role as president of Quechee Lakes Corp. in Hartford, Vt., a NECO subsidiary, gave him insufficient time to spend with NECO. ``It was probably a little premature the board electing me president,'' he said. ``I just don't have the time to spend with NECO.'' LaRoche was out of the office Tuesday and did not return phone calls. He is the company's majority stockholder, as well as chairman and chief executive officer. Buff said the board discussed LaRoche's time constraints, but felt ``he had the expertise and understood the company well enough to do it.'' Richard J. Hayes, NECO's departing treasurer and chief financial officer, said the geographical distance between Vermont and Rhode Island had made the job difficult for Buff. Hayes' resignation was announced Sept. 23. He said he would stay until a replacement was found.

DOC.HEAD: Collins to Dump Kentucky Fried Chicken Restaurants in Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Collins Food International is getting out of the domestic chicken business and trying to gain a greater stake in its Sizzler restaurant chain. The Los Angeles-based Collins said Tuesday it had agreed to swap its 209 U.S. Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants with PepsiCo Inc. for PepsiCo stock worth about $122 million. PepsiCo is the parent company of Kentucky Fried Chicken Corp. Pepsico has been trying to turn the franchise around, in part by renegotiating contracts with franchisees. Collins was the second largest franchisee in the United States. The swap is part of a restructuring by Collins, a restaurant operating company that also controls the Sizzler steak, seafood and salad bar restaurant chain. The emerging company will own and operate 64 Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants in Queensland, Australia, and will operate or subfranchise a total of 32 Sizzler restaurants in Australia. Sizzler owns and operates or franchises a total of 664 Sizzler Buffet Court and Grill restaurants. Collins said it would trade 1.25 shares of stock in a newly organized, wholly owned subsidiary called New Collins for each of the shares in the 34 percent of Sizzler Restaurants International stock it does not already own. Collins' chief executive, Richard P. Bermingham, said the restructuring would simplify Collins' corporate structure and give Sizzler stockholders a chance at a tax-free swap for a stock with increased market liquidity. He said the PepsiCo deal would provide tax-free benefits to shareholders. Shareholders and regulators must approve the PepsiCo deal. Closing of the Sizzler exchange is conditional on completion of the PepsiCo transaction, receipt of enough shares to increase the ownership of Sizzler to 80 percent, and approval by regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Grim Prospects for Cocoa Producers into Next Century
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa producing countries were advised Tuesday to reduce drastically their areas under cultivation because of grim prospects if output continues growing as it has in recent years. Increasing oversupply and persistently low prices are indicated for cocoa under three of four projected scenarios in a study by the International Cocoa Organization and the Geneva-based United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. The market already has a heavy surplus, following six seasons of overproduction. World stocks are at a record 1.37 million tons, according to estimates released last month by the London-based cocoa organization. In February, the price of cocoa dropped to its lowest in 14 years. Experts are projecting another world surplus in the 1990-91 season, which begins Oct. 1. Under the baseline scenario projected by the study, world cocoa production will peak at 3.1 million tons in 2001-2002, compared with estimated output of 2.361 million tons in 1990-91. The biggest increases are foreseen in Southeast Asia (up 62 percent) and Africa (up 32 percent), particularly in the Ivory Coast, the world's biggest producer. Growth in Latin America is projected at only 10 percent because output is expected to fall in Brazil. Demand should also grow through the period, the study says, but not to a projected peak of 3.1 million tons until 2005. Use in 1989-90 is estimated at 2.211 million tons.

Stock prices slipped today as the market remained concerned about oil prices, the Iraqi standoff and interest rates, analysts said. With five minutes of trading remaining, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down 0.49 point to 2,615.10.

Stock prices slipped today as the market remained concerned about oil prices, the Iraqi standoff and interest rates, analysts said. Oil prices seesawed today, with the October contract for crude down 30 cents a barrel at $31 at about 4 p.m. EDT on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Earlier the price was higher. Investors also remain wary about interest rates, analysts say. Rumors over the past few days have said the Federal Reserve would ease rates, but the central bank didn't take any action. An additional uncertainty in the market was the fate of budget negotiations in Washington, said William R. Rothe, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. Rothe said there are ``too many issues that remain unresolved'' for investors to commit money to stocks. The market received no help from abroad, with stock prices closing lower in Japan and London.
