DOC.HEAD: Discounter May Unveil New Symbol
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp.'s multibillion-dollar, 5-year plan to update its discount stores makes this a smart time to say ``attention shoppers'' with a new logo as well, retail consultants say. The company scheduled a news conference Wednesday at its Oak Park outlet, prototype for its newer, brighter stores, where a new sign was wrapped in a white tarpaulin marked with the old K mart symbol. Company officials would not confirm a new logo was in the works, saying only that a major announcement was planned. But the Detroit Free Press reported Monday that the store's red K and turquoise m-a-r-t were taken down last week. The Detroit News ran a picture Tuesday of new shopping carts found out back bearing a changed logo. The new gray carts were marked with a big red K. Instead of following the K in turquoise letters, the word mart is inside the K in script. K mart announced plans earlier this year to remodel its stores along the lines of the Oak Park store with its brighter lights and wider aisles. ``You can change the inside of the store. But if you can't get the customer in it, it doesn't mean anything,'' said Linda Morris, retail analyst for PNC Financial Corp. in Pittsburgh, Pa. Morris said a new logo ``might say to the consumer, `Come in and see us, we're different.''' With growing competition from discounters like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Dayton-Hudson Corp.'s Target chain, ``They obviously have to do everything they can to compete.'' said Otto Grote, analyst for Derby Securities in New York. ``They're under a lot of scrutiny to bring the company forward,'' Bloomfield Hills retail consultant Frederick Marx said. Anthony Camilletti of the Berkley store design company Jon Greenberg & Associates helped design the Oak Park store that opened last year. He said designers talked with K mart officials at that time about a storefront design that would integrate a new logo. K mart may have taken its time making a change because updating a symbol as familiar as the red K can be risky, Camilletti said. ``You don't want to alienate that instant recognition.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Unveils New First-Class Strategy
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines unveiled Tuesday its latest strategy to try to lure more business travelers, but the carrier's survival was still in doubt at the end of court-appointed trustee Martin Shugrue's ``100 Days'' campaign. Wednesday marks the end of the campaign, marketed through perhaps the biggest media blitz in Eastern's history, in which Shugrue vowed to improve the airline every day and get it headed in the right direction. ``Congratulations. We're still here,'' he told some 1,000 employees packed into a steamy hangar at Miami International Airport. ``We intend to be here for a good long while.'' He also unveiled the company's new strategy for the business traveler. Under it, Eastern is nearly doubling the size of its first-class cabins, while offering a new ``corporate rate'' for first-class travel that it says is 15 to 35 percent below full-fare coach rates of its major competitors. On its B-757 planes, for example, Eastern will have as of Oct. 1 28 first-class seats, compared to 16. An Atlanta-Chicago ``corporate rate'' will be $313, available for $247 if purchased three days in advance. The industry-average full-coach rate is $379, Eastern said, and the average first-class rate is $565. Neil Monroe, Delta Airlines spokesman, said the Atlanta-based competitor doesn't anticipate trying to match the Eastern fares. Shugrue said the airline was filling more seats, from 54 percent in May to nearly 73 percent in August, but the carrier needs more high-paying, frequent-flying business travelers. Its summer passenger growth was spurred by sharply discounted fares geared toward vacationing families. During questioning from mostly enthusiastic employees, and then mostly skeptical journalists, Shugrue insisted his goal had been accomplished. Eastern's passenger load and on-time performance are up, and customer complaints are down, he said. He did acknowledge that Eastern still must climb from ``a large, deep hole.'' ``Airlines don't get in trouble in 100 days and they don't get out of trouble in 100 days,'' Shugrue said. ``We're not there yet. We still have a very long way to go.'' Shugrue had little specific progress to report on two goals _ financial viability and labor peace _ he set in April when a federal bankruptcy judge put him in charge of the troubled carrier, moving aside controversial Chairman Frank Lorenzo. In the second quarter, Eastern posted an operating loss of $234.4 million, and a net loss of $129.3 million after sales of assets. Shugrue said the airline's yield was better than expected for August, but he declined to give figures. ``We made progress,'' he said. ``Yeah, we lost a little bit of money.'' He agreed Eastern's creditors ``are a little nervous'' about the airline's financial prospects. He said Eastern's spending on marketing, as well as an estimated $8 million to reconfigure its first-class cabins, is an investment in the company's future. He was appointed to operate Eastern, not liquidate it, he said. Meanwhile, relations with Eastern's unions have deteriorated. The Machinists union, whose March 4, 1989, strike spurred Eastern to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, remains on strike, and pilots and flight attendants unions are unhappy that few of their members have gotten their jobs back in the 10 months since they ended sympathy walkouts. ``It takes two to tango,'' said Shugrue, who said he wanted to negotiate but refused to give in to unrealistic financial demands or to bargain away the jobs of 18,000 Eastern workers who have crossed picket lines. ``Look around, this is labor peace,'' Shugrue said, drawing applause from employees. Frank Ortis, president of the Machinists Miami local, said Shugrue hadn't live up to his promises. ``He in fact went just the opposite way,'' Ortis said. ``He's continued on Lorenzo's path.'' Shugrue's meeting with employees was filmed for future commercials, as was a similar meeting that provided the basis for the ``100 Days'' blitz. Ortis was critical of the media effort and plans to put leather seats, airphones, new carpeting and other improvements in the first-class section. ``They have had a lot of glitz, Madison Avenue, and the business traveler is still not coming back. They're still losing between $1 million and $3 million every day,'' said Ortis, who pinned the company's hopes on a merger or takeover by another airline. Shugrue said there have been contacts with other airlines, but he said there was no major activity to report, and his focus is on making Eastern viable independently. He said the improvements in first-class travel wasn't a gimmick, but a ``fundamental change'' in marketing strategy after earlier discounted first-class fares.

DOC.HEAD: From Genius to `Vicious Criminal': Writers Tell It to the Judge
DOC.TEXT: The guy who rents Michael Milken a car in Washington wants a federal judge to know that the financial felon cares about the little guy. And he always rides a sedan _ never a limo _ and pays his bills on time. CBS Inc. chief executive Laurence Tisch considers Milken ``a person of high integrity'' whose criminal offenses belie his character. Ordinary citizen J.B. Spence of Miami disagrees. He says Milken is a ``vicious criminal and thief.'' Friends, colleagues and strangers have barraged U.S. District Judge Kimba A. Wood with about 300 letters appraising the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive and offering ideas for his sentence. The six-inch thick file is replete with testimonials that portray Milken in a way few news reports of his illegal conduct have: caring family man, devoted philanthropist, humble achiever and driven but honest professional. ``He is not a man given to pomp or materialsm,'' wrote Samantha Grier, a social worker who said Milken visited her ailing father in the hospital. ``He is a man who uses a Bic pen as he works toward creating his vision of a better world.'' A handful of letters, all from people who don't know Milken personally, are less flattering. One man was upset because Milken was seen on television smiling as he entered federal court in April to enter his guilty plea. ``I think he should languish in prison for at least 10 years,'' wrote Claude Daughtry, 72, of Berkeley, Calif. ``It will give him plenty of time to rethink his scruples.'' Milken faces up to 28 years in prison when he appears before Judge Wood on Oct. 1. He pleaded guilty to six felonies involving violations of tax and securities laws after a dogged four-year government investigation. Those writing favorable letters urged leniency for Milken, recommending some form of community service rather than prison time. Most judges in recent Wall Street fraud cases have ordered time as a deterrent to future crimes. Presentencing letters often are written at defense lawyers' urging and the role the letters play in sentencing is up to the judge. But they can be considered a measure of support; in comparison to Milken's 300 letters, inside trader Ivan Boesky was the subject of just 21 presentencing letters. The roster of letter-writers urging leniency for Milken includes Time Warner Inc. Chairman Steven J. Ross; Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp.; former ``Let's Make a Deal'' host and Milken friend Monty Hall; ex-football players Rosey Grier and Fran Tarkenton; the chief of the Los Angeles police department; takeover lawyers and Milken's old competitors; and educators from a Harlem high school to the University of California at Berkeley's business school, who praised Milken's wide educational activities. Some sought to distance Milken from other felons such as Boesky, who swapped suitcases of cash for information and is widely regarded as a pariah on Wall Street. Tisch said Milken's success is ``based on the merit and power of his ideas, not improper dealings.'' A former Drexel associate, Paul S. Levy, said Milken is not someone who ``wantonly and blatantly flouted the law.'' ``Good people make mistakes,'' he wrote. ``There were no offshore accounts, bags of cash, calls from phone booths or clearly identifiable, aggrieved victims. Michael is not a Pied Piper of greed and lawlessness.'' Wall Street lawyer Joseph H. Flom said that while he didn't condone the acts to which Milken pleaded guilty, ``I can only assume that they were the result of his preoccupation with his clients' interests.'' Hammer proclaimed that Milken through his junk bond revolution that helped raise billions for corporations including Occidental ``led the charge which helped to assure that American democracy could thrive.'' Others are more personal. Friends and former secretaries recall Milken delivering flowers after a family crisis, attending company picnics, buying candy for their children at the movies and tutoring disadvantaged children on Saturday mornings at ``Mike's Math Club.'' The car dealer, Douglas Grimes, said Milken was his only client who immediately called his California home, listened happily to a tape of Grimes' original music and ``would always make a point to ask how the business was going.'' One writer said part of Milken's penalties should be used to build an ``industrial exhibition village.'' Another said Milken should be sentenced to help the Soviet Union, Hungary or Poland reshape their economies, while living there. Others said Milken should develop programs to finance low-income housing or feed the hungry. Alfred Avins, an administrator at Northern Virginia Law School, asked the judge to sentence Milken to law school _ at his institution, on weekends, for four years. ``I believe that this will do more to rehabilitate Mr. Milken than any form of incarceration,'' Avins wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher; Gold Recovers in U.S. But Off Abroad
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose Tuesday but the Japanese yen continued to take center stage on world foreign exchange markets. Gold prices posted minor gains after taking a steep tumble overseas. Trading was choppy and thin in New York. Curreny dealers reported the dollar initially surged, following the lead of Asian and European markets, before settling back to end moderately higher against most of its major foreign counterparts except the Canadian dollar. Ian Foakes, foreign exchange manager at PaineWebber International Inc. in New York, said a nervous mood prevailed in the market, which was marked by volatility and slack activity. European currency dealers, meanwhile, said the dollar got a lift from speculation that the cost of German unification will undermine the mark. The West German government said Monday it would pay 12 billion marks, or about $8 billion, to the Soviet Union to help repatriate the country's soldiers from East Germany, but overall cost estimates of unification run into the hundreds of billions of marks. The Japanese yen was the focus of activity on many foreign exchange markets where dealers sold yen to pocket profits made during the currency's recent advance. The yen, which suffered when tensions first flared in the Middle East, has since regained strenth. The Bank of Japan's decision to raise a key interest rate on Aug. 30 coupled with a recovery on the Tokyo Stock Exchange had renewed buying interest in the yen. The dollar moved higher against the yen in New York, ending the day at 140.305, up from 139.52 yen late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 139.85 yen, up 0.42 yen from Monday's finish. In London, the dollar was quoted at 139.20 yen late in the session. British sterling benefitted from the profit-taking in yen but still lost ground against the dollar. The pound finished at $1.8565 in New York, compared to $1.8580 late Monday. In late London activity, a pound was quoted at $1.8490 compared with $1.8565 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.5865 German marks, up from 1.5820; 1.3245 Swiss francs, up from 1.3175; 5.3125 French francs, up from 5.3005; 1,183.00 Italian lire, up from 1,180.00; and 1.16095 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16675. Late rates for the dollar in Europe compared with late levels on Monday were: 1.5905 German marks, up from 1.5808; 1.3290 Swiss francs, up from 1.3197; 5.3270 French francs, up from 5.2985; 1.7935 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7822; 1,186.00 Italian lire, up from 1,180.50, and 1.1627 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1703. Precious metals dealers said trading lacked direction. Many dealers are still feeling the sting from losses on gold purchased when the prospect of a Middle East war was stronger, traders said. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for September delivery rose $1.90 a troy ounce to settle at $380.50, after slumping $10.90 on Monday. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $380.25 an ounce, or 35 cents higher than Monday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold traded in London at a late price of $381.25 per troy ounce, down from $384.75 on Monday. In Zurich, gold was bid at $381.50 an ounce, down from $387.00 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $4.90 an ounce to $379.6. Silver prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange, silver for September delivery settled at $4.777 a troy ounce, up from $4.755 on Monday. In London, the late silver bid was $4.81 a troy ounce, up from $4.78 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Banking Industry Healthy, Executives Say
DOC.TEXT: Banking executives shrugged off a barrage of negative reports on their industry Tuesday, pronouncing the business sound but adding that it could be in better shape if Congress relaxes restrictions on the kinds of products the banks can sell. ``The commercial banking industry is healthy, strong enough to weather a tougher economic climate in the 1990s,'' said Michael P. Esposito, chief financial officer of Chase Manhattan Corp. at a news conference held by the American Bankers Association. Esposito noted that the banking industry had almost $26 billion in profits last year, while the savings and loan industry lost more than $19 billion. He also said the threat to the banks by potentially uncollectable loans to Third World nations had diminished now that the banks have added billions of dollars to their reserves for such loans. The bankers were on the defensive following a string of downbeat assessments of the industry. The latest was a report by the General Accounting Office issued Tuesday that said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which insures deposits at the nation's banks, could be wiped out by losses banks are suffering from declining real estate values and risky investments. The GAO, the auditing arm of Congress, said at least 35 of the nation's 200 largest banks are likely to fail or require assistance over the next year at a cost to the government of $4.4 billion to $6.3 billion. The FDIC already faces losses of $2 billion this year, in addition to losses of $5.1 billion in 1988 and 1989, the GAO said. ``A $13 billion fund balance could be eliminated by the costs related to one or more large money center banks with assets of $130 billion,'' said Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who directs the GAO. ``While I'm not saying that any money center banks are currently in danger of failing, this demonstrates the vulnerability of the fund.'' But Esposito said he doubted the FDIC would run into trouble, largely because the premiums banks pay into the fund have gone up. He conceded, ``There are going to be swings and cycles'' but said the ABA's economists have drawn up projections that show the fund will increase over time. Tuesday's GAO report came on the heels of an FDIC announcement Friday that nationwide, commercial banks' profits fell 24 percent during the second quarter. The performance of banks in the Midwest, South and West improved during the period, but loan problems increased in the Northeast and Southeast, the FDIC said. The bankers noted the industry has problem areas including the Northeast and they said U.S. banks are becoming less competitive with foreign banks. Their proposed solution to the latter problem is for Congress to allow banks to sell securities, mutual funds, insurance and other products that are now off-limits to the industry. The bankers used Tuesday's news conference to call once again for changes in the Glass-Steagall and Bank Holding Company acts that regulate the businesses that commercial banks may be involved in. ``The rules the banking industry has to live with place us at a disadvantage'' with foreign banks and non-banking lenders like General Motors Acceptance Corp., said Esposito. GMAC, which is owned by General Motors Corp., finances loans and mortgages for cars, trucks, homes and other properties.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Forecast for North Sea
DOC.TEXT: Workers in the British North Sea oil and gas industry said they planned to strike installations in one sector for 24 hours beginning Wednesday morning. Ronnie McDonald of the Offshore Industries Liaison Committee predicted 1,500 men would participate in the action starting at 7 a.m. Workers rejected any further job actions in a ballot conducted by Shell U.K. Ltd. in the Brent field, McDonald said. He said the strike would be limited to the southern sector gasfields. A total work stoppage throughout the British North Sea would affect 10,000 workers on 100 platforms. The strikers, who want recognition of unions and higher safety standards, brought work to a halt on a number of installations throughout August. They protested the alleged refusal of the employers in the Offshore Contractors' Council to organize a ballot on union recognition and the refusal to reinstate 1,500 workers who were fired for striking. A council spokesman said another strike would mean more firings. Safety has been a concern following a number of accidents in the British North Sea. The area suffered the world's worst oil platform disaster in July 1988 when an explosion and fire killed 167 men. A helicopter crash which killed six oil workers on July 25 was the latest in a string of aircraft accidents in the oilfields over the past four years.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Gains Mount with Supply Fears
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose strongly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending a rally rooted in the worsening condition of the new crop as harvest time approaches. Grain futures closed mostly higher, following the lead of the soybean and soybean meal markets. On other commodity markets, oil futures retreated; platinum futures dropped while other precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 5 cents to 7\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $6.25{ a bushel. Soybean meal futures surged $2 to $4 with September ending the session at $184.60 per ton. Wheat futures ended { cent lower to 1{ cents higher with September at $2.67\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents higher with September at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were 3 cents to 4\ cents higher with September at $1.11{ a bushel. Soybeans built on Monday's solid gains after the Agriculture Department released a weekly report showing deterioration of the U.S. soybean crop. The USDA said 52 percent of the crop was in good to excellent condition as of Sunday compared with 58 percent a week earlier. The USDA rated 76 percent of the corn crop good to excellent compared with 79 percent a week ago. Dry weather has stressed soybean plants in the Southeast and Mississippi Delta regions, although recent rains are believed to be easing those problems, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Nevertheless, ``the crop condition is worsening and it's September already,'' said Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the exchange. Zusel said traders' questions include whether the crop will come back and ``how much will it be able to come back.'' William Biedermann, research director with the Chicago-area futures brokerage Allendale Inc., said any yield losses would only worsen the supply prospects for the coming year. Experts already are projecting relatively tight supplies due to an expected decline in South American soybean production and strong world demand for soybean meal. Traders will get an update on harvest prospects after Wednesday's close, when the USDA is scheduled to release a monthly crop report. Analysts expect little change from the government's August soybean crop estimate of 1.84 billion bushels. But the government is expected to raise its corn crop projection to nearly 8 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 7.85 billion. Oil futures ended mostly lower in a volatile session on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting perceptions of easing tensions in the Persian Gulf area. In one sign of cooling hostilities, Iraq informed U.S. officials that Arab-born American males residing in Iraq and Kuwait would be allowed to return to the United States. The Iraqis previously had allowed no U.S. males to leave the two countries. In a bearish surprise after the close, a weekly American Petroleum Institute report showed a 2.1 million barrel increase in U.S. supplies of crude oil last week. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 30 cents to 89 cents lower with October at $31 a barrel; heating oil was 1.70 cents to 3.17 cents lower with October at 83.03 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.12 cents lower to .19 cent higher with October at 93.60 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures rallied modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange, reversing some of Monday's steep losses. But platinum futures continued to decline on the New York Merc, reflecting weakening industrial demand for the metal, said William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch Futures. Gold finished $1.70 to $2.40 higher with September at $380.50 a troy ounce; silver was 2 cents to 2.2 cents higher with September at $4.777 a troy ounce; platinum was $4.60 to $4.70 lower with October at $452.80 a troy ounce. Higher cash markets continued to lift livestock futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange but pork bellies ended mostly lower amid disappointment that the weekend meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev produced no offer of food export credits to the Soviets. Live cattle settled .10 cent to .40 cent higher with October at 78.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .45 cent higher with September at 87.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent to .55 cent higher with October at 50.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 52.72 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: House Supporters Launch Bid for Tougher Standards
DOC.TEXT: House proponents of legislation to require that new car fleets average 40 miles per gallon within a decade asked House Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Tuesday to promise a vote this fall. As the Senate prepared to begin debate on the bill, 13 House supporters made their request in an apparent effort to prevent the legislation from being trapped in the Energy and Commerce Committee. The panel's chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., is a staunch ally of the auto industry, which is fighting the bill. ``I know he's going to be opposed to it,'' Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., told reporters. ``It's no secret. We may have to fight it out on the floor. I only hope that we can get it to the floor.'' A spokesman for Dingell declined to comment. Foley aides did not immediately return a phone call. Boxer introduced a bill Monday identical to pending Senate legislation that would require automakers to boost fuel efficiency 20 percent by 1995 and 40 percent by 2001. The bill is expected to reach the Senate floor this week. But a spokeswoman for Majority Leader George Mitchell said the timetable was uncertain because of other pressing business. The auto industry stepped up its attack on the bill, saying it would cost up to 300,000 jobs and deprive consumers of such popular family vehicles as station wagons and minivans. ``If the bill were enacted into law, we'd have economic disaster on our hands,'' said Tom Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents the Big Three U.S. automakers. Representatives of foreign car manufacturers and U.S. auto dealers also criticized the bill at a news conference. The groups are sponsoring newspaper and radio advertisements in hopes of inspiring grassroots opposition. The United Auto Workers union was mailing 40,000 letters to Capitol Hill urging the bill's defeat. The Bush administration opposes it. Current law sets the minimum ``corporate average fuel economy'' or CAFE at 27.5 miles per gallon. The law requires that each new car fleet _ all the cars a company manufactures in a given year _ meet that standard. Under the legislation, the typical new car fleet would average 34.4 miles per gallon in 1995 and 40.2 mpg by 2001. Proponents have sought tougher standards for years without success. But they say momentum has swung their way since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait focused attention on the nation's reliance on Middle Eastern oil. In a letter to Foley, Boxer and 12 other House members said, ``It is critical that the House speak out strongly in support of efforts to promote efficiency and conservation.'' It said, ``We are seeking a commitment that the House have an opportunity to vote on the Bryan bill, or another auto efficiency bill, before the end of the session.'' The proposed CAFE standards could save 2.8 million gallons of oil per day, nearly one-third of the nation's daily consumption of imported oil, the letter said. It also contended there was ``no technological barrier to meeting these higher standards; indeed, automobile industry executives admit that a 50 mpg standard is feasible.'' Automakers insist the only way to meet the proposed standards is to reduce drastically the size of new cars. All available fuel-efficiency technology already is being utilized and efforts to improve are continuing, they said. Fuel costs determine energy efficiency, Hanna said. If the price is down, consumers want larger cars and manufacturers meet the demand. If the price rises, demand for smaller cars rises.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations Continue Against Midnight Friday Deadline
With AM-Auto Talks-Then&Now Bjt
DOC.TEXT: National contract talks between the United Auto Workers and General Motors Corp. continued Tuesday after a union executive told local leaders to prepare the troops for a strike. Negotiators were working against a midnight Friday deadline to reach a national contract covering about 300,000 active GM workers. UAW contracts with Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. also expire at the same time, but the union has chosen GM as its target for a strike. In all, more than 450,000 active auto workers are covered by UAW contracts with the Big Three automakers. The union's main bargaining goal is job security, and a union telephone recording said Tuesday that little progress had been made on that issue. ``The corporation must become more serious in their attitude,'' said UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich, in charge of the union's GM bargaining team. He told local union leaders they should be ready for a strike. ``I trust that you will do everything necessary to prepare the membership for a disciplined response to whatever action is required in the difficult days ahead,'' Yokich said. The last time the UAW struck GM over a national contract was in 1984, when the union staged a weeklong walkout at 12 assembly plants and the company's Technical Center in Warren, Mich. This year, members of UAW Local 659 at GM's AC Rochester West component plant in Flint staged a six-day strike that shut down seven assembly plants and parts of more than a dozen component factories. ``We haven't heard hardly anything,'' said UAW Local 662 Vice President Larry Howerton of Anderson, Ind. ``We're going to have to hear something pretty soon. We've got to be notified.'' There has been little news coming out of the talks this year. UAW and GM officials have been available to media only occasionally and when they have appeared, they rarely talked about contract details. They have preferred instead to say both sides were working hard and there still was time to reach an agreement before the deadline. So far, union officials have said tentative agreements have been reached on nearly all non-economic issues, such as military leave and jury duty provisions. But the economic issues, which include job security, are the tough ones. The UAW leadership has a strong strike authorization vote under its belt, clearing the way for it to call a strike against GM if an agreement cannot be reached.

DOC.HEAD: Things Different Now Than in 84
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The last time the United Auto Workers bargained a pattern national contract with General Motors Corp., tensions were high and a weeklong strike resulted. With three days left in this year's bargaining, the stress isn't as noticeable as it was in 1984, and some even feel the union's position has been strengthened since the last big strike. ``I feel that we are more on the offense than on the defense now,'' said Larry Howerton, vice president of Local 662 in Anderson, Ind. ``It seems like we were trying (in 1984) to hold everything we got and (now) we're trying to get what we want.'' But one basic fact underlies the process this time around, and it has the attention of both sides. That's the loss of market share to the Japanese. ``You're dealing with some very fundamental things here,'' auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Brothers said Tuesday. In past years, including 1984, negotiating arguments centered on a percent or two in wages or on how financial guarantees for laid-off workers would work. These days, the issues and especially their potential effects are much deeper and, according to Phillippi, it's mostly due to the growth of the U.S. manufacturing base by Japanese automakers. During the 1980s, the Big Three watched their collective share of the U.S. auto market drop 6 percentage points to about 68 percent, while the share of cars with Japanese nameplates increased about 6 points to 25.4 percent. ``It's become abundantly clear that we (U.S. automakers) are unable to pry people out of their Nissans, Hondas or Toyotas and get them to buy American products,'' Phillippi said. ``We've tried cash, Japan-bashing, you name it and it hasn't worked. ``Any right-thinking individual has got to be really, really concerned,'' he said. Because of that concern, Phillippi suggested, negotiators aren't talking outside bargaining meetings. ``The people are under wraps,'' UAW Local 160 President Pete Kelly, a member of the union's 1984 bargaining committee. ``There is nobody down there who is going to buck the hierarchy of the UAW.'' Auto labor observers have said this year's talks have been remarkably lacking in public details. Officially, union and company officials say that indicates both sides are hard at work, toiling against a midnight Friday deadline. UAW contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., covering more than 450,000 active workers, expire at the same time. Late last month, the union chose to focus its bargaining at GM. The union plans to use a contract ratified by GM workers as a pattern for agreements with Ford and Chrysler. It is expected to take about two weeks for UAW members to vote on any tentative agreement. In 1984, the union picked dual targets _ Ford and GM. With less than a week remaining in the bargaining, the UAW targeted GM. Then and now, the main issue was job security. But unlike this round of bargaining, tensions were much higher six years ago, perhaps because of lingering anger over a series of concession contracts the union signed a few years earlier with the Big Three. At the time, the automakers were in the financial dumps. As the final minutes ticked off of the bargaining clock in 1984, the UAW leadership couldn't hold its membership. Workers began walking off their jobs before the midnight deadline. By the time UAW President Owen Bieber announced a strike at 12 GM assembly plants and its Technical Center in Warren, Mich., employees already were walking picket lines. The following day, not enough workers showed up at their jobs at GM's Lordstown, Ohio, assembly plant, which was not officially struck, and that factory shut down. The strike lasted for seven days, and the union bragged that it had won major guarantees on job security and important wage and benefit gains. Three years later, the union said it built on the job security provisions of 1984. But since 1987, GM has closed four assembly plants, putting about 9,000 UAW members on layoff.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf pvs, `Several other ...,' to ADD Texas Instruments stock up sharply on report in Japanese newspaper.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell marginally in light, quiet trading Tuesday as the market remained concerned about oil prices, interest rates and federal budget negotations, analysts said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks slipped 2.97 to 2,612.62. In the broader market, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 609 up, 835 down and 513 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 113.22 million shares, down from 119.73 million Monday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 136.36 million shares. Oil prices seesawed below and above Monday's closing price, taking stock prices along for the ride. At one point when oil prices were higher, the Dow was down as much as 22 points. The October contract for crude eventually settled at $30.76 a barrel, down 54 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Stock investors also remained wary about interest rates, analysts say. Rumors over the past few days have said the Federal Reserve would ease rates, but the central bank didn't take any action. An additional uncertainty in the market was the fate of congressional budget negotiations in Washington, said William R. Rothe, a managing director at the brokerage Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. Rothe said there were ``too many issues that remain unresolved'' for investors to commit money to stocks. The market received no help from abroad, with stock prices closing lower in Japan and London. Tandem Computer was the most-active NYSE issue, falling 2[ to 11{ as 2.8 million shares changed hands. The company said its growth rate may not be as high as stock analysts predicted and that it was cutting costs to preserve profits. Several other technology stocks also were hurt. Compaq Computer fell 2 to 43\ and Motorola slipped 1] to 59~. Both also were on the NYSE most-active list. But another computer stock, Texas Instruments, climbed 3{ to 29[ on a Japanese newspaper report that the company is seeking $1.5 billion a year in additional royalty payments from Japanese companies for two microchip patents. Among most-active blue chip issues on the NYSE, AT&T was up } at 31[, Philip Morris rose [ to 45, IBM advanced 1| to 107{ and General Electric gained 1[ to 62\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $6.995 billion, or 0.23 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.31 to 176.39. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 0.34 to 380.23, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 0.59 to 321.04. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 2.24 to 379.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.20 to 323.01.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS date of bankruptcy filing to April 1985 in 10th graf, Wheeling-Pitt has.
DOC.HEAD: Steelworkers Approve Wheeling-Pitt Pact
DOC.TEXT: Members of the United Steelworkers union overwhelmingly approved a new contract with Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. on Tuesday, clearing a major hurdle in the company's attempt to reorganize. Jim Bowen, USW District 23 director, said 4,615 steelworkers voted in favor of the pact with 329 workers against it. A simple majority was needed to approve the pact, which expires in March 1994. ``This is the very climax of what I think will be a very important process for Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel and our union,'' Bowen said. ``I think these numbers reflect the confidence the workers have in their union.'' Leaders from all 13 Wheeling-Pitt locals urged their members to vote for the pact, which affects 5,500 union workers in West Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio. ``I learned a long time ago that if you ever get everything you asked for you didn't ask for enough to start with,'' said Bowen. ``We asked for plenty and I'll tell you I think we got our fair share of it.'' Ray Johnson, a Wheeling-Pitt spokesman, said company officials were surprised by the lopsided tally. ``We did expect a very good vote for it, but this was overwhelming,'' he said. Bowen said the vote opens the door for Wheeling-Pitt officials to file an amended reorganization plan with U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz in Pittsburgh. ``The lawyers and accountants ought to quit playing their games,'' said Bowen. ``They got their labor agreement. It's been confirmed. Now I say to the judge and all the rest of them, It's time to get this over with.'' Wheeling-Pitt has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since April 1985. Bentz still must review the labor agreement. Johnson said an amended reorganization plan will be voted on by creditors, shareholders and all Wheeling-Pitt employees. He said it will likely be another two months before an amended reorganization plan incorporating the new contract is confirmed by the bankruptcy court. The contract includes a wage increase of $1.50 per hour, which would restore wages sacrificed earlier, and a $3,000 signing bonus for each union worker. The company also agreed to give the steelworkers 2.2 million shares of stock worth $22 million and a cash payment of $38 million in return for wage concessions made in 1982 and 1985.

DOC.HEAD: AMEX's Jones See Fewer Stock Exchanges in the 90s
DOC.TEXT: The head of the American Stock Exchange said Tuesday that he expects the globalization of securities markets in the 1990s will lead to a shakeout among smaller exchanges in this country. ``I would be very suprised to see more than three significant marketplaces survive the 1990s,'' AMEX Chairman James R. Jones told the National Economists Club. Jones, a former Oklahoma congressman, also said he expected only one of those three survivors to trade solely through electronic methods. Currently, the AMEX and the larger New York Stock Exchange trade through the in-person auction system between buyers and sellers. The 14 smaller exchanges are linked to the larger New York exchanges to facilitate transactions. ``I think for most of the regional exchanges, they're going to have a very difficult time in the 1990s and I think at the very least, there will be joint ventures with the larger exchanges,'' Jones told reporters after giving a talk on the United States' role in the stock markets of the 1990s. ``I don't know how exactly it's going to come out,'' he said. ``I think it's going to be very hard for some of the smaller regional exchanges to compete, to have the capital needed for new technology etc., etc. so I think you'll either see mergers or perhaps joint ventures.'' Just back from meetings of the international stock exchange association, in Frankfurt and Berlin, Jones said the United States also will have to liberalize its securities laws. ``We're going to have to revisit our own securities laws and ask if we're going to make them so rigid that they would not be competitive in the world market,'' he said. Jones also said it would be a mistake to impose a tax on securities transactions, a revenue-raising plan said to be under consideration by budget negotiators, when other countries are lowering or eliminating theirs. He noted that options trading moved from Sweden to London after the Swedish government imposed a transaction tax. A transaction tax ``would make us non-competitive,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Agency Sells Junk Bonds in Open Market
DOC.TEXT: The Resolution Trust Corp. on Tuesday offered for sale on the open market part of its portfolio of high-risk junk bonds, a spokeswoman for the agency said. ``We have been selling'' junk bonds, spokeswoman Kate Spears said. She declined to provide any details. But bond traders said the RTC sold about $70 million of junk bonds, nearly the full amount it had intended to sell. ``They traded very well,'' said Steve Shenfeld, a trader at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. in New York. Two of the issues the RTC sold, Golden Nugget and McCaw Cellular, together accounted for some $25 million, said market sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other issues sold by the agency included Eastern Airlines, Penn Traffic and Telemundo Group. The RTC, the federal agency set up to dispose of failed savings and loans, has around $2.9 billion of the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds which it took over from the collapsed thrifts. The once-thriving junk bond market has been cited as a factor in the failure of some S&Ls that invested heavily in the bonds and took losses when the market weakened. ``The implications of what happened today are a positive,'' said Joseph C. Bencivenga, the head of high-yield research at Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. ``It shows that the market is not dead and investors are willing to pay for issues they consider to have value.'' Traders said they expect the RTC, which also sold junk bonds last week, to offer more of the issues for sale later this week. ``They will be in the market (at various times) over many, many months,'' Shenfeld said. ``In general, I think the RTC's portfolio will eventually find a home.'' On Monday, federal regulators announced they had blocked the proposed $3 billion sale by Columbia Savings & Loan Association of its junk bonds to a group of Canadian and Hong Kong investors. The Office of Thrift Supervision said it cannot approve the sale in its current form because Columbia neglected to seek an adequate number of bids for the junk bond portfolio. Columbia, a troubled thrift based in Beverly Hills, Calif., failed to seek any all-cash bids as part of the bidding process, the OTS said. Columbia at one time had the thrift industry's largest portfolio of junk bonds. Regulators have held off seizing Columbia while its managers tried to find a buyer for the junk bonds, despite the fact that the thrift is insolvent. Columbia was $350 million in the red according to the latest report, largely due to the declining value of the junk bond portfolio but also because of recent real estate losses. Analysts have suggested that the regulators may be reluctant to take over Columbia because they don't want the government to have the junk bonds on its hands.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola, Siemens in Cross-Licensing Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. announced an agreement Tuesday with Siemens A.G., a West German electronics manufacturer, to cross-license each other's essential patents for a pan-European digital cellular telephone network. The agreement also covers technology for a proposed European personal communications network, a type of cellular phone system in which many more users would be able to gain access to the phone network at once, and phone costs would be much lower than with today's cellular systems. The agreement follows a similar pact two months ago between Motorola and the Dutch communications company Alcatel N.V., also designed to help clear the way for development of the proposed cellular phone network based on a single standard throughout Europe. The companies each are supplying part of the network and need the cross-licensing agreements to complete the system, said Mario Salvadori, a Motorola spokesman. Bernard Smedley, a Motorola senior vice president, said the agreements with European manufacturers demonstrate that ``the appropriate forum for resolving intellectual property rights issues ... is among manufacturers through fair, bilateral negotiations.'' Terms of the licensing agreements were not disclosed. Motorola, based in suburban Schaumburg, has been awarded contracts to build digital cellular systems in several European countries. It also is a minority owner of Mercury Personal Communications Ltd., which is building a personal communications network in the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Ups, Downs of Oil Markets Often Caused by Shadow-Chasing
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It's no secret that the oil futures market loves a good rumor, but the mill has been working overtime since the Iraq invasion of Kuwait. ``Somebody on the floor will say we heard this, this and that, and people will start trading pretty quickly,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``I think this is a very unusual situation because ... we're in an uncertain situation in the Middle East.'' With most petroleum prices keying off futures, the gossip game can eventually have an impact far beyond the trading floors. These days, consumers fill their cars with gasoline or stock up on home heating oil that costs more money, thanks in large measure to what happened on the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``Sure, rumors can ultimately affect the consumer,'' said Art Wiese, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute. Gauging the impact would be hard, however. ``You'd have to be able to determine fairly specifically what the impact of the rumor was, versus all the other things going on in the market all day,'' Wiese said. Executives of the Merc view any trading based on rumors as a ``momentary aberration,'' according to Neal L. Wolkoff, senior vice president for regulatory affairs and operations. ``I would think that a market move of an hour would tend to be corrected fairly quickly and would have a minimum impact on people's pocket books,'' Wolkoff said in an interview Tuesday. But the price paid for current delivery of oil largely reflects the price established in the futures market. Speculation on contracts for future delivery of petroleum products has virtually eliminated long-term pricing in the industry, forcing oil buyers to pay a price similar to the latest Merc price. The effects of the grapevine were apparent Monday, when lower oil prices were suddenly pushed higher late in the afternoon on rumors that Iraq had either amassed troops on the Jordanian border or even sent troops into Jordan. There were also rumors that Iraqi paratroopers had attacked Saudi Arabian oilfields or that shooting had broken out in the military standoff. Exchange officials said Tuesday they were looking into what happened to determine whether any rumor was spread with an intent to influence prices. ``We're trying to investigate,'' Wolkoff said. ``It's obviously very difficult to get to the source of a story that gets started, then somehow gets repeated, then somehow gets adopted.'' The Merc would not hesitate to discipline anyone trying to manipulate the market through rumors, or even to turn them in to the Justice Department, Wolkoff said. As much as Merc managers dislike floor rumors, they have been around since the exchange began trading oil in 1983. ``In the '80s, there were occasional rumors of the Ayatollah's death,'' Wolkoff said, referring to past Iranian crises. ``There were rumors that the president, President Reagan, died. These things affected the markets across the board. The rumors of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death perhaps had more impact than his death.'' The latest oil crisis has seen more than just Monday's rumors. A little more than a week earlier, oil markets in Asia were sent tumbling by rumors that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had lost power. That rumor had its own brief effects on the U.S. markets. ``First, I believe it was that there had been a coup and then someone said he had been killed, and that's how the rumor started,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It affected Asia and it somewhat affected our opening here, but by the time it got here it had been discounted.''

DOC.HEAD: New Head of Philip Morris Domestic Tobacco Unit
DOC.TEXT: William I. Campbell, a senior vice president at Philip Morris Cos. Inc., has been appointed head of the firm's domestic tobacco business, Philip Morris USA, it was announced Tuesday. Campbell replaces Ehud Houminer, who was appointed a senior vice president of Philip Morris Management Corp. Houminer will be involved in ``special projects of a strategic nature,'' Philip Morris said in a statement. Campbell has been with the company since 1967. Until his latest promotion, he was a senior vice president of corporate planning for Philip Morris Cos. Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline up 2.1 Cents Since Last Week
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices rose 2.1 cents per gallon nationwide since last Wednesday, the American Automobile Association reported Tuesday. AAA's Fuel Gauge Report found self-serve regular unleaded averaged $1.294 per gallon across the United States on Tuesday. That's the second highest price since Aug. 1, the day before Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. The average retail price, which hit $1.307 on Aug. 29, is 21.9 cents higher than on Aug. 1, AAA said. Prices increased in all regions of the country this week, but the largest hikes were in the mid-Atlantic, Southwest and Midwest, AAA said. It said supplies of gasoline remain adequate throughout the country.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Close Lower After Day of Swings
With Gulf-Market Rumors, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices settled lower Tuesday after swinging nervously during the day in response to shifting news from the Middle East. ``It's really a very, very uncertain and skittish market,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude oil for October delivery settled 54 cents lower at $30.76 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for later months were also down. In early trading, oil fell as markets realized the rumors that sparked a rally on Monday were untrue. But news later Tuesday indicated Iraq was increasing its military activities near Syria and Turkey, and oil shot back up. It dropped as traders began taking profits and developing a sense that the price needed to move downward. ``It's difficult to come up with a reason in a market like this,'' Hittle said. ``It's getting skittish on its own.'' Other petroleum futures traded on the Merc were generally down. Unleaded gasoline for October fell 1.12 cents to 93.60 cents per gallon, while later contracts were mostly down. Home heating oil for October fell 2.86 cents to 83.03 cents per gallon, and later months were also down. Natural gas for October was unchanged at $1.525 per 1,000 cubic feet. Trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said heating oil took the biggest fall in anticipation that American Petroleum Institute statistics released after the market closed would show an increased stockpile of distillates, which include heating oil. According to the API report, distillate stocks rose from 126.7 million barrels to 131.7 million barrels for the week ending Sept. 7, while distillate production and imports were down. The stockpile of distillates had been 119.8 million barrels a year earlier, API said. Crude oil imports for the week rose to 6.9 million barrels per day from 6.8 million barrels, while crude stocks were up to 374.3 million barrels from 372.2 million barrels. A year earlier, crude imports had been running at 6.5 million barrels per day, while the stockpile had been 338.6 million barrels. Gasoline stocks stood at 211.1 million barrels, up from 210.5 million barrels a week earlier but down from 218.4 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline imports rose to 261,000 barrels per day from 192,000 barrels a week earlier, but were down from 272,000 barrels a year earlier. Meanwhile, prices at the pump were up. The American Automobile Association reported a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded rose 2.1 cents to $1.294 per gallon nationwide since last Wednesday. The average retail price was 21.9 cents higher than Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and sent oil markets into a state of chaos.

DOC.HEAD: PBS To Provide TV Show Listings Through For-Profit Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of the Public Broadcasting Service and another company said Tuesday they would launch a nationwide system to transmit television show listings to viewers' homes to help set videocassette recorders. The system would send the TV listings in the ``vertical blanking interval,'' the empty space in a television signal that is seen as black bar when a TV picture rolls. The system from PBS National Datacast, a for-profit PBS subsidiary, and InSight Telecast would provide subscribers with detailed on-screen TV show schedule information that could be used to set a VCR through the use of a special device, the companies said. The system is expected to be available in early 1992, the companies said. National Datacast says it has been using the vertical blanking interval to send information, such as stock quotes and credit card verification data, since 1984. InSight is a provider of TV listings.

DOC.HEAD: NYSE Board Approves Two Stages of 24-Hour Plan
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday approved two stages of its plan to implement 24-hour trading by the end of the decade. Approved were two trading periods, called crossing sessions, that would allow completion of trades after hours. The NYSE board also approved a series of rules for trading after the exchange's regular hours of 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Big Board president Richard A. Grasso said the plan ``reflects the NYSE's commitment to innovative services for its customers and positions the exchange competitively in the evolution of the 24-hour marketplace.'' NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. unveiled the extended trading plan earlier this year in response to increasing competition from other markets. The first stage of the exchange's five-part plan was introduced Aug. 3, permitting some late trades at the market closing price for orders already in place. The two after-hours trading sessions approved Tuesday would be instituted pending approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The first session would run from 4:15 to 5 p.m. and permit trading at the market's closing price. All orders placed during this session would be matched up and executed at 5 p.m. The second session, running from 4:15 p.m. to 5:15 p.m., would allow traders to execute computerized program trades based on aggregate prices tied to a market index. The NYSE said the fourth phase of its plan, targeted for 1991, would allow auctions several times during the night of all listed securities. The fifth phase would provide for conventional trading round the clock. Phelan has said 24-hour trading is planned for the end of the decade, but other officials have said it could be in place within five years. Round-the-clock trading now exists in the foreign currency and U.S. Treasury bond markets, where dealers conduct transactions via telephone and computer links. The two Chicago futures markets plan to begin computerized, extended-hours trading in November. Also Tuesday, the NYSE board approved the formation of a market for trading unregistered securities under a new federal regulation. The NYSE said the new market could be in place by early 1991. The American Stock Exchange also has announced plans for trading unregistered securities, which are placed privately with big institutions. The SEC passed Rule 144a earlier this year easing trading of such securities.

The deficit in the country's broadest measure of foreign trade rose slightly in the April-June quarter to $21.84 billion, still the second-best showing in six years, the government reported. However, private economists forecast Tuesday that the deficit will head sharply higher in the months ahead as the Persian Gulf crisis boosts America's foreign oil bill and cuts into Americans' overseas earnings.

The Russian republic's parliament voted overwhelmingly for a radical economic reform program, and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he favored it over a moderate plan proposed by his prime minister. Gorbachev's surprise statement Tuesday increased the chances that the radical plan will go into effect throughout the Soviet Union. The plan calls for transferring most economic authority from the national government to the country's 15 republics, which could then free prices, privatize government industries, legalize private ownership of land and take other steps toward a market-based economy.

Eastern Airlines unveiled its latest strategy to try to lure more business travelers, but the carrier's survival was still in doubt at the end of court-appointed trustee Martin Shugrue's ``100 Days'' campaign. Wednesday marks the end of the campaign, marketed through perhaps the biggest media blitz in Eastern's history. On Tuesday, Shugrue unveiled the company's new strategy for the business traveler: nearly doubling the size of its first-class cabins and offering a new ``corporate rate'' for first-class travel that it says is 15 to 35 percent below full-fare coach rates of major competitors.

The last time the United Auto Workers bargained a pattern national contract with General Motors Corp., tensions were high and a weeklong strike resulted. With three days left in this year's bargaining, the stress isn't as noticeable as it was in 1984, and some even feel the union's position has been strengthened since the last big strike. ``I feel that we are more on the offense than on the defense now,'' said Larry Howerton, vice president of Local 662 in Anderson, Ind.

The Resolution Trust Corp. offered for sale on the open market part of its portfolio of high-risk junk bonds, a spokeswoman said. Bond traders said Tuesday the RTC sold about $70 million of junk bonds, nearly the full amount it had intended to sell. The RTC, the federal agency set up to dispose of failed savings and loans, has around $2.9 billion of the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds which it took over from the collapsed thrifts.

It's no secret that the oil futures market loves a good rumor, but the mill has been working overtime since the Iraq invasion of Kuwait. ``Somebody on the floor will say we heard this, this and that, and people will start trading pretty quickly,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. With most petroleum prices keying off futures, the gossip game can eventually have an impact far beyond the trading floors. These days, consumers fill their cars with gasoline or stock up on home heating oil that costs more money, thanks in large measure to what happened on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

The New York Stock Exchange approved two stages of its plan to implement 24-hour trading by the end of the decade. Approved Tuesday were two trading periods, called crossing sessions, that would allow completion of trades after hours. The NYSE board also approved a series of rules for trading after the exchange's regular hours of 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m.

The guy who rents Michael Milken a car in Washington wants a federal judge to know that the financial felon cares about the little guy. And he always rides a sedan _ never a limo _ and pays his bills on time. CBS Inc. chief executive Laurence Tisch considers Milken ``a person of high integrity'' whose criminal offenses belie his character. Ordinary citizen J.B. Spence of Miami disagrees. He says Milken is a ``vicious criminal and thief.'' Friends, colleagues and strangers have barraged U.S. District Judge Kimba A. Wood with about 300 letters appraising the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive and offering ideas for his sentence.

A major Japanese company has begun marketing something consumers have long awaited _ a videocassette recorder that automatically cuts out commercials. Even the maker's own. And while sales have been good, the product has raised the ire of television networks, which argue that the possibility of fewer people viewing commercials may prompt advertisers to pay less for air time. The VCRs, made by Mitsubishi Electric Corp., cost from $600 to $1,200.

Stock prices slipped in light, quiet trading Tuesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 2.97 to 2,612.62. Bond prices rose moderately. The dollar rose and gold prices posted minor gains. Soybean futures prices rose strongly; grain futures closed mostly higher; oil futures retreated; platinum futures dropped while other precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Overbooked Passengers Can Sue Airline, Appeals Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Airline passengers bumped from overbooked flights can turn down the free tickets and refunds they're offered and sue for damages, a federal appeals court ruled Tuesday. In a case from Montana, a three-judge panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said a federal ban on direct state regulation of airlines does not prevent a passenger from suing under ordinary state law for harm caused by airline practices. The ruling allows William D. West, a Helena, Mont., patent lawyer, to pursue a suit against Northwest Airlines for selling tickets that cannot be exchanged or refunded but are subject to bumping when flights are overbooked. West is seeking punitive damages. ``Selling nonrefundable tickets limits a traveler's ability to make changes but not the airline's ability . . . to switch to a smaller-size aircraft, increasing the chances of bumping,'' said attorney Cornish Hitchcock of the Public Citizen Litigation Group, a Ralph Nader organization that helped represent West. The right to sue for overbooking was established in a 1976 Supreme Court decision, a case that started when Allegheny Airlines bumped Nader from a Washington-to-Hartford flight. In Tuesday's ruling, the appeals court said the federal deregulation of airlines in 1978 did not prohibit all such suits. The airline was studying the ruling Tuesday and had no comment, said its lawyer, Jon Metropoulos. Hitchcock said West's case was unusual because it holds the possibility of sizable damages if the airline is found to have acted in bad faith under Montana law. Many airlines offer free-trip coupons to passengers on overbooked flights. Federal law also entitles a bumped passenger to a refund of the ticket price, up to $200, if a substitute flight is more than an hour later than the original flight, or twice those amounts if more than two hours late. Hitchcock said the typical traveler probably should take one of those options rather than sue. ``We generally recommend that people take the money or take the free ticket as a quick and easy way of resolving the matter,'' he said. ``The litigation can drag on for some time and there's no guarantee of recovery.'' West was bumped from a Northwest flight from Great Falls, Mont., to Arlington, Va., in September 1986 when the airline switched from a 146-passenger plane to a 78-passenger plane without warning ticket agents. West, who had been scheduled to land in Arlington at 9 p.m., turned down an alternative flight to a nearby airport at 3 a.m. and instead rescheduled his trip two weeks later. His suit under Montana law for bad-faith dealing by the airline was dismissed by U.S. District Judge Charles Lovell, which said it was barred by federal law. But the appeals court disagreed. The 1978 federal airline deregulation law, which prohibited state laws ``relating to rates, routes or services of any air carrier,'' bars only those state laws that purport to regulate airlines, said Judge Dorothy Nelson in the 3-0 ruling. ``State laws that merely have an effect on airline services are not pre-empted,'' Nelson said. She said one such law was the Montana statute invoked by West, requiring good-faith conduct between buyers and sellers or any other parties in a contract. The court said it was not deciding whether West had a valid claim under that law, only that he had a right to sue.

DOC.HEAD: Salomon Inc. Agrees to Pay $83.75 Million to Department of Energy
DOC.TEXT: Salomon Inc. said Tuesday it has agreed to pay the U.S. Department of Energy $83.75 million to settle claims of alleged violations committed by the commodities broker Phibro Corp. before it merged with Salomon. Salomon said the Energy Department alleged that it violated crude oil price and allocation regulations. The brokerage was not specific about the allegations in a brief statement. The payment would be far below the $311 million payment originally sought by the Energy Department when it began administratrative proceedings in September 1988. Salomon, which had set aside reserves for a payment, said Tuesday the agreement would not affect earnings. Phibro merged with Salomon in 1981. The unit is now called Phibro Energy Inc. The alleged violations were committed by Phibro between 1978 and 1980. The regulations expired in 1981. In its statement Tuesday, Salomon said most of the DOE's allegations are without merit, but it decided to agree to the $83.75 million payment to avoid the cost of pursuing the matter in the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Two Commodity Fraud Trials Under Way in Chicago
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys Tuesday mimicked the frenzied action in the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Japanese yen pit as opening arguments began in the trial of 14 currency traders accused of cheating customers. Attorneys Ed Genson and Joseph Duffy, the first to make their opening statements before U.S. District Judge William T. Hart, imitated the rapid calls and hand signals of the pit. They described the noise and stress caused by about 100 traders competing for currency futures contracts every business day. They also questioned the worth, as evidence, of surreptitious tapes made by undercover FBI Agent Dieter Volk, who posed as a corrupt trader as part of a sting investigation at the world's two largest futures exchanges. ``The pit is not a quiet, whispery place,'' said Genson, attorney for independent yen trader Robert Bailin, 36. His comment was a challenge to the opening statement of Assistant U.S. Attorney Lisa Huestes. ``You will be hearing about whispered conversation after whispered conversation,'' Huestes told the jurors earlier Tuesday. Huestes said the government would try to show systematic collusion between brokers and independent _ or ``local'' _ yen traders to defraud the brokers' customers, often through locals agreeing to buy brokers' erroneous contracts in exchange for trading favors. She said the motivation was ``plain and simple greed.'' Duffy, defense attorney for John M. Baker, 51, said many of the tapes Volk made of Baker were made in a bar, where Volk often bought beers for the broker. ``The FBI recorded the musings of a drunk. That's not credible evidence,'' he said. The charges resulted from an unprecedented undercover investigation in which FBI agents posed as corrupt traders. They secretly tape-recorded conversations among traders at the two commodity exchanges. A federal grand jury indicted 48 people in the probe. Twenty have pleaded guilty, and one pleaded no contest. In the first trial resulting from the investigation, a U.S. District Court jury in July convicted two Swiss franc traders of relatively minor trading violations and acquitted a third. The jury could not reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one of the three defendants. The men are to be tried again on those charges early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Black-Owned Businesses Up Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, During the, to CORRECT figure in first sentence to $19.8 billion sted $9.6 billion
DOC.TEXT: Black-owned businesses increased more than twice as fast as overall business growth over five years, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday. But the money earned by black firms went up at only the same rate as business overall, reflecting that the minority-owned companies were relatively smaller than businesses overall. The bureau reported that black-owned businesses increased from 308,000 in 1982 to 424,000 in 1987, the most recent year for which detailed information is available. That was an increase of 38 percent, compared with a rise of just 14 percent in the total number of businesses in the country. During the same period, receipts of black-owned firms rose 105 percent to $19.8 billion. Total business income increased 106 percent to more than $1.9 trillion in the same period. According to the Census report, based on the 1987 Economic Census, 94 percent of black-owned businesses were sole proprietorships. Receipts per company averaged $47,000 for black-owned companies compared to $146,000 for all businesses. And 54 percent of black-owned firms had receipts of under $10,000. About half of all black-owned businesses were service companies, while 16 percent were in retail trade. By income, automobile dealers and service stations were the top black-owned business, followed by business services, health service, contractors and miscellaneous retail firms. New York, with 28,063 businesses, has the most black-owned firms, the report said. Los Angeles was second at 23,932, followed by Washington, 23,046; Chicago, 15,374 and Houston, 12,989.
